webTitle: Dazzler is back and England are beaming

fields.headline: Dazzler is back and England are beaming
fields.standfirst: Darren Gough has rediscovered his rhythm
fields.trailText: For a disconcertingly long time now English cricket has resembled a particularly barren series of Search For A Star. Now that Darren Gough has rediscovered his rhythm, maybe something is starting to shine in the England camp.
fields.body:
For a disconcertingly long time now English cricket has resembled a particularly barren series of Search For A Star, or perhaps a convention of astrologers on a cloudy night.

For almost a decade the game of games, rather like an early Mike Leigh movie offering, has had no star, nothing to aid navigation through a squally era.

For most of this time Darren Gough has striven to burst through the cumulus. This is also the player the men at Lord's hope to hang their blazers on, the cricketer they thought might haul the game out of its twee village and give it a wider appeal, as Lennox Lewis, Tim Henman, Nick Faldo and Eddie Irvine have done in their sports.

It never quite happened. Gough flirted with greatness but was scorned by it. He will never be bracketed with Harold Larwood or Freddie Trueman or John Snow who, with apologies to Bob Willis, was the best fast bowler we have had since Fiery Fred.

All too often the bowler known as Dazzler has been watchable without recourse to Ray-Bans. The good news here, as England looked forward to taking on South Africa again tomorrow, was the suggestion that the man himself was getting used to the idea of looking in the mirror without shielding his eyes from the glare.

In the five Tests against South Africa he took only 14 wickets at a fraction under 40. As he is now in his 30th year, some view his decline as terminal.

But it is Gough's misfortune that there has always been a long queue to dismantle him. Some do not like his rather un-English cocksureness. Others feel betrayed by a man who promised to lead the nation's cricket out of the wilderness only to mislay his Ordnance Survey.

The would-be successor to Ian Botham and Willis as prolific wicket-taker is, instead, the new Graham Dilley or Chris Old. Yet, as he showed once again in Bloemfontein on Sunday, when he took four wickets and the individual award, this is still a match winner, a man capable not only of raising his game but of galvanising those around him with a mischievous medley of skidding pace, reverse swing, off-cutters and sheer personality.

After the Test series Gough had raged and raged against the dying of the light. He said then: "I charged in every time. People said I'd lost my sparkle and bounce. But I bowled the same this winter as I did last winter. I haven't had the breaks."

This reeked of self-delusion. This winter he has not looked match-fit, and some wise observers even questioned his usually impeccable attitude.

Yesterday, though, there was a little realism in his voice as he came to terms with the fact that he is no longer England's champion fast bowler.

"I've got a good record in Test cricket, with 139 wickets, and in one-day internationals with 112. Not many people have done that and I deserve some respect. But if someone asks me who is the best fast bowler in the country, I'd say Andy Caddick." He had not said that when he arrived back from Australia last year.

Gough feels that one-day cricket represents his best chance of getting back to the bowler he was before his four-month lay-off last summer because of a calf injury.

"People say you need to bowl overs to be at your best, but for me the best way is to play a lot of one-day cricket.

"You need to bowl under pressure at the start, to bowl back of a length and straight, to come back and mix it up at the end and come back again and bowl yorkers.

"Anyone can bowl bouncers. But in one-day cricket you need discipline and line and length. You need to use your brain and vary it.

"Against South Africa on Sunday I went back to my old, shorter run for the first time in 18 months. It was my idea. Everyone was telling me I should use the longer one. Suddenly everything went smooth. I felt good rhythm.

"I also used a lot of slower balls. So did Caddy, who doesn't normally bowl them, and Craig White. The thing about a slower ball is that you have to change it to keep one move ahead, otherwise they will pick it. I've got an off-cutter and a leg-break. I've also got a new one, which I will be trying in the nets but I'm not too confident of using it in a match.

"I love one-day cricket. It will always be my preference over Test matches. We were a decent one-day side but we've drifted in the past couple of years. We play a lot of it at home but seem behind at international level."

Gough is one of only four men here who played in England's last World Cup match, against India in Birmingham in June. "I feel it's a compliment that people think I might be around in 2003 to play in the next World Cup," he said. Also a compliment, perhaps, to his physio.

webTitle: Rivaldo shoo-in  Brazilian is world player of year

fields.headline: Rivaldo shoo-in  Brazilian is world player of year
fields.trailText: Rivaldo is Fifa's world player of the year. The Barcelona and Brazil forward beat David Beckham into second place.
fields.body:
Rivaldo is Fifa's world player of the year. The Barcelona and Brazil forward beat David Beckham into second place.

Despite hilarious attempts to keep the result of the voting under wraps, everyone bar the most naive observer knew that Rivaldo, the European footballer of the year, had won the prize when Beckham and Gabriel Batistuta, the other two nominees, failed to turn up at a press conference here. Luckily George Best was around to enliven otherwise predictable proceedings.

"David Beckham is a good player but not a great player," said Best, who was in typically tigerish mood after flying into Brussels the morning after attending a late-night function as a guest of the Football Writers Association.

"He can't kick with his left foot, he doesn't score many goals, he can't head a ball and he can't tackle. Apart from that he's all right."

Best, 53, had been invited to Brussels as one of three inductees into Fifa's International Hall of Champions, which trumpets the exploits of the game's legends. The Hall of Champions, bizarrely, has not yet been opened. Fifa's attempt to set up shop in Paris during France 98 was frustrated and now London has been chosen as the venue.

Rivaldo is also reported to be considering a move to England. After a falling-out with his coach Louis van Gaal over the position he should be playing, he was left out of two recent Barcelona games. Then Barca hinted that he might be for sale - at £44m.

The Brazilian refused to go into detail but hinted that all was not well in Catalonia. "If the president and especially the coach would say that I am not for sale until the end of my contract, it would be good for me and the team," he said. "From what I've read I have had doubts in my mind and would like them to say that I am staying. I didn't like playing on the left but I'm very happy to play at a great club."

Rivaldo was placed first by 91 of the 140 national team coaches who voted for their player of the year. Beckham came second, with 18 first-place votes, Batistuta was third and Zinedine Zidane, who won last year's award, finished fourth.

fields.headline: Stealthy Spurs swoop for teenager
fields.trailText: Tottenham's manager George Graham temporarily abandoned his protracted search for a new striker yesterday to indulge his passion for buying defenders when he purchased 19-year-old centre-back Anthony Gardner in a deal worth up to £1.5m.
fields.body:
Tottenham's manager George Graham temporarily abandoned his protracted search for a new striker yesterday to indulge his greatest passion: buying a defender.

In the kind of stealthy operation which has become his trademark in recent transfers, Graham signed Port Vale's 19-year-old centre-back Anthony Gardner in a deal worth up to £1.5m.

Gardner agreed personal terms with the Premiership club yesterday after passing a medical last week. Spurs are understood to be paying an initial £900,000, with a further £600,000 dependent on appearances.

Tottenham's director of football David Pleat said: "He's a highly promising young defender and we're delighted to have him here."

Although the 6ft 5in Gardner has started only a handful of senior games for Vale, his swift progress up football's learning curve has been monitored by a host of Premiership clubs this season, notably Liverpool and Aston Villa.

Liverpool are intensifying their search for a cure to Michael Owen's hamstring problems. After suffering at the weekend his sixth such injury in less than 12 months, the young striker faces the prospect of another series of exhaustive tests.

"Whilst we do not believe the problem to be very serious it is obviously causing us some concern," said the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier.

"In an ideal world we would have this problem diagnosed and cleared up very quickly. Michael is disappointed that he is again having problems but we remain optimistic about his chances of being fit and available for our next game against Leeds United on Saturday week."

If Owen misses that game it is inconceivable he would be released to play any part in England's friendly international against Argentina at Wembley next month.

Despite losing both Owen and Robbie Fowler to injuries, Houllier insisted he had no intention of seeking to return Pierre van Hooijdonk to English football.

Van Hooijdonk is currently playing his football in his native Holland with Vitesse Arnhem but recently announced a desire to move back to the Premiership.

At Everton, the manager Walter Smith is expected to sign a two-year extension to his contract in the next 48 hours, a deal which will keep him at Goodison Park until 2004.

Ray Harford has joined the coaching staff at Millwall, and the former Blackburn and West Bromwich manager, who quit as director of football at Oxford United last week, will coach at all levels of the London club. He is a direct replacement for David Kemp, who left the New Den for Portsmouth last month.

 Togo, one of the rank outsiders, pulled off the first surprise of the African Nations Cup by holding Ivory Coast to a 1-1 draw in their Group A game in Accra yesterday.

Ivory Coast, for whom the former Everton striker Ibrahima Bakayoko missed a good first-half chance, were ahead at the interval through a Tchiressoua Guel penalty but Togo struck back and fully deserved their equaliser from Lantame Ouadja in the 62nd minute.

webTitle: Fans talk when the Premier goes to the people

fields.headline: Fans talk when the Premier goes to the people
fields.standfirst: Supporters given their say
fields.trailText: This is the sixth season that groups of supporters have had chance to meet with Premier League bigwigs - discussions which are rarely open to the media - and most recently it was Tottenham fans' turn to ask the questions.
fields.body:
The players' lounge at White Hart Lane is the place you would least expect to find a shopping list being drawn up for Tottenham's chairman Sir Alan Sugar. Fill the place with supporters, though, and the club's need for a new striker is bound to get an airing.

It was the Tottenham fans' turn to talk to a deputation of senior Premier League officials, including for good measure the chief executive Richard Scudamore, who inspected for the first time the work his organisation is doing to gauge the opinions of its customers across the land.

The gathering's central theme was the treatment of families at Premier League clubs and the 26 invitees - 12 parents and 14 children - were more inclined to discuss concessions, facilities, atmosphere and the effect of television than whether Sugar should open his chequebook for a Rivaldo or Ronaldo. The fans saved that for later in the day after Sheffield Wednesday had beaten Spurs.

It is the sixth season that groups of supporters have met Premier League bigwigs, discussions which are rarely open to the media, and Scudamore views them as a vital part of the league's agenda.

"They are excellent," he said on Saturday. "They start slowly, everybody wonders why they are here and then after another five minutes they are raging away and are difficult to stop.

"It has to be right to hold these forums. We hear the voices of fans all the time but I think it's absolutely right that the league and the clubs should want to sit down with them in the right environment and get them to open up and really hear their concerns.

These focus groups run alongside the fan survey carried out by John Williams of the Sir Norman Chester Centre for Football Research. Come season's end the views gathered will be collated into a report. An impossible task? Paul Johns, who set up the panels, says not.

"We write a report which outlines the views about which there was a consensus, and then other ideas which we believe worth considering. Just because an idea has only been suggested by one fan does not mean it is not worth listening to."

In the past few years, as a result of views expressed at the meetings - there is one per club per season - all Premier League clubs are now obliged to offer concessions to away fans, poster campaigns on the use of abusive language have been launched and away fans are guaranteed a specific allocation of seats at every ground.

Should some of Saturday's debates influence policy, allocated singing areas will become commonplace, children will be encouraged through reduced prices and by meetings with players, and information during a game will be more available.

"Not everything goes into the 'do-able' pile", Scudamore said, "but the consumer liaison side is something which has to be vigorously supported and when we get the chairmen together we have to spend time making sure that they do take notice of these kind of issues.

"It makes good business sense. When you look at the 20 chairmen of the clubs, they are all successful businessmen and at some point in their careers they have been making customers happy day in, day-out. It's not that much different when it comes to football."

webTitle: Gregory is keen to bag Heskey

fields.headline: Gregory is keen to bag Heskey
fields.standfirst: Villa manager hopes to sign Worthington Cup adversary
fields.trailText: John Gregory announced yesterday that he is keen to sign Leicester's Emile Heskey, a striker who had not seemed his cup of tea - or more accurately his bag of potatoes.
fields.body:
John Gregory announced yesterday that he is keen to sign Leicester's Emile Heskey, a striker who had not seemed his cup of tea - or more accurately his bag of potatoes.

In September the Aston Villa manager accused Heskey of "falling like a sack of spuds" to get Gareth Southgate sent off. The timing of his change of heart might be construed as mind games, coming hours before Villa and Leicester meet in the first leg of their Worthington Cup semi-final at Villa Park tonight. But Gregory sounded serious as he discussed the 22-year-old he values at £10m-£12m.

"We've looked," he said. "We're big admirers. He said after we played them that, if he was playing for Villa and had fallen over like that, John would have been happy. It's fair to say I would be very pleased if he was part of the Villa team; no question.

"He's got a lot of qualities you can't readily find. Exceptional pace is one thing, being 6ft 2in is another. We've got little [Julian] Joachim who has a lot of pace and power but lacks the height. Emile's got everything. He finishes well with both feet, he's good in the air. He's an absolute handful with his strength. If you try to wrestle him... well, they call him Bruno for the obvious reason." And not, he added, because he is flat on his back so often.

Gregory stands by his view that Heskey was responsible for Southgate's first red card of his career in Leicester's 3-1 win at Filbert Street. But having worked with Heskey briefly while a coach at Leicester and followed his progress, he prefers to dwell on the positive. "He may not be a prolific goalscorer," he said, "but he causes so many problems."

There seems little doubt that Heskey will move next summer, a year before his contract expires, and already Liverpool are thought to have set up a deal with Leicester.

Even at £10m Gregory would consider it good business if he got Heskey and lost Stan Collymore in the opposite direction. He has given Leicester's manager Martin O'Neill and Bradford's Paul Jewell permission to talk to the striker. O'Neill said he would make an announcement tomorrow morning.

By then it may be clearer whether Leicester are likely to reach a third Worthington Cup final in four years. Robbie Savage, Gerry Taggart and Stefan Oakes are back from injury tonight and O'Neill said there was a "good chance" that Muzzy Izzet, Andy Impey and Steve Guppy would play.

Villa are short up front, with Dion Dublin and Darius Vassell injured and Benito Carbone cup-tied, though Lee Hendrie returns to the squad.

Meanwhile, the Football League will visit Uefa in the next month to lobby to keep a European berth for the Worthington Cup after this season. "Uefa have said there will be a place for a second cup competition provided all teams join it and the FA recommends it," said the chief executive John McKeown. He said an agreement prevented any club dropping out.

 The Bolton manager Sam Allardyce has earned Tranmere's Dave Challinor a towel ban. He complained that Rovers' ball-boys are armed with towels at Prenton Park to give Challinor a better grip for his long throws. A league spokesman said: "Sam Allardyce has contacted the Football League, and Tranmere and the player have been asked to desist from the practice."

Challinor is in any case suspended for tomorrow's Worthington Cup semi-final second leg between the sides, with Rovers leading 1-0.

Allardyce yesterday escaped punishment by the FA for comments made to the referee Steve Dunn while still Notts County's manager.

Allardyce yesterday escaped punishment by the FA for comments made to the referee Steve Dunn while still Notts County's manager.

fields.headline: Double vision for Euro 2000
fields.trailText: Des Lynam and Gary Lineker will go head-to-head for the first time when the BBC and ITV provide simultaneous live coverage of England's Euro 2000 game against Germany in Charleroi on June 17.
fields.body:
Des Lynam and Gary Lineker will go head-to-head for the first time when the BBC and ITV provide simultaneous live coverage of England's Euro 2000 game against Germany in Charleroi on June 17.

Lynam, who left the BBC for ITV last year, and the Match of the Day anchorman Lineker are to host their channels' quotas of live games throughout the four-week championship in Holland and Belgium.

But in a break with tradition, the two stations will compete directly for viewers by both showing the England-Germany game. Half the population of Britain, around 26.2m, watched when both channels broadcast the last European Championship encounter between the countries at Wembley in 1996.

ITV will show England's first group game against Portugal and BBC1 the third game against Romania. If England reach the quarter-finals, both BBC1 and ITV will show their next match live, with the latter screening two of the remaining games in that round.

An England semi-final would again be shown simultaneously on both sides and the final on Sunday July 2 will be broadcast live by both.

fields.headline: Dalglish given official warning
fields.trailText: Kenny Dalglish was up before the Scottish Football Association yesterday and Celtic may be in further trouble today after recent angry incidents involving Ian Wright and Jim Lauchlan.
fields.body:
Kenny Dalglish was up before the Scottish Football Association yesterday and Celtic may be in further trouble today after angry incidents involving Ian Wright and Jim Lauchlan which followed Sunday's game at Kilmarnock.

The referee John Rowbotham reported Celtic's director of football earlier this season after Dalglish, enraged by the dismissal of Vidar Riseth, entered the official's dressing room in Dundee. The SFA gave him a warning.

Rowbotham's dressing room has been a full house this season. Three Rangers officials, the manager Dick Advocaat, his assistant Bert van Lingen and John Greig, also appeared before the SFA for incidents in the Old Firm match in November. Advocaat claimed Paul Lambert should have been sent off for a tackle on Jorg Albertz. With his colleagues he burst into Rowbotham's room at half-time. All three escaped with a warning yesterday.

Sunday's trouble at Kilmarnock saw Wright and Lauchlan kept apart by team-mates, then hauled into the referee's room for a caution, which meant a red card for Lauchlan.

Wright was involved in another incident with the fourth official Willie Young in the tunnel.

fields.trailText: Harry was still an underage wizard, and he was forbidden by wizard law to do magic outside school. His record wasn't exactly clean either. Only last summer he'd got an official warning that had stated quite clearly that if the Ministry got wind of any more magic in Privet Drive, Harry would face expulsion from Hogwarts.
fields.body:
Harry was still an underage wizard, and he was forbidden by wizard law to do magic outside school. His record wasn't exactly clean either. Only last summer he'd got an official warning that had stated quite clearly that if the Ministry got wind of any more magic in Privet Drive, Harry would face expulsion from Hogwarts.

He heard the Dursleys leaving the table and hurried upstairs out of the way.

Harry got through the next three days by forcing himself to think about his Handbook of Do-It-Yourself Broomcare whenever Aunt Marge started on him. This worked quite well, though it seemed to give him a glazed look, because Aunt Marge started voicing the opinion that he was mentally subnormal.

At last, at long last, the final evening of Marge's stay arrived. Aunt Petunia cooked a fancy dinner and Uncle Vernon uncorked several bottles of wine. They got all the way through the soup and the salmon without a single mention of Harry's faults; during the lemon meringue pie, Uncle Vernon bored them all with a long talk about Grunnings, his drill-making company; then Aunt Petunia made coffee and Uncle Vernon brought out a bottle of brandy.

"Can I tempt you, Marge?"

Aunt Marge had already had quite a lot of wine. Her huge face was very red.

"Just a small one, then," she chuckled. "A bit more than that . . . and a bit more . . . that's the ticket."

Dudley was eating his fourth slice of pie. Aunt Petunia was sipping coffee with her little finger sticking out. Harry really wanted to disappear into his bedroom, but he met Uncle Vernon's angry little eyes and knew he would have to sit it out.

"Aah," said Aunt Marge, smacking her lips and putting the empty brandy glass back down. "Excellent nosh, Petunia. It's normally just a fry-up for me of an evening, with twelve dogs to look after. . . ." She burped richly and patted her great tweed stomach. "Pardon me. But I do like to see a healthy-sized boy," she went on, winking at Dudley. "You'll be a proper-sized man, Dudders, like your father. Yes, I'll have a spot more brandy, Vernon. . . ."

"Now, this one here -"

She jerked her head at Harry, who felt his stomach clench. The Handbook, he thought quickly.

"This one's got a mean, runty look about him. You get that with dogs. I had Colonel Fubster drown one last year. Ratty little thing it was. Weak. Underbred."

Harry was trying to remember page twelve of his book: A Charm to Cure Reluctant Reversers.

"It all comes down to blood, as I was saying the other day. Bad blood will out. Now, I'm saying nothing against your family, Petunia" - she patted Aunt Petunia's bony hand with her shovel-like one - "but your sister was a bad egg. They turn up in the best families. Then she ran off with a wastrel and here's the result right in front of us."

Harry was staring at his plate, a funny ringing in his ears. Grasp your broom firmly by the tail, he thought. But he couldn't remember what came next. Aunt Marge's voice seemed to be boring into him like one of Uncle Vernon's drills.

"This Potter," said Aunt Marge loudly, seizing the brandy bottle and splashing more into her glass and over the tablecloth, "you never told me what he did?"

Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia were looking extremely tense. Dudley had even looked up from his pie to gape at his parents.

"He - didn't work," said Uncle Vernon, with half a glance at Harry. "Unemployed."

"As I expected!" said Aunt Marge, taking a huge swig of brandy and wiping her chin on her sleeve. "A no-account, good-for-nothing, lazy scrounger who -"

"He was not," said Harry suddenly. The table went very quiet. Harry was shaking all over. He had never felt so angry in his life.

"MORE BRANDY!" yelled Uncle Vernon, who had gone very white. He emptied the bottle into Aunt Marge's glass. "You, boy," he snarled at Harry. "Go to bed, go on -"

"No, Vernon," hiccuped Aunt Marge, holding up a hand, her tiny bloodshot eyes fixed on Harry's. "Go on, boy, go on. Proud of your parents, are you? They go and get themselves killed in a car crash (drunk, I expect) -"

"They didn't die in a car crash!" said Harry, who found himself on his feet.

"They died in a car crash, you nasty little liar, and left you to be a burden on their decent, hardworking relatives!" screamed Aunt Marge, swelling with fury. "You are an insolent, ungrateful little -"

But Aunt Marge suddenly stopped speaking. For a moment, it looked as though words had failed her. She seemed to be swelling with inexpressible anger - but the swelling didn't stop. Her great red face started to expand, her tiny eyes bulged, and her mouth stretched too tightly for speech - next second, several buttons had just burst from her tweed jacket and pinged off the walls - she was inflating like a monstrous balloon, her stomach bursting free of her tweed waistband, each of her fingers blowing up like a salami -

"MARGE!" yelled Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia together as Aunt Marge's whole body began to rise off her chair toward the ceiling. She was entirely round, now, like a vast lifebuoy with piggy eyes, and her hands and feet stuck out weirdly as she drifted up into the air, making apoplectic popping noises. Ripper came skidding into the room, barking madly.

"NOOOOOOO!"

fields.body:
Harriet Smithson's presence in the Conservatoire Hall on the afternoon of 9 December 1832 set the seal on one of the high dates of the Romantic calendar. Few can have missed the symbolism. Berlioz had not exactly kept his infatuation with la belle Irlandaise to himself, and though d'Ortigue's biographical essay in the Revue de Paris telling the story of the symphony's genesis had not yet appeared, many in the audience would have known it or would have been apprised of it by their neighbours, as Heinrich Heine was by the man next to him. The sudden appearance of the actress herself in a prominent place just above the orchestra, with the composer no longer metaphorically but physically at her feet, had the hall buzzing. Here was the living original of the idée fixe, the inspirer of the symphony, come to receive back the music she had called into being. The passions she evoked were returning, if not to "plague the inventor", then to trouble and perhaps inspire her in her turn.

All over the hall people were staring at her. She could hardly mistake their glances; Paris audiences had long ceased to show her that kind of attention - not since the great days of 1827 and 1828 had she been the object of such excitement. Though her knowledge of French was as yet sketchy she knew enough to grasp the gist of the literary programme she held in her hand, even without the thinly veiled allusions of Maurice Schlesinger, and the English Journalist Schutter, to the emotional origins of the work. If there was still any doubt who its heroine was, none was possible when in the sequel to the symphony she heard Bocage, the actor who took the role of the composer-hero, speak of his longing for "Juliet, the Ophelia that my heart cries out for". From that moment "she felt the room reel about her; she heard no more, but sat in a dream, and at the end went home like a sleepwalker, hardly aware of what was happening". The words are Berlioz's, not Harriet's, but there is no reason to think them exaggerated. As Peter Raby remarks, it is not everyone who is wooed by a full orchestra.

For Berlioz it brought five years of disdain and indifference to an abrupt end. His life was revolutionised. Even the revenge against Fétis, target of Bocage's fiercest tirade, was forgotten. Within hours Miss Smithson had sent him her congratulations on his success. Next day he was granted permission to be introduced to her and they met. From now on he called every evening the English company was not performing. When he could not see her he wrote, in French, and she answered in English. Less than a week after the concert, "like Othello" he was telling her the story of his life since the day he had first set eyes on her, and she was weeping. "You can imagine with what intoxication I saw her tears flow." On 18 December, scarcely able to believe it, he heard her say, "Eh bien, Berlioz ... je vous aime": his feelings were answered at last. It did not matter that hers were not of the same intensity as his, but rather - he told his sister Nancy - "feelings which combine love, friendship and gratitude". The agonising hopelessness was over and past. She loved him.

Yet it was not till nine and a half months later, after a series of delays only partly external in origin, that they were married. Looking back on it many years later, Berlioz recalled it as a time of continual, almost unbearable agitation in his life; he was alternately "elated with wild hopes and racked with fearful apprehensions". The course of true love never ran less smooth.

During those fraught, protracted months they did not become lovers, though gossip assumed they were. Whatever he may have desired, to her it would have been unthinkable. Her reserve often drove him to distraction - even his most restrained caresses alarmed her - yet at the same time he admired it and marvelled to find such innocence in a woman whose whole life had been lived in the theatre. It was bitterly ironic, he told his father, that Dr Berlioz should consent to his engagement to Camille Moke, a thoroughly promiscuous woman (as he had since discovered), but should oppose his marrying Harriet Smithson, whose behaviour had always been irreproachable.

The family's opposition was the first obstacle. Berlioz did not break the news to his father until the beginning of February, nearly eight weeks after he had begun courting Harriet; but Nancy's reply to an earlier letter in which he opened his heart to her (as in the old days) gave a taste of what the reaction would be. She dismissed it as a passing fancy, adding a warning - like Germont pére in La Dame aux camélias - that such an alliance would jeopardize AdéIe's chance of making a good marriage.

As actress, Protestant and penniless woman, Miss Smithson was trebly obnoxious. Félix Marmion, who was in Paris (Berlioz watched him parade down the boulevard at the head of his regiment on 23 January), characteristically fastened on this last objection. It was not even a speculation on his nephew's part, he wrote to Nancy: "the actress is ruined". Colonel Marmion pinned his hopes on certain "information" about Miss Smithson, which according to Alphonse Robert had reached Hector and was causing him to think again. (This is a recurring note in the correspondence. Berlioz's Côtols friend Edouard Rocher hints darkly to him about "fears" - presumably as to Harriet's virtue - which the inquiries of "well-informed persons" have confirmed.) In the second week of February Marmion took himself to the minor theatre in the Rue Chantereine where the English company had been playing for the past month, and sent a report to Nancy next day.

"I was very curious to analyse the potent charms which have wrought such havoc. Her features are indeed remarkable, she has an exquisite voice, and her gestures are noble. The theatre is so small that it's not at all favourable to illusion. Miss Smithson is necessarily at a disadvantage there. On that stage she doesn't even appear young. Without having my nephew's eyes or unique nature, I nevertheless understand the impression this woman must have made on his artist's soul. But has sober reflection, have the entreaties of his family no weight with him? We must see that he does not lack for either, so that we may have no reason to reproach ourselves. I confess that I do not hold out much hope."

fields.trailText: After a while, of course - the 1980s being the 1980s - I managed to make enough money for some kind of new, fresh version of my Shepherd's Bush self. Like the Bush itself, I was tarted up, I was an up-and-coming area. But it became apparent to me that it wasn't enough. fields.body:
After a while, of course - the 1980s being the 1980s - I managed to make enough money for some kind of new, fresh version of my Shepherd's Bush self. Like the Bush itself, I was tarted up, I was an up-and-coming area. But it became apparent to me that it wasn't enough. The cash was good - you could get the suits, the cars, the gear, the little mews house in W6, well on the ladder to W11 and then, finally, W8.

But they still always found me out somehow, those people I wanted to be, with their secret codes, and pampered voices and hidden assumptions, and knowledge of wine and opera, and the people they knew. It became clear to me that if I really wanted to get out of Shepherd's Bush, I needed more than a big bank balance. After all, now the 1990s have come and nearly gone, along with my twenties, I needed someone to teach me escapology, fast. And I needed a symbol to show that I wasn't who people kept insisting I was.

I didn't know when I first saw Veronica that she was my ticket out of there. That is to say, that I was going to fall in love with her. At first I thought she was just another mark, another sucker punter.

We'd arranged to meet at the flat, which was in a large mansion block in West Kensington - exorbitant service charges and a truly old-style rapacious freeholder I had to keep off the agenda somehow. I was all Prada'd up on my last month's commission, plus a full-on tan that I'd got from two weeks in Koh Samui, and I had the Beemer outside. I could actually feel the money on me like the touch of some strange, fragrant oil. I felt like I could get exactly what I wanted, what money demanded. Because money isn't paper and metal and plastic and bank statements. It's a feeling, like everything else.

The buzzer buzzed and I let her into the flat, which was small and grubby and badly overpriced. This was not something only I could see; I knew she would see it too. David Blunkett would be able to see it, on a dark night. That's the point. She's not meant to buy this one - this is part of the psychological softening up that one has to undergo, as a punter. It's about lowering expectations. So that when we finally show anything half or even quarter decent, it'll look like the bargain of a lifetime. On such matters as the psychology of need and diminishment of self, we could advise Mossad.

She was class, I could see that from the moment she walked in the room. Manolo Blahnik shoes, a little black and white Bardot dress which I would guess was Agnés B, short-cut Peter Pan hair, shocking red. Five five, slightly shorter than me, not bad-looking but more Zoe Ball than Eva Herzigova. A kind of stretched face, as if the bones were trying to get out, with soft cottony skin. I liked her nose particularly, kind of fleshy, as if God had thrown a lump of dough at the centre of her face instead of designing one just for a bit of a giggle, or perhaps because he was bored. A fat nose then, but cute. The eyes were slightly mismatched - one larger than the other - but they had those lazy, heavy eyelids that always hinted at a powerful libido. Very slim too, with long, terrific legs. Flat-chested, but I'm very liberated about such matters. Looked her age, but not older than. She was certainly in her late twenties, possibly early thirties.

Posh, but not too much so - maybe two rungs above me, but not three. Three is too many to jump. I'm realistic about these things. I'm an estate agent - you learn to be realistic. You learn the value of things, you learn about people with an inflated idea of themselves. They come in the office every day, flakes we call them, or mincers, asking to look at places they can't afford, salivating over fixtures and fittings that cost more than their entire credit rating, drooling at the prospect of something somewhere in the future that will make them feel like they're in a television ad or a copy of Vogue Decor. It's not realistic. There's a ceiling.

Now Veronica was right there, at the ceiling. Touchable if you balanced on tiptoe. She spoke well, but not cut-glass or anything. You definitely can't jump too far in terms of class. You get young and old together, black and white, ugly and handsome, rich and poor. But it's still practically unheard of, in England, for the classes to cross the great divide - at least in my experience. Me and Veronica were definitely pushing the limits, but it was just about on the cards.

So. She was attractive, not beautiful. On the turn, a bit of a retread, probably just broken up a long-term relationship and getting very slightly worried about her prospects. I checked her watch: Raymond Weil, mid-range, too new to be inherited.

From the flat she was looking at, I could infer that she was well heeled, but not stinking rich. I guessed she was educated from the book she was carrying with her when she came in - something by Virginia Woolf. I could also tell from the fact that it was dog-eared in three places in the first ten pages that she was reading it out of a sense of duty rather than enjoyment, which was fine with me. That meant she was a woman who understood that appearances matter.

I did the obvious - asked whether it was for her and her boyfriend (no, they'd just split up), whether she'd be living alone (yes, but no archness in the reply, no flirt). She told me her name was Vronky, which I thought I had misheard, until she explained it was short for Veronica, Veronica Tree.

'We're distantly related to the Beerbohm Trees, don't you know?' she murmured, saying the last three words mock-posh, ultra-posh, as if it was a joke, but underneath I could tell she was proud of it. And although I didn't have the faintest idea who the Bare Bumtrees were, I was impressed.

She hummed and hawed her way round the flat. and I could tell she wasn't keen, which established a ground-floor intelligence. But then, Vinnie Jones with a head injury ...

I told her what she already knew, that she didn't want this flat, that we get a lot better than this for the same price, that the freeholder was an old villain and that she shouldn't touch it with a bargepole. Again, part of the softening-up process. Get them to trust you. Get them to like you. If they're a woman, get them into bed if possible, but only after you've closed the deal. I'm a closer, me. I always close.

fields.trailText: A lamp is lit.
fields.body:
A lamp is lit.

Until this moment, when the flame of the lamp flares blue, then settles to steady yellow inside its ornate globe, the young man had been impressed by the profound darkness into which, upon his late-night arrival at the palace of Rosenborg, he had suddenly stepped. Tired from his long sea Journey, his eyes stinging, his walk unsteady, he had been questioning the nature of this darkness. For it seemed to him not merely an external phenomenon, having to do with an actual absence of light, but rather as though it emanated from within him, as if he had finally crossed the threshold of his own absence of hope.

Now, he is relieved to see the walls of a panelled room take shape around him. A voice says: 'This is the Vinterstue. The Winter Room.'

The lamp is lifted up. Held high, it burns more brightly, as though sustained by purer air, and the young man sees a shadow cast onto the wall. It is a long, slanting shadow and so he knows it is his own. It appears to have a deformity, a hump, occurring along its spine from below the shoulder-blades to just above the waist. But this is the shadow's trickery. The young man is Peter Claire, the luternist, and the curvature on his back is his lute.

He is standing near a pair of lions, made of silver. Their eyes seem to watch him in the flickering gloom. Beyond them he can see a table and some tall chairs. But Peter Claire is separate from everything, cannot lean on any object, cannot rest. And now, the lamp moves and he must follow.

'It may be', says a tall gentleman, who hurries on, carrying the light, that His Majesty, King Christian, will command you to play for him tonight. He is not well and, his physicians have prescribed music. Therefore, members of the royal orchestra must be ready to perform at all times, day and night. I thought it best to advise you of this straight away.

Peter Claire's feelings of dismay increase. He begins to curse himself, to berate his own ambition for bringing him here to Denmark, for taking him so far from the places and people he had loved. He is at the end of his journey and yet he feels lost. Within this arrival some terrifying departure lies concealed. And suddenly, with peculiar speed, the lamp moves and everything in the room seems to rearrange itself. Peter Claire sees his shadow on the wall become elongated, stretching upwards for a few seconds towards the ceiling before being swallowed by the darkness, with no trace of it remaining.

Then the end of a corridor is reached and the gentleman stops before a door. He knocks and waits, putting a finger to his lips and leaning close against the door to listen for the command from within. It comes at last, a voice deep and slow, and Peter Claire finds himself, in the next minute, standing before King Christian, who is sitting in a chair in his night-shirt. Before him, on a small table, is a pair of scales and by these a clutch of silver coins.

The English lutenist bows as the King looks up and Peter Claire will always remember that, as King Christian first glimpses him in this dark middle of a winter's night, there comes into His Majesty's eyes a look of astonishment and, staring intently at the lute player's face, he whispers a single word: 'Bror.'

'I beg your pardon, Sir ... ?' says Peter Claire.

'Nothing,' says the King. 'A ghost. Denmark is full of ghosts. Did no one warn you?'

No, Your Majesty.'

'Never mind. You will see them for yourself. We are one of the oldest nations on earth. But you should know that it is a time of storms here, of confusion, of incomprehension, of bitter boiling muddle.'

'Of muddle, Sir?'

'Yes. This is why I am weighing silver. I weigh the same pieces over and over again, to ensure that there is no error. No possibility of error. I am trying, piece by piece and day by day, to reimpose order upon chaos.'

Peter Claire does not know how to reply to this and he is aware that the tall gentleman, without his noticing, has gone from the room, leaving him alone with the King, who now pushes the scales aside and settles himself more comfortably in the chair.

King Christian lifts his head and asks: 'How old are you, Mr Claire? Where do you come from?'

A fire is burning in the room, which is the Skrivestue, the King's study, and the small chamber smells sweetly of applewood and leather.

Peter Claire replies that he is twenty-seven and that his parents live in the town of Harwich on the east coast of England. He adds that the sea in winter can be unforgiving there.

'Unforgiving. Unforgiving!' say's the King. 'Well, we must hurry on, pass over or skirt around that word. Unforgiving. But I tell you, lutenist, I am tortured by lice. Do not look alarmed. Not in my hair or on my pillow. I mean by cowards, rascals, liars, sots, cheats and lechers. Where are the philosophers? That is what I constantly ask.'

Peter Claire hesitates before answering.

'No need to reply,' says the King. 'For they are all gone from Denmark. There is not one left.'

Then His Majesty stands up and moves towards the fire where Peter Claire is standing, and takes up a lamp and holds it near the young man's face. He examines the face and Peter Claire lowers his eyes because he has been warned not to stare at the King. This King is ugly. King Charles I of England, King Louis XIII of France, these are handsome men at this perilous moment in history, but King Christian IV of Denmark - all-powerful, brave and cultured as he is reported to be - has a face like a loaf.

 Extracted from Music and Silence by Rose Tremain, © Rose Tremain 1999, published by Chatto and Windus

fields.headline: Beowulf by Seamus Heaney
fields.standfirst:
'Grendel Strikes' from Beowulf
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText:
In off the moors, down through the mist-bands
God-cursed Grendel came greedily loping.
The bane of the race of men roamed forth,
hunting for a prey in the high hall.
Under the cloud-murk he moved towards it
until it shone above him, a sheer keep
of fortified gold. Nor was that the first time
he had scouted the grounds of Hrothgar's dwelling -
although never in his life, before or since,
did he find harder fortune or hall-defenders.
Spurned and joyless, he journeyed on ahead
and arrived at the bawn. The iron-braced door
turned on its hinge when his hands touched it.
Then his rage boiled over, he ripped open
the mouth of the building, maddening for blood,
pacing the length of the patterned floor
with his loathsome tread, while a baleful light,
flame more than light, flared from his eyes.
He saw many men in the mansion, sleeping,
a ranked company of kinsmen and warriors
quartered together. And his glee was demonic,
picturing the mayhem: before morning
he would rip life from limb and devour them,
feed on their flesh; but his fate that night
was due to change, his days of ravening
had come to an end.

In off the moors, down through the mist-bands
God-cursed Grendel came greedily loping.
The bane of the race of men roamed forth,
hunting for a prey in the high hall.
Under the cloud-murk he moved towards it
until it shone above him, a sheer keep
of fortified gold. Nor was that the first time
he had scouted the grounds of Hrothgar's dwelling -
although never in his life, before or since,
did he find harder fortune or hall-defenders.
Spurned and joyless, he journeyed on ahead
and arrived at the bawn. The iron-braced door
turned on its hinge when his hands touched it.
Then his rage boiled over, he ripped open
the mouth of the building, maddening for blood,
pacing the length of the patterned floor
with his loathsome tread, while a baleful light,
flame more than light, flared from his eyes.
He saw many men in the mansion, sleeping,
a ranked company of kinsmen and warriors
quartered together. And his glee was demonic,
picturing the mayhem: before morning
he would rip life from limb and devour them,
feed on their flesh; but his fate that night
was due to change, his days of ravening
had come to an end.

Mighty and canny,
Hygelac's kinsman was keenly watching
for the first move the monster would make.
Nor did the creature keep him waiting
but struck suddenly and started in;
he grabbed and mauled a man on his bench,
bit into his bone-lappings, bolted down his blood
and gorged on him in lumps, leaving the body
utterly lifeless, eaten up
hand and foot. Venturing closer,
his talon was raised to attack Beowulf
where he lay on the bed, he was bearing in
with open claw when the alert hero's
comeback and armlock forestalled him utterly.
The captain of evil discovered himself
in a handgrip harder than anything
he had ever encountered in any man
on the face of the earth. Every bone in his body
quailed and recoiled, but he could not escape.
He was desperate to flee to his den and hide
with the devil's litter, for in all his days
he had never been clamped or cornered like this.
Then Hygelac's trusty retainer recalled
his bedtime speech, sprang to his feet
and got a firm hold. Fingers were bursting,
the monster backtracking, the man overpowering.
The dread of the land was desperate to escape,
to take a roundabout road and flee
to his lair in the fens. The latching power
in his fingers weakened; it was the worst trip
the terror-monger had taken to Heorot.
And now the timbers trembled and sang,
a hall-session that harrowed every Dane
inside the stockade: stumbling in fury,
the two contenders crashed through the building.
The hall clattered and hammered, but somehow
survived the onslaught and kept standing:
it was handsomely structured, a sturdy frame
braced with the best of blacksmith's work
inside and out. The story goes
that as the pair struggled, mead-benches,were smashed
and sprung off the floor, gold fittings and all.
Before then, no Shielding elder would believe
there was any power or person upon earth
capable of wrecking their horn-rigged hall
unless the burning embrace of a fire
engulf it in flame. Then an extraordinary
wail arose, and bewildering fear
came over the Danes. Everyone felt it
who heard that cry as it echoed off the wall,
a God-cursed scream and strain of catastrophe,
the howl of the loser, the lament of the hell-serf
keening his wound. He was overwhelmed,
manacled tight by the man who of all men
was foremost and strongest in the days of this life.

 Extracted from Beowulf by Seamus Heaney, © Seamus Heaney 1999, published by Faber and Faber

fields.headline: A morass of Welsh emotion
fields.standfirst: What a true leader needs is flair, personality and sheer, damn hwyl
fields.trailText: 25 January 2000: What a true leader needs is flair, personality and sheer, damn hwyl.
fields.body:
It is appropriate now and again to bring to readers' attention the politics of far-off countries that do not normally command much space in British newspapers. Sometimes it is even important to do so. Quite possibly you are unaware of the current crisis in a small, mountainous, inaccessible, mostly beautiful, European principality whose political life has hitherto been stunted by outside domination. The principality is called Wales.

Whereas the London mayoralty contest has engaged Fleet Street's constant attention, the Welsh crisis has been almost wholly ignored. There are sound reasons for this, starting with the fact that the mayoral race constitutes a municipal freak show unmatched anywhere outside the borough council of Royston Vasey, whereas Wales has only Alun Michael. As they say, charisn'tma.

But Wales might not have Alun Michael much longer. Next month he faces a vote of no confidence in the Welsh assembly . If the non-Labour parties all vote together against him, Mr Michael will lose: he only has 28 seats out of 60. Since the assembly is less than a year old and precedent is in short supply, it isn't entirely clear what would happen next, though we may assume - since this involves New Labour - that it will be something dishonourable.

The immediate casus belli is Objective One. This is the status recently granted by Brussels to huge tracts of west Wales and the Valleys, ranking them with Europe's most disadvantaged areas. No one is insulted, since it involves the injection of vast quantities of cash which is unlikely to be re-offered once the eastern countries start joining the EU, and Wales moves away from the bottom of the European non-champions' league. But this cash requires pounds 85m worth of matching funds from the British government, which shows no sign of appearing.

There is a secondary cause of discontent, which concerns Mr Michael himself. No one wanted him to have the job of first secretary (and what a quaint title that is), including Mr Michael. And he has on the whole lived up to expectations: he is conscientious, hard-working and masterful with detail.

He has also been utterly unable to be the kind of leader Wales needed: someone with the flair and personality and sheer damn hwyl to embody the contradictory morass of emotions that constitute Welsh national aspirations, and enthuse the people with support for an assembly widely regarded as a waste of money. Less obviously, he has also been seen as dictatorial, and unable to adapt to the new cooperative forms of politics that were supposed to come with devolution, especially in a body that has no majority party.

There is some fascinating jockeying going on. At the centre of it is Ron Davies, aka Confused of Clapham Common, whose political death may have been exaggerated. He is now positioning himself as philosopher-king. Last week he gave a lecture at Cardiff University (Western Mail headline: `We can't go on like this'') in which he advocated a full-scale coalition at the assembly, an option described by one hysterical Labour MP as `the road to fascism''.

A Davies comeback is still improbable, though as he nudges closer to the nationalists, not impossible. The only other visible rival to Michael is Rhodri Morgan, whose stock has fallen in the year since Tony Blair sabotaged his moral victory in the battle to lead Welsh Labour. Being despised by Downing Street is probably a necessary qualification to be a credible leader in Wales, but not a sufficient one. Apart from that there are only people no one has heard of the option of a Plaid Cymru-Lib Dem coalition, also without a majority and (most likely of all) a fix, with some semi-bogus cash injection from Gordon Brown that enables Michael to limp on.

At the moment life is carrying on as ever. Michael yesterday unveiled a white paper with his plan for Wales. The aims include reducing teenage pregnancies so that there are no more than elsewhere in the UK, and increasing non-car journeys to work from a fifth to a quarter. All by 2010. This is just soooooo exciting, I can hardly tell you. But there are some far more general implications. Next week there is a Westminster byelection in Ceredigion (as in `I'm cold, I must find my ceredigion''). Plaid is expected to romp it. Indeed, if things go on the way they are, Labour could lose heaps of seats to them in the next election.

We see the same pattern all over Britain. No one, but no one, wants the Tories back. There remains great goodwill towards Mr Blair. However, when the opportunity comes to teach him a lesson without giving aid and comfort to William Hague, voters take it. The lesson is that devolution means giving away power: if that means letting in Rhodri or Ken, tough luck. Yet the prime minister can't grasp it at all. His infernal bossiness may yet destroy him.

Matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

webTitle: Lib Dems face row after tuition fees climbdown

fields.headline: Lib Dems face row after tuition fees climbdown
fields.trailText: January 25 2000: The row over university tuition fees in Scotland intensified yesterday after the Liberal Democrats were accused of breaking manifesto promises by entering into a compromise deal with Labour.
fields.body:
The row over university tuition fees in Scotland intensified yesterday after the Liberal Democrats were accused of breaking manifesto promises by entering into a compromise deal with Labour.

The final blueprint for reforms to the system of student finance in Scotland is being drawn up by a Scottish cabinet committee for publication by the end of the week. It is understood that, under the proposals, only Scots studying in Scotland will have up-front tuition fees abolished. Scottish students studying elsewhere in the UK will have to pay the fees, as will English students studying in Scotland. But students from the EU studying in Scotland will be exempt.

The deal has been hammered out by the Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, and his Liberal Democrat deputy, Jim Wallace, to keep the fragile coalition government alive.

However, problems with European legislation - which, in effect, would make it illegal for the Scottish executive to abolish up-front tuition fees for all Scottish students - mean neither Labour nor the Lib Dems are entirely happy with the compromise.

The Lib Dems made abolition of the fees the 'non-negotiable'' centrepiece of their election manifesto and it will now be difficult. In order to abolish up-front tuition fees for all Scots, the Westminster government would have been forced to pay the fees of all 99,000 EU students studying in Britain. This was immediately vetoed by Tony Blair and has left Mr Wallace with the task of defending an obvious compromise. The Scottish National Party is accusing the Lib Dems of U-turns. 'Labour in Scotland are devising a political fix to get London Labour off the hook, and the Lib Dems are preparing to aid and abet them by breaking their manifesto pledge,'' said John Swinney, shadow lifelong learning minister.

But Labour are also unhappy that the deal will create such a dichotomy on student finance across Britain. Senior figures believe it plays into the hands of the SNP, but they are prepared to go ahead with the deal to save the coalition.

To help the Lib Dems save political face, it is understood that Labour are prepared to charge graduates a third less for their tuition fees than the level recommended by the independent Cubie report into student finance.

fields.headline: Away with our heavy burden
fields.standfirst:
Fierce debate over plans for university teaching assessments comes
to a head at this week's meeting of vice-chancellors. Howard
Newby defends the proposals
fields.trailText: Fierce debate over plans for university teaching assessments comes to a head at this week's meeting of vice-chancellors. Howard Newby defends the proposals
fields.body:
Universities are close to achieving the big prize: retaining public confidence in the quality of university teaching while removing the huge bureaucratic burden under which we labour.

Nothing has recently caused more resentment in the university world than the enormous bureaucracy arising from the proliferation of quality assessments. They are about to reach a climax with both the research assessment exercise in 2001 and the introduction of a new system of assessing teaching quality.

I'm not sure the wider world has any idea of the volume of work and preparation involved. Under the current system for teaching quality for example, a single subject appraisal in an individual university often generates around 150 box files of documents and requires several months' preparation. Multiply this 30 or 40 times for a typical university and the call for a "lighter touch" by universities is clearly understandable and, indeed, essential.

A new streamlined and informative system of assessing academic teaching standards in higher education is recognised by both the Quality Assessment Agency and the Committee of Vice-chancellors and Principals as essential, and is agreed. Once up and running, we must ensure the new process will provide prospective students and parents with useful, valuable information about teaching quality in particular subjects, and assure us all that public funds are being well spent.

In such matters the devil is in the detail. At the heart of the new proposals is a simple pass/fail overall judgment. Essentially, all degree schemes will be given either a green or a red light approved or not approved.

But the chief issue under discussion over recent months has been the ostensibly arcane matter of the reporting format. Why is this so important? It is crucial because, by a kind of perverse law, the more finely detailed are the reporting formats, the more burdensome is the bureaucracy. The ever-finer judgments must stand up to possible external judicial review.

Universities argued long and hard for a simplified system of reporting outcomes that would instead guide prospective students and their parents toward the narrative comment about particular subjects in particular universities. That would be the really useful substance of any report. This aim has largely been achieved.

Each assessment will cover three elements (teaching and learning, student progression, and use of resources) rather than the present six. These reports will be summarised as "commendable", "approved but action recommended" or "failing" (where urgent action is required and a re-visit will follow after a year).

Based on knowledge gained from the current system, I don't doubt that the vast majority of provision will fall into the commendable category. That will lead students to look at the underlying diversity of course offerings rather than relying on a spurious numerical summary.

The narrative assessments will also include special reference to any "exemplary" aspects where we could learn from each other. This will not constitute a separate category but will be specifically referred to in the report so that the sector as a whole will be able to identify best practice - and learn from it. For example, a particular department might have a superb record for placing students in valuable work experience arenas; another might make brilliant use of computer-aided learning techniques.

I am confident this system will be sufficiently simplified to allow us to move on to the so-called "lighter touch". Our best brains in universities should be devoted to teaching and research, not endless rounds of paper-chasing and meetings explaining their processes.

 Professor Howard Newby is president of the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals.

fields.headline: Class acts
fields.trailText: Here today
fields.body:
Here today

Dr James Chalmers of the information and statistics division of the NHS in Scotland reports that there is a higher incidence of heart attacks among Scottish males on a Monday than on any other day of the week. This he attributes to binge drinking at the weekend. So congratulations to all those north-of-the-border readers still standing. You've got at least another week. Probably.

Long live the chat

In a lecture to last week's Foresight conference on the future of universities, Sir Graham Hills, former principal of Strathclyde University, declared: "The lecture is dead," adding, "This is not a lecture, by the way. This is an extended chat." That makes a seminar "a good gossip" and a tutorial a "private bitching session".

Ground force

Still in Strathclyde, the assistant registrar received a letter from two students expressing their deep remorse and disgust for their vandalism to a university shrubbery while drunk, and enclosing £40 to cover the damage. Maybe they're still too pissed to remember their own names.

Heads I win, tails you lose

The office of fair trading is launching a website to help students cope with money management and debt. This is thoughtful of the government, since its abolition of the grant system and the introduction of student loans is largely responsible for the problems.

fields.headline: Lunchtime learning
fields.standfirst: Michele Hanson gives an insight into the lifelong habits of the teaching profession
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson gives an insight into the lifelong habits of the teaching profession
fields.body:
Teachers can never afford to stop learning. They must keep abreast of things, learn new techniques, follow the whims of the inspectorate, read the ever-changing curriculum, then throw away the huge chunks that they've just sweated through and read the new chunks.

To help the teacher adapt to change, workshops are held, a little further education in your lunch hour or after school. I remember a maths workshop to help us adapt to SMILE (Secondary Mathematics Individual Learning Experience). Our instructor was Derek - young, blond, pink-faced and earnest.

"SMILE can be a bit controversial," said Derek. "No one classroom does it the same." He held up an Entry Guide test paper to show what level the child is at. If they can do it, it's the right level. The Entry Guide led to the Matrix - a set of ten cards of questions at the appropriate level. The Matrix was on a very long sheet called the Network. The Network was illegible because the writing was too small.

"Get a child to read it," said Derek helpfully. "Use a microscope."

The Network would cover the national curriculum, helpfully indicating the levels of national curriculum that corresponded to the levels of Matrix. Tick the boxes. SMILE has teachers' record sheets to be filled in. Tick the pupils' record sheets. Pupils should get over 80% of questions right. "It's normal to get 100%," said Derek proudly. "It's giving them work they can do."

Children would hopefully work through the Matrix on their own, marking their own work. That's why it was called an Individual Learning Scheme. It had come to save us from the hated chalk-and-talk method.

Mr Snave, dedicated chalk-and-talker, did not agree. In his experience, all SMILE pupils queue up to ask the teacher for help because they get stuck. They don't want to work on their own. They prefer a lovely red tick in their books and a remark from teacher to show that someone knew they were doing something and had seen it. Or perhaps they couldn't find the right card.

"There are always going to be things that you can't find when you want them." Derek plodded on. "Card numbers have no relation to difficulty. Cards are numbered in the order in which they were invented. So number 3 may be harder than number 18. Seventy card tasks make one GCSE assessment," babbled Derek. "Twenty must be 'extended working', that is, they must have done more of it."

"Does teacher give them more?" asks Miss Pringle.

"No, they make it themselves. But, in practice," says Derek going very pink, "you have to help them rather a lot. Twenty can be two, because it depends on time. Forty minutes equals one card."

"What if they just sit looking at it?" "It still counts as forty minutes' work." So four hundred minutes makes 10 cards, even if it's one card.

Mrs Pringle, a fellow reactionary, asked what happened when a child came across a card that it could not do or understand. Did she then look for a card in the Matrix to explain the difficulty?

"No," said Derek. Nothing could be done about the card the child couldn't do, he explained. "They mustn't keep trying it. They'd get bored. Remember we're giving them work they can do."

This was difficult for Miss Pringle, of the old school and keen on batting away at a problem until it is understood.

"Then how do they progress?" she snapped.

"Very gradually," said Derek.

Teachers, on the other hand, must always progress very quickly.

SMILE has teachers' record sheets to be filled in. Tick the pupils' record sheets. Pupils should get over 80% of questions right. "It's normal to get 100%," said Derek proudly. "It's giving them work they can do." Children would hopefully work through the Matrix on their own, marking their own work. That's why it was called an Individual Learning Scheme. It had come to save us from the hated chalk-and-talk method. Mr Snave, dedicated chalk-and-talker, did not agree. In his experience, all SMILE pupils queue up to ask the teacher for help because they get stuck. They don't want to work on their own. They prefer a lovely red tick in their books and a remark from teacher to show that someone knew they were doing something and had seen it. Or perhaps they couldn't find the right card. "There are always going to be things that you can't find when you want them." Derek plodded on. "Card numbers have no relation to difficulty. Cards are numbered in the order in which they were invented. So number 3 may be harder than number 18. Seventy card tasks make one GCSE assessment," babbled Derek. "Twenty must be 'extended working', that is, they must have done more of it." "Does teacher give them more?" asks Miss Pringle. "No, they make it themselves. But, in practice," says Derek going very pink, "you have to help them rather a lot. Twenty can be two, because it depends on time. Forty minutes equals one card." "What if they just sit looking at it?" "It still counts as forty minutes' work." So four hundred minutes makes 10 cards, even if it's one card. Mrs Pringle, a fellow reactionary, asked what happened when a child came across a card that it could not do or understand. Did she then look for a card in the Matrix to explain the difficulty? "No," said Derek. Nothing could be done about the card the child couldn't do, he explained. "They mustn't keep trying it. They'd get bored. Remember we're giving them work they can do." This was difficult for Miss Pringle, of the old school and keen on batting away at a problem until it is understood. "Then how do they progress?" she snapped. "Very gradually," said Derek. Teachers, on the other hand, must always progress very quickly.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.standfirst: Class assistants; elite funding; Islington LEA; second languages
fields.trailText: Class assistants | Elite funding | Islington LEA | Second languages
fields.body:
A higher profile

The government is already taking action to improve teaching assistants' opportunities for training and career development (Talents Not Being Tapped, January 19). We are providing £130m through the Standards Fund to recruit up to 15,000 more teaching assistants in 2000-2001. This is on the road to the goal of an extra 20,000 by 2002 and is in addition to 2,000 already recruited.

As outlined in the Teachers' Green Paper, we are developing a national framework of training and qualifications in consultation with the relevant national bodies and local authorities. Another plank in our commitment to improve training is to offer local authorities the use of new introductory training materials from September 2000.

Building on the good practice which already exists, the training will help ensure that new recruits have a clear understanding of their roles and responsibilities, and will improve the quality of professional support available to teachers, particularly during the literacy hour and daily maths lesson. We are also developing guidance on the effective deployment of teaching assistants by heads and teachers. We are raising the profile of teaching assistants and fully acknowledge the contribution well-trained assistants can make in helping schools achieve higher standards.

Estelle Morris, School Standards Minister.

Oxbridge blues

Is David Marquand trying to insult the vast majority of his academic colleagues (Oxford Calling, Guardian Higher, January 18)? Not only does he snub all other British universities by claiming that "[Oxbridge] provide a superbly good undergraduate education - how good, only those who have taught elsewhere in the British university system can appreciate," but he manages to defame all the great universities of the European continent to boot: "[Oxbridge] may well be the last university in Europe capable of challenging the dominance of the American ivy league."

More importantly, his argument is inconsistent. It is becoming "ever more important to equalise opportunities". Why, then, celebrate that "an Oxbridge degree still opens more doors than most?" Given such attitudes, it is hardly surprising that only 379 students from FE Colleges even applied to Oxford last year; or that their admission rate, of under 30%, was so low.

Most importantly, the pleas for more resources in the article would be amusing if there were not a chance that such resources might be forthcoming. Even the "poorest college in the university" (as David describes Mansfield College) has resources beyond the appreciation of most people working in higher education. Resources for widening participation should follow the students, not be granted on the basis of promises to behave better in future.

Daniel Dorling, school of geographical sciences, University of Bristol.

Whose authority?

What on earth is going on at Islington? (A very public privatisation, January 18). Here we have a local education authority - note "authority" not "agency" - apparently on the verge of handing over much of its authority, no doubt at considerable public expense, to an unaccountable private organisation.

This does not say much for the self-respect and self-confidence of Islington's elected councillors, who are supposed to carry the responsibility for the borough's services.

Worse, the company concerned is run by a former LEA official, and appears to have poached a serving education director from another part of London to head up its work.

What is the point of all this when Islington could just as easily have got hold of some good people as part of its education service? John Carvel's article about the excellent in-house achievement of Liverpool City Council shows what can be done by councillors who refuse to be browbeaten by the Ofsteds and other opinion-offering bodies of this world.

It would be good to think that Islington will soon be able to follow Liverpool's example.

Robin Wendt, 28 Church Lane, Upton-by-Chester, Chester.

Global links

Two recent government announcements: dis-application for some pupils from languages at KS4, and "support" for languages in primary schools (Lips), herald a new skirmish in the battle for a curriculum for the next century.

Some teachers, understandably, will feel relief at allowing disaffected pupils to drop a subject they "are not interested in and won't need". But the importance of a second language to every member of a global community cannot be underestimated. Increasingly, a second language is becoming a requirement.

There is a deal to be struck: if pupils are permitted to abandon a vital element of a "broad and balanced" curriculum, it must be for positive and not negative reasons, and only after a firm foundation in language learning has been laid at an early stage. This argues strongly for the introduction of languages in primary schools. In the interests of equality of educational provision for all children, it cannot be ignored that languages are taught in the primary phase in virtually every independent school.

George Varnava, Chair of Professional Committee, and Professor Ray Page, Chief Executive Officer, The College of Teachers, Theydon Bois, Epping, Essex.

Brought to book

I read John Davitt's article Recycled Learning with great interest - until I reached the closing remarks on management. The "special individual" he's looking for, this "part network manager, part learning specialist and part information architect," already exists. The word he is groping for is "librarian".

I manage a school Learning Resources Centre. Using the Alice library system, I can catalogue not only the books and other resources in the centre, but also web pages and even word-processed files.

A student or teacher can make an inquiry on any computer in the school. The system will show which relevant resources are on loan, which are on the LRC shelves (with a floor plan and flashing spot to show where!), which are web pages - with a single button to go straight into them - and which are Word files, also opened from the catalogue. The key is careful key-wording, and a grasp of the basic cataloguing, classification and indexing principles acquired during library and information-science training. There's no need to reinvent the wheel.

Wendy Raybould, LRC Manager, Weston Favell Upper School, Northampton.

Feeding the fat cats

Eddie McIntyre (New year wishes, Guardian Further, January 11) claims that "The vast majority of governing bodies value their staff and the excellent work they do, but adequate [salary] increases have not been paid simply because governing bodies cannot afford them."

This shifting of the blame for low staff salaries onto the government is disingenuous. Many colleges and universities easily unearth the sums necessitated by huge, but undeserved, management pay increases, and this at a time of ruthless cuts in teaching staff, notwithstanding the recent vast increase in student numbers. To give but one example, Leeds Metropolitan University accepted onto its Graphic Design BA last September approximately 30% more students than the previous year's intake, at the same time axing virtually its entire quota of related part-time staff.

McIntyre advocates that college employees be allowed to purchase company shares. If he's so keen on sharing out the profits, I suggest that he and his fellow "fat cat" managers take a substantial salary cut, distributing the surplus to their underpaid, but no doubt overworked, employees.

Peter Suchin, London, E1.
