fields.headline: My inspiration
fields.standfirst: Mike Gayle
fields.trailText: Mike Gayle | Steve Austin
fields.body:
Age 28
Occupation Author
Favourite teacher Steve Austin
Where they met Lordswood Boys School, Birmingham

I've been disappointed by education due to the influence of TV. I thought Lordswood would be like Grange Hill, and later on I genuinely thought university would be like The Young Ones. I was very wrong!

My two brothers had been to Lordswood before me and the main thing in the school's mind was "great - another Gayle!" My eldest brother, Andy, was one of the top 15 pole-vaulters in the country and Phil was in the top 12 triple-jumpers! Unfortunately, I'm the runt of the litter, which led to bitter disappointment.

Mr Austin was my history teacher. Amusingly, his first name is Steve - but you couldn't meet anyone less like the six-million-dollar man. He'd obviously gone to university in the mid-70s, and that kind of "radical student" image never quite left him. He was very much one for wearing corduroy trousers.

The thing about him I liked the most, although he was really good at teaching history, too, was that he was a really nice kind of guy. Given a good distraction he'd rather talk about something other than history. We would consciously try to steer him into a diversion. He'd be talking about the origin of the first world war then we'd somehow get a question in that related to music or, even better, one that went back to his time at university. It was really refreshing! Mr Austin had a well developed, sarcastic sense of humour. You need teachers like Mr Austin. He had a good rapport with the kids, even the bad lads.

The first thing we studied with Mr Austin was Roman settlements. We had a trip to an original Roman site and one of the exhibits was a real Roman skeleton. I remember we dropped our pencils down on to it so we would be able to retrieve them and touch a real skeleton - very exciting!

A few months ago, I went back to school for the first time since I left over 10 years ago, with my brother Phil. It was a very odd experience. We were invited into the head's room. The last time I'd been in there was to get the cane for helping throw a lad off the side of a massive drop at the edge of the south playground! He wanted to be thrown, but unfortunately he broke his arm.

Mr Austin looked exactly the same. We had a chat; he'd bought my book, which he hadn't had the chance to read - it had joined his "to be read" mountain. Seeing the building itself brought back all sorts of memories. I saw a door next to the English room and remembered something about it that has been a secret until now.

I had always wondered what was behind that door, which was always locked, and one day I managed to get hold of a set of teachers' keys from another kid. I opened the door and saw ladders leading up. I went and got a couple of my friends out of lessons, using the excuse that another teacher had asked to see them, and we climbed up the ladders. They led up to a boiler room and then to the roof of the school. We opened the window and went on to the roof. It was the greatest achievement of my school career!

Steve Austin has taught history at Lordswood School since 1973.

Lordswood is the sort of school where teachers hang around. There are three teachers here who have been here even longer than me! A lot of us have grown up in this place. It was my first job and I suppose it shows a terrible lack of ambition to still be here.

Mike was quite interested and reasonably well-behaved. On the whole, he was a pupil who was more likely to ask intelligent questions, the one most likely to be awake and listening to me rambling on. Mike was fun to have in the classroom and he'd even get some of the references! It's no surprise that he has done so well - his intelligence, personality and get-up-and-go made that pretty clear.

I'm a classic drifter. I got a degree in history and forgot to do anything about a job. After doing a PGCE, I thought I'd give teaching a go, just for a trial period. I've stuck with it for the duration. It's probably as right for me as anything else I could have done. It's been a lot of fun, with the pupils and my colleagues. We're fighting a constant fight - it would be nice to be left alone by the government for a year or two to just get on with things.

It was great to see Mike last summer. I'm very impressed by his achievements. I'm sure the school looked the same to him as ever, it probably hasn't been painted since he left. Birmingham Council - are you listening?!

 Mike Gayle is the author of the best-selling novel, My Legendary Girlfriend. His latest book, Mr Commitment, is published on Feb 3 by Flame (Hodder & Stoughton) at £6.99.

fields.headline: New UK brand is launched
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston on plans to double the number of foreign students in colleges
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston on plans to double the number of foreign students in colleges
fields.body:
First details of how Tony Blair's scheme to double the number of overseas students coming to British further education colleges is to be achieved, are to be unveiled tomorrow.

A new "UK Education Brand", endorsed by Terence Conran and other internationally recognised celebrities, and designed to update Britain's credentials as a world leader in education and training will be launched by Tessa Blackstone, the higher education minister.

Meanwhile plans are almost complete to prevent colleges and private training providers from making disastrous overseas ventures which have previously dented Britain's reputation abroad.

A centrally approved list of further education colleges and private providers offering courses deemed suitable for export has been virtually completed by British Training International (BTI), an initiative launched by David Blunkett to focus the marketing of vocational education and training.

BTI itself has been boosted and its future probably assured beyond its initial three years by a favourable report from Price Waterhouse Coopers, consultants sent in by the DfEE to assess its progress. This concludes that the organisation's work as a single point for overseas customers is important if British vocational education and training is to be successfully sold.

Germany, Canada and Australia, the other leading players, with the UK, in the international vocational education and training market, have each set up centrally co-ordinated organisations for the international promotion of their training skills.

Last June the prime minister launched a campaign to attract more international students to the UK. The further education sector has to double the numbers of its overseas students from 25,000 to 50,000 by 2005.

Tomorrow Baroness Blackstone will unveil the Brand, including a new logo, which will spearhead the marketing efforts in the British Council's 110 offices around the world.

The aim will be to capitalise on Britain's traditional reputation for quality, particularly the standards of its qualifications, while refreshing people's perceptions of UK plc. A MORI survey for the British Council found that the predominant images of Britain were out of date.

According to most recent figures gathered for the DfEE, annual exports by private sector training providers total £1.25 billion a year. These exports go to some 120 countries. Awarding bodies are the main exporters, and the subject areas most in demand are management and business skills.

A British Council report in 1998 estimated that students coming in to further education institutions from overseas were bringing in about £200 million a year. But there are no figures available for the total worth of work performed overseas by British colleges.

British Training International's chief executive, Ruth Gee, said that despite - in fact because of - the huge upheavals which have taken place in the further education sector in the past 15 years there was growing interest abroad in British vocational education and training.

In particular, she said, other countries want to examine the radical switch there has been from a rigid "time-bound system", when courses lasted set periods irrespective of the needs of industry and colleges decided what had to be studied, to a system where employers set the agenda to a much greater extent.

fields.headline: Seeing is believing
fields.standfirst: University styles in architecture have to inspire students so, asks Dominic Janes, has olde gothic had its day?
fields.trailText: University styles in architecture have to inspire students so, asks Dominic Janes, has olde gothic had its day?
fields.body:
The chairs at one university entrance interview I went to were old and worn, just like the historians questioning me. By contrast, I was so desperate to look good in my new suit that I must have appeared positively awkward.

Presentation is not a key aspect of an academic essay. What matters, apart from the odd rule on indenting, is content. I have been taught to be suspicious of a student who writes on coloured paper and creates a medieval exuberance of illuminations among the text. Similarly the "shiny suit" can be seen as a uniform that thinkers don't need. But to the outside world, scruffy people might appear to deserve scruffy surroundings.

Fraying curtains and splitting linoleum can be comforting for governments who may wish to save money by stressing a utilitarian, no-frills view of higher education. Yet this reckons without the Ivy League and Oxbridge factor. By that I mean gothic turrets, portraits, quadrangles and, well, ivy.

Some people are impressed, otherwise Oxford and Cambridge would not be plagued by tourists. But do these, or indeed any universities, need impressive buildings? One can argue that they do.

Firstly, care spent on buildings suggests what takes place within is considered important. Universities should be seen to take their role seriously. There are the clear motivational advantages of being in a pleasant environment. And there is the importance of first impressions.

When I went for university interviews, my choice was influenced by whether the toilets flushed properly, the department had enough space, the halls of residence were attractive, and yes, the look of those sad old chairs. Higher education needs to look like a winner as well as be a winner. Excellent new architecture can help achieve these linked ambitions.

Now the money has to be found for buildings to house a further expansion in student numbers - but for what style of architecture?

Universities have one well-known architectural brand image - "ye olde gothic". This plays well with parts of the establishment, with tourists and some alumni. But what about the future, the new millennium, steel, metal, the Dome?

Scatterings of round, tented internet-hubs could be a way of saying to students that higher education has its finger on the pulse. The problem is that colleges do not exist to reflect contemporary society but to better it by applying careful (and to the outsider, frequently unexciting) intellectual methodologies to scientific, social and artistic problems. Academia should be prestigious, not trendy.

Universities do not have the private sector's resources to tear buildings down once fashions have changed, so if they buy in the latest design, they will be forced to live with the results. One well-intentioned Cambridge college built an extension that showed it was up-to-the-minute. The result was an aggressively stepped structure in concrete and glass popularly known as the typewriter.

By contrast, I was so desperate to look good in my new suit that I must have appeared positively awkward. Presentation is not a key aspect of an academic essay. What matters, apart from the odd rule on indenting, is content. I have been taught to be suspicious of a student who writes on coloured paper and creates a medieval exuberance of illuminations among the text. Similarly the "shiny suit" can be seen as a uniform that thinkers don't need. But to the outside world, scruffy people might appear to deserve scruffy surroundings. fields.headline: Health and safety at work
fields.trailText: Health and safety at work
fields.body:
Health and safety, eh?Used to be a popular read in the fourth form, I recall. I believe, although I never saw a copy, that you may be referring to a magazine called Health & Efficiency. So what is it all about then? It's about keeping the workplace safe and troublefree.

What, an office with no back-stabbing or character assassination? How fearfully dull. Don't fret, it's got nothing to do with office politics, or shouldn't have. Health and safety advisers, who may also boast the titles health and safety managers, officers, practitioners or specialists, work with managers and employees, trade unions and safety groups to ensure that safety policies and practices are carried out...

Lumme! Please don't interrupt, it could cause an accident. As I was saying, their role is to minimise occupational health problems and accidents and to dish out advice and specific training to improve safety. They are responsible for identifying working practices that may be unsafe and they assess potential problems or dangers so they can be eliminated.

Please don't stop. I won't. There are also health and safety inspectors, who are employed by the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), which is part of the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. They're responsible for inspecting workplaces that fall within the HSE's remit. They are mainly concerned with a company's strategy for controlling risks to health and safety. They check machinery, management systems, equipment, substances and working methods.

Do they pack much muscle? Size is irrelevant.

No no, can they bang heads? Are there any fun bits to this job? They have various legal powers they can invoke against firms with dodgy safety practices if verbal persuasion doesn't work.

So that's it, is it? Since you ask, no. There's also environmental health.

Spill all! That's an unfortunate expression. It's about reducing the risk to human health from the living and working environment. Environmental health inspectors bear wide responsibilities, including food safety, public health, housing, health and safety at work and the control and notification of infectious disease. They visit homes, shops, factories, refuse disposal sites, air and sea ports and other places to check food-safety, hygiene, living and working conditions.They also monitor pollution and emissions.

So, how do you get some of this action? Colleges and private training providers run a wide variety of short courses at the health and safety adviser level. Some companies will train on the job. Qualifications range from a basic First Aid course, to an NVQ/SVQ in Occupational Safety and Health, and include, for example, a National Certificate in Construction Health and Safety and a Specialist Diploma in Environmental Management. The Institution of Occupational Safety and Health (IOSH) has designed a programme of continuing professional development.

What about the inspectors? Hold your horses. It takes two years to train as an inspector. Inspectors normally need a degree or its equivalent, but exceptions are occasionally made for candidates with the right qualities. They must study for a postgraduate Diploma in Occupational Health and Safety. Within their first three years in post they are also expected to pick up NVQ Level 4 in Health and Safety Regulation.

And environmental health? Various paths lead to a certificate of the Environmental Health Officers Registration Board. For instance, a degree or MSc accredited by the Chartered Institute of Environmental Health.

 Institution of Occupational Safety and Health, The Grange, Highfield Drive, Wigston, Leicestershire LE18 1NN, Telephone 0116 2573100

 The National Examination Board in Occupational Safety and Health, 5 Dominus Way, Meridian Business Park, Leicester LE3 2QW, Telephone 0116 2634700

 Health and Safety Executive, St Hugh's House, Stanley Precinct, Bootle L20 3QY Telephone 0151 9513366

 Chartered Institute of Environmental Health, Chadwick Court, 15 Hatfields, London SE1 8DJ, Telephone 0171 9286006

 Learndirect 0800 100900 offers informationand advice on courses.

fields.headline: A harsh inheritance
fields.standfirst: Kate Thompson's The Missing Link follows Christie's search for his roots
fields.trailText: Kate Thompson's The Missing Link follows Christie's search for his roots
fields.body:
The Missing Link
By Kate Thompson
Published by Random House Children's Books
Price £10.99
Age 11+

When his mother re-marries, Christie inherits a "freak" for an older stepbrother.

Nobody seems sure exactly what's wrong with Danny, but in his more intelligible moments, even he acknowledges that he is "some kind of mistake". It is on Danny's insistence that Christie reluctantly agrees to help him find his birth mother, and they embark on an epic journey from their home in Ireland to the Scottish Highlands.

This is a book that successfully touches on such issues as family tensions, drug use and homelessness with sensitivity but without self-consciousness, whilst matching any teen horror on adventure, thrills and intrigue.

We see Christie propelled into a bizarre but wholly convincing world, caught between the harsh realities of a national fuel shortage and the surrealism of an encounter with animals apparently blessed with the gift of speech.

The novel twists and turns right up to the last page, as Christie uncovers a spectacularly sinister laboratory hidden in the cellars of the Scottish farmhouse, a grisly tale of genetic engineering - and the truth behind his brother's unusual condition.

A thoroughly satisfying and thought-provoking read.

fields.headline: You've been warned
fields.standfirst: Last week the government shook universities awake to a futuristic world of global education where corporations award their own degrees
fields.trailText: Last week the government shook universities awake to a futuristic world of global education where corporations award their own degrees
fields.body:
British universities are ill prepared to cope with the rising forces of globalisation, the government's Foresight programme has been warned. A world in which huge commercial organisations sign up students across the globe and corporations award their own degrees was outlined last week to an Office of Science and Technology conference of vice-chancellors and other senior academics.

Although rumours that Harvard Business School was setting up a centre at the luxury Gleneagles Hotel in Perthshire turned out to be groundless - the hotel's overtures were politely rebuffed - the UK's traditional institutions face competition from new kinds of commercial universities which tap into massive resources and operate internationally via the internet.

Michael Thorne, vice-principal of Napier University, pointed to the "stunningly profitable" University of Phoenix, the largest private university in the United States which makes $12.8m a quarter through online and distance courses. Wall Street analysts were eyeing the $635bn education sector as ripe for investment because it was a low-tech cottage industry managed by amateurs.

Sylvan Learning Systems, which aimed to become "the leading provider of educational services to families, schools and industry", had signed agreements with leading universities such as Berkeley and MIT and was buying up garages and sites in shopping malls as learning centres.

In New Zealand the government's qualifications authority is now prepared to license companies to award their own degrees, if they meet criteria including a proportion of staff with PhDs and a percentage of budget spent on research. IBM New Zealand is now under consideration. As Professor Thorne said, this would have a more high-profile global brand than any single New Zealand university. Corporations like Motorola or Microsoft which already have their own "universities" could quickly expand globally if they were permitted to accredit their own degrees.

John Sperling, chairman of the company that owns the University of Phoenix, said publicly traded institutions would have the advantage of being able to hire and fire staff easily (most would be part-time instructors) and motivating managers who could build up personal wealth. They would operate at a profit and have access to capital markets.

A Foresight document, Britain towards 2010, published by the department of trade and industry, said students no longer needed to be resident at universities. "Currently the majority of students raise loans and then work long hours in part-time jobs in order to study and afford to live. But for what purpose? To sit in lecture classes with several hundred other students listening to academics reading the same notes as they may have done for a number of years."

The use of university intranets to distribute notes to students and allow them to work in virtual teams was already common in the US and Australia - popular with students and cheaper. The document dismissed objections about face-to-face interaction between student and teacher - for most students it does not happen under traditional methods - and lifestyle. "Where is the quality of life working in supermarkets three hours each day to be in residence at a university?"

Universities' teaching would change dramatically. Students would supplement personal learning on a PC with short-term residential courses.

The potential of the internet could mean too many academics in future, it added. "For those who wish to hang onto a traditional academic lifestyle the future looks bleak unless they are employed by the 'high branded' universities. Even so their roles will change as they embrace the potential of the new technologies. They will no longer be able to rely on last year's lecture notes."

Thorne strongly disputed the prediction of too many academics - he stressed the need for more universities and more people to work in them.

Edinburgh, he said, was agonising about a fourth university in the city. Boston, with a very similar population, has 65.

"Which of the two cities," he asked, "has stimulated more start-up companies?"

webTitle: The long and short of Ofsted

fields.headline: The long and short of Ofsted
fields.standfirst: After a successful trial run last term, short inspections will replace full ones for schools identified as 'improving'. This will be a great relief for the lucky ones; but there could now be a stigma attached to a normal inspection, says  Stephen Hoare
fields.trailText: After a successful trial run last term, short inspections will replace full ones for schools identified as 'improving'. This will be a great relief for the lucky ones; but there could now be a stigma attached to a normal inspection, says Stephen Hoare
fields.body:
If you were a hospital patient awaiting diagnosis, would you rather have exploratory surgery or a scan? With a new framework launched this term, Ofsted has already decided which schools go under the knife with a full inspection and which will be offered the "keyhole" techniques of a short inspection. Schools in line for short inspections are over the moon at what promises to be a relatively painless process - the long-awaited "light touch".

Last term, pilot short inspections were held up and down the country. Dunraven - a Lambeth secondary with a mixed multi-ethnic intake and a high proportion of pupils eligible for free school meals - volunteered as a guinea pig. Standards had been rising continuously and the headteacher, Richard Townsend, was moderately confident. He says: "The availability of reliable, up-to-date evidence meant we were likely to get a clean bill of health. Getting a short inspection is a tremendous boost to a school like ours."

With only a draft handbook and some advice from HMI to guide them, the team of four registered inspectors and a lay inspector were breaking new ground. There is a lot less paperwork needed for a short inspection. Teachers need no longer produce plans of work or heads of department conjure up policy documents.

The issues for the inspection were thrashed out in a meeting between the head and the lead inspector, Peter McGregor. Like all Ofsted inspectors, McGregor came armed with robust data - the PICSI or pre-inspection context and school indicator. Benchmarking the school's intake, SATs results and other data, like ethnicity and eligibility for free school meals, the PICSI gives the inspectors a general feel for the issues. But a visit is essential to put theories to the test.

Establishing a relationship of trust was vital. McGregor explains: "The meeting helped to shape our perceptions of the school's strengths and weaknesses. When we went in there were no surprises." Townsend agrees. "This is a new relationship with Ofsted. I felt as though we were being treated in a grown-up way."

Self-evaluation is an important feature of the new inspection system. At Dunraven, the headteacher and senior management routinely monitor and observe lessons carried out in the classroom. Having made in-service training and supporting teachers a priority, Townsend knew that Ofsted's verdict could be unforgiving if any lessons were found to be less than satisfactory.

The team was in and out in a matter of three days and the eventual report was an endorsement of the school's progress in raising standards. The most positive point was that 36% of pupils were getting five GCSE grades A-C and 80% were getting grades A-G - almost double the figure of five years ago. McGregor says: "The only way to improve standards is through teaching, and the only way to improve teaching is through the quality of management and leadership."

As Ofsted takes the wraps off its new framework for all inspections, schools that have been identified as improving will be offered short inspections, while those where the progress is not so clear cut - even though they might have high standards - will get a full inspection. The two-tier system promises greater consistency and a better use of valuable resources.

What can schools expect?

Where a team of a dozen inspectors would have taken a week to cover a large secondary school on a full inspection, a short one can be carried out by a team of four individuals in two to three days. As these inspections are much more focused, so the inspectors' judgments have to be precise. The new system reflects Ofsted's confidence in the performance data it has built up since it started inspecting schools in 1996 and reflects a robust quality assurance regime: short inspections are carried out by Ofsted's most experienced and senior inspectors.

A short inspection is supposed to take the pressure off staff. Many teachers at Dunraven never saw an inspector and those that did were given a verbal feedback after the lesson. But Ofsted insists short does not mean superficial. Ofsted team member Denise Lynn of Capital Inspections can spot the essentials of good teaching. "We looked at the pace of a lesson, how it was managed, and the planning that had gone into it. It's fairly obvious when children are involved in the work they are doing."

On a short inspection, first impressions are important. McGregor says: "When we were walking down the corridors, if we passed any children the head would introduce us - he knew all their names. During lunch break, pupils would come up to us and ask politely 'What do you think of our school, then?' That says a lot about the headteacher. He's not someone who stays out of sight in his office."

The head reflects. "The parents are behind us and the pupils think it's cool to learn. The boys are performing as well as the girls and everyone's aspirations are high."

What is the reason for Dunraven's rising standards?

Townsend says: "I have gone for a balanced intake, taking equal proportions of pupils from all ability bands. By keeping the school truly comprehensive, all pupils have a chance to perform to the best of their ability and everyone has a stake in the school's success."

As ever, no system will ever be perfect. The pilot inspections drew negative comments as well as praise. Gillian James, head of Archbishop Temple Church of England school in Preston, missed the detailed feedback on teacher performance. "It doesn't give you a very searching look at your departments and we got no teaching profiles. For some of our newer department heads this would have been helpful." On the positive side, James welcomed the endorsement. "A short inspection is quite a pat on the back. It's a health check."

Barbara Hilton, the registered inspector from CEA, the contractor that carried out the Archbishop Temple inspection, believes the short inspections put more emphasis on the role of the lead inspector. "It's very positive to set the agenda for the inspection within a consultation framework. The focus is 'what can be improved and why? What is positive and why?' But you've got to be flexible; we adjusted our plans to take account of what we saw."

But equally the announcement of a full inspection will set alarm bells ringing. McGregor says: "I can see a stigma being attached to a full inspection. It makes parents believe a school is not first rank. It's a clearer message than the league tables. It's the difference between premier league and first division."

Ofsted's criteria for a short inspection are clear; schools have to be maintaining a high standard or have a trend in attainment which is above the national average. Says McGregor, "you've got to be improving rapidly."

Ofsted's criteria for a short inspection are clear; schools have to be maintaining a high standard or have a trend in attainment which is above the national average. Says McGregor, "you've got to be improving rapidly."

fields.headline: Young blood
fields.standfirst: College students have finally made it onto their boards of governors
fields.trailText: College students have finally made it onto their boards of governors
fields.body:
David Croll, the man brought in to clear up the mess at Derby Wilmorton College, sees student governors as a key part of the new openness.

"They have a steep learning curve though" he says. "A lot of jargon and initials are used to keep them out." But "they can use their inexperience as a tool to open up the process."

The infrastructure for effective student governors at Derby is a well-organised student union, and one of the governors is the union president.

New College, Nottingham, is the result of a merger of four colleges, making it the biggest in Britain, with 60,000 students. Chief executive Dame Pat Morgan-Webb is not enthusiastic about the prospect of student governors "It's difficult with further education because the population in a college is more transient. And it's a bit demanding for an 18-year-old to sit on a board with business people."

Eighteen-year-old BTEC Performing Arts student Layla Brown is on the governing body of Carmarthanshire College of Technology. None of the 6,000 students voted when they put out the ballot boxes, so the college's student liaison officer chose Layla, both as student union women's officer and one of the two student governors. Next year she'll run for president, and do something about the apathy.

"The problem with student governors is one of continuity" says college principal Brian Robinson. "But at their best they bring a very valuable dimension to the board."

The other side of the Bristol Channel, in the west country, it's a very different story. Out of 1,000 students at South East Devon College 300 voted in the student union elections, and they chose 18-year-old A-level student Zoe Parnell as student governor.

A new force is emerging in further education: the students. University students have always been allowed to have opinions, but the 17- and 18-year-olds in further education were expected to go to their lectures, know their place, and stay well out of the corridors of power. After colleges were incorporated in 1993, students found an even more ignominious role. They became mere units of resource in cash-strapped colleges.

This is the year all that changes. Further education students are flexing their political muscles. They are demanding, and getting, a real say in the way their colleges are run. They are getting onto the governing body, and the handful of sabbatical student union officials is increasing fast. Further education student politics is becoming the sort of force for change that universities have long since learned to live with.

Paradoxically, what finally enabled students to kick down the boardroom door was exactly the sort of principal most anxious to keep them out. Principals who liked to gather round them like-minded businessmen, and keep their staff, as well as their students, well away from decision-making, caused serious scandals at colleges like Halton, Stoke on Trent, and Derby Wilmorton colleges, and eventually brought about the government's insistence on tighter governance.

One of the new provisions was that all colleges must have at least one student governor elected by the students. Some principals welcome them. Others complain crustily.

"Some colleges have been led to the water, but are determined that they are not going to drink," says the National Union of Students vice-president for further education, Mark Atkinson. He has heard all the usual excuses. " We've got a place for a student governor, but no one is interested." "We had one once, but they never turned up." "There's a lot of apathy, you know.'"

But he's got no time for any of them. NUS has been waiting for this moment ever since, in the mid 1970s, it appointed its first regional officials specifically to develop student unions in further education and is determined to make the rule stick.

Are your students too apathetic to vote in a ballot? Worry not, says Mr Atkinson reassuringly: "NUS has been helping students unions organise elections for years, and I'm quite prepared to share that expertise with any college which is struggling to generate interest in their student governors' position."

Mr Atkinson has made a crucial ally in this campaign: David Melville, chief executive of the Further Education Funding Council. The funding council distributes public funds to colleges, and intervenes if things go wrong, so Professor Melville is a man to whom college principals must listen.

He goes out of his way to tell anyone who will listen how much he values his alliance with Mr Atkinson, whom he meets regularly, and he recently sat down for a working lunch with the union's eight regional officers in England to help and advise on the problems they had with college managements.

The funding council will train student governors, and Professor Melville wants them to be effective: to make sure their voice is heard, to give their principals a hard time when necessary. He sees them as an important check to ensure that college principals are properly supervised, and cannot run amok with public money, or bully staff and students, in the way that some have done in recent years. He's clearly relying on their sharp eyes and ears, and lack of cynicism, to help keep the sector clean.

"There is a difference" he tells them "between public and private money and how it can be spent." There are very few things that should be kept secret from them, he says, and they should question any secrecy closely. He promises to investigate all whistleblowing, and says he has 20-30 investigations going on now. And "if you are in doubt, think how governing body actions would look as headlines in Private Eye or the Guardian."

fields.headline: Three's company
fields.standfirst: Though born with severe disabilities,  Andy Stevenson is now happily studying English - thanks to a dream team of two energetic helpmates
fields.trailText: Though born with severe disabilities, Andy Stevenson is now happily studying English - thanks to a dream team of two energetic helpmates
fields.body:
Whoever you are, the start of your first term can be traumatic: getting used to choosing between the ready-meal lasagne or the boil-in-the-bag chicken, for example, while being expected to work and party hard in equal measure. In my case, at Warwick, aside from the demands of my English literature course and bars that stay open until 2am, I have discovered something called a "washing machine", but sadly not how to use it properly.

So far, this is all pretty well-known "student speak", so at this point I should explain why I've been asked to write this piece. For some unknown reason, I was born with no arms and only one fully formed leg. This has not stopped me in the past, so why should university be any different?

I've always been pretty independent (or stubborn!) and have never been one for mollycoddling or interference from outside sources. Even so, going to university and leaving home has been the biggest change I will ever face in my life. Although I can do a lot for myself, for the first time I was going to have to be relatively dependent on people I had never met before.

This is where Community Service Volunteers stepped in. In dating-agency style, a profile of my needs was sent out nationwide, and eventually, two suitable lads responded to my "Teenage males wanted, GSOH necessary" appeal.

Three months on, Mark and Ed are good friends of mine. Friends who also put my artificial leg on, do my shopping and cooking as well as a whole host of other stuff - not a bad arrangement, eh? Given that on October 1 I'd never met them, and on October 2 they were doing all that for me, things have turned out very well. They work on a "two days on, two days off" rota, and although they are by no means on duty 24 hours a day, what they do for me is vital. Without such suport I couldn't have studied at university.

Most importantly, thanks to their age (18 and 20 respectively) and their drinking capacity, they fit in perfectly with me and my other university mates and don't stick out like sore thumbs. Ed's knowledge of university life (he will continue his English degree at Aberystwyth next year) and Mark's TV and Playstation made both instantly popular with my corridor-mates - they are certainly not seen as "Andy's Little Helpers".

Their weekly allowance, their six days off per fortnight and their complete lack of academic work to do mean they are both apparently content. Ed has immersed himself (literally) in the Warwick Surf Club and is sharpening up his German skills, while Mark had a brief flirtation with the Warwick Wind Band and is preparing for university in September at Royal Holloway, London. (On a bitter note, their activity still doesn't compensate for the fact that I have essays to do and they don't.)

Mark is also the producer of, and half of the comedy double act, that makes up The Andy Stevenson Show on the university's radio station. Chris Moyles and Comedy Dave watch out!

It's not all been plain sailing. In fact, over the first weekend, I began to wonder if I was pushing myself too far. But I've really enjoyed my first term, and those cynical doubts have been solidly quashed. Before I began looking for two helpers, I feared I could become a Community Service Victim. But it has been a Community Service Victory.

 Andy Stevenson studies English at Warwick University. For more information on CSV call freephone 0800 374991.

fields.headline: Sizing up the system
fields.standfirst: With the government offering subsidies to teachers buying new home computers, it's important to make the right choice
fields.trailText: With the government offering subsidies to teachers buying new home computers, it's important to make the right choice
fields.body:
Like every other teacher, I too, picked my jaw up off the floor on reading the news this month that I was to get a 50% government subsidy on a brand new computer system. My first thought was to grab an application form and order a machine within the week, in case (like the Blunkett laptops-for-teachers scheme) the benefactors removed this golden carrot. However, it pays to heed advice before entering a crowded marketplace.

If you haven't considered buying a PC or laptop for home use before, perhaps now is the time. You may never get an "offer you can't refuse" like this again. As an information communication and technology coordinator (ICT), I have been inundated with requests for advice and help by fellow teachers in choosing the "right" machine from the list of 19 accredited suppliers. So first ask your ICT coordinator or computing inspector. Ask a friend in industry who may be using the systems from one of the accredited suppliers.

After short-listing companies with a good track record for quality products, contact each one for literature on their particular deal. You will be surprised how much they differ, even though all comply with the specifications laid down in the application booklet.

So what will you need?

 Try to get the fastest processor you can, 500mhz if possible.

 128Mb of RAM (memory) will provide you with plenty of room as your needs grow. But if this pushes the price up too much, ensure that your chosen machine can be upgraded from 64Mb later.

 A large hard disc drive is also essential. Treat the specified 6 Gb as a minimum. The bigger the better.

 Monitors deteriorate from the time you first switch them on. A flat screen monitor does not and is better all round (no radiation, low power, clear and bright). If you can negotiate one of these in the deal, all well and good. Remember, too, that a 15-inch flat screen is equal in viewing area to a 17-inch CRT (standard) monitor. If the flat screen has a video input as well - you will have a stunning video display.

 Don't buy a computer with on-board video memory or on-board sound or a so-called "soft" modem. A 4mb graphics card with 3D capability, a high specification sound card (like a SoundBlaster) and a 56K integral modem are all desirable.

 A DVD drive may be a better bet in the long term than a fast CD-Rom. But do ensure the DVD (6-speed or greater) will play all the latest CD-Roms without hiccupping. Similarly, if it has MPEG capabilities you will be able to use and store digital video for multimedia presentations. Software MPEG is not good enough.

 The keyboard and mouse are personal preferences. If possible, check the keyboard - some are very "spongy" while others are overly "clacky"! A mouse with a central roller is helpful when scrolling in windows and web pages.

 External speakers can be placed in strategic positions to improve sound reproduction if you have the room. Mains-powered speakers are a must.

If you have a good idea about the specification of system you need, don't be limited by the specification laid down in the booklet. Thanks to the generosity of the scheme, I can specify a very capable machine with a lot more beef than I could afford previously. Negotiate with the suppliers to get the system you want. Many are adding all sorts of software and peripherals that are not part of the government's scheme.

Similarly, as bundled software and hardware can represent a compromise in quality and robustness, you may prefer to negotiate a price excluding these items should they be offered. This will free you to buy your chosen items separately.

 For scheme details plus application form: DfEE on 020 7273 5907, email eve.trueman@dfee.gov.uk, British Educational Commmunications and Technology Agency (for suppliers): 024 7641 6994, email andre_wagstaff@becta.org.uk

Do:

 Seek advice from colleagues

 Get offers from more than two companies

 Take your time to make a well-judged decision

 Decide on a spec to allow the system to "grow" as your needs grow.

 Read the conditions in the back of the application booklet carefully as you are unable to apply until your school signs on to an NOF training provider.

Don't:

 Rush into making decisions

 Buy cheaply unless you have a very tight budget. Cheap computer systems always equate to cheap components inside - they will prove unreliable long term - usually just after the guarantee runs out!

 Sign up for any training provider just so staff can get computers ordered early. You have to research carefully to get the best machine.

fields.headline: Questions of survival
fields.standfirst: Many children suffer from cancer. And even more have parents who do. How do you explain to them what cancer is, and what to expect? Since teachers often have to deal with this, Macmillan Cancer Relief has produced educational resources for primary and secondary schools
fields.trailText: Many children suffer from cancer. And even more have parents who do. How do you explain to them what cancer is, and what to expect? Since teachers often have to deal with this, Macmillan Cancer Relief has produced educational resources for primary and secondary schools
fields.body:
Things we know. The sun rises in the east and sets in the west. We're born, we grow up, we grow old, we die. Now try telling this to one of the 1,000 children under 15 diagnosed with cancer each year in the UK.

Few of us cope well with death. We see young people starving in Africa, we see children dying in war zones and we feel gutted. But we also feel distanced. We mediate our feelings through television and we rationalise how it couldn't happen here, especially not to those we love.

Yet bad things do happen here. Children do get life-threatening illnesses and so, more frequently, do their parents. Much as we may want to preserve an idealised version of a natural order, we can't. There is no guaranteed immunity on offer. So, many children have to face the big questions of mortality much sooner than anyone would want. Which leaves parents and teachers to work out how best to handle them.

Jennie Fishwick, 13, lives in Whickham, Newcastle-upon-Tyne. Just over two years ago she was diagnosed with a tumour in her shoulder blade. This was her second experience of cancer. When she was three, she had a tumour on her kidney, but doctors are still not sure whether the second tumour is linked to the first. She had an operation to remove her shoulder blade, followed by six months of chemotherapy. Her treatment ended in July 1998, and she has been free of cancer since.

"Many of my friends cried when I told them I had cancer again," says Jennie. "They were all very supportive and treated me as if I was normal. But I didn't feel normal. I still feel different today. I get out of breath easily, my stamina's not back, I pick up infections easily and I don't have full use of my arm. My friends think it's great I can't do PE, but I miss it and there are some clothes I can't wear any more. Sometimes I get so frustrated when I see nasty people on the TV that I shout, 'It should have been you, not me'."

Midway through her treatment, Jennie moved from her primary school in Whickham to a secondary school in Blaydon. The teachers maintained consistent levels of support, giving her extra help and attention when needed, but some of her new school mates teased and bullied her. "I used to wear a hat to hide the fact that my hair was growing back after chemo," she continues. "One of the boys pulled it off and several others started saying I was a boy, not a girl."

Jennie's illness has had a knock-on effect throughout the family. Her parents say their lives have been shattered and her 11-year-old sister, Nicola, has had to grow up fast. "I was devastated," she says. "I didn't know she wouldn't die, I just hoped she wouldn't. I spent some nights in the hospital but I often felt happiest at school. I knew my parents didn't have as much time for me, but I knew Jennie needed the attention."

Sarah Hoburn, 15, has found things a little easier. A year ago she was diagnosed with colon cancer. She has since had an operation and chemotherapy and is now back at school. "My hair didn't even fall out during chemo and my energy levels are now back to normal," she says breezily. "Even when I was told I had cancer, my first thought was I was going to get better."

Such positivity is by no means the norm. Many children have no real concept of what cancer is. If they've heard of it at all, they generally assume it's fatal but have no idea of how it develops and whether it's contagious. Typically, it also inspires fear and uncertainty, both in the patient and in friends and family, and the combination can cause havoc in the classroom.

It is with this in mind that Macmillan Cancer Relief has produced new educational teaching resources to be used in primary and secondary schools. Macmillan is ideally placed to do this, as it is often the Macmillan counsellor who liaises with children, parents and teachers on the best way of breaking the news to classmates.

"I try to keep things as normal as possible," says Patricia Williams, a Macmillan counsellor. "Children facing survival issues - either their own, a parent's or a friend's - often feel anxious, clingy or depressed. In some cases their behaviour may also be affected. However, there is no point in overloading children with information as that can make them feel worse. It is often best to start by finding out what they know and what they don't and what they are curious to know. This allows you to work at their pace. If children can't articulate their feelings in words, they can often do so through drawing. However, you can't generalise as each situation is different."

Macmillan's watchword is inclusion, and a measure of the impact they have made can be judged by the experience of Miles Meacock, who was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's disease while at Seaford College 10 years ago. "I only discovered I had cancer while I was on my third session of chemo," he says. "I was probably rather naive, but neither the doctor, the surgeon nor my parents told me and I didn't have a clue. I just thought I had some kind of nasty bump. I was terribly angry when I discovered, as I felt I had been lied to. When I eventually got back to school, everyone was kind, but they made it clear that they didn't want to talk about it, either. It made me feel I had a disease to be ashamed of, and it was years before I could talk about it properly."

Becky Mepsted, a primary teacher at Honeywell School in south-west London, who has a boy in her year 3 class away from school with leukaemia, tries to pre-empt such problems wherever possible. "It is the child's illness, so you have to work with the child and the parents," she says, "but I always try to build on what they know and prepare them for the future. Sometimes we can do this better than parents, especially those who are not confident. Above all, I believe in honesty. When children ask me about the scar on my neck, I tell them I had an operation for a tumour. I say, 'I'm a 28-year-old healthy woman who has had cancer and you don't always die'."
fields.bodyText: Things we know. The sun rises in the east and sets in the west. We're born, we grow up, we grow old, we die. Now try telling this to one of the 1,000 children under 15 diagnosed with cancer each year in the UK. Few of us cope well with death. We see young people starving in Africa, we see children dying in war zones and we feel gutted. But we also feel distanced. We mediate our feelings through television and we rationalise how it couldn't happen here, especially not to those we love. Yet bad things do happen here. Children do get life-threatening illnesses and so, more frequently, do their parents. Much as we may want to preserve an idealised version of a natural order, we can't. There is no guaranteed immunity on offer. So, many children have to face the big questions of mortality much sooner than anyone would want. Which leaves parents and teachers to work out how best to handle them. Jennie Fishwick, 13, lives in Whickham, Newcastle-upon-Tyne. Just over two years ago she was diagnosed with a tumour in her shoulder blade. This was her second experience of cancer. When she was three, she had a tumour on her kidney, but doctors are still not sure whether the second tumour is linked to the first. She had an operation to remove her shoulder blade, followed by six months of chemotherapy. Her treatment ended in July 1998, and she has been free of cancer since. "Many of my friends cried when I told them I had cancer again," says Jennie. "They were all very supportive and treated me as if I was normal. But I didn't feel normal. I still feel different today. I get out of breath easily, my stamina's not back, I pick up infections easily and I don't have full use of my arm. My friends think it's great I can't do PE, but I miss it and there are some clothes I can't wear any more. Sometimes I get so frustrated when I see nasty people on the TV that I shout, 'It should have been you, not me'." Midway through her treatment, Jennie moved from her primary school in Whickham to a secondary school in Blaydon. The teachers maintained consistent levels of support, giving her extra help and attention when needed, but some of her new school mates teased and bullied her. "I used to wear a hat to hide the fact that my hair was growing back after chemo," she continues. "One of the boys pulled it off and several others started saying I was a boy, not a girl." Jennie's illness has had a knock-on effect throughout the family. Her parents say their lives have been shattered and her 11-year-old sister, Nicola, has had to grow up fast. "I was devastated," she says. "I didn't know she wouldn't die, I just hoped she wouldn't. I spent some nights in the hospital but I often felt happiest at school. I knew my parents didn't have as much time for me, but I knew Jennie needed the attention." Sarah Hoburn, 15, has found things a little easier. A year ago she was diagnosed with colon cancer. She has since had an operation and chemotherapy and is now back at school. "My hair didn't even fall out during chemo and my energy levels are now back to normal," she says breezily. "Even when I was told I had cancer, my first thought was I was going to get better." Such positivity is by no means the norm. Many children have no real concept of what cancer is. If they've heard of it at all, they generally assume it's fatal but have no idea of how it develops and whether it's contagious. Typically, it also inspires fear and uncertainty, both in the patient and in friends and family, and the combination can cause havoc in the classroom. It is with this in mind that Macmillan Cancer Relief has produced new educational teaching resources to be used in primary and secondary schools. Macmillan is ideally placed to do this, as it is often the Macmillan counsellor who liaises with children, parents and teachers on the best way of breaking the news to classmates. "I try to keep things as normal as possible," says Patricia Williams, a Macmillan counsellor. "Children facing survival issues - either their own, a parent's or a friend's - often feel anxious, clingy or depressed. In some cases their behaviour may also be affected. However, there is no point in overloading children with information as that can make them feel worse. It is often best to start by finding out what they know and what they don't and what they are curious to know. This allows you to work at their pace. If children can't articulate their feelings in words, they can often do so through drawing. However, you can't generalise as each situation is different." Macmillan's watchword is inclusion, and a measure of the impact they have made can be judged by the experience of Miles Meacock, who was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's disease while at Seaford College 10 years ago. "I only discovered I had cancer while I was on my third session of chemo," he says. "I was probably rather naive, but neither the doctor, the surgeon nor my parents told me and I didn't have a clue. I just thought I had some kind of nasty bump. I was terribly angry when I discovered, as I felt I had been lied to. When I eventually got back to school, everyone was kind, but they made it clear that they didn't want to talk about it, either. It made me feel I had a disease to be ashamed of, and it was years before I could talk about it properly." Becky Mepsted, a primary teacher at Honeywell School in south-west London, who has a boy in her year 3 class away from school with leukaemia, tries to pre-empt such problems wherever possible. "It is the child's illness, so you have to work with the child and the parents," she says, "but I always try to build on what they know and prepare them for the future. Sometimes we can do this better than parents, especially those who are not confident. Above all, I believe in honesty. When children ask me about the scar on my neck, I tell them I had an operation for a tumour. I say, 'I'm a 28-year-old healthy woman who has had cancer and you don't always die'."

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.trailText: Broadcasting
fields.body:
Faith Stories (BBC2, Tues 25 and Thurs 27, 09.45-10.00am, except Scotland) takes a look at Islam and Prayer through real-life examples. Today's storyteller introduces Muslim beliefs and retells the story of Bilal and the First Call of Prayer on location in North Africa. It develops understanding of the beliefs, values and practices of Islam. For 5- to 7-year-olds.

Look at Africa through children's eyes with Eureka! Africa's Child (C4, Wed, Jan 26, 11.30-11.45am, repeated Fri Jan 28, 10.35-10.50am). This week we meet Nkoidila, a 13-year-old Kenyan boy who walks an hour to school every day, being careful to avoid the elephants. He has learnt a lot about animals from his elders, and at school he likes to write articles for the Friends of Conservation magazine. This series for 9- to 13-year-olds introduces children in the UK to a positive view of life in Africa.

Discover how French families live and work in Zig Zag - France (BBC2, Wed 26, 11.10-11.30am, age 7-9). This week we continue Zig Zag's tour of France for 7- to 9-year-olds in the region of Brittany. Presenter Josette Aitman teams up with some young Bretons, who show her the city sights of Quimper and life and culture in the rural idyll of inland Brittany. But our geography tour of the region wouldn't be complete without a visit to the rugged Atlantic coast where Josette goes sea fishing and visits a famous fish auction.

Liverpool's top screenwriter Jimmy McGovern turns his hand to writing a script about the Liverpool docker's two-year fight to win back their jobs. McGovern joined forces with 12 of the 500 sacked dockers to write a drama of their struggle in a series of weekly writing workshops. This week's English Programme: Dockers (C4, Thurs, Jan 27, 11.00-11.30am) looks at the creation of the script. The drama will be shown in three parts in this slot from next week. For 14-16-year-olds.

Despite what many people may think, the internet and the world wide web aren't the same - for one thing, the Internet is some 20 years older. The Open University tells us all in TheWebStory.com/Yesterday (BBC2, Fri, Jan 28, 1.00am). The story of British and American pioneers who changed our world explains how these technologies work, and why they are hard to censor and control.

What's on the web?

 BBC listings tailored by category (across TV and radio)

 BBC's Learning Zone - record the programmes you are interested in during the night and play them back at your leisure.

 Complete Channel 4 Schools TV listings

 Open University

www.discovery.com (an American site but with European TV highlights)

fields.headline: Sad tails
fields.standfirst: The graceful giants of Africa and India are once again under threat from ivory poachers
fields.trailText: Elephants
fields.body:
Last week was the tenth anniversary of the ban on international trade in elephant ivory. The ban was one of the biggest conservation successes of the 1990s. But now the Environmental Investigation Agency say elephants in Africa and Asia are under threat again.

Why are elephants in danger?

The Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA) say poaching (the illegal killing of elephants, mainly for their tusks) is on the increase, after being at a low in the early 1990s when the international trade in ivory was first banned. There aren't many facts and figures available because there is not a proper system in place to monitor elephants and the numbers poached.

However, in Kenya's Tsavo National Park 29 elephants were illegally killed for their ivory in 1999 - five times more than the average annual total poached in the six years before. The EIA have also spoken to many park rangers in Africa, who report that the illegal killing of elephants for ivory has increased.

Is international ivory trading still banned?

In general, yes. In 1990, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (or CITES - this is a group of 147 countries who have joined to control international trade in a list of endangered species) put elephants on their most endangered list - called Appendix 1.

This meant that all international trade in ivory and other elephant products such as hide was banned. Since then, some countries in Africa have tried to get the ban lifted, and in 1997 CITES agreed on one special case. Zimbabwe, Namibia and Botswana could put their elephants on a less-endangered list called Appendix 2, and make a one-off sale of ivory to Japan.

They were only allowed to sell their stockpiles of legal ivory. This meant that ivory from elephants that had died naturally or been killed for conservation - for example if there were too many elephants in one area.

It was also agreed that the sale could only take place if a proper system was set up to monitor poaching and to look at elephant populations in general. The actual sale went ahead in April 1999, when Japanese ivory traders bought nearly 50 tonnes of ivory - representing 5,446 tusks and costing around $5m.

Why should selling off old ivory stocks be a problem and lead to poaching?

The EIA say a legal ivory trade sends out the wrong message to poachers, and encourages the sale of illegal ivory (known as the black market). In the 1970s there were 1.3m elephants in Africa; by 1989 poaching had reduced them to around 600,000.

Before the ivory trade ban, more than 2,000 Africa elephants were slaughtered each week and there are worries that allowing even limited ivory trading badly affects elephants. Although the April 1999 sale of ivory to Japan was a special case, Julian Newman from the EIA says, "this information does not filter down to ground level. Ordinary people just hear the ban is lifted and so poaching increases."

Since that legal sale of ivory, seven of the largest ivory seizures since the ban in 1990 have taken place. For example in October 1999, 1.8 tonnes of African ivory were seized at Dubai airport.

Another problem is that CITES agreed that the ivory could only be sold to Japan on the condition that a proper elephant monitoring system was set up, to keep a close watch on elephant populations and elephants illegally killed. This system has not been set up yet. A temporary system where countries must send in reports about illegal killings is not working because few countries are providing the reports.

Why do some countries want to sell their ivory?

Because ivory is worth a lot of money, and the countries which have elephants are some of the poorest in the world. Countries such as Zimbabwe and South Africa say the money raised from selling their stores of legal ivory would be spent on conservation projects. The main market for ivory is the Middle East and Asia, particularly Japan.

Does everyone agree that the illegal trading of ivory is on the increase?

No. Illegal trading has always gone on and Traffic, the scheme for monitoring wildlife trade, say there is no evidence of illegal trade increasing. They say one reason for increased ivory seizures is better training of customs officials in airports. It is difficult to get a true picture until an effective elephant monitoring system is put in place.

Will more legal sales of ivory be allowed?

Maybe. The next CITES meeting will in Kenya in April this year, and ivory trading will be discussed. Now South Africa as well as Zimbabwe, Namibia and Botswana want to sell their ivory. Kenya and India are calling for all international trade in ivory to be fully banned again - both report an increase in elephant poaching in the past two years and rely heavily on living elephants in the tourist industry.

More information can be obtained from the EIA.

fields.headline: Part-time punch up
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston wishes he could be a fly on the wall at tomorrow's all-party ding-dong
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston wishes he could be a fly on the wall at tomorrow's all-party ding-dong
fields.body:
It promises to be lively. But drama lovers will have to miss tomorrow night's behind-closed-doors confrontation at the Palace of Westminster between Paul Mackney, Natfhe general secretary, and Richard Eve, boss of Education Lecturing Services (ELS), the largest agency for lecturers. Only MPs on the all-party further education committee will be able to enjoy the bout.

If the atmosphere is charged, it will not just be down to the central dispute between the two men's organisations: whether part-time workers, and ELS lecturers specifically, should enjoy the same conditions and benefits as their full-time colleagues. Natfhe accuses ELS of limiting lecturers' contracts to 12 weeks or less - firing and rehiring them if necessary - in order to avoid having to cough up holiday pay. Eve says that if colleges book assignments requiring more than 12 weeks' continuous teaching without a break, the lecturers get their holiday pay entitlements.

And tomorrow's atmosphere won't be entirely due to the long-running and as yet unresolved tribunal case by a lecturer, Debra Allonby, with the union's backing, against Accrington and Rossendale College and ELS. This stemmed from the college's decision in 1996 to sack its part-time staff, including her, and re-employ them through ELS.

Extra piquancy will lace tomorrow's encounter because of the grudge Natfhe has borne Eve since what Mackney describes as "probably one of the most disgraceful defections in the history of trade unions" in the spring of 1995.

Eve was then a senior Natfhe official. As assistant secretary (industrial relations) he was playing a crucial role in the union's bitter negotiations to thrash out a national agreement with Roger Ward, chief executive of the now defunct Colleges Employers Forum.

His sudden career switch - joining ELS - came as a stunning blow to his colleagues.

Mackney says: "There are lots of people who see industrial relations as a technical matter, and transfer sides. But there are very few people who transfer sides in order to deny the legal entitlement of people who were formerly their members and whom they were serving."

Eve remains unabashed. "I chose a career move in 1995 for personal reasons. That was my decision.

"It might upset some people in Natfhe. If they have a difficulty with it, that's their problem."

Natfhe believes that the lecturers ELS supplies to colleges are part-time employees and, as such, should get the same benefits, including equal pay, as comparable full-time lecturers. These benefits include sick and maternity pay, equal access to pension schemes and training, paternity leave and time off for dependants.

This, says Natfhe, is the intention of the European part-time workers directive from which the Department of Trade and Industry has just issued draft regulations to come into force in April.

Eve insists that ELS is a "service provider", not an employment agency. Its lecturers are hired on contracts for services, not employment, a critical distinction, he says. The 65,000 people on its books are engaged as self-employed teachers to deliver lectures on ELS's behalf in 160 colleges around the country. Last year they provided 3.25 million hours of teaching.

"The directive applies to part-time employees," says Eve. "There are those who say it will apply to all workers. But our lawyers' advice is that we won't need to change the way we operate."

Eve cites research on part-time lecturers by the Further Education Development Agency (FEDA), reported by Guardian Further last week, to back up his contention that many teaching staff prefer this mode of work.

He refutes the accusation that his operation tends to depress salary levels in the sector. ELS pays an average of £17 an hour. The rate is higher in London - £22-23 an hour - and lower in some rural areas - £14.50-15, he says.

fields.headline: Pay as you learn
fields.standfirst: How is Britain to tackle its dismal record on basic skills?  Alan Wells proposes a radical, yet potentially economic solution
fields.trailText: How is Britain to tackle its dismal record on basic skills? Alan Wells proposes a radical, yet potentially economic solution
fields.body:
Almost everyone knows that we have a serious problem with basic skills in the UK. And not just among children at school. The most recent international survey suggests that at least 22% of adults - seven million or so people - have difficulties with reading, writing and using numbers. In the international league table, we came above only the Republic of Ireland and Poland. Whichever way you look at it, we have a much more serious problem than countries such as Sweden, Germany or Canada.

The government-initiated Moser Report, A Fresh Start, advocated a national strategy to remedy our situation: new learning opportunities, better use of computers and new technology, a core curriculum, new national tests and a host of other measures. The case for this strategy was argued well. Poor basic skills cost the individual in lost opportunities and cost the economy in dependence on benefits, higher unemployment and skills gaps. We need citizens with good basic skills and workers who are able to cope with changing jobs.

One of the major proposals of the Moser Report was for a concerted campaign to get adults to want to get better at the basics. This is a tall order. At present of the seven million in need only 250,000 are actually on basic skills courses. And many of the rest show little inclination to join them.

Last year the Basic Skills Agency ran a major TV and radio campaign in London to get more adults onto basic skills courses. We spent almost £1 million over 5-6 weeks and the results were positive. More than 25,000 adults telephoned the freephone number and many ended up on courses. However, 25,000 is a long way short of seven million - or even one million.

We don't know why adults don't want to do anything about their literacy and numeracy skills. Some face barriers like childcare or distance to get to a course, or find the time of day that courses are held difficult. But even removing all of these barriers will only motivate relatively few. So what can we do to get to the many?

Pay them to go.

This may seem a weird suggestion, but, if adults with poor basic skills cost us so much, shouldn't we consider whether paying people to go to courses - or to improve in some other way - might be cheaper than living with the status quo?

Of course, we'd have to have a system which rewarded genuine effort and which couldn't be abused. But giving adults an incentive to join a course - and a further incentive when they've stayed on it for a given period - might encourage rather more of them than just removing barriers. Paying adults to get themselves out of the seven million might be the cheap option.

 Alan Wells is Director of the Basic Skills Agency.

Yellow Yale

Shame on Yale College, Wrexham for caving in to those big bullies at Bill Clinton's alma mater. The contention by Yale, the American Ivy League university, that the Welsh college could be passing itself off as a satellite outstation is complete horsey do-dos. To quote a judge's ruling in a famous passing off case, "a blind moron in a hurry" wouldn't mistake this fine Welsh institution for that Mickey Mouse outfit over the pond.

Chairwoman

Congrats to Ethel Truin, 82, who has notched up 40 years as a keep-fit lecturer at West Suffolk College. These days her Increase Your Mobility class for the 80- and 90-plus is mostly done from a chair.

Piping hot

Welcome, first Scottish School of Asian Cuisine, which was launched yesterday amid massive splendour in Edinburgh. Growing skill shortages in Asian catering, the fastest growing food sector north of the Tweed, prompted Fife College, Kirkcaldy and the Scottish Asian Restaurants Association to set up this venture. And yes, there was a piper, and a haggis pakora, to mark the eve of Burn's night.
