fields.headline: Parents into the fray
fields.standfirst: In the final part of our series on parental involvement in schools,  Karen Gold meets some of those who have taken on the demanding role of being a governor
fields.trailText: In the final part of our series on parental involvement in schools, Karen Gold meets some of those who have taken on the demanding role of being a governor
fields.body:
A few months after moving to the Cambridgeshire village of Histon, accountant Ian Strachan went to a meeting at his children's junior school. He arrived as one of a handful of parents who wanted to find out more about being a governor. By the time he left that evening, he was chair of the finance committee.

In the 20 years since parents officially gained the right to sit on school governing bodies, they have become indispensable to schools. As the paperwork and responsibilities have increased, many of the retired aldermen and political young bloods have dropped out. Their replacements, not only as elected parent governors but also as co-opted experts or nominated by local authorities and churches, are more and more likely to be parents. They, after all, have a vested interest in getting the work done.

So why do parents become school governors? What do they expect to achieve over one or two four-year terms of office? Do their expectations stay the same? Is it ever possible to fulfil them? Many parents become governors because, like Ian Strachan, they get asked to take on the job. They say yes partly because they feel unable to say no, and partly because they want to help.

Few parent governors stand for election on a manifesto of radical change, according to consultant and writer Joan Sallis, who trains governors all over the country. "They want to play a part in their own school, and they feel they have something to offer," she says.

They also want to get to know the school from the inside - an opportunity that appeals particularly to parents of older children, according to Margaret Charlesworth, a social survey interviewer now in her eighth year as parent governor at Thurston Community College, a 14-18 upper school in Suffolk: "You see what's going on and you meet the staff. You do have to restrain yourself in meetings from saying 'Ah, but my daughter's teacher does so and so'. But you don't get an insight into an upper school otherwise, because your children don't want you around".

The self-restraint habit is one that many parent governors feel obliged to adopt. Gordon Gillespie, a college lecturer and new governor at Thurston, stood for election because he wanted to be a voice for low achievers in a highly successful academic school. The amount of work needed to make his voice heard came as a shock, he says:

"They have these enormous agendas to get through, with perhaps 17 items, and the governors' meeting will last for two or three hours. The presentations from the school are very professional, but it tends to be more telling us what they intend to do than a decision-making process. I expect it to take a year before I have any effect, and I am a fairly outspoken person."

In fact, the bulk of governors' work does not take place in the once or twice-termly governing body meetings anyway, but in sub-committees. Most schools now have these at least for finance, curriculum, personnel and premises. Then there will be ad hoc committees for recruiting staff or hearing disciplinary appeals or appeals from families refused entry to the school. Most schools also organise regular governors' visits to classrooms, usually focusing on a particular subject or aspect of work, for governors now have a formal responsibility to monitor standards. During an Ofsted visit, the inspectors will grill them as well.

Exercising that responsibility can be difficult, says Lisa Challens, who recently finished her four-year term as a governor at Rushmore Junior School in Hackney. The then-chair of governors asked her if she would be co-opted onto Rushmore governors, at a time when the school was struggling - the government has since recognised it as one of the fastest-improving schools in the country - because she is a qualified accountant, but also because she has a disabled son.

"It was wanting to help parents with children with special needs that persuaded me to do it," she says. "I felt that people complain all the time about schools, so why not get in there and do something?" As part of the job, she went into school twice a week to talk to the bursar and the special needs co-ordinator. She also observed teachers and reading recovery assistants at work.

It was a sobering experience: "I knew those teachers could have felt terribly threatened by me, and I needed them to feel supported. I was also aware that I couldn't go in and niggle about things. When I reported back to the head, I tended to criticise by omission, to leave out someone I didn't feel I could praise.

"I felt I could influence things by my views and my personality, but I would have had to be very, very persistent where there was a need to bring about big changes. Whereas when a new head came in, she said 'we must deal with this' and did, almost straightaway."

Headteachers can be wary of parent governors, says Joan Sallis, particularly those who bring up other parents' complaints under Any Other Business: "Heads say that parents' views are too short-term, that parents find it difficult to take a strategic view. Sometimes that's because they don't know what to do with comments that are thrown at them in the supermarket. Sometimes it's because they are too interested in their own child's group or class.

"I usually say that parents may be like that in their first year, but give them responsibility for a working party on special needs, for example, and they become tremendously aware of the mix of advantages and disadvantages in a school."

She sees that change as a growth in understanding. Others might see it as a taming of parent governors, a gradual erosion of their outsiders' viewpoint and consumer role. Parents who do come in as consumer champions can find they have a battle on their hands: Ellen Jones (not her real name) became a governor at her daughter's primary school, where two staff were on long-term sick leave and there was a critical Ofsted looming, because she felt "they needed more governors who were in touch with people in the playground".

At her first meeting, the scale of the task became clear: "I suppose it confirmed all my worst fears. The headteacher did all the work and the governors just turned up to meetings. I found myself pushing, saying 'you need to do this, you need to do that, you need a plan, you're not meeting your responsibilities', and it was very difficult indeed to achieve change."

It was a frustrating and miserable experience; after two years she resigned. But even in the most open schools, the representative role of parent governors is difficult. Like MPs, once elected they are expected to bring forward all their constituents' points of view, but vote according to their own conscience. Some parent governors are told firmly by the head that they must not solicit parental opinions, says Joan Sallis. Others are encouraged to set up suggestion boxes or run surgeries.

These can be more trouble than they are worth: "The biggest debate we had was about whether there should be a uniform or not," recalls Lisa Challens. "I didn't care and the head didn't care, but I ended up with a collection of vehement letters on both sides."

Rushmore's new chair of governors, parent and health service worker Yvonne Servante, wants to find new mechanisms to open up the system, to draw parents into the work of governors without actually taking on the whole job: "Governors need such a broad range of expertise. One minute you might be talking about education policy, the next about catering contracts. I want us to link into wider networks: for example, we have had parents who were complaining about lunchtimes on a lunchtime working party and we have found a parent to advise us on underachieving African-Caribbean boys."

Yet she, too, sees inevitable barriers between the parent who is not a governor and the parent who is. Once governors have taken a decision, all of them must stand by it - even if they opposed it all the way. Sometimes, because of employee, pupil or commercial confidentiality, they cannot even give the reasons why it was made.

So it is true that the parent governor knows more than the ordinary parent. But ironically, knowing more can mean acting less. "Because I'm a parent governor I try to make an extra effort to be undemanding and supportive of my child's teachers," says Yvonne Servante. "I do balance what I think about what my child gets by what I know about the school overall".

The point was frequently repeated. Parent governors, far from feeling empowered or active in their child's education, actually feel inhibited from intervening on their behalf. "There were times when I wanted to go into school as a parent," says Margaret Charlesworth, "and I didn't." That does not mean governors feel powerless. All those interviewed felt they made a difference through their opportunities to question, monitor, steer, dissuade and inspire.

But it is gradual, strategic work away from the classroom, and the inhibitors, as Ian Strachan soon discovered, are strong. "You have significant responsibility, but your power is very constrained. You can't build an extension or recruit another teacher to get class sizes down because you can't afford it. You don't have powers over what is taught because it's dictated by the national curriculum and SATs. You want to be strategic and look ahead, but often all you have is an annual 'where can we cut costs?' It's difficult to make a difference. You carry on because the only alternative is to give up, and that would be more detrimental to the children."

On the PTA, you can do cakes or the accounts

It sounds unglamorous, and often - while you sweep up the polystyrene dots that some post-modernist packed into the lucky dip - it is. But supporting your school's Parent Teacher Association can have more impact on your child's education than you might think.

If you help a teacher in the classroom, you might exchange a few words at the start of the lesson. But if, after school, you discuss how you can help her book week, or you dry dishes together during a dance, you not only get to know each other but you become colleagues and equals.

If you become a school governor, you are hemmed in by governments, inspectors, committee timetables, the state of the toilets. But on the PTA you can set your own goals. You can build a new library. You can run a community arts weekend. You can go ahead and paint the toilets.

Good PTAs build strong communities. They produce newsletters and directories of family phone numbers. They run autumn teas to draw in newcomers. They underpin alliances between the head and parents, between teachers and parents, between parents and other parents. When they work well, these relationships are hardly noticed. Without them, schools can fall apart. Everyone plays to their strengths on a PTA. You have an MBA and 20 years' marketing experience? Write those begging letters now.

On top of all this, the money that you raise will buy books and equipment that your child needs now, not when the school budget can afford them. Of course the PTA risks being the headteacher's patsy: just staying silent and signing the cheques. But most heads want to confide in parents who they see as supportive: they will swap ideas which, in the general run of assemblies or parents' meetings, they normally have no time to discuss.

So when survey after survey shows teacher morale at rock bottom, is there any harm in a bit of unequivocal support? You don't swear never to criticise when you sign up for an hour on the tombola. What you do is to say: "I want to help. I am doing this for you and for my child. I am also doing it because even two hours on the tombola is easier than facing 33 nine-year-olds on a Friday afternoon."

webTitle: No home yet for the gene machine

fields.headline: No home yet for the gene machine
fields.standfirst: A highly profitable marriage is on the rocks over the siting of a multi-million pound X-ray project. The Wellcome Trust wants it in Oxford, the government prefers Cheshire.  Lee Elliot Major  charts a sorry saga
fields.trailText: A highly profitable marriage is on the rocks over the siting of a multi-million pound X-ray project. The Wellcome Trust wants it in Oxford, the government prefers Cheshire. Lee Elliot Major charts a sorry saga
fields.body:
It was heralded by ministers as the greatest public-private partnership of its kind. In July 1998, the government and the Wellcome Trust unveiled a joint £600m fund for scientific facilities in universities. After years of underfunding, university laboratories were finally set for a life-saving boost. Almost as an afterthought, the world's largest medical charity announced it was committing £110m to a joint government project to build an X-ray synchrotron machine.

The unprecedented partnership was a biomedical scientist's dream: a charity prepared to channel hundreds of millions of pounds into biomedical research; and a government persuaded that scientific discoveries will underpin tomorrow's successful high-flying businesses.

Who would think, then, that after 18 months the marriage would be on the rocks? Last week, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers told MPs the question where to site the new synchrotron, called Diamond, was still unresolved.

New studies to determine if the Daresbury Laboratory in Cheshire or the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory outside Oxford should house Diamond had remained inconclusive. Byers stressed that with up to £300m committed to the project, he would "be conscious of wider government objectives in relation to employment in the regions and economic regeneration" when making the long delayed final decision this week.

It was these wider social and political factors which last year persuaded Byers that Diamond should be housed in the north-west rather than Oxford. But the House of Commons' science and technology committee also heard last month from Dr Mike Dexter, director of the Wellcome Trust, that unless the latest reviews provided substantial scientific evidence against Oxford, the charity's favoured site, the trust would be forced to withdraw from the partnership altogether. Last week Byers conceded that without Wellcome, the government could not fund existing synchrotron plans.

The row over Diamond has raised uncomfortable questions over the government's commitment to science, and public-private partnerships in general. Some fear it might jeopardise the future support of scientists, and the UK's economic future as a whole. A north-south rift has emerged among academic leaders, with vice-chancellors from universities in the north-west, such as Manchester and Liverpool, lobbying government officials behind the scenes, complaining about the concentration of research funds in general in the south-east.

According to a submission to MPs from Wellcome, as early as April 1999 civil servants from the Office of Science and Technology were convinced that joint siting with another major research facility, and the cluster of scientific expertise in the Oxford region, made the Rutherford Lab the best location for the synchrotron. By June 1999, the siting of Diamond at Rutherford had become a government "non-negotiable" in the project talks. And by September 1999 the project's newly acquired French government partners backed the Oxford plans.

Then in early October Wellcome received a bombshell: Byers wrote to say he "was minded" to site Diamond at Daresbury. Correspondence between Byers and Dexter since has become increasingly strained, with Dexter insisting on Rutherford and Byers sticking with Daresbury.

On at least two counts Byers last week directly contradicted the trust's evidence. He claimed no earlier government decision had been made and this was a "misunderstanding" by the trust. The minister also said French officials had not "expressed openly any preference for one side or the other". Civil servants have privately said they had no inkling of the controversy to arise over Diamond. But past lab closures have shown powerful forces can be unleashed from a group of close-knit scientists, whose future is suddenly threatened.

Every scientific plus point for Oxford has been rebutted by the Daresbury trade union campaign. The mire of claims and counter-claims is more usually encountered during in-depth legal disputes. Diamond decisions being carried out almost exclusively behind Whitehall's closed doors have not helped.

Dexter, who comes from the north-west, has stressed that Wellcome's preference for Oxford has been based strictly on its scientific mission to improve human health. In truth, the split is about two different visions from two men in very different circumstances. Dexter envisages Diamond as another step in the development of the south-east as a world centre for biomedical research, which will in years to come yield new powerful medicines and benefits for the country as a whole. Byers sees a need to safeguard the scientific community, as well as jobs and businesses, (and some cynics would say Labour seats) in the north-west.

Byers said last week that other joint Wellcome schemes would be unaffected by the Diamond debate. Yet the trust is known to be more reluctant to commit further money to the fund for university scientific facilities. At the very least, Wellcome is likely to demand decision-making procedures are clarified before it signs up for future collaborations.

Meanwhile, Byers reassured MPs that the lab that loses out will receive other science funds. One senior government offical recently met heads of the north-west universities to discuss a new computing centre for the region. A signal that Rutherford will get the go-ahead? The university community waits with baited breath.

Why Welcome is pivotal to UK research

The government would probably not be able to take part in any debates about the future of UK biomedical science, if it was not for the Wellcome Trust. Without the billions of pounds channelled into UK universities and research institutes by the world's richest charity, the country would not be competing with the likes of the US to push back the frontiers of genetic science and develop the new drugs and medical treatments of the future. Government funding for research in the UK has fallen well behind levels in other Western nations.

The Wellcome Trust was created in 1936 from share capital assets of the Wellcome drug company as an independent funder of non-commercial research following the final wish of the US philanthropist company, Sir Henry Wellcome. But it was not until the late 1990s, after the Trust sold most of its Wellcome shares and the Glaxo and Wellcome drug companies had merged, that the charity was catapulted into the big money league.

With assets of some £13bn, Wellcome has spent £600m during the latest financial year. The recent merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham could be further good news for biomedical researchers: the trust owns 4.7% of GW shares, although this is the only link between the two organisations.

Its meteoric rise to power has meant that relations between Wellcome and the government have always been strained. Early disagreements concerned the trust's support of research project grants in universities, which did not include overheads for general support facilities.

It has also used its position to pressurise the government into improving researchers' pay; eg increasing its own PhD grants and postdoctoral salaries. Unlike the government, the trust can wipe the slate clean annually and decide where next to allocate its funds. One area it does not support, though, is cancer research.

Both the scale and nature of the partnership unveiled by Wellcome and the government after the 1998 Whitehall spending review shocked universities. Over £1bn extra was committed to researchers over three years. For the first time, the government revealed a clear priority for the new funds: exploiting research into the human genome, a goal shared by the trust.

But last year witnessed a major fall-out over Wellcome's building proposals for a bioscience campus for new high-tech businesses outside Cambridge. The decision by deputy prime minister John Prescott to turn down the proposals came only days after the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, has stressed the importance of biotechnology clusters.

The arguments over Diamond have led to further rifts. Yet most scientists believe the trust will still not go through with its many threats to go abroad with its money. Over 90% of its budget goes to UK-based researchers.

The X-ray synchrotron

This machine enables scientists to probe the fundamental make-up of materials. Electrons are whirled around inside a circular tube at high speed, emitting highly powerful X-rays that are channelled down a series of connecting beam lines. By monitoring how the X-rays collide and bounce off materials, researchers can then gain an insight into their microscopic structures.

The synchrotron is likely to play a key role in deciphering the genetic information emerging from the sequencing of the human genome.

But the House of Commons' science and technology committee also heard last month from Dr Mike Dexter, director of the Wellcome Trust, that unless the latest reviews provided substantial scientific evidence against Oxford, the charity's favoured site, the trust would be forced to withdraw from the partnership altogether. Last week Byers conceded that without Wellcome, the government could not fund existing synchrotron plans. The row over Diamond has raised uncomfortable questions over the government's commitment to science, and public-private partnerships in general. Some fear it might jeopardise the future support of scientists, and the UK's economic future as a whole. A north-south rift has emerged among academic leaders, with vice-chancellors from universities in the north-west, such as Manchester and Liverpool, lobbying government officials behind the scenes, complaining about the concentration of research funds in general in the south-east. According to a submission to MPs from Wellcome, as early as April 1999 civil servants from the Office of Science and Technology were convinced that joint siting with another major research facility, and the cluster of scientific expertise in the Oxford region, made the Rutherford Lab the best location for the synchrotron. By June 1999, the siting of Diamond at Rutherford had become a government "non-negotiable" in the project talks. And by September 1999 the project's newly acquired French government partners backed the Oxford plans. Then in early October Wellcome received a bombshell: Byers wrote to say he "was minded" to site Diamond at Daresbury. Correspondence between Byers and Dexter since has become increasingly strained, with Dexter insisting on Rutherford and Byers sticking with Daresbury. On at least two counts Byers last week directly contradicted the trust's evidence. He claimed no earlier government decision had been made and this was a "misunderstanding" by the trust. The minister also said French officials had not "expressed openly any preference for one side or the other". Civil servants have privately said they had no inkling of the controversy to arise over Diamond. But past lab closures have shown powerful forces can be unleashed from a group of close-knit scientists, whose future is suddenly threatened. Every scientific plus point for Oxford has been rebutted by the Daresbury trade union campaign. The mire of claims and counter-claims is more usually encountered during in-depth legal disputes. Diamond decisions being carried out almost exclusively behind Whitehall's closed doors have not helped. Dexter, who comes from the north-west, has stressed that Wellcome's preference for Oxford has been based strictly on its scientific mission to improve human health. In truth, the split is about two different visions from two men in very different circumstances. Dexter envisages Diamond as another step in the development of the south-east as a world centre for biomedical research, which will in years to come yield new powerful medicines and benefits for the country as a whole. Byers sees a need to safeguard the scientific community, as well as jobs and businesses, (and some cynics would say Labour seats) in the north-west. Byers said last week that other joint Wellcome schemes would be unaffected by the Diamond debate. Yet the trust is known to be more reluctant to commit further money to the fund for university scientific facilities. At the very least, Wellcome is likely to demand decision-making procedures are clarified before it signs up for future collaborations. Meanwhile, Byers reassured MPs that the lab that loses out will receive other science funds. One senior government offical recently met heads of the north-west universities to discuss a new computing centre for the region. A signal that Rutherford will get the go-ahead? The university community waits with baited breath. Why Welcome is pivotal to UK research The government would probably not be able to take part in any debates about the future of UK biomedical science, if it was not for the Wellcome Trust. Without the billions of pounds channelled into UK universities and research institutes by the world's richest charity, the country would not be competing with the likes of the US to push back the frontiers of genetic science and develop the new drugs and medical treatments of the future. Government funding for research in the UK has fallen well behind levels in other Western nations. The Wellcome Trust was created in 1936 from share capital assets of the Wellcome drug company as an independent funder of non-commercial research following the final wish of the US philanthropist company, Sir Henry Wellcome. But it was not until the late 1990s, after the Trust sold most of its Wellcome shares and the Glaxo and Wellcome drug companies had merged, that the charity was catapulted into the big money league. With assets of some £13bn, Wellcome has spent £600m during the latest financial year. The recent merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham could be further good news for biomedical researchers: the trust owns 4.7% of GW shares, although this is the only link between the two organisations. Its meteoric rise to power has meant that relations between Wellcome and the government have always been strained. Early disagreements concerned the trust's support of research project grants in universities, which did not include overheads for general support facilities. It has also used its position to pressurise the government into improving researchers' pay; eg increasing its own PhD grants and postdoctoral salaries. Unlike the government, the trust can wipe the slate clean annually and decide where next to allocate its funds. One area it does not support, though, is cancer research. Both the scale and nature of the partnership unveiled by Wellcome and the government after the 1998 Whitehall spending review shocked universities. Over £1bn extra was committed to researchers over three years. For the first time, the government revealed a clear priority for the new funds: exploiting research into the human genome, a goal shared by the trust. But last year witnessed a major fall-out over Wellcome's building proposals for a bioscience campus for new high-tech businesses outside Cambridge. The decision by deputy prime minister John Prescott to turn down the proposals came only days after the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, has stressed the importance of biotechnology clusters. The arguments over Diamond have led to further rifts. Yet most scientists believe the trust will still not go through with its many threats to go abroad with its money. Over 90% of its budget goes to UK-based researchers. The X-ray synchrotron This machine enables scientists to probe the fundamental make-up of materials. Electrons are whirled around inside a circular tube at high speed, emitting highly powerful X-rays that are channelled down a series of connecting beam lines. By monitoring how the X-rays collide and bounce off materials, researchers can then gain an insight into their microscopic structures. The synchrotron is likely to play a key role in deciphering the genetic information emerging from the sequencing of the human genome.

webTitle: New DNA evidence 'should lead to second murder trial'

fields.headline: New DNA evidence 'should lead to second murder trial'
fields.standfirst: What is double jeopardy?
fields.trailText: Suspected killers cleared by the courts should be forced to stand trial again where DNA genetic fingerprinting unearths "compelling" new evidence, the director of public prosecutions recommended today.
fields.body:
Suspected killers cleared by the courts should be forced to stand trial again where DNA genetic fingerprinting unearths "compelling" new evidence, the director of public prosecutions recommended today.

David Calvert-Smith QC said the law on double jeopardy - where no defendant can be tried twice for the same crime - should be relaxed in exceptional cases for serious crimes like murder.

In evidence to the Commons home affairs select committee, Mr Calvert-Smith backed the law commission's proposal in the report into the death of Stephen Lawrence to change the current law.

The head of the prosecution service in England and Wales told the committee: "Firstly, victims deserve better treatment than they are getting.

"Secondly, it is a scandal that people can go about boasting about crimes they have committed without fear of redress."

He suggested the rule change be retrospective, allowing fresh trials for crimes dating back dozens of years, even though he predicted it would only affect a "handful" of cases.

He said one key reason for a relaxation was the "dramatic" advance in forensic science, including the development of genetic fingerprinting, which is increasingly used to devastating effect in trials.

Other important innovations included "corneal mapping" - where photographs can record and identify the unique pattern of people's eyes - and the enhancement of closed circuit TV images.

Fresh proceedings could also be sparked by religious conversion, when a religious convert confessed to past sins or when previously untraceable witnesses had been located, said Mr Calvert-Smith.

He told the committee: "I would hope that a number of defendants would realise that with new DNA evidence the game is up and plead guilty at a new trial."

But the QC warned that the state should not be allowed to bring unlimited fresh proceedings, or to renew old cases to make up for police incompetence.

A line had to be drawn somewhere in the prosecution's ability to bring fresh proceedings - or the law would become "oppressive".

In a blow to victims of bungled police inquiries, Mr Calvert-Smith went on: "No judge would ever allow the prosecution to have a second bite at the cherry to make up for police incompetence at the first trial.

"No prosecutor under my control would ever consider that that was an appropriate way of carrying on."

Kent's chief constable David Phillips - also appearing before the committee - estimated that several cases where defendants had been acquitted could be revisited with a change in the law.

He told the MPs: "There are one or two cases involving child homicide where there is DNA evidence where someone has been acquitted."

Backing the proposed change, Mr Phillips - chairman of the crime committee of the association of chief police officers - added: "I am always suspicious of lofty principles that we are encouraged to believe should stand alone. The reality is that in most of these questions there are competing principles.

"One is that the notion that in general there should be finality to prosecutions and the other is that there is a real interest in justice in that the truth is seen to [come] out."

webTitle: New M&S chief offers long slog

fields.headline: New M&S chief offers long slog
fields.trailText: Luc Vandevelde, the Belgian executive who was yesterday named as the new executive chairman of Marks & Spencer, issued an immediate warning to shareholders that they might have to wait another year for the business to show real improvement.
fields.body:
Luc Vandevelde, the Belgian executive who was yesterday named as the new executive chairman of Marks & Spencer, issued an immediate warning to shareholders that they might have to wait another year for the business to show real improvement.

He also hinted that the turnaround in M&S's high street fortunes could be even further away if more major strategic changes had to be made.

But the 49-year-old executive - who has been negotiating his arrival at M&S since last September and secured a remuneration package worth £19m over the next five years if the company's share price doubles - said he thought key problems and "really tough issues" had already been tackled.

Changes to the M&S organisation which had removed some layers of bureaucracy and the decision to source some goods outside the UK - which has angered unions and suppliers - were the most important changes necessary to revitalise the brand, said Mr Vandevelde, whose appointment was first revealed by the Guardian last month.

Shares in the group fell back by 3.25p to 305p as analysts questioned whether Mr Vandevelde had the credentials needed to turn around the beleaguered retailer.

But Peter Salsbury, the chief executive whose own job is under pressure from a number of investors, said Mr Vandevelde would help M&S better manage its brand and drive customer relations management.

He denied he was being usurped by the newcomer and stressed that the reporting lines in the business and the day to day management of M&S remained in his hands.

It is clear, however, that one of the reasons Mr Vandevelde has been appointed is to give the public face of M&S some chutzpah; Mr Salsbury is a shy man, uncomfortable with large-scale presentations, and part of the group's lacklustre performance in the City is attributed to this.

Mr Vandevelde, who will be charged with the group's strategic direction, yesterday refused to rule out the possibility that M&S might consider a global merger, but said in the short term it was imperative that the group revived its clothing ranges and rekindled customer confidence on the high street.

"The fundamentals of M&S are still very strong: it is one of the strongest and best recognised brands in the world. It also has a large consumer base to exploit," he said. "There is nothing preventing this brand getting back to where it was in the eyes of the consumer."

But he added: "The fundamental problems are internal and merging is not an immediate solution. M&S has the scale not to need to merge but once the UK is sorted, we have to ensure we keep that scale on a global basis. No retailer can afford not to be international."

Mr Salsbury denied that M&S had been keen to look outside the UK for its full time chairman, saying "nationality was not an issue".

But Mr Vandevelde's appointment follows the arrival at FTSE 100 firms of a number of high profile overseas executives, raising questions about the quality of the UK's home-grown management talent.

Although Mr Salsbury said Mr Vandevelde was the "first choice" for M&S chairman, analysts said he lacked retail muscle and suggested he came on to the executive market only because he failed to land the top job at the French retail group, Promodès-Carrefour.

fields.headline: Vandevelde takes the helm
fields.trailText: The arrival of Luc Vandevelde in the hot seat at Marks & Spencer's headquarters in London next month may do as much to quicken merger hopes for the high-street retailer as to damp them down.
fields.body:
The arrival of Luc Vandevelde in the hot seat at Marks & Spencer's headquarters in London next month may do as much to quicken merger hopes for the high-street retailer as to damp them down.

He recently masterminded the merger of French retail group Promodès with its rival Carrefour to create the world's second largest player after American group Wal-Mart.

Yesterday he chose to concentrate on the management track record rather than on his deal- making skills that had some investors hoping for a takeover bid by retail entrepreneur Phillip Green or supermarket group Tesco.

Mr Vandevelde said that he was not intimidated by the task of trying to woo big shareholders back into the M&S fan club, claiming acquaintance with many as they had held shares in Promodès.

webTitle: Hanged uncle and nephew 'victims of racist mob', family claims

fields.headline: Hanged uncle and nephew 'victims of racist mob', family claims
fields.trailText:
The family of two black men found hanged within six months of each other
today claimed they had been victims of a campaign of harassment by far-right
extremists.
fields.body:
The family of two black men found hanged within six months of each other today claimed they had been victims of a campaign of harassment by far-right extremists.

Harold McGowan, 32, and his 20-year-old nephew Jason McGowan had both been subjected to racial harassment in the months before their deaths, the family's solicitor said.

Friends of the two men, both of Telford in Shropshire, believe they were the victims of a "lynch mob" of racist killers and are calling for the police to investigate further.

Michael Mansfield QC, the leading human rights barrister who acted for the family of the murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence, has agreed to represent the men's family.

Police are currently treating the deaths as two separate incidents. An inquest into Harold McGowan's death is due to be held next month.

Detective Chief Inspector Ken Crane, who is heading the investigation into Jason's death for West Mercia police, has acknowledged the "unusual" nature of the deaths and confirmed that the two men had been subjected to racial harassment.

He said: "It is very unusual to find deaths in a similar fashion in the same family in such a short space of time."

Harold McGowan, a builder who was known to his family as Errol, had been warned he was on a "death list" of the extreme rightwing group Combat 18. He became a target for racists during his work as a part-time pub doorman after he stopped a barred man from entering a pub, according to the family's solicitor Errol Robinson.

Mr McGowan, a father of three, was attacked at least twice and told the police on several occasions that he believed his life was in danger. He endured a two-year campaign of harassment before he was found dead at a friend's home in Telford on 2 July 1999. He had been minding the empty house while the friend was away and was found with the flex of an iron around his neck. Mr Robinson said Mr McGowan had been abused by a small racist group who intimidated him by repeatedly driving past the pub where he worked.

Six months later, on new year's day, his nephew Jason was found hanged on railings outside a leisure centre in Telford. Hours before his body was found, Jason, who was newly married, had been celebrating the new year at a local pub with his wife and friends.

The newspaper production worker had recently started to investigate his uncle's death and, four weeks earlier, another member of their family had received an anonymous telephone call warning them to stop their inquiries.

Harold McGowan's brother, Clifton, said: "We are convinced that both Harold and Jason were killed by racists. They had no reason to take their own lives." Neither of the men had left suicide notes, he said.

Speaking on behalf of the McGowan family, Mr Robinson said: "Whether some third party was involved cannot be discounted."

West Mercia police said today that despite "exhaustive inquiries" into Harold's death there was no evidence of a link with anyone else. The police report has now been handed to the coroner ahead of the inquest. Investigations are continuing into the second hanging but a spokesman said there was also no evidence that anyone else was involved in that death.

webTitle: Labour to toughen stance on equality

fields.headline: Labour to toughen stance on equality
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to reinforce its commitment to promoting equality to avert damning criticism, on next month's anniversary of the Lawrence inquiry report, that it has failed to confront racism and sexism.
fields.body:
The government is to reinforce its commitment to promoting equality to avert damning criticism, on next month's anniversary of the Lawrence inquiry report, that it has failed to confront racism and sexism.

Tony Blair is poised to appoint a cabinet minister for diversity to give a higher profile to the promotion of equality. The minister - expected to be Mo Mowlam - will have the political clout to ensure that Whitehall acts on race and gender issues, or on those affecting disabled people.

At the same time the cabinet is set to give way amid a threatened revolt by black and Asian Labour peers. The peers are upset at the government's failure to extend the new race relations legislation to cover indirect discrimination and institutional racism in the public sector, of the type identified by the Lawrence inquiry.

It is widely believed that the momentum built up in the immediate aftermath of the Lawrence report has not been sustained. The drive to confront racism in the police degenerated into a row over the use of stop-and-search powers, and the goodwill over the reform of the race relations act was lost amid arguments over how far reform should go.

Ms Mowlam, the cabinet "enforcer" who is also responsible for co-ordinating the government's policy on equality, is expected to be given the job of minister for diversity. However Baroness Jay, minister for women, has been pressing to take over part of the job.

The campaign to promote equality for women is currently fragmented among junior and middle-ranking ministers, none of whom has enough clout to make real progress in Whitehall or or in the country at large. Apart from Baroness Jay, Tessa Jowell is minister for equal opportunities at the department for education and employment, and Margaret Hodge is the junior minister for equal opportunities. At the home office, Mike O'Brien, is minister for race relations.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, is expected this week to give way to demands that the race relations (amendment) bill be extended to cover indirect forms of discrimination. This follows sharp criticism from nearly all Labour's newly appointed black and Asian peers.

They include Baroness Howells of St Davids, a close friend of the Lawrence family, who has warned Mr Straw that the legislation as currently tabled would fail to "address the causes of the police's failure properly to investigate the murder of Stephen Lawrence".

Next week Mr Straw is likely to decide who will replace the disillusioned Sir Herman Ouseley as chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality, a decision that will shape the future of the government's approach to equality.

Three shortlisted candidates were interviewed last Friday. They are Gurbux Singh, the modernising chief executive of Haringey council; Peter Herbert, the chairman of the Society of Black Lawyers; and Beverley Thompson, the strategy director of the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders.

fields.headline: NTL, SFA and DHMF
fields.trailText: SEVEN DEADLY GRINS
fields.body:
SEVEN DEADLY GRINS

'Steve Watson's All-New Geology Hour' took a step closer to becoming reality today after Aston Villa signed a deal with cable giants NTL. The agreement, announced this morning, will see an NTL subsidiary (probably Venezuela or something) take control of Villa's key media rights in exchange for a five-year loan of £26m. Which just about covers the money they have spent on Stanley.

Stanley was unavailable for comment today (presumably he was in his room putting together a sitcom about a talented man locked in his room) but The Deadliest Doug Of Them All wasn't. "It means very simply that £26m is being invested - £11m of it in three weeks' time - subject to our shareholders agreeing," said the Villa chairman of the deal, "and I'm sure they will."

After putting his silent movie villain top hat and twirly moustache kit away, Deadly explained the nature of Villa's relationship with those lovely wire people. webTitle: US press reaction to the Iowa caucus

fields.headline: US press reaction to the Iowa caucus
fields.body:
Bush will be pummelled personally and tested ideologically
The debates tomorrow night in New Hampshire promise to be more personal and, on the GOP [Republican] side, ideological. Governor Bush remains the frontrunner in his race, but for the next seven days he will be pummelled personally and tested ideologically. Despite the gracious tone of Mr Bradley's concession speech in Des Moines, competitive pressures will almost surely throw him and Mr Gore into more heated confrontations. These things happen when real votes replace polls and prognostication. Over the next few weeks, delegates will be won and candidacies will either strengthen or die. And a sequence of elections that sometimes seems irrational, debilitating and endless will eventually show its value in seasoning the candidates and shaping the choice offered to voters in November. New York Times: leader comment

Iowa marks the high point of Christian conservative influence
The end of the campaign for Iowa's precinct caucuses last night may also mark the high point of Christian conservative influence on American politics this year. The caucus process, which demands a high degree of commitment and fervour, multiplies the influence of organised groups battling for a cause, including the cause of the Lord. The Iowa dynamic enabled Christian conservatives to push frontrunner George W Bush hard for a stronger commitment to oppose abortion.

For the rest of the campaign, though, the Christian right will be forced to confront problems that have weakened the movement, scattered its forces among several presidential campaigns and led some in its ranks to decry a lack of leadership in their own house.
Washington Post: the religious right - peaking in Iowa, by EJ Dionne

An ugly business
Sometimes this is an ugly business.

What am I saying?

This is usually an ugly business.

Actually, ugly and uninvited is how I ended up in the 31st-floor suite of Texas Governor George W Bush on Monday night, just as the votes started coming in.

First, the scene in the room of the man who lots of Republicans think is the next president of the United States: Bush and his wife, Laura, were sitting side by side in matched, stuffed chairs. His hand was on hers, then they held hands.

"Loving," I wrote. "Not creepy."

Everybody in the suite was delighted, thrilled and relieved. Mostly, they seemed relieved.

Put it this way: The governor's smile was as big as the one pasted on the guy from Sabula who won $32m in the Powerball lottery last week.
The Des Moines Register: John Carlson with the Bush team

All the candidates intersect in the middle more often than not
Yes, differences exist between Mr Gore, Mr Bradley, Mr Bush and Mr McCain on issues like health care and taxes. Messrs Gore and Bradley definitely lean left of centre, and Messrs Bush and McCain clearly lean right, but all intersect in the middle more often than not. Unlike in some recent elections, the leading figures from the two major parties are not starting from far ends of the political spectrum. America is better off for that result. Their presence should make for a sane, but hard-fought general election campaign. Dallas News: leader comment

At last, the real start
Of course the winners in Iowa, and in New Hampshire's primary on February 1, will not necessarily become the Democratic and Republican presidential nominees. But these states can wield enormous influence on the selection process. It's a role Iowa and New Hampshire cherish and are loath to surrender as pressure mounts for the parties to adopt a system of regional primaries a month apart. Reformers argue that these early tests receive an inordinate amount of candidate and media attention and skew the process.

It's reasonable for a Californian to ask why Iowa and New Hampshire should have such an impact while the influence of the nation's most populous state could count for nothing. The answer can be found in timing. The national parties have been unable to force Iowa and New Hampshire to give up their kickoff status.

But the political doings in the two states serve valid purposes. Iowa tests a campaign's ability to mobilise a field operation that gets supporters out to the 2,142 precinct caucuses beginning at 7pm Iowa time today. New Hampshire voters demand that candidates handle face-to-face meetings. Consider the New Hampshire voter who couldn't make up his mind because the candidates had been to his house only twice.

The thing about electoral politics is that, despite the improving science of polling, no one can declare victory until after the votes are cast. That point at last is here.
Los Angeles Times: leader comment

New Hampshire: the ground zero of US politics
Starting this morning and continuing for the next week, New Hampshire will be the ground zero of American politics. That makes it the perfect setting for pushing presidential candidates in both parties toward safer positions on nuclear weapons.

The Republican contenders seem determined to run in the opposite direction, because they agree to a man that the United States should deploy a missile defence system. Even if such a system worked - and that's a big "if" - it would make the world more dangerous, not less so, by setting a new nuclear arms race in motion.

Nobody in either party is doing much to advance a far more sensible and certain notion: taking the thousands of nuclear warheads in the United States and Russia off of high alert. By reducing the greatest threat we face - an accidental strike - this small step would go a long way toward making us all safer.
The Concord Monitor (New Hampshire): leader comment

fields.headline: Divorce, remarriage and religion
fields.trailText:
Divorce is an anguishing experience for most people, regardless of their 
religious persuasions - or lack of them. And those who choose to remarry face 
a bewildering range of prohibitions, restrictions, customs, laws and rituals.
fields.body:
Divorce is an anguishing experience for most people, regardless of their religious persuasions - or lack of them. And those who choose to remarry face a bewildering range of prohibitions, restrictions, customs, laws and rituals.

The Church of England's soul-searching reappraisal of second marriages reflects a modest move away from a Christian traditional orthodoxy which frowns sternly on divorce. And yet, as marriage advisers on the internet and elsewhere point out, some Anglican priests have for many years quietly ignored the ban on divorced people remarrying in church.

There will continue to be ample scope for personal interpretation of the suggested new rule on remarriage of divorcees. Church leaders have made it plain that there will not be 'marriage on demand'. Rather, it will still be up to the clergy to decide whether to sanction and carry out a church ceremony.

Other denominations, and indeed other faiths, have their own ways of fudging the issue:

Roman Catholics: The Church holds marriage to be indissoluble - excepted in rare cases, notably involving non-consummation. It does not recognise civil marriage or divorce, so it will sanction church weddings of divorcees, providing their first marriage was a civil ceremony.

Nonconformists: Methodists, Congregationalists, United Reform and other main denominations do not attempt to lay down a uniform law on church remarriages. Instead, as with the Church of Scotland, the decision is generally left to the discretion of individual clergy. However, that broad definition could be dangerously misleading. The more radical and evangelical sects have their own customs, often varying from one congregation to the next. Church customs are also influenced by regional and national cultures. In the so-called Bible Belt of the USA, for example, some churches have been known to expel divorcees when they remarry.

Quakers: The Society of Friends has a deep-rooted democratic tradition. Whether a divorced member can have a religious remarriage ceremony, is decided by the monthly meeting.

Muslims: There are enormous variations of custom and practice in the various strands of Islam - Sunni, Shi'ite, Wahhabi, Ismaili, etc. In general, however, Islamic scholars and clerics believe divorce should be the last resort in a flawed marriage. Contrary to much simplistic Western thinking, divorce is not just a male decision. Women too can institute proceedings. There is a three-month 'cooling off' period before the separation is formally recognised, and strict rules about the fair division of property and custody of children. There is no religious bar on remarriage, though in some cultures it is frowned upon for women.

Jews: Again, there is a huge diversity of opinions and customs within the Ashkenazi and Sephardi (broadly, western and eastern) traditions, and between the various strands of religious observance: Orthodox, ultra-Orthodox, Conservative, Liberal, and Reform. In all, divorce is recognised, though it is bedevilled by the ancient requirement of formal consent by either or both parties. Once it is given, there is no bar on remarriage.

Hindus: There is, by definition, no such thing as orthodox Hinduism. It is a philosophy as much as a religion, with no commonly accepted liturgy or core of beliefs. In general, however, Hindus think of marriage as a sacrament rather than - as in Islam and Judaism - as a civil contract. Religious dissolution of marriage is therefore impossible. Civil divorce is recognised in most Hindu communities. But many conservative Hindus find it difficult to conceive that a divorced woman (or a widow) could even think of remarriage.

Sikhs: As with Hindus, Sikhs think of marriage as a holy sacrament. But they tend to encourage civilly-divorced people to marry again.

fields.headline: ITV lays on the Des bus for Euro 2000
fields.trailText: ITV unveiled its plans for Euro 2000 coverage yesterday with a novel solution to the question of how to ensure the ubiquity of Des Lynam.
fields.body:
ITV unveiled its plans for Euro 2000 coverage yesterday with a novel solution to the question of how to ensure the ubiquity of Des Lynam.

Lynam, ITV's face of football since defecting from the BBC last year, will travel around Holland and Belgium in a specially converted coach, nicknamed the Des-mobile.

The bus has been developed to counter the problem of moving the anchorman to and from 10 live games at seven venues in 12 days. Equipped with video machines and screens so he can watch other matches, the luxury coach will function as a travelling production office with "all home comforts", according to ITV.

Brian Barwick, ITV's head of sport, said: "Unlike the World Cup in France, Holland and Belgium present a slightly different challenge because by the time you've got to the airport you could be halfway to the next venue, so we decided to do it by road."

Lynam's route has been mapped out by executives in a test run, and he will be making a practice tour by coach next month. "This was the practical solution which gives the opportunity for Des to do every game live. We think he is such an important part in our Euro 2000 jigsaw that it's worth pulling out the stops to make sure he's there," Mr Barwick added.

Lynam's worth to ITV will be tested by head to head opposition with BBC1, led by former colleagues Gary Lineker and Alan Hansen described as "the nation's favourite team for football," by the BBC. BBC1 and ITV have joint television rights to the tournament and will split live coverage of the competition. They will broadcast the first round match between England and Germany on June 17 simultaneously, because of the historical rivalry of the fixture. Should England reach the quarter final, that match will be shown by both channels.

A BBC spokesman said the decision to show England v Germany on both channels at the same time was taken to avoid one station losing out.

webTitle: Talk Sport beats BBC to Tyson fight

fields.headline: Talk Sport beats BBC to Tyson fight
fields.standfirst: Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: Kelvin MacKenzie's all-sport radio station Talk Sport has paid a six-figure sum to beat its BBC rival, 5 Live, to the rights to broadcast Mike Tyson's fight in Manchester this weekend.
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie's all-sport radio station Talk Sport has paid a six-figure sum to beat its BBC rival, 5 Live, to the rights to broadcast Mike Tyson's fight in Manchester this weekend.

Both stations are known to have negotiated in advance with Tyson's promoter, Frank Warren, to broadcast the fight against the British heavyweight Julius Francis. But last night it emerged that Talk had secured the rights.

The fight is the first big event to have been up for grabs since Talk Radio's relaunch as an all-sport network this month.

Mr MacKenzie said: "For us it's a very big moment. This will be one of the biggest fights in recent history, and I'm delighted we've got it."

He declared that he was unaware of the BBC's bid, adding: "They're not really interested in boxing are they?"

A BBC spokeswoman played down Radio 5 Live's loss and emphasised the widely held view that it will not be a long bout.

She said: "Radio 5 Live made a fair and reasonable offer which sought to balance interest in a main title fight which might only last a few minutes against value for licence payers' money."

The difference between the two bids is thought to have been around £25,000.

A BBC insider said 5 Live "just couldn't go any higher".

Talk Sport is 20% owned by Rupert Murdoch, whose Sky television will screen the live pay-per-view coverage of the fight.

Despite his substantial backers, Mr MacKenzie has been anxious not to overstate Talk's powers to poach sports rights from the BBC.

He bought the five-year-old station last year, and he has been campaigning ever since against what he describes as the BBC's monopoly on sports rights.

He has confirmed, however, that he will bid against 5 Live for its greatest asset, the £5m deal to broadcast Premier League football, which runs out in 2001.

webTitle: In search of a better body

fields.headline: In search of a better body
fields.standfirst: It's Britain's first glossy magazine devoted to cosmetic surgery. Its cover line? 'Beauty is skin deep.'  Oliver Burkeman can only wince
fields.trailText: It's Britain's first glossy magazine devoted to cosmetic surgery. Its cover line? 'Beauty is skin deep.' Oliver Burkeman can only wince
fields.body:
Britain's first magazine dedicated to cosmetic surgery is launched this month, and nobody could accuse it of beating about the bush. "Beauty is skin deep," declares the coverline of Body Beautiful, a quarterly promising to help you get "the body you want - as fast as you can".

It's a market waiting to be tapped: the magazine claims that 65,000 cosmetic operations are performed each year in the UK, and there's certainly been a "huge increase", according to the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons - indicating that the eightfold rise in the US over the past decade may soon be duplicated here. Controversy should attract a few readers, too: from worries over children seeking cosmetic modifications to speculation about the exact degree of Britney Spears' acquaintance with the surgeon's knife, it's a subject on everyone's lips, collagen-enhanced or otherwise.

Sure enough - doubtless to the delight of its publishers - Body Beautiful's launch issue has created a controversy of its own. Cindy Jackson, who spent £60,000 on more than a decade of improvements to her waist, breasts and face, and who is copiously quoted in issue one, is unimpressed. "There's a lot of good information in there, but there's also a lot of incorrect information," she said. "I don't know how a person is supposed to decide which is which. There's a lot of self-promotion... There are few mentions of the risks."

It's true that Body Beautiful doesn't dwell on the alleged dangers of certain treatments - "the major problems with implants are local but not life-threatening complications" is among the glibber statements. Yet even though it reads, superficially, like a glossy 147-page ad for the "cosmetic enhancement" industry, it's hard to see how it will really help its bottom line. For there can be few experiences short of unanaesthetised plastic surgery quite as wince-inducing as reading Body Beautiful's blow-by-blow accounts of slicings, enlargements, reductions and extensions.

Gravity-defying breast modifications are the main focus, illustrated with the magazine's trademark before-and-after photographs (before: poor lighting and frowns; after: good lighting, make-up and smiles). But there's abdominoplasty, rhinoplasty, ankle liposuction, chin-cheek implant, blepharoplasty (eyelids) and - most eye-watering of all, for this reader at least - an excruciating first-person account of penoplasty, or penis extension. "I'd be lying if I said it was painless," writes "Ian", 34 years old and a master of understatement. "Erections were a tearful business. Put it this way - I got through a lot of packets of frozen peas... my penis was, unsurprisingly, red and angry for a week."

One of the more amazing claims Body Beautiful makes is to be found in its media pack: "According to NatWest bank, the most common reason for taking out a bank loan is to pay for plastic surgery or cosmetic enhancement of some kind."

"Er, no, that's wrong," said a NatWest spokesman, confirming that cars and holidays remain the most common reasons for borrowing money. Somehow, it seems unlikely that the purchasing of life subscriptions to Body Beautiful is about to become another one.

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText:
Tuesday

In 10 days I go under the knife for my deviated septum - and still no one has talked to me about procedure, recovery time and possible complications. "What do you care about any of that," my wife asks over dinner, "if you're going to become a vegetable due to some freak anaesthetic accident?" I suppose she has a point - I have mentioned my fears on this matter once or twice - but need she be quite so blunt?
fields.body:
Tuesday

In 10 days I go under the knife for my deviated septum - and still no one has talked to me about procedure, recovery time and possible complications. "What do you care about any of that," my wife asks over dinner, "if you're going to become a vegetable due to some freak anaesthetic accident?" I suppose she has a point - I have mentioned my fears on this matter once or twice - but need she be quite so blunt?

Wednesday

A colleague pops over to relate how he suffered an anaesthetic reaction during surgery in 1993, and woke up in intensive care to find a doctor moving his fingers in front of his eyes, and asking him who was prime minister. A panic attack ensues, and I ring the Charing Cross's day surgery unit to seek reassurance from Rosanne Charles, the very sweet nurse who so mystifyingly declared me fit for surgery. Rosanne is busy, and the receptionist suggests I speak to the ENT surgeon himself, a Mr McKay. I am too distressed today, but may do so tomorrow.

Thursday

Mr McKay (no doubt he has a first name, but I take a dim view of familiarity with surgeons said to be pre-eminent in their fields) has just rung me back from his Harley Street rooms, and very patiently explained everything. The sub-muchosal resection (in which he will break the septum, scoop out some of the cartilege beneath, and then reset it) has an 85% chance of improving my breathing, and he suggests a week or so at home recovering. As for complications, he outlines three possibilities: severe bleeding requiring a return to hospital (very unlikely); a perforation of the septum (not uncommon, but unusual for the patient to notice it); and - another very long shot - "although the op is not intended to change the shape of the nose, you can't guarantee that it won't".

"Oh splendid, you mean I might come out of it looking like Jimmy Durante?"

"That's extremely unlikely." And with that, Mr McKay bids me farewell until tomorrow week.

Friday

I awake shattered and morose, having passed a desperately troubled night. In the dream, I suffer a violent anaesthetic reaction, and awake two days later in intensive care. A cheery, bearded man, whose badge reveals him as a Dr Dobson, wags his finger in front of my eyes, and then asks who is prime minister. "Alastair Campbell," I reply in a tiny voice, "it's Alastair Campbell."

"Oooh, you amaze me," says the doctor. "Turn the machine off, would you, nurse and call the morgue? We need the bed for someone from a more sensible newspaper."

Saturday

When I call my physician, Dr Sarah Jarvis, at work, she is in the middle of a coughing fit. "That sounds nasty," I say, " you should see a doctor." Eschewing the sarcastic laugh, Dr Jarvis asks after the purpose of the call. "It's about my surgery. I'm worri..."

"You are NOT going to suffer brain damage."

"...worried that I might bec..." "You will NOT become a vegetable."

"But I'm breathing better at the moment, and ..."

"You ARE going to have your operation, and you ARE going to come through it perfectly well."

Mm. It's easy for her to say that.

Sunday

Listening to the Archers omnibus as I drive to Newbury to see my godson Benjamin on his birthday, it occurs to me that there is a cure for cancer after all: move to Ambridge. They may have steamy sex scenes in the shower in the cause of realism, but no one ever has the semblance of a tumour.

Monday

I awake feeling drained and jumpy from another troubled night. In this dream, I come round in the recovery room to find two people in white aprons smiling down on me. It is amazingly hot, partly because there is a very strong flame beneath what is not, on closer inspection, a bed at all, but a huge griddling pan.

"OK, Deeliaugh," says a Dr Grossman, "wort are weeee gawinn to do nauuuow?"

"Well, Lloyd," says Dr Smith, "the thing about frying aubergine is making sure you season it well before cooking."

"Eau absoloootely," says Loyd, and begins to douse me in lemon juice and garlic.

I try to speak. I want to shout: "For God's sake, what about a pinch of paprika?" But remembering that I am now an aubergine, I abandon this plan and awake, nervy and disorientated and more tempted than ever to pull out of the op.

fields.headline: The danger of false hope
fields.standfirst: During his first visit to Britain since his accident, Christopher Reeve has talked about making a full recovery.  Peter Mansell, who also has a spinal cord injury, is not impressed
fields.trailText: During his first visit to Britain since his accident, Christopher Reeve has talked about making a full recovery. Peter Mansell, who also has a spinal cord injury, is not impressed
fields.body:
It was great to see pictures of Christopher Reeve in the Millennium Dome at the weekend. I went myself at the start of the month. The kids loved it, access was brilliant; it was well thought-out.

But suppose that Reeve had wanted to go to watch Arsenal and take his family with him - and suppose he didn't let slip that he was Superman when he tried to arrange it.

The fact is that he'd be told on the phone to apply in writing two months in advance, and, if he was lucky, would get one of the 36 allocated tickets. However he wouldn't be able to take his whole family, because only one carer per wheelchair-user is permitted.

Of course, these sort of rules don't apply to those few wheelchair-users with high profiles. And that's the problem: people like Reeve don't see all the problems.

He could use his profile to do something genuinely useful. He could go to a theatre and be slung out because of fire regulations. He could go to Waterloo station and discover how many taxi drivers suddenly become visually impaired because setting up the ramps for a wheelchair-user is too much effort. He could work out how much benefit he would get if he were living in England - the vast majority of spinal cord injured people are unemployed. Now that might be interesting.

But instead, from my point of view, Reeve has swapped film stardom for a new role as victim and super-cripple. Nothing he has done has helped disabled people who want a better quality of life now - and not in five years' time.

Of course Reeve is a fellow human being who has suffered a terrible injury, and one way that some people come to grips with something like this is to focus on hopes for a cure, however unrealistic.

But the high profile that Reeve enjoys means that his words take on power. He doesn't mean to do it, but his promises of a cure imply that it is we wheelchair-users, and not society, that have to change.

Secondly, pinning your hopes on a cure is no way to live your life. I'm sure lots of people live, like Reeve, in hope of a cure. To someone three months after an injury - which is a catastrophic and life-changing thing - I'm not saying, forget about a cure. I am saying that if you lie in bed and wait for a cure, you are not going to have a good quality of life. If you can get on with your life and the cure comes, great. But if it doesn't come, it's not life-ending.

When I woke up after my accident in 1978, I thought, "This is awful." I got hooked on valium, watched Neighbours and felt sorry for myself. I spent more than a year in hospital and decided that I had three options: to blow my brains out; to spend the rest of my life feeling sorry for myself and destroy the people around me in the process; or to do something about it.

So I did something about it. I was an unskilled manual worker, but I chose to do an Open University degree and started working at my local Citizen's Advice Bureau, which is where I became interested in social policy and poverty.

It's easy to dwell on how awful it all is, but the fact is that you have to get your head round it and get on with life.

Personally, I'm not interested in the Reeve foundation or the research that's going on. It's irrelevant to me, and it draws the focus away from the real issues of quality of life: employment, transport, housing. It may be the hot and sexy thing to give money to a brave individual to find the cure to make him walk again. But it doesn't help the vast majority of those with spinal cord injuries.

Finally, it's naughty and it's dangerous of Reeve to speak of us finding a cure in five years. It does no good to anyone to put a deadline on these things: it raises false hopes. Imagine that you've just suffered a spinal injury. You might actually believe it.

 Peter Mansell is to take over as chief executive of RADAR (the Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation) next month.

webTitle: How I put back pain behind me

fields.headline: How I put back pain behind me
fields.standfirst: Two years ago, just getting dressed was agony for  Felicity Lawrence. Her back was so bad that she spent days lying on the floor in agony. Osteopathy didn't help and nor did drugs or a corset. Then she found a cure - Pilates
fields.trailText: Two years ago, just getting dressed was agony for Felicity Lawrence. Her back was so bad that she spent days lying on the floor in agony. Osteopathy didn't help and nor did drugs or a corset. Then she found a cure - Pilates
fields.body:
There comes a point with bad backs when your muscles go into excruciating spasm, the painkillers don't work, and you find yourself unable to move. Two years ago I was falling into this state more and more often. I had got used to waking up in pain, to the fact that bending down to put my knickers on in the morning would reduce me to tears and that the rest of the day would be spent hobbling around in thoroughly bad-tempered discomfort. But this chronic pain was increasingly being overtaken by days spent lying on the floor in agony.

My general practitioner referred me for osteopathy, which helped the first time but not much thereafter. A locum prescribed tranquillisers for the acute episodes, to relax the muscles and get them out of spasm. This guaranteed two days in bed in a woozy sort of bliss, but I would come to with the pain and bad temper intact. Both doctors had been vague about a diagnosis of the problem.

In desperation I tried a private appointment with a leading orthopaedic consultant. He introduced it to New York, where it was taken up by the great choreographer George Balanchine to help his ballet dancers. It is now the fashionable exercise of Hollywood stars, and has become flavour of the month. The queue for Ackland's Body Maintenance studio has featured on Vogue's list of most desirable waiting lists. All of which sounds rather intimidating and would normally have been enough to put me off, but I was desperate.

It is true that in a typical session you might be sharing equipment with a few exquisite and wounded ballerinas, half the cast of London's latest hit musical, or a fashion designer's muse, but you are just as likely to be sharing it with someone crippled by RSI, or doubled up with scoliosis, or with a lump like me, who hasn't exercised regularly since school.

In the studio, where about eight people will be following an individual programme at any one time, there is an atmosphere of calm concentration, punctuated by raucous badinage and the latest gossip.

By the time I had got to Lesley Ackland, I was a fairly typical wreck. I was frightened to move and I was compensating for the pain in my lower back by gripping other muscles. My shoulders were so tense they could have done service as earrings. My posture was terrible but I didn't have any stomach muscles to hold myself better and my pelvis was out of balance. And because I had lost all spontaneity of movement, I was putting even more pressure on my joints. I needed to develop the muscles to support my back to break the vicious circle.

Like the best teachers, Ackland has a certain indefinable charisma and years of experience. She likes wrecks because they present her with an intellectual challenge. The first thing she did was give me confidence and show me I could move more than I thought without hurting. She taught me to breathe properly and then she devised a programme of simple exercises to stretch the muscles I had been over-tensing and to stengthen my abdominals, which act like a corset for the back and organs. I was able to ditch the neoprene support.

The effect was almost immediate. I felt myself uncurling. After a few sessions I could feel what was wrong with my posture and at least begin to correct it. I quickly developed enough strength in other muscles to do the things I wanted without putting pressure on my back. Although it would build up between visits, at the end of an hour's exercise, the pain would miraculously have disappeared.

On the whole, the exercises are very simple, and while they require concentration only a few need specialist equipment. Most I can do at home in between visits, and this week Lesley publishes a book for those who can't find a teacher near them.

The exercises have seen me through my third pregnancy without significant problems and helped me get back into shape quickly. The damaged joint still aches on and off, but the grinding chronic pain is under control. I have never been able to stick at any exercise regime before, but now I go every week and would no more consider not doing my stretches than not brushing my teeth. If I take a holiday of more than two weeks, the pain returns and pain is a very effective goad.

Like all treatments there are side effects, but with Pilates they happen to be rather nice ones: a flatter stomach, no more wobbly bottom and thighs, a transformed pelvic floor, and better sex. As life sentences go, it could be worse.

Send £3 and an SAE to 16, Elmtree Road, Teddington, Middlesex, TW11 8ST.
