fields.headline: Mind over matter
fields.standfirst: Hundreds are hospitalised after a gas leak - but there's no gas. Meanwhile scores are left seriously ill by a poisoned soft drink - only there's no poison.  Sarah Boseley on the phenomenon of mass delusion
fields.trailText: Hundreds are hospitalised after a gas leak - but there's no gas. Meanwhile scores are left seriously ill by a poisoned soft drink - only there's no poison. Sarah Boseley on the phenomenon of mass delusion
fields.body:
Just over a year ago, a teacher in Tennessee noticed what she described as "a gasoline smell" in her high-school classroom. Soon afterwards she felt ill. She had a headache and nausea, she couldn't breathe properly and felt dizzy. Several pupils developed similar symptoms.

The classroom was evacuated and somebody set off the fire alarm to clear the school. Pupils and staff poured out of the building and watched as firefighters, police and emergency medical teams arrived from three counties, and the teacher and some of her pupils were taken away in an ambulance.

All classes were cancelled. That day, 80 pupils, 19 staff and one relative who had come to pick up a child ended up in casualty; 38 of them were kept in hospital overnight. The school, Warren County High, in McMinnville, was only four years old. Built on farmland, it was virtually taken apart by the fire department, the local gas company and state officials of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

They found nothing. Hundreds of hours were spent on tests which came back negative. An aerial survey was conducted, local caves were explored, air, water and waste were examined, core samples were drilled from the ground around the school. Result? Nothing.

But 186 people in all - there was a second outbreak and the school was closed again five days later - reported symptoms that most believed had been caused by some toxic environmental substance in the school. They all reported an unusual smell, although it was reported in 31 different places in the building. Those who said they smelled it had headaches, dizziness, nausea, drowsiness, tightness in the chest and difficulty breathing. Yet the tests carried out on them in hospital also found nothing.

What was going on? Was this some stealthy toxic substance that leaked in, overcame pupils and staff and disappeared again? Scientists who have investigated the Warren County episode, writing in the New England Journal of Medicine, have now bitten the bullet and said what none of those affected will want to hear - that this was an outbreak of mass psychogenic illness.

It doesn't mean that those who were rushed to hospital did not feel ill. They had real symptoms. But the underlying cause was not a toxic invisible gas, but the fear of one. They were made ill - genuinely ill - by anxiety.

"It is a social phenomenon, often occurring among otherwise healthy people, who suddenly believe they have been made ill by some external factor," write Timothy Jones and colleagues from the Epidemic Intelligence Service . Women and girls are more often affected than men and boys, they say (69% at Warren County). This outbreak had all the ingredients - an environmental scare, fire alarms, anxiety, a huge response from the emergency services which was witnessed by people who then became ill, and intense media speculation about what was going on.

Despite all the reassurances and all the negative scientific reports, people from the school were still reporting persistent headaches more than a month after the outbreak. "Some people believed that the investigation had simply failed to find the real cause of the illness. Paradoxically, in such circumstances, the observation of vigorous investigative activities may reinforce the suspicion that a genuine problem is being covered up," say the authors.

This sort of phenomenon has been happening for as long as people have been afraid of events outside their control. "People always believe they are oppressed. It is a question of who the oppressor is," said Simon Wessely, professor of epidemiological and liaison psychiatry at Guy's, King's & St Thomas's School of Medicine in London. "They seize on explanations that are credible and make sense within their world view: 300 years ago, people believed in possession by demons."

These days, he writes in an editorial in the journal, those demons have been replaced by the evil spirits we most fear and do not understand today - "our contemporary concern about invisible viruses, chemicals and toxins". That we should be afraid is not surprising; the names of Seveso, Bhopal and Chernobyl are enough reason. But to that justifiable concern must be added a suspicion of authority, tainted with tales of cover-up.

The Coca-Cola scare in Belgium last year was finally marked down as another of these episodes - this time christened mass sociogenic rather than psychogenic illness - in a bid to remove the "in the mind" tag which victims so much resent. They hate even more the older description of "mass hysteria" which was used of the Coca-Cola furore by Belgian doctors in the Lancet.

That outbreak affected around 100 people, who complained of stomach cramps, nausea, headaches and palpitations. Millions of cans and bottles were withdrawn from sale. The whole thing cost is thought to have cost Coca-Cola some $900m. But it's not something they particularly want to talk about. They would prefer that people thought it was a minor factory problem which has been put right. The alternative is to say their customers were imagining things. They think they know which is the worse publicity.

Are these outbreaks on the increase? Wessely doubts whether media reporting and the internet have caused an upsurge. "I have a file going back 150 years. I'm tempted to say the internet hasn't increased them. At any time in human history there has been a new technology that has been a threat: it was believed that if the railways went too fast people would asphyxiate because they wouldn't be able to breathe."

But it is possible that increasing fears of bioterrorism may precipitate more of them, particularly in the US. "America has an obsession with chemical and biological terrorism," says Wessely, "because the cold war is over and they don't have a proper enemy any more. There is a Hollywood agenda and it has developed its own legs.

"It is now a major public health concern and they are spending billions of dollars." Yet, he says, major chemical or biological attacks can only be carried out by armies, not individuals. "The nutters aren't clever enough and the clever ones can't do it."

He believes the psychological reaction to the fear could do more damage in social and economic terms than any possible chemical or biological attack is likely to. "In the Tokyo subway attack seven people died. That doesn't bring a nation to its knees." But fear and the illness it breeds could potentially cause immense social and economic disruption, he says.

So how do you deal with a mass psychogenic/sociogenic illness? That's a hard one. Too big a response, as at Warren Grange, and the anxiety levels and numbers falling ill increase. Ignore it and people are convinced something is being covered up. "The challenge is to convey the scientific reality without being seen as blaming or demeaning the victims," writes Wessely. We are nowhere near that yet.

webTitle: Now there are four, as MP3 threatens the record labels

fields.headline: Now there are four, as MP3 threatens the record labels
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Rapid consolidation in the global music industry has left control of publishing and recording in fewer hands than ever before. There are now only four major labels: Time Warner-EMI, Sony, BMG and Universal. Smaller concerns are either being swallowed up or are scrabbling to survive.
fields.body:
Rapid consolidation in the global music industry has left control of publishing and recording in fewer hands than ever before. There are now only four major labels: Time Warner-EMI, Sony, BMG and Universal. Smaller concerns are either being swallowed up or are scrabbling to survive.

But what is really concerning the delegates at the week-long Midem festival, the music industry's annual jamboree in the south of France, is the growth in the importance of the internet to the industry. Online retailers like Amazon.com have shown how effectively the net can be used as a distributor of CDs and music videos, undercutting traditional high street retailers and threatening their profitability.

New technologies like MP3, which enables internet users to download music from the web for free, are challenging traditional distribution, marketing and sales models for the industry. Bands no longer need artist and repertoire departments to promote them, they can do it through the net. Ultimately they may not even need traditional recording deals, just the ability to get their music on to the net where fans can download it.

David Bowie, one of the rock industry's earliest net converts, has predicted that the web will soon make conventional record companies and shops extinct. Fellow converts believe CDs will soon be re placed by music that is digitally delivered from the internet to a PC or disk-less digital mobile music player.

Forrester Research estimates that the market for digitally downloaded music will grow to $1.1bn (£670m) by 2003. Hence America Online's determination to control the music publishing assets held by Time Warner and now EMI.

For the major record labels the net is a distribution channel that throws up many, as yet, unresolved security, copyright, rights and delivery standardisation issues.

MP3, the most popular technology for downloading music over the net, allows users to download music for free and has been widely used in successful promotional campaigns that let listeners hear a sample of an album before deciding whether to buy it. A pre-Christmas promotion on CDnow, which gave Beastie Boys fans the opportunity to create their own DIY compilation albums, increased sales of the group's traditional albums by 265%, CDnow chief executive Clive Mayhew-Begg said.

But the major labels are reluctant to expose their catalogues to MP3 because it is not secure and opens up the possibility of piracy. MP3 faces challenges from the likes of Liquid Audio and Microsoft Windows Media, which offer a secure method of digital delivery. Other firms such as Lucent are marketing their own delivery technologies, making the adoption of an industry standard increasingly unlikely.

The different offerings have already split labels and artists. Last year singer Alanis Morissette agreed a tour sponsorship agreement with MP3 but later opted to offer downloads of her music through the secure Liquid Audio and Microsoft system.

Universal Music Group's Larry Kenswil predicts that the major labels will offer easy to download singles and albums by next Christmas.

EMI has been on an acquisition spree to prepare. Last June it took an equity stake in Musicmaker.com, one of the largest custom-compilation CD and digital download sites. It has since taken a stake in Liquid Audio.

For now digital downloads will remain experimental. MP3 may have overtaken sex as the most commonly entered term in internet search engines and is growing at an exponential rate, but for many net users downloading music remains a slow and technologically baffling process.

webTitle: Amazon adds drugstore to virtual shopping mall

fields.headline: Amazon adds drugstore to virtual shopping mall
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Online shoppers will soon be able to buy toothpaste and deodorant at the same time as books after a deal announced yesterday by Amazon.com, the internet bookseller.
fields.body:
Online shoppers will soon be able to buy toothpaste and deodorant at the same time as books after a deal announced yesterday by Amazon.com, the internet bookseller.

Drugstore.com, which is the market leader for online pharmaceuticals in the United States, will become the first separate company to be prominently displayed on Amazon's home page.

Drugstore.com - which was established in 1998 and floated on the stock market last year - is to pay Amazon $105m (£63.6m) over the next three years for this access to the Seattle-based company's some 1.6m customers.

In return Amazon, which already owns 27% of the drugs company, is to buy another $30m worth of shares, bringing its total investment to 28%.

Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder and chief executive, said yesterday: "We're working to make Amazon.com the only place where you can find anything and everything you might want to buy online."

Bill Curry, a spokesman for Amazon, said that the deal was likely to be the first of many. "We expect more arrangements like this when it makes sense for our customers."

fields.headline: Sweet, but kinda scary
fields.standfirst: She plays victims and psychos, but there's always a touch of film noir about Ashley Judd. She talks to Sarah Gristwood Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Seven years a starlet, never a star? Hollywood's spin on "Three times a bridesmaid, never a bride" usually holds true. But Ashley Judd is proving the exception.
fields.body:
Seven years a starlet, never a star? Hollywood's spin on "Three times a bridesmaid, never a bride" usually holds true. But Ashley Judd is proving the exception. For years she has been famous for her partners (Michael Bolton, Matthew McConaughey, Lyle Lovett, reputedly Robert De Niro), her parentage (the country-and-western Judds) and, yes, even her potential. Everything, in fact, except her movies.

Hollywood-watchers have been forecasting that this would change ever since her debut in Ruby in Paradise, in 1993. Now, at last, it's happened. Double Jeopardy, an apparently unremarkable thriller, has taken $114m in the US alone. Judd's price was around $1m a movie after Kiss the Girls three years ago. Now it has soared to $4m or $5m.

Judd almost never got her big break. Jodie Foster pipped her to the part in Double Jeopardy, but dropped out when she got pregnant. Paramount's preference for Foster was "disappointing," Judd says, "but it's not a casting choice you can argue with. It's not like being passed over for some talentless nitwit who hasn't won the studio two Oscars."

In Double Jeopardy Judd plays a wife who is framed for her husband's murder and out for revenge against the pair who have wronged her. "The film goes way beyond the traditional roles and behaviour of women in movies," she says stoutly. "The part has a lot of spunk."

One's a victim, the other a killer, but there is a certain similarity to the abused psychopath she plays in the yet-to-be-released Eye of the Beholder, opposite Ewan McGregor ("a very sweet kid.") Judd seems to have found her place, and it's wherever the poor ghosts of film noir hang out today. In practical terms that means she often winds up in violent or plot-heavy films (she was a woman living on the edge in Normal Life, and played bank robber Val Kilmer's girlfriend in Heat. She was cast in Natural Born Killers but wound up on the cutting room floor).

There is a knowingness in her face, along with a Southern sweetness. In the flesh - tiny, with chestnut hair - she comes over as intensely focused. Double Jeopardy's director Bruce Beresford says she "latches on to things". Hers is the scary kind of low-key confidence you get among the religious of Hollywood. She is a committed Christian. "All my life," she once said, "I believed that things work to good for all those who are good and who love God."

Stephan Elliott, who directed The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, had a Streep or Sarandon in mind for the role in Eye of the Beholder but says Judd "basically stalked me. She hounded the hell out me for months. She would not give up." Talking to her, you sense that intensity. And anger, maybe.

Judd disclaims much interest in the Hollywood star system. "I don't know because I won't live there." She was an outsider long enough to see the game. "I observe. I can usually understand the castings. The pecking order is standardised."

Now the parts are coming thick and fast. With a couple of so far unseen pictures in the can, she has been signed up to make The Notebook for Jim Sheridan, a love story described as The English Patient meets Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistle Stop Cafe. There's talk of an adaptation of dating novel Animal Husbandry, and her name has been linked with everything from Charlie's Angels to the Basic Instinct sequel.

Judd, aged 31, knows there's a danger that "the more successful you become, the more focused you become on the single most elusive echelon of success." But she's already reached the place to which she aspired when starting out. She's holding that fact in mind. "I know my interests are very much the same as they were back then - I like the same books and the same music - but what has changed is, I'm much more standoffish than I used to be. My love for any art is the same, but my disenchantment with the things contingent around it knows no bounds.

"If you get too involved with a sense of your own stardom, then you're really looking for personal disaster..." She has, of course, the advantage of having seen fame "first-hand and early". She was 14 when the hardship of her early years changed to privilege. The combination has visibly made her what she is today. From a single mother dragging her two daughters around the South in search of work and living on welfare cheques, Naomi Judd and her elder daughter Wynonna became a country-and-western success story. Ashley Judd sang with the band occasionally, but her sights were always set on drama. And she maintains that in film, she still had to make her own way.

"When I went to Hollywood country music was not that big a deal on the West Coast. The way my background helped me was much more personal - I saw that money can't buy you happiness and that nothing is more important than a good night's sleep. I didn't go to Hollywood with a bunch of empty pipe dreams."

Since her LA home burned down in the Malibu fires in 1996, Judd has been based on a 1,000-acre farm in Tennessee, within a mile of Wynonna and Naomi. She spends some time in Scotland with her current partner, racing driver Dario Franchitti. But basically, he's moved to Tennessee. There's a niece and a nephew there, a cat called Buttercup and a dog called Buttermilk. There may have been friction around Naomi Judd's autobiography, Love Can Build a Bridge, but if so, fences have been mended. "Sister says she's going to write her own version of Mom's autobiography [sic] someday, and it's going to be called The Truth," Judd told American Elle - but tolerantly.

Her new position is something "for other people to deal with," she says. I just have to mind my personal life and my private interests and things that nourish me. I have a life. I've been lucky to have, a long time ago, a set of priorities that are more profound and long-lasting than having a movie that opens huge: personal fulfilment, a sense of peace and all of that."

Double Jeopardy is on general release from Friday.

webTitle: Gore romps home in Iowa caucuses but Bush still has work to do

fields.headline: Gore romps home in Iowa caucuses but Bush still has work to do
fields.standfirst: Republican frontrunner faces strong challenge from millionaire Forbes
fields.trailText:
Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W Bush flew out of Des Moines in the
early hours of this morning the clear winners in last night's Iowa caucuses,
after voters in the midwestern plains state cast the first votes of the 
2000 American presidential election campaign.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Des Moines, Iowa
fields.body:
Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W Bush flew out of Des Moines in the early hours of this morning the clear winners in last night's Iowa caucuses, after voters in the midwestern plains state cast the first votes of the 2000 American presidential election campaign.

The two winning candidates, both of whom are backed by their party establishments, confirmed their long-time frontrunner status by beating their various challengers by substantial margins. However, the picture could be dramatically changed in next week's primary in New Hampshire, where both Mr Gore and Mr Bush will be campaigning today.

The biggest winner on a day when settled and fine Iowa winter weather facilitated a high caucus turnout was Vice-President Gore. He crowned an impressive recent campaign fightback by trouncing his only rival, former Senator Bill Bradley, by an unexpectedly large margin of 63% to 35% in the Democratic contest.

Mr Gore, who watched the results come in at his Des Moines hotel headquarters with his wife Tipper, later told supporters that he had won "the biggest victory in the history of the contested caucuses in Iowa". Punching the air at his victory rally, an obviously delighted and relaxed vice-president told the crowd "We've just begun to fight".

Within minutes, Mr Gore was being driven out to Air Force Two to be flown to New Hampshire to resume his contest with Mr Bradley there in the 1 February primary. The candidates meet in what could be a crucial final televised debate of the New Hampshire campaign tomorrow night.

Mr Bradley made clear that his defeat would not cause him to throw in the towel or, more surprisingly, to change a campaigning style which is being criticised for being too aloof for many voters. The former New Jersey senator had "no less confidence that I can win", he told supporters.

"Tonight I view as not an end but a beginning, a beginning of a debate and dialogue for where we're going to take this country," Mr Bradley told NBC television.

Mr Bush, who is the governor of Texas and the son of former President George Bush, claimed a "record shattering victory" in the Iowa Republican race. "This victory marks the beginning of the end of the Clinton era," Mr Bush told cheering supporters. But although Mr Bush finished well ahead of any of his party rivals, the Republican result left many more unanswered questions than did the Democratic contest.

In a six-man contest, Mr Bush took 41% of the votes. The millionaire publisher Steve Forbes finished second with 30%, while the black anti-abortion conservative Alan Keyes was third with 14%, followed by family values campaigner Gary Bauer on 9%, Arizona Senator John McCain on 5% and Utah Senator Orrin Hatch in last place with 1%.

Mr Bush surpassed his stated target, the 37% won by Bob Dole in a six-candidate field in 1988, but his total did not match the combined votes won by Messrs Forbes, Keyes and Bauer, all of whom had criticised Mr Bush as soft on abortion.

Mr Bush's inconclusive victory in Iowa means that the New Hampshire Republican contest is likely to become a crucial test for his reputation as a natural winner. Mr Bush will be hoping to reverse the poll lead in New Hampshire of Mr McCain, who did not campaign in Iowa at all, while simultaneously fighting off the renewed strength of Mr Forbes and Mr Keyes.

Mr Forbes's strong showing enabled him to lay immediate claim to the mantle of conservative frontrunner in the Republican race. "I am pumped," Mr Forbes told supporters. "This is a victory for ideas. New Hampshire is now a tight three-way contest with me fighting the conservative cause against two moderates."

The importance of Mr Forbes's second place was somewhat subverted by the surprisingly strong showing of his fellow conservative Mr Keyes, a staunch Roman Catholic and former Reagan administration ambassador who has climbed from the bottom of the heap to a clear third place largely on the strength of his trenchant moral values oratory.

As so often in the past, the 2000 Iowa caucuses are likely to winnow the field of candidates. Senator Hatch admitted last night that he would have to make an early decision about the future of his campaign, which has failed to evoke any response from the voters. The moral conservative Mr Bauer will also have to ask himself whether there is much point in going on after being eclipsed by both Mr Forbes and Mr Keyes.

The presidential nominations of both parties could be decided on 7 March when 16 states are holding primaries or caucuses. The presidential election will take place on 7 November.

webTitle: Far-right Freedom party poised for power

fields.headline: Far-right Freedom party poised for power
fields.standfirst: Austria's conservatives enter coalition talks with Jörg Haider Coalition talks with Austria's conservatives bring Haider into fold
fields.trailText: Austria's conservatives enter coalition talks with Jörg Haider Coalition talks with Austria's conservatives bring Haider into fold
fields.body:
Austria's far-right Freedom party announced last night that it would begin coalition talks with the conservatives, giving the party's leader, Jörg Haider, possibly the biggest break of his political career.

Earlier Wolfgang Schüssel, the foreign minister and head of the conservative People's party - the junior partner in the former administration - said a stable government could not be formed without the Freedom party.

His comment, carried in today's Austrian newspapers, was a response to the collapse of talks last Friday aimed at renewing the traditional coalition between his party and the leading Social Democrats.

After a three-hour meeting last night, the Freedom party leadership said talks with the People's party should last between a week and 10 days, and that failure would pave the way for fresh elections to resolve the political deadlock since inconclusive elections nearly four months ago.

Asked whether he would seek the chancellorship, Mr Haider said his party favoured him for the post but he was inclined to stay on as governor of Carinthia province.

The gridlock has paved the way for Mr Haider to enter government, despite international concern about his politics, particularly his pro-Nazi remarks. He has been candid about his desire to become chancellor.

In his newspaper commentary, Mr Schüssel said: "A stable government is... still possible, either by a coalition between the Social Democrats and the Freedom party or a coalition between the People's party and the Freedom party."

His party's general secretary, Maria Rauch-Kallat, told today's Die Presse newspaper that she expected talks with the FPO to begin today, "in order that new elections and an unstable situation can be avoided".

President Thomas Klestil, the kingmaker, is still desperate to keep Mr Haider out of government, fearing the harm he could do to Austria's international image and economy. He still backs attempts by the acting chancellor, Viktor Klima, to form a minority government of his Social Democrats with likely support from the Greens. Mr Klima has so far ruled out a coalition with the Freedom party.

Both the conservatives and the Freedom party have opposed such an administration. But after four hours of talks with Mr Klestil on Friday, Mr Haider revealed that he sought to form a government.

In parliamentary elections on October 3 the Social Democrats won 65 of the 183 seats - finishing first but without enough support to form a majority government.

Mr Haider's party, whose platform opposed immigration and rapid European Union expansion, finished second, just ahead of the conservatives in votes. Both hold 52 seats; the Greens have 14.

The conservatives had ruled out a coalition with Mr Haider, but newspapers had reported secret backroom discussions with the far-right party - denied by both parties.

Analysts said Mr Schüssel would have much to gain by joining forces with Mr Haider. His party was under the thumb of the Social Democrats in their 13-year coalition.

President Klestil has come under widespread attack for seeming to disregard the will of the electorate by insisting on a return to the traditional alliance for stability's sake.

"He is ignoring the fact that so many people chose the Free dom party and, however much he tries to suppress that fact, it is not going to go away," a constitutional expert said.

Mr Klestil faces pressure from abroad, notably Israel, whose foreign minister, David Levy, has threatened to break diplomatic ties if the Freedom party enters government.

fields.headline: Country of the Month: Spain
fields.standfirst: Finding a job | Making money | Career prospects | La vida españa In the field: teachers in Spain talk
fields.trailText: Finding a job
fields.body:
Finding a job

'The English language is hugely valued here,' says Lynn Jenkins, a director of one of the English Language Institute Schools in Seville, of English teaching in Spain. 'The TEFL market is booming and the opportunities for career progression are improving.'

Teachers have a huge variety of schools to choose from in Spain. There are the big players at the cutting edge of language instruction such as International House centres. New arrivals include the mushrooming numbers of Wall Street and OpenIng schools offering individuated multimedia programmes of study. At the other end of the scale are the small academies providing extra-curricular lessons to local school children - sometimes run on tiny budgets by people with a very paternalistic view of their responsibilities as employers.

The best times to apply for posts vary from city to city. On the whole, directors of study will be looking to plug gaps from June onwards but they probably will not have a clear idea of student numbers until September and it is then they will start the major teacher recruitment drive. Madrid schools want to hear from teachers in early September and the advice is to follow up your CV with a telephone call to see that it has been received safely. According to Nick Eperon, a TEFL teacher in Seville, it has become much harder to find jobs at schools in the city: 'to get a good post you will need several year's experience and qualifications.' At the Language Institute Schools in Seville they sift through the CVs in May and June. Many of their candidates are already teaching in Spain and take a long weekend break to travel down to Andalusia for interview.

If you are looking for vacancies, the best places to look are the key TEFL magazines and the internet. Most of the big school chains in Spain have their own web pages. If you are already in town, there are local versions of the Yellow Pages to help your research.

It is entirely possible to train as a language teacher in Spain itself. 'For some it is a cheaper option to study for the Certificate [in teaching English as a foreign language] at the International House here in Madrid,' says course tutor Paul Murphy. 'And if you do the course in September, there is the chance you will find yourself work immediately on qualifying.'

'One of the biggest adjustments an English teacher new to Spain has to make is to the shape of the working day,' explains Lynne Jenkins. 'Spaniards fit their language lessons in around their day-time work or schooling and so this can mean early starts and late ends if teachers are unlucky.' This point is echoed by Paul Murphy in Madrid. 'People need to check their hours carefully and spot if there is an awkward gap in the middle of the day splitting their timetable. It is not unheard of for people to start at 8am and finish at 10pm. There is a law in Spain that employers cannot ask people to work times that deny them twelve clear hours off in every 24.'

One of the biggest markets for English lessons is among young adults between 18 and 30, but most schools cater for a wide diversity of age groups. Most language schools receive an influx of school children after 4.30pm once their main school day is done. According to Paul Murphy it is important for teachers to be flexible. 'You cannot guarantee that your students are going to be grown up and as many of the children you do see have been drummed into attending language lessons by their parents there are inevitably some discipline problems to contend with. Many are there under duress and after a long day in school.' A good rule of thumb is to expect twelve people in adult classes and 10 in children's lessons.

Another variation on the theme occurs when parents' associations approach language institutes and arrange for a teacher to travel out to give lessons to pupils at their local school. Similar arrangements occur between language centres and prominent businesses. 'Travelling time is an important issue when you are evaluating your contract,' warns Paul Murphy. 'Try to ensure that your hours take your time on the road into account. A large portion of some teachers' days are spent between classes and Madrid is a big place to traverse.'

There is a lot of talk of people working in Spain illegally. The Partido Popular government is committed to liberalising labour law in favour of employers but teachers are still entitled to take their contracts to be checked by a lawyer of one of the big unions such as Commerciones Obreras (CC.OO). Most language school contracts only run from October to June - and that disqualifies teachers from claiming many Spanish employment rights, such as sick pay - but holiday pay should be available on a pro-rata basis - three weeks is typical. Teachers at Wall Street and OpenIng schools are usually employed all year round. Another tip is to check if your contract contains provision for the payment of a 'finiquito'. This small pay off may be forgotten unless you specifically ask for it.

Making money

Teaching in Spain is not the way to become rich. Salaries are generally in the region of 120,000 pesetas a month and may be higher in Madrid. At the Wall Street schools teachers start on an annual salary of two million pesetas and there are bonus payments for schools whose students maintain their progress in terms of their individual study programmes. Last, it is important to check whether or not any Christmas bonus is being paid piecemeal or in a lump sum - if the former, then it can be a shock to find that you have already spent what you thought was still on the horizon earmarked for your trip home.

Offering private lessons is another way of boosting your earnings. The biggest demand for extra tuition usually occurs in December and May/June when the key public examinations are imminent. Rates of pay range from 1,700 to as much as 4,000 pesetas an hour.

If you want to develop your Spanish skills, consider setting up an 'inter-cambio' by arranging to meet someone to 'exchange' conversation in English for time spent speaking Spanish. Usually people meet in a bar, no money changes hands and if you are lucky you may make a life-long friend. Advertisements for 'inter-cambios' can be found in libraries, in British consulates and on university notice boards. In Seville, you are advised to look in the city's equivalent of Loot - 'Cambalache'. Neil Clarke in Barcelona has a word of warning about inter-cambios. 'They can be rather hit or miss and it can be awkward extricating yourself if you don't like your conversation partner.'

Career prospects

'When I interview candidates for Diploma courses,' says Paul Murphy, ' I am often disappointed how their professional development has been neglected. Too often people acquire initial training and are then left to get on with it. It is no wonder that many TEFL teachers have a Year 3 crisis which convinces them they must return home and start a 'real career'.

The opportunities for promotion are not vast for English teachers in Spain but they are growing. Lynne Jenkins acquired her directorship at a time when the English Language Institute decided to open a new school in the Macarena district of Seville. 'It was a matter of right place, right time,' she explains. 'International House Schools have teacher centres attached,' he adds. 'People receive inset training to help them improve their knowledge and classroom skills.'

'There is a thriving private sector in which many schools claim to offer a bilingual education. This can often be rather a hollow promise.' The advantages of teaching in such places are the slightly better pay (200,000 pesetas a month), more secure contracts and working day-time hours. 'But the contact time expected can be far too high,' says Neil Armstrong. '30 hours a week in the classroom is not uncommon and this inevitably has a knock on effect on the quality of teaching. Private schools are very conscious of their marketing too,' he adds, 'and sell themselves to parents by setting students more tests (evaluaciones) during the year than they would get at a state school. This means more marking for the teacher.'

It is virtually impossible for an English person to work in Spain's state education system. The bureaucratic barriers are legion. All qualifications have to be translated and even then they may not be recognised. Teaching posts are made available through public examinations administered by the city council with the jobs going to those people who achieve the highest grades.

'Life beyond the classroom is very pleasant,' says Nick Eperon in Seville. 'Here we have 300 days of sunshine and sitting outside reading the newspaper is one of life's great joys. Things are definitely more laid back.' The cost of living in Spain tends to vary according to the size of the town you live in. Accommodation will typically absorb about a third of a teacher's salary (45-60,000 pesetas) but if you are prepared to share or 'go-native' in terms of district then the bills will come down. Neil Clarke in Barcelona is keen to warn newcomers away from letting agencies: 'They can be a complete rip off - in exchange for a hefty sum you receive a list of useless addresses and there is no comeback.' The best tactic is to check the local equivalent of Exchange and Mart - in Barcelona this is 'Primera Mar' and in Madrid 'Sugunda Mana'. You will be expected to pay a deposit which can be as much as two months rent. This is known as the 'sianza' or trust. Some schools will lend teachers the money they need to secure accommodation. It is important not to be fobbed off at the end of a tenancy with promises of the deposit being sent on - get it while you are still in town.

The best way to save on your shopping bill is to avoid El Corte Ingles (the equivalent of Marks and Spencers) and go for the markets and the discount warehouses such as the Dia chain. 'But you need to know the systems or you will never get served,' explains Neil Clarke. 'In the markets ensure your place in the queue is secure by asking 'quien es la ultima' and keeping an eye on this person.'

All teachers speak of the night life in Spain, which starts late and goes on to the early hours. Many clubs do not open until 1 or 2am. And life revolves around the street with people meeting in bars for tapas and to drink wine or copas with friends. 'But,' warns Nick Eperon, 'do not be upset if the person that was your best buddy the night before is cool the next time you see him. That is the way with people in the south. I have been in Seville for ten years and it still takes me by surprise.'

fields.headline: Bigger and bumpier than ever
fields.standfirst: Jack Schofield talks to Toy Story's John Lasseter, the Walt Disney of the computer age
fields.trailText: John Lasseter walked into his suite in a London hotel this week with two superstars tucked under his arm. Or at least, toy versions of two superstars, Woody and Buzz Lightyear.
fields.body:
John Lasseter walked into his suite in a London hotel this week with two superstars tucked under his arm. Or at least, toy versions of two superstars, Woody and Buzz Lightyear. They rocketed to fame five years ago in Toy Story, the first full-length computer-animated feature, and now they're going to infinity and beyond in Toy Story 2, cheered on by a genial, soft-spoken geek in a Hawaiian-style Woody-themed shirt.

Lasseter, who directed both movies, doesn't need to be told that Toy Story 2 is one of the few sequels that's better than the original. In the US it grossed £35m in its first three days. In box office terms, that put Toy Story 2 in fourth place on the all-time list.

The film is a virtually perfect merchandising vehicle. Mr Potato Head, Slinky Dog, Barrel of Monkeys, Etch-A-Sketch, Barbie and other favourites don't just appear in scenes thanks to back-room product placement deals: they're integral to the story. The Toy Story 2 computer game has already been launched, and the spin-offs will ultimately generate far more money than the cinema screenings. Three successes in a row - A Bug's Life was the other - have established Lasseter as the Walt Disney of the computer age. Indeed, it was in the Walt Disney feature animation division that he learned his trade for five years after he graduated from university until, in 1984, fascinated by computer graphics, he left to join Pixar Animation Studios. But, as Lasseter is the first to admit, the computers are a means to an end.

"To me the story and the characters are the most important things," he says. "They dictate technical development, everything. The goal is to let the audience get swept away, and not really think about the technology." Disney would certainly have agreed with that. But the computer animation is still important. "I fell in love with the imagery you could achieve," Lasseter says. "Truly 3-D images that have shadows and reflections and textures."

Where Lasseter differs from the special-effects people is that he's not trying to fool you into thinking something is real when it's not. Rex, Lasseter's neurotic toy dinosaur, for instance, wouldn't cut it in Jurassic Park. "We'll always stay in the caricature world," he says. "If you make sure that the audience knows the world you're creating doesn't exist, then you can use this photorealistic technology and make it seem as believable as possible. The magic is that the audience can sit there and say: 'I know this doesn't exist, but boy, it sure looks real!'"

Making it look real requires huge amounts of computer power and a lot of attention to detail. "Toy Story 2 exists in a bigger world than Toy Story, and that's due to increases in computer power. The street scenes, the airport, the baggage area: those are things we could not have done five years ago," Lasseter says. "In hand-drawn animation, when a character goes into a new environment, it's just a new painting that's created. With us, as long as the characters stay in the same environment, it's like a live action set built within the computer. But in Toy Story 2 the toys get out on the road and go from place to place, and each time they go to a new place we have to build a whole new set."

The extra computer power allows more imperfections to be introduced to the "sets". According to Lasseter, "inherently the computer likes to make things perfect: perfectly clean, perfect edges, flat. It's very geometric - which is why people have said in the past that computer graphics look cold. So we put a tremendous amount of effort into making things have nicks, and there are bumps and nicks and marks all over the place."

If you love computer graphics you'll have a lot of fun looking out for the litter and dust, the way an earlier generation watched the shadows move in Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. And there's more fun to be had spotting references to Star Wars, Forrest Gump and other blockbusters. "We love movies," Lasseter says. "We put those references in for the pure fun of it. If people get them, great, and if they don't, well, it doesn't ruin the story."

The stage must be set for Toy Story 3 - an exciting prospect, since, unlike traditional film directors, Lasseter can look forward to having ever better tools to work with.

Toy Story 2 is on general release from February 4.

'Barcelona is a great city - everything you could want in a small space. Getting to know Catalans may take longer but relationships seem to be more durable... You have to be flexible. At some point in the week you may be giving a one-to-one class to a senior executive in a plush office and then later you will be with a gaggle of school children... The choice is between working in a school where you can get block hours but these tend to be kids' classes or going for business clients which leads to a more disjointed timetable. Teaching adults is my preference - they are more forthcoming. The pitfalls are the usual ones. Schools can exploit you and wages in Barcelona don't increase because there are always new teachers arriving - Easyjet has a lot to answer for. There are hundreds of language schools in Barcelona and it is important not to pick one that is struggling because your classes will be small and there is always the chance students will drop out leaving you high and dry after Christmas.'
Neil Clarke, whose teaching experience includes a commercial contract at the headquarters of the Caixa Bank.

'I was 29 [when I started teaching EFL] and since then I have worked in a number of schools including a stint at one in Huelva. It was a small place and it was possible to save money there and the beach-life was fun. But I became disillusioned with the summer lay off which was disruptive.

One week my hours will be 8am to 3.30pm and the next week they are 3.30pm -10pm. The day is peppered with half-hour breaks. My principal duty is offering group classes to check students' progress. There are usually about five people to a class. All the lessons are set down and although there is scope for individual teaching styles, the method frees you from the many hours of preparation and marking that other language teachers face. The school encourages students to take workshops which teachers can devise and there are teacher/student club events such as trips to the cinema. Seville is a great place to live but is it quite conservative. Co-habiting is not approved of and people tend to live at home until their thirties. In the cold months families still gather around the main table to watch television - their legs and feet under a thick table cloth being heated by a brasero - a heater, while the top halves of their bodies freeze.'
Paul Rogers, who teaches at the OpenIng school in Seville, where students follow personal learning plan via computer programmes

The school encourages students to take workshops which teachers can devise and there are teacher/student club events such as trips to the cinema. Seville is a great place to live but is it quite conservative. Co-habiting is not approved of and people tend to live at home until their thirties. In the cold months families still gather around the main table to watch television - their legs and feet under a thick table cloth being heated by a brasero - a heater, while the top halves of their bodies freeze.' Paul Rogers, who teaches at the OpenIng school in Seville, where students follow personal learning plan via computer programmes

fields.headline: Hollywood hat-trick for British director
fields.trailText: The director Sam Mendes, who made Hollywood history yesterday by winning three Golden Globes for his debut film American Beauty, confessed the key to his success was a piece of whispered advice from Steven Spielberg - "wear sensible shoes".
fields.body:
The director Sam Mendes, who made Hollywood history yesterday by winning three Golden Globes for his debut film American Beauty, confessed the key to his success was a piece of whispered advice from Steven Spielberg - "wear sensible shoes".

American Beauty, his scabrous suburban comedy about a middle-aged adman stuck in a stale job and staler marriage, won best feature-length drama, best director and best screenplay - putting it at the head of the pack for the Oscars in March.

Mendes, 34, from London, who admitted he knew "less than nothing" about film-making when Spielberg's studio DreamWorks asked him to direct it, thanked his stars Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening "for trusting me", and Spielberg for his tips on footwear and "letting me make the movie I wanted to make".

Champagne flowed yesterday at the Donmar Warehouse theatre, London, where Mendes is artistic director and he first directed his Tony award-winning version of Cabaret, which made his name in America.

But the biggest surprise of the night was the victory of another star of the London stage. Janet McTeer beat Sharon Stone and Julia Roberts to the best comedy actress globe for Tumbleweeds, a low-budget caper in which she plays a hippy, dippy Southern belle kept in line by her old-before-her-time daughter. "This is my first time at something like this," said McTeer, who won a Tony last year for her Broadway performance in A Doll's House.

Veteran pop star Phil Collins completed a British hattrick by winning the best original song with You Will Be In My Heart, from the new Tarzan movie. "All of us in this room know the flows and the ebbs of careers," he said. "Actors know this, musicians know this - and I would like to thank you for making me feel like my career is in a flow."

British films had dominated the shortlists for the Globes - once seen as a jamboree, but regarded now as a reliable guide to Oscar form - but neither Anthony Minghella's much-fancied The Talented Mr Ripley nor Neil Jordan's The End Of The Affair won anything. Even so, both are expected to be in the running with Mike Leigh's Topsy-Turvy when the Oscar nominations are announced in a fortnight.

The most poignant moment at the unusually subdued ceremony in Los Angeles came when Michael J Fox was named best TV actor for the comedy Spin City, which Parkinson's disease has forced him to quit. With his voice cracking, Fox said: "Who knows, you may be here next year. I won't."

Earlier, Denzel Washington had set the sombre tone after winning best actor for the miscarriage-of-justice tale The Hurricane. He invited Rubin "Hurricane" Carter, the former boxer he played, and who spent 20 years in prison for a crime he did not commit, to join him on stage and said: "This man is love."

Spanish film-maker Pedro Almodovar did his best to revive the Globes' reputation for wit and waywardness by ignoring the producers' increasingly frantic pleas for him to wind up his speech after winning best foreign-language film for All About My Mother.

He compared himself to Barbra Streisand, confessed to being "a dictator" and apologised to his brother and producer Agustin. "It is quite profitable to be my producer but sometimes it is not so easy to be my brother," he said. With the stage managers now making exaggerated gestures at him, he added: "This is one of the moments when you are not responsible ... when you behave like crazy. Because not every day does Hollywood give you a present like this, so I don't know what that means, adios."

Who won what at the Globes

Best drama: American Beauty

Best drama actress: Hilary Swank for Boys Don't Cry

Best actor: Denzel Washington for The Hurricane

Best musical or comedy: Toy Story 2

Best actress in a musical or comedy: Janet McTeer for Tumbleweeds

Best actor in musical or comedy: Jim Carrey for Man On The Moon

Best foreign language film: All About My Mother

Best supporting actress: Angelina Jolie for Girl, Interrupted

Best supporting actor: Tom Cruise for Magnolia

Best director: Sam Mendes for American Beauty

Best screenplay: Alan Ball for American Beauty

Best original score: Ennio Morricone for The Legend of 1900

Best original song: Phil Collins, You'll Be In My Heart from Tarzan

fields.headline: Gore's big mo
fields.standfirst:
Former New York correspondent Mark Tran analyses the latest developments in the US presidential race
Plus: God's Army
fields.trailText: American politicians and pundits call it the "big mo", an inelegant but apt term for a candidate who has the momentum for the next hurdle in the gruelling US presidential campaign.
fields.body:
American politicians and pundits call it the "big mo", an inelegant but apt term for a candidate who has the momentum for the next hurdle in the gruelling US presidential campaign.

After the Iowa caucuses, Democrat vice-president Al Gore is the man with the wind in his sails. He thrashed Bill Bradley, capturing 63% of the vote, to 35% for his opponent, even though Mr Bradley took the Iowa caucuses very seriously, devoting more time and money to the contest caucuses than the vice-president.

But the voters did not take to the tall, courtly former senator. They faulted him for a lack of spirit and for running a ramshackle campaign in an operation where sound organisation is crucial. The omens for Bradley in New Hampshire, the first primary on February 1, do not look promising either. After leading there in the polls for months, he now trails Mr Gore.

Bradley initially enjoyed a honeymoon with the press when he presented himself as an alternative to the rather dull Mr Gore. But Mr Bradley is no live wire himself, despite his past career as a star basketball player for the New York Knicks.

These past weeks have shown that while he was a whiz on the court, he's a plodder on the campaign trail. Just as Walter Mondale once sank Gary Hart by asking "Where's the beef?" in the 1984 Democratic nomination, so Mr Gore may have inflicted irreparable damage to his rival when he accused Mr Bradley of refusing to "stay and fight" the Republicans by leaving the Senate in 1996.

Mr Gore was floundering last year, to the point where President Bill Clinton expressed doubts over his ability to win. But Mr Bradley's challenge has forced the vice-president to shake off the complacency of the politically anointed. Mr Gore has shown he should not be easily written off. It was the vice-president who neutered Ross Perot on the Larry King show by branding the eccentric billionaire a protectionist in the debate on Nafta, the North American free trade area.

On the Republican side, George W Bush, the Texas governor, also won comfortably. Although he described his victory in Iowa as "the beginning of the end of the Clinton era", Mr Bush's position is not as secure as Mr Gore's.

Mr Bush goes to New Hampshire with a pack of Republicans baying at his heels. Magazine publisher Steve Forbes did well enough to want to continue the fight next week. Mr Forbes and Alan Keyes, the fiery anti-abortion activist, who did surprisingly well in Iowa, can be expected to siphon off votes from the right, while Arizona senator John McCain, who did not compete in Iowa, is to come at Mr Bush from the other direction.

Mr McCain, a war hero imprisoned during the Vietnam war, poses a greater threat to Mr Bush than Mr Bradley does to Al Gore. Although the shine has gone off Mr MrCain the longer the campaign has dragged on, he still is a great favourite with the press for his easy and irreverent style, while his best-selling memoirs attest to his popularity with the public.

McCain skipped Iowa to focus on New Hampshire, which has a tradition for upsets, and holds a three to six-point lead over Mr Bush. A win or a strong second place could make Mr McCain a real contender.

But the odds are against the maverick senator. Mr Bush has the Republican establishment in his pocket - or is it vice versa? - and stacks of money. The front-loaded nature of the race, with key primaries bunched together on March 7, does not lend itself to the kind of guerrilla tactics that would favour an underdog candidacy like Mr McCain's.

So the odds are that in the end it will be a contest between Mr Gore and Mr Bush to restore a presidency tainted by a second-rate sex scandal.

Related documentary
The US elections: special report

God's Army

Order has been restored in Ratchaburi, 75 miles west of Bangkok, after Thai forces stormed a hospital where Burmese rebels trapped hundreds of patients, visitors and staff in a 22-hour hostage drama.

The God's Army rebels, who follow a pair of 12-year-old cigar-smoking twins, did not exactly win over the Thai public by choosing a hospital as a target and most paid with their lives in this exercise of futility.

But not quite. The episode reminded the world of the plight of the Karen tribes to which the rebels belonged. The Karens, who inhabit the mountainous jungle along the border between Burma and Thailand, have been consistently persecuted by the Burmese authorities for their Christian beliefs. Misguided as it was, the gesture was also the act of a desperate and forgotten people.

Related stories
Army storms hospital held by rebels
God's Army holds hundreds hostage
The ringmasters of terror who tame a suffering nation of 48m

webTitle: Jury sent out in GP murder trial

fields.headline: Jury sent out in GP murder trial
fields.standfirst: Doctor accused of killing 15 female patients awaits verdict
fields.trailText: The jury trying Harold Shipman, the family doctor accused of murdering 15 of his patients, will resume their deliberations today as they try to reach verdicts after hearing evidence for 10 weeks.
fields.body:
The jury trying Harold Shipman, the family doctor accused of murdering 15 of his patients, will resume their deliberations today as they try to reach verdicts after hearing evidence for 10 weeks.

At the end of the 52nd day of the trial at Preston crown court yesterday, the seven men and five women were sent home after meeting in their room for five and a half hours. They were warned by the judge, Mr Justice Forbes, not to make contact with each other overnight to discuss the case, nor to talk about it to anyone else.

The press benches and the public gallery were packed at the beginning of the day as the jury filed out of their seats at 10.37am carrying black court files and their own pads of notes.

Some left behind the red cushions that had given them some comfort while sitting for extended periods on the hard wooden benches.

Dr Shipman, sat in the brass-railed dock in the panelled courtroom between two prison officers, with his wife Primrose and son Richard in the gallery behind him. Nearby sat relatives of some of Shipman's alleged victims. Senior detectives who had led the inquiry were also in court.

The crown alleges that Dr Shipman, 54, whose practice is in Hyde, Greater Manchester, killed 15 of his female patients between 1995 and 1998 by injecting them with lethal doses of diamorphine.

During the trial the court heard that traces of morphine were found in nine bodies that were exhumed. The prosecution claims six other women, whose bodies were cremated, were murdered the same way. It said Dr Shipman killed them because he enjoyed having the power of life and death over them. The prosecution also says that Dr Shipman forged the will of Kathleen Grundy, an 81-year-old former mayoress of Hyde, in order to benefit from her £386,000 estate.

He denies all the charges.

Wearing a light brown suit and striped tie, Dr Shipman watched as the judge completed his summing-up, which had lasted almost 50 hours spread over two weeks.

Mr Justice Forbes reminded the jury members that the burden of proof had rested on the prosecution for the entire duration of the trial and that they had to be sure of Shipman's guilt.

"Nothing else will do," he said. Dr Shipman did not have to prove anything.

He also reminded them to judge the case only on the evidence. "You must not speculate or be drawn into speculation," he told them. "You must put out of your mind anything that you may have heard, read or seen outside the court."

The judge asked for unanimous verdicts and added: "These counts do not stand or fall together. You must deliver a separate verdict in respect of each count on this indictment."

The press and public remained in the court lobby until 4.17pm when the clerk summoned the jury back so that members could be sent home.

fields.headline: Democrats
fields.trailText: Al Gore
fields.body:
Al Gore

With a buoyant economy, Al Gore should be a sure thing for president, a job for which he is eminently qualified. The vice president knows his stuff about defence, the Internet - although he did not invent it as he once boasted - and he is an expert on the environment, having written a best-seller on the subject. But on the campaign trail he is alternatively stiff or wildly over the top.

Mr Gore comes across as an uptight school prefect and his efforts to be cool have backfired amusingly. He once claimed to be the model for Oliver in Love Story, which only underlines how out of touch he is. But the real millstone around his neck is Bill Clinton. The president survived the Monica Lewinsky scandal, but Americans resent him for having tarnished the dignity of the office. Mr Gore may be blameless, but he rose with Bill Clinton and he may well be dragged down by him.

Bill Bradley

It's a sign of Mr Gore's vulnerability that the basketball star turned senator has emerged as a viable candidate, even though his lack of brio makes Mr Gore look like a party animal. Worthy and deadly dull, Mr Bradley wouldn't normally get a second look, but there are enough Democrats who fear that Mr Gore is so tainted that Mr Bradley would be an acceptable fallback.

The New Jersey senator retired in 1997, declaring that "politics is broken." Now he thinks he can fix them. He makes a lot of the fact that he played with blacks during his basketball years, saying he would be a man who can bring people together. He has performed more than creditably by raising $12 mmillion, two thirds of Mr Gore's total.

fields.headline: Republicans
fields.trailText: George W. Bush
fields.body:
George W. Bush

There hasn't been such a strong favourite at this early stage for a very long time. The Republican answer to Bill Clinton, Mr Bush appeals to a broad political spectrum. He has stayed deliberately vague on the issues, but preaches "compassionate conservatism," with government caring for society's most vulnerable citizens in an economy in transition.

Smoother than his notoriously tongue-tied dad, but has made some gaffes. He confused Slovakia and Slovenia. Expressed concern for the Grecians and the East Timorians. But the US public forgives those it embraces, like Ronald Reagan. Has winner written all over him.

John McCain

Vietnam war hero, imprisoned in Hanoi Hilton for five years. A maverick, he has clashed with his own party on campaign finance reform, tobacco legislation and Kosovo, where he advocated the use of ground troops. Well-liked by the media, which partly explains why he is Bush's most serious candidate.

Steve Forbes

Money is no object for the publisher of Forbes magazine. He spent $36 million dollars in his failed 1996 campaign. This time Mr Forbes has gone out of his way to woo the religious right and to establish a grass roots organisation, which he lacked last time. Margaret Thatcher is a supporter and has accompanied him to Iowa. Conservative on social issues, Mr Forbes is best-known for his advocacy of a flat tax.

Pat Buchanan

This is the third run at the White House for this crotchety former journalist and political commentator, who rails against globalisation, the United Nations, immigration, affirmative action and abortion. He still preaches the same message of economic nationalism and blames unfair trading practices for the decline in the US industrial and manufacturing base. This time his support could drained by other uncompromising conservatives like activist Gary Bauer and Senator Chris Smith of New Hampshire.

webTitle: Amnesty goes to court on Pinochet

fields.headline: Amnesty goes to court on Pinochet
fields.trailText: Human rights groups will today launch a legal challenge to Jack Straw's decision that he is "minded" to halt the extradition proceedings against the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet.
fields.body:
Human rights groups will today launch a legal challenge to Jack Straw's decision that he is "minded" to halt the extradition proceedings against the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet.

Amnesty International and various other human rights groups will lodge papers at the high court in London seeking leave for a judicial review of the home secretary's decision on the grounds that the procedures he has employed are unfair and against natural justice.

A judge is expected to hear the appeal tomorrow. Last night the home office confirmed it was aware of the action and said Mr Straw would delay making a final decision on the issue until the judicial review proceedings had been completed.

Geoffrey Bindman, the lawyer representing the various human rights groups, said the legal challenge was being made now because of fears there would be too little time to seek judicial review of any final decision by Mr Straw before the general was whisked out of the country. A Chilean air force jet has been waiting on the tarmac at Bermuda airport since last week, waiting to implement "operation return" when and if confirmation comes that extradition proceedings against Gen Pinochet have been halted.

Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture, the Redress Trust and the Association of Relatives of the Disappeared will make their legal bid on three counts: the general procedures used by the home secretary to reach his decision were not fair; the failure to disclose details of the medical reports on which Mr Straw based his decision meant parties were not able to challenge the findings; and concern over the choice of experts who conducted the medical tests on the general.

In particular, there was concern that an old-age psychiatrist was not involved in the tests, which were carried out earlier this month and which Mr Straw said "unequivocally and unambiguously" ruled the 84-year-old former dictator was unfit to stand trial.

The move to seek leave to appeal came after a day of frantic manoeuvres by those hoping to stop the general from returning to Chile.

For a while it appeared the Belgian government, which along with Spain, France and Switzerland has a warrant out for Gen Pinochet's arrest, was going to make the first legal move.

But after the Belgian authorities indicated they would not challenge Mr Straw until after he had made his final decision the human rights groups decided to take the law into their own hands. The papers were due to have been lodged yesterday afternoon, but "last minute glitches" held up proceedings until today.

fields.bodyText: Human rights groups will today launch a legal challenge to Jack Straw's decision that he is "minded" to halt the extradition proceedings against the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet. Amnesty International and various other human rights groups will lodge papers at the high court in London seeking leave for a judicial review of the home secretary's decision on the grounds that the procedures he has employed are unfair and against natural justice. A judge is expected to hear the appeal tomorrow. Geoffrey Bindman, the lawyer representing the various human rights groups, said the legal challenge was being made now because of fears there would be too little time to seek judicial review of any final decision by Mr Straw before the general was whisked out of the country. webTitle: The ringmasters of terror who tame a suffering nation of 48m

fields.headline: The ringmasters of terror who tame a suffering nation of 48m
fields.trailText: Repression, brutality and terror are watchwords of the Burmese military junta, in which two dozen generals control the minds, if not the hearts, of 48m people.
fields.body:
Repression, brutality and terror are watchwords of the Burmese military junta, in which two dozen generals control the minds, if not the hearts, of 48m people.

Since coming to power in 1962, 16 years after the country won its independence from Britain, the generals have sealed the nation off from the rest of the world. Only North Korea matches Burma in the way it cocoons its people from outside influences.

They have done it through force. Thousands of people have been slaughtered, tens of thousands more subjected to years of hard labour and democratic movements have been all but eliminated.

In 1988, the army crushed a pro-democracy uprising and two years later ignored the results of the general election that gave 82% of the vote to the National League for Democracy led by the Oxford-educated Aung San Suu Kyi.

She was put under house arrest but continued to campaign from her gilded cage. The following year, in 1991, she was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize but democracy remains an elusive dream. Pro-democracy campaigners are still regularly imprisoned on the flimsiest of pretexts and free elections are unlikely to be held for decades.

The only changes have been cosmetic. In 1997, the generals decided their government's name, the state law and order restoration council - Slorc - sounded too harsh, so they renamed it the state peace and development council.

Other alterations include formally renaming the country Myanmar. Rangoon has become Yangon.

Few countries choose to trade with Burma and tough sanctions remain in force against it. But despite the lack of funds, the generals spend more than a third of the national budget on the military while more than 25% of the population is fighting for survival below the poverty line.

Burma's most lucrative export is heroin. Last week the generals took foreign journalists to a site where acres of opium poppies were being destroyed and 50,000 people resettled.

But, as with the name changes, few people believe it will result in any substantial improvements.

The country's intolerance of interference in its affairs is reflected by the seven years' hard labour imposed on a British protester, Rachel Goldwyn, 28, for singing a pro-democracy song in the street.

She was freed after serving two months. On her return to Britain she described how she had been subjected to pyschological abuse. A fellow human rights protester, Ko Aung, had been kept in a 20ft-deep pit for six days with a rotting human corpse.

Another Briton, James Mawdsley, 26, is serving a 17-year sentence in Kengtung prison for distributing anti-government literature.

Mr Mawdsley had been arrested on two previous occasions in Burma but was released after promising never to return.

He has said he was tortured during his second arrest, when he was released after 99 days in solitary confinement. He was inspired by Aung San Suu Kyi to work non-violently for democracy in Burma. After he was sentenced in September, he decided not to appeal.

fields.headline: God's Army holds hundreds hostage
fields.standfirst: 12-year-olds' fighters seize hospital in protest against Burma regime
fields.trailText: Hundreds of terrified Thai patients spent last night as hostages after their hospital was stormed by guerrillas from a Burmese rebel group commanded by a pair of 12-year-old cigar-smoking and gun-wielding twins.
fields.body:
Hundreds of terrified Thai patients spent last night as hostages after their hospital was stormed by guerrillas from a Burmese rebel group commanded by a pair of 12-year-old cigar-smoking and gun-wielding twins.

The insurgents, wearing military fatigues and balaclavas and brandishing automatic rifles, planted booby traps around the hospital in Ratchaburi, 75 miles west of Bangkok. They threatened to blow it up if the Thai army did not meet their demands.

As the drama unfolded it became clear that the threats were not to be taken lightly. The guerrillas are motivated by a powerful cocktail of Christian militancy, decades of ethnic persecution, and fanatical loyalty to their child commanders, Johnny and Luther Htoo.

For the foot soldiers of God's Army, the semi-literate boys, who are barely taller than their automatic rifles, have mystical powers and are virtual deities.

The legend that has grown around them was planted three years ago during a massive Burmese military offensive against the Karen tribes to which the God's Army guerrillas belong. The tribes, whom the Burmese authorities have consistently persecuted for their Christian beliefs and desire for ethnic autonomy, inhabit the mountainous jungle along the border between Burma and Thailand. Village after village was destroyed as hundreds of Karen fighters were killed, dozens of women raped and thousands fled in the face of overwhelming odds.

Only two people, so the legend goes, stood their ground. Johnny and Luther - then aged nine - refused to flee and instead launched a counter attack, killing numerous Burmese soldiers as they overran a fortified military position.

No one knows how much truth there is to the story. But the members of God's Army are convinced that Johnny and Luther are nvincible and can dodge bullets and step on landmines without setting them off.

In an interview last month with Associated Press Television News, the boys said they had lost count of how many Burmese soldiers they had killed. The interviewers were struck by their lack of emotion.

"I have never cried," Luther said. "Why would a man cry?" He then let off a few rounds from his AK47.

Despite being twins, the boys are far from identical. "They are very different in character," said Jerry Harmer of APTN. "Johnny looks like a girl. He has an angelic feminine face and long black hair. Luther, meanwhile is a psycho. He has an unpredictable, volatile character. The front part of his head is shaved and the back part has long straggly hair."

Their father claims to have had a vision before they were born in which it was revealed to him that his sons would grow up to be great leaders. Their mother's whereabouts are unknown.

The boys now com mand a guerrilla army formed partly of child soldiers. "It's weird to see this gaggle of smiley, laughing children going round with guns," Mr Harmer said. The third-in-command is even younger than the twins, a boy who earned the title Black Tongue after suffering a deforming tropical illness.

All three boys are heavy smokers, but otherwise they lead a highly regulated life. Alcohol, swearing, pork and eggs are among the items the young fundamental Christians have banned. There are also thought to be strict rules about liaisons with the opposite sex.

It was thought that the boys were not among the hostage takers at the hospital yesterday. But observers of the God's Army detected their stamp on the guerrillas' demands.

Top of the list of five demands was that Thailand should grant the Karen people a refuge from the relentless onslaught of the Burmese army. They claimed that far from supporting the Karen insurgency, the Thai army had shelled their compounds, killing up to 300 people.

Yesterday's drama began at 7.30am when a dozen adult God's Army soldiers arrived at the hospital after a 40-mile journey on a hijacked bus from the Burmese border. About 200 staff and 600 patients and visitors were taken hostage.

"We want to tell the world how the Karen and Burmese refugees live during the fighting," one of the guerrillas, named Nui, said. "Do not be worried. We will not hurt any hostages."

The gunmen appeared to keep their word during hours of protracted negotiations with senior government figures and army commanders. Fifty hostages were released, mainly elderly people but also a pregnant woman and a five-year-old boy. Dozens of others managed to escape.

Prasert Panpongpaew, aged 63, a diabetic recuperating from a leg operation, was among patients who escaped at after no gunmen appeared in their ward. "We helped each other get up and down the stairs and outside," he said.

The Thai authorities find themselves in a serious dilemma. The Burmese government is furious with them for allowing five students - calling themselves the Vigorous Burmese Student Warriors - who seized the Burmese embassy in Bangkok last October, to escape by helicopter and take refuge with the God's Army guerrillas.

The Thais made some concessions during the afternoon. Lieutenant General Taweep Suwanasingha, the regional army chief, said that shelling of God's Army positions would stop, and that unarmed refugees could enter Thailand for medical treatment. However he stressed that no Thai doctors would be sent into Burma and no one carrying weapons would be allowed to enter Thailand.

Last night there was no sign that the crisis was drawing to a conclusion.

Mr Harmer said that the situation on the border must be desperate for the God's Army insurgents to have resorted to seizing the hospital. "If they've been driven to this they must have taken a real pounding. They could well be on the brink of oblivion," he said.

It is not known who finances the God's Army. The much more established Karen National Union used to raise money by levying taxes on goods crossing the border. But that ended after one of the many Burmese army offensives seized much of the group's land.

"They're probably existing on very little," said Mr Harmer.

webTitle: Army storms hospital held by rebels

fields.headline: Army storms hospital held by rebels
fields.trailText: Thai security forces early this morning stormed a hospital where                                                                 guerrillas from a Burmese rebel group commanded by a pair of                                                                 12-year-old cigar-smoking and gun-wielding twins had trapped                                                                 hundreds of patients, visitors and staff in a 22-hour hostage                                                                 drama.
fields.body:
Thai security forces early this morning stormed a hospital where guerrillas from a Burmese rebel group commanded by a pair of 12-year-old cigar-smoking and gun-wielding twins had trapped hundreds of patients, visitors and staff in a 22-hour hostage drama.

All the hostages were freed and nine rebels were reported killed. Automatic weapons fire and explosions thudded through the night skies, possibly from grenades or explosives and mines that the gunmen had rigged around the hospital in Ratchaburi, 75 miles west of Bangkok, after taking it over yesterday morning.

They had threatened to blow it up if Thailand did not grant the Karen tribes to which the rebels belong a refuge from the onslaught of the Burmese army. They also claimed that, far from supporting the Karen insurgency against the Burmese regime, the Thai army had shelled rebel areas, killing up to 300 people.

At about 5.40am local time this morning, trucks and jeeps filled with Thai police and soldiers sped into the floodlit hospital compound and helicopters circled overhead. About 10 explosions were heard.

Sporadic gunfire could still be heard in the compound more than an hour after the commando assault.

"All the hostages are safe," a senior Thai army officer at the scene said. "Nine hostage-takers were killed; the others fled," said Lieutenant General Taweep Suwannasingh. "We are looking for them."

A government spokesman, Akapol Sorasuchart, told the ITV television network that there were believed to be 16 terrorists involved in the hospital siege, and that the Thai authorities took the decision this morning "to clear the situation as soon as possible".

As the drama unfolded yesterday it had become clear that the rebel threats were not to be taken lightly. The guerrillas, wearing military fatigues and balaclavas and brandishing automatic rifles, were motivated by a powerful cocktail of Christian militancy, decades of ethnic persecution, and fanatical loyalty to their child commanders, Johnny and Luther Htoo.

For the foot soldiers of God's Army, the semi-literate boys, who are barely taller than their automatic rifles, have mystical powers and are virtual deities. The legend that has grown around them was planted three years ago during a massive Burmese military offensive against the Karen tribes to which the God's Army guerrillas belong.
