Only two people, so the legend goes, stood their ground. Johnny and Luther - then aged nine - refused to flee and instead launched a counter attack, killing numerous Burmese soldiers as they overran a fortified position.

No one knows how much truth there is to the story. But the members of God's Army are convinced that Johnny and Luther are invincible and can dodge bullets and step on landmines without setting them off.

In an interview last month with Associated Press Television News, the boys said they had lost count of how many Burmese soldiers they had killed. The interviewers were struck by their lack of emotion.

"I have never cried," Luther said. "Why would a man cry?" He then let off a few rounds from his AK47.

Despite being twins, the boys are far from identical. "They are very different in character," said Jerry Harmer of APTN. "Johnny looks like a girl. He has an angelic feminine face and long black hair. Luther, meanwhile is a psycho. He has an unpredictable, volatile character. The front part of his head is shaved and the back part has long straggly hair."

Their father claims to have had a vision before they were born in which it was revealed to him that his sons would grow up to be great leaders. Their mother's whereabouts are unknown.

The boys now command a guerrilla army formed partly of child soldiers. "It's weird to see this gaggle of smiley, laughing children going round with guns," Mr Harmer said. The third-in-command is even younger than the twins, a boy who earned the title Black Tongue after suffering a deforming tropical illness.

All three boys are heavy smokers, but otherwise they lead a highly regulated life. Alcohol, swearing, pork and eggs are among the items the young fundamental Christians have banned. There are also thought to be strict rules about liaisons with the opposite sex.

The boys were not believed to have been among the guerrillas at the hospital yesterday. But observers of the God's Army detected their stamp on rebel demands.

Yesterday's drama began at 7.30am when a group of adult God's Army soldiers arrived at the hospital after a 40-mile journey on a hijacked bus from the Burmese border. About 200 staff and 700 patients and visitors were taken hostage.

"We want to tell the world how the Karen and Burmese refugees live during the fighting," one of the guerrillas, named Nui, said. "Do not be worried. We will not hurt any hostages."

About 450 people were freed in batches - mostly the elderly, women and children - or managed to escape from eight outlying buildings during the course of the day and night.

The Thais made some concessions during the afternoon. Lt Gen Taweep, the regional army chief, said that shelling of God's Army positions would stop, and that unarmed refugees could enter Thailand for medical treatment. However he stressed that no Thai doctors would be sent into Burma, and no one carrying weapons could enter Thailand.

Mr Harmer said that the situation on the border must be desperate for the God's Army insurgents to have resorted to seizing the hospital. "If they've been driven to this they must have taken a real pounding. They could well be on the brink of oblivion," he said. "They're probably existing on very little."

"If they've been driven to this they must have taken a real pounding. They could well be on the brink of oblivion," he said. "They're probably existing on very little." fields.headline: Sundance gets loved up
fields.standfirst: Also today, Spielberg hogs the limelight at US Directors Guild night, Polanski to shoot Holocaust drama, and are Hugh Grant and Liz Hurley tying the knot?
fields.trailText: The chequebooks are coming out at the Sundance international film festival as film buyers scour Park City, Utah, for that low-budget little sleeper that could become this year's Blair Witch.
fields.body:
The chequebooks are coming out at the Sundance international film festival as film buyers scour Park City, Utah, for that low-budget little sleeper that could become this year's Blair Witch.

Last night, it was confirmed that Artisan Entertainment (who famously snapped up Dan Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez's horror classic in 1999) had signed up the distribution rights to the buddy-reunion caper Chuck and Bud for a figure which the Hollywood Reporter estimates as "north of $1m". Chuck and Bud tells the story of two childhood chums who hook up again in their 20s. It is directed by Miguel Arteta and stars Chris and Paul Weitz, the sibling producer-director team behind last year's American Pie.

But despite Chuck and Bud's success, the Sundance buzz continues to concentrate around the rave comedy Groove (pictured). A slice-of-life youth flick in the style of last year's Brit pic Human Traffic, Groove premiered to an enthusiastic crowd last Friday and was promptly bought up for a reported $1.5m by Sony Pictures Classics. Such whirlwind success looks to have taken even the film's creators aback. "It's unfathomable," its awestruck star, Steve Van Dormer, told Hollywood.com. "It was always in the back of our minds, but it's a total, total dream I don't even know what else to ask for."

True to its guerrilla roots, the Sundance festival celebrates the little folk while leaving the big guns begging. Still searching a buyer at this year's event is writer-director Tim Disney - the grand-nephew of Walt and son of Disney vice-chairman Roy. Disney Jr is touting his debut film Blessed Art Thou (starring Naveen Andrews) around Park City, but is finding his famous surname something of a burden.

Since the festival began last Friday, he has had to fend of speculation that his picture is nothing more than a vanity project funded by the Disney coffers. "In the independent film context, having the Disney name is a mixed blessing," Disney tells Monday's New York Times. "People make presumptions about how I had the means to do this, or what the film is about Everyone has their own associations, memories, points of view, which they apply to me. And some of those associations are negative."

Spielberg hogs the limelight at US Directors Guild night

So just what is Steven Spielberg working on next? Is it that Harry Potter adaptation, Minority Report with Tom Cruise, or the futureworld fable AI (a project long held dear by the late, great Stanley Kubrick)? No one seems entirely sure - least of all the great man himself. Fielding questions at last night's nominations for the 52nd Directors Guild of America awards, Spielberg invited reporters to "tell me what you'd like me to direct. I'm open to suggestions."

It appears clear, though, that the main frontrunners remain Harry Potter and Minority Report, with Spielberg hinting that the latter currently has the edge. According to Variety, the director commended the Potter stories as "a remarkable series of books. I'm interested in talking to people about it. But," he added, "I've been working for the last year and three months with Tom Cruise and (writer) Scott Frank on Minority Report, and that's the film I continue to focus on right now."

Yet Spielberg's insistence is somewhat undermined by reports (circulated on Ain't It Cool News) that the film-maker is currently hunting "unknown young actors" for an Untitled Steven Spielberg Project. According to industry insiders, this implies that the director is poised to commit to the Potter film first.

The fascination with Spielberg's next choice rather overshadowed last night's Directors Guild nominations. Spielberg was on hand to announce the shortlist for outstanding directorial achievement. For the first time ever, the five nominees included three first-time directors: Sam Mendes (for American Beauty), Spike Jonze (Being John Malkovich) and M Night Shyamalan (The Sixth Sense). This trio are up against old hands Michael Mann (for The Insider) and Frank Darabont (for his Stephen King adaptation The Green Mile). Darabont won back in 1994 for The Shawshank Redemption, ironically adapted from another Stephen King story.

 The winner of the 52nd Directors Guild award will be announced on March 11, at the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. By then, insiders hope, Spielberg will have finally chosen between Harry Potter and Minority Report.

Polanski to shoot Holocaust drama

Roman Polanski confirmed yesterday that he is planning to write and direct a Holocaust-themed picture, to be shot in his native Poland later this year. The as yet untitled project will focus on the experiences of true-life Jewish composer Wladyslaw Szpilman, who survived incarceration in the Nazi death camps during the second world war.

The project sees an about-turn for Polanski, who himself lost friends and family in the Holocaust. In the early 90s, the film-maker was sounded out by Steven Spielberg with a view to directing Schindler's List. Polanski turned the project down because he felt it would be too painful, leaving Spielberg free to make the film himself. Eight years on, Polanski now appears ready to confront the ghosts of his past.

Speaking to the Polish daily Gazeta Wyborcza, Polanski admitted that he was currently working on the screenplay. "I don't want any stars," he says. "I am committed to finding new faces. Filming should start in the fall."

In brief

Next Friday clung onto the top slot at the American box office for the second straight weekend. New Line's ribald rap outing was widely expected to be unseated by Miramax's romantic comedy Down to You, starring Freddie Prinze Jr and Julia Stiles. In the event, Down To You's opening weekend takings of $7.6m were a whisker short of Next Friday's tally of $8m. Financed on a medium budget and released to little fanfare, the sequel to the 1995 film Friday continues to outpace all expectations, with a total box office now topping $30m. A third instalment is already being discussed.

Long-time partners Elizabeth Hurley and Hugh Grant are rumoured to be planning a spring wedding. Empire Online quotes an unnamed source as claiming that "the wedding will be like something out of Four Weddings and a Funeral, and will be the highlight of the London season". The pair have been together for over a decade, and weathered the storm caused in 1995 when Grant was arrested in the company of LA hooker Divine Brown. It is not expected Ms Brown made it on the invite list.

fields.headline: An institution
fields.standfirst:
EW Swanton, a titan among cricket writers, has died aged 92. As a tribute,
 we reprint this appreciation by Matthew Engel, editor of Wisden
 Cricketers' Almanack. Written to mark Swanton's 90th birthday in February
 1996, the piece first appeared in Wisden Cricket Monthly.
fields.trailText: I was once asked if I liked EW Swanton. The question is a preposterous one. You might as well ask if I like the sky, or the soil, or Nelson's column. It is not a matter of liking. Jim Swanton is a fact.
fields.body:
I was once asked if I liked EW Swanton. The question is a preposterous one. You might as well ask if I like the sky, or the soil, or Nelson's column. It is not a matter of liking. Jim Swanton is a fact.

On February 11 he will celebrate his 90th birthday. Only a small minority make it through to this landmark. Even fewer get there in robust mental and physical condition. Hardly any do so still pursuing their lifelong vocation vigorously and effectively. Jim Swanton is still writing columns on cricket. He is still sharp-eyed, still trenchant and sometimes he is even right. He has more energy than men half his age. I know this: I am half his age.

Longevity is part of what makes Swanton special, but only part. He likes to refer to himself as a dinosaur, but that is absolutely what he is not. He had an interview with Frank Woolley published in a magazine called All Sports in 1926. For a journalist - to whom yesterday is old hat - this is not so much Jurassic as Palaeozoic.

Most great journalists are at their peak for ten or maybe 20 years. Then they start repeating themselves. But Jim, unlike the dinosaurs, has adapted. He has never been so obsessed with the past that he could not appreciate the present.

Yet his literary style has not adapted. He wrote as a 19-year-old much as he does as a near-90-year-old. It is impossible not to mention John Warr's delicious description of Swanton's writing: 'halfway between The Ten Commandments and Enid Blyton'. Yet it might be more accurate to quote Matthew Arnold: 'People think I can teach them style! What stuff it all is! Have something to say, and say it as clearly as you can. That is the only secret of style'. Swanton has always said it clearly, indeed sonorously. This may not explain his longevity as a human; it explains his extreme longevity as a journalist.

But Swanton would have been among the great influences of cricket this century had he packed in completely on his retirement (three years after the normal age) as Daily Telegraph correspondent in 1975. It is hard to convey now just how much it mattered what Swanton said in the years after the war.

He had the advantage of being a famous broadcaster as well as a writer. And there was not much opposition: The Independent was un-dreamed-of, The Guardian still on its way down from Manchester and The Times (until 1966) did not provide anything as vulgar as bylines, so the existence of John Woodcock was a secret to all but close friends.

Swanton, however, radiated authority, and not just in print. When he turned up at a county match it was a major event. It is said he only ever went to Northampton and Leicester once, and the clubs were expected to make preparations for him, and his amaneusis, only slightly less elaborate than would have been demanded by a reigning monarch. And they complied. That, in a sense, was his journalistic style. He made people feel he was important.

I hold to the firm belief that journalists are ragged-arse groundlings, temporarily elevated ex officio to a ringside at history (or, in the case of cricket writers, more usually at deep backward square leg). The moment they forget that, and start to believe they are personages who are part of The Establishment, is the moment they stop serving their readers properly and begin serving themselves, trimming their journalism in the hope of preferment or free lunches.

This never applied to Swanton, because he so rapidly became The Establishment itself. The 'Cricket in West Indies' section of Wisden 1957 consisted simply of two lines: 'No Quadrangular Tournament took place because of the West Indies tour of New Zealand and the visit of EW Swanton's XI.' You want style? That's style.

So even if he had written de haut en bas, he has never been afraid to say what he felt had to be said. A game which depends on timeless values has benefited immeasurably from having someone willing to re-state them frequently, forcefully and influentially. But, when necessary, he has changed, most famously over apartheid, which he saw for the unmitigated iniquity it was long before most members of MCC stopped whinnying on about 'building bridges'.

Read him on Botham's career*, for instance: 'Many among senior generations are too sentimentally attached to the modest heroics of old to appeciate the Botham style. But if the swagger is not for us, as he leaves the first-class scene, we must acknowledge the greatness at his best of a lion-hearted all-round cricketer...Only one all-rounder surely stands ahead of him as of all others, the incomparable Garry Sobers.' Other writers could have put it more neatly: it is hard to imagine anyone else of nearly 90 getting it quite so right.

It was Ray Illingworth who supposedly claimed that Swanton was too snobbish to get in the same car as his chauffeur. There's a nugget of truth in that. His flaws - his hopeless addictions to Kent cricketers and MCC policies, for instance - have often been the result of seeing the game and the world from committee rooms and president's boxes rather than the cheap seats.

But Illy, a far younger man, turned out to be less well-equipped for the modern world than Jim. Swanton dates back to an age when it wa possible for Pelham Warner to be both chairman of selectors and cricket correspondent of the Morning Post (one day it would be interesting to research the accuracy or otherwise of his pre-selection tips). That soon became an unthinkable combination.

I suspect future generations will find it hard to believe that someone like Swanton could be quite so influential both in print and inside the corridors of power. There will never be another and, on the whole, I think that's a good thing. But in the meantime let us salute his integrity, his grandeur and the lustre he has brought to cricket, and wish a great man very many happy returns.

* From The Telegraph, July 1993, and Last Over (Richard Cohen Books, 1996).

Matthew Engel is editor of Wisden CricketersÕ Almanack and a staff writer on the Guardian

fields.headline: Jill McGreal
fields.standfirst:
A mission for Canadian movies
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: As a teacher and film entrepreneur, Jill McGreal, who has died of cancer aged 50, did much to put Canadian film and the art of animation on the British cultural map.
fields.body:
As a teacher and film entrepreneur, Jill McGreal, who has died of cancer aged 50, did much to put Canadian film and the art of animation on the British cultural map.

Her mission to promote adventurous and challenging work resulted in two Channel 4 seasons of Canadian features (produced by John Wyver and introduced by Kiefer Sutherland), early support for directors David Cronenberg and the gay activist John Greyson, and the critical success of Patricia Rozema's I've Heard The Mermaids Singing. She also initiated visits to Britain by Canadian film-makers - including Michael Snow, Joyce Wieland and Caroline Leaf - and an ambitious programme of international exchanges.

Jill was film officer at the Canadian high commission from 1983 to 1990, an editor at Sight & Sound, a tireless worker for the animation festivals in Bristol and Cardiff, a member of film advisory committees and action groups - whose views were sought by the Arts Council - and a producer with her own company, Codename Cartoon. With her Codename partner, Ken Anderson, and animator An Vrombaut, she developed 64 Zoo Lane, the children's animated series currently running in America and shortly to be screened in this country.

Jill had the broad interests of a 1960s cinephile, but animation became her specialist subject. She had an association with the Royal College of Art animation department, and latterly taught film history and theory at the Surrey institute of art and design, at Farnham. In 1998, with her partner Anthony Harrild, she established the institute's animation research centre and became its first director. Sadly, illness curtailed her involvement.

Jill was brought up in Surrey and educated at Wimbledon high school, a girls' day public school - which she confessed probably contributed to her self-direction, but also propelled her to become a founder member of Epsom Young Socialists. At Leicester university, where she became a Marxist, she met her husband, John McGreal, and graduated in social sciences. She then enrolled to study French at University College, London, but emerged with a first in philosophy, which - with politics - remained a lifelong passion.

A chance opportunity to research Canadian cinema for Richard Collins, of the Central London polytechnic, confirmed her interest in film. She also began a 17-year partnership with the film his torian Michael O'Pray, and started writing for Afterimage, the London Film-Makers' Co-op magazine Undercut, and later for Sight & Sound.

At the high commission, Jill was an instant ally for the fledgling Piccadilly film festival - her Underground Canada season championed gay and lesbian work when it was still controversial to do so. She also began a sometimes fraught 12-year relationship with the board of the animation festival and, in 1993, produced the British animation week at the Institute of Contemporary Arts.

Jill liked the intensity of festivals, and was at her best out-talking and out-lasting anyone else in late-night argument. Her combination of aesthetic and political interests was rare in the animation world.

She could be ferocious in her denunciation of the failures of British television, or the shortcomings of some artist's work - then bowl you over with her enthusiasm for English gardens, a passion we shared. She was impervious to hierarchical thinking; if her seniors occasionally felt uncomfortable, artists, film-makers and colleagues found her a loyal friend.

Jill is survived by her daughter Frances McGreal, and her son Thomas O'Pray.

Jill McGreal, film animator and teacher, born March 6 1949; died January 9 2000

fields.headline: THE BEST GIFT SCENE: SLEEPY HOLLOW
fields.trailText: Big city constable Ichabod Crane (Johnny Depp) broods silently, staring out of the window at the woods of Sleepy Hollow. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci), the daughter of his host, stands beside him.
fields.body:
Big city constable Ichabod Crane (Johnny Depp) broods silently, staring out of the window at the woods of Sleepy Hollow. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci), the daughter of his host, stands beside him. Reaching inside her robe, she removes a small blue book, then holds it before him.

"Here," she says, "take this."

Crane glances down at the book's cover.

"A COMPENDIUM OF SPELLS, CHARMS AND DEVICES OF THE SPIRIT WORLD."

He shakes his head.

"No," he mutters, resignation in his voice. "I have no use for it."

Katrina regards him coolly.

"Are you so certain of everything?"

Crane hesitates, lost in thought. He takes the book. Opening the inside cover, he reads an inscription.

"ELIZABETH VAN TASSEL, KATRINA VAN TASSEL."

Crane looks up.

"It was your mother's."

Katrina moves toward the door.

"Keep it close to your heart. It is sure protection against harm."

Don't see also: The Firm

fields.headline: Kohl und die Kohle
fields.standfirst: Leading German politicians are facing serious allegations of sleaze. Nicole Prestle asks young people for their reaction
fields.trailText: Secondary German
fields.body:
Ein Aktenkoffer voller Geld hat die CDU aus dem Konzept gebracht. Ein Aktenkoffer und einige "Unklarheiten" beim Verbuchen von Parteispenden. Diesmal dürfte sich Ex-Kanzler Helmut Kohl schwer tun mit dem Aussitzen des Problems. Diesmal, munkeln Experten, könnte es um seine (und nicht nur seine) politische Zukunft gehen.

Was ist geschehen? Seit bekannt wurde, daß Helmut Kohl Spenden in Höhe von über 1,5 Millionen Mark entgegengenommen und an den offiziellen Konten der Partei vorbeigeschleust hat, ist die Parteienwelt nicht mehr in Ordnung. Jeden Tag neue Enthüllungen, jeden Tag neue Vorwürfe, jeden Tag neue Ausflüchte.

Nun hat auch Parteichef Wolfgang Schäuble zugegeben, im Namen der Partei eine Barspende von 100000 Mark - überreicht in einem Aktenkoffer - angenommen zu haben. Eine Spende, die zunächst falsch verbucht wurde und erst drei Jahre später im Rechenschaftsbericht der CDU auftaucht. Dabei hatte Schäuble noch vor wenigen Tagen vor Journalisten beteuert, den vermeintlichen Spender noch gar nie gesehen, geschweige denn Geld von ihm angenommen zu haben...

Doch es knirscht nicht nur im Gebälk der CDU. Wegen der sogenannten Flug-Affäre ist auch die nordrhein-westfälische SPD ins Zwielicht geraten. Mehrere Male sollen Politiker auf Kosten der Westdeutschen Landesbank Privatflüge unternommen haben - unter anderem der heutige Bundespräsident Johannes Rau. Und dann wären da noch die Grünen, die einen Teil ihrer Gehälter zur Finanzierung der Partei abführen, obwohl dies rechtlich gar nicht zulässig ist.

Was ist los mit den Parteien in Deutschland? Ist das System durcheinander geraten oder gar veraltet? Sind Politiker überhaupt noch glaubwürdig? Wir haben uns bei Jugendlichen erkundigt.

Was haltet Ihr von den immer neuen Enthüllungen um die Geldpolitik der Parteien?

Natalie (15): Ich schaue mir im Fernsehen schon gar keine Sendungen zu diesem Thema mehr an. Meine Eltern regen sich nämlich total darüber auf, und ich muß mich dann auch aufregen.

Schelli (14): Mich nervt dieses Thema, weil ich auch gar nicht richtig kapiere, wer jetzt wem zu welchem Zweck Geld gegeben hat und wo die Kohle schließlich gelandet ist. Das ist doch alles ziemlich verwirrend.

Sylvia (15): So langsam reicht es mir mit den täglichen Streitereien. Ich finde, die Parteien sollten mal wieder zu den wichtigen Themen zurückkommen. Sind Politiker nach all diesen Verwicklungen für Euch noch glaubwürdig?

Hanne (16): Zum Teil schon, ja. Was sie vor den Wahlen versprechen, versuchen sie ja meistens irgendwie umzusetzen. Bei diesen Themen kann man ihnen auch noch vertrauen. Was die Sache mit dem Geld betrifft, bin ich skeptischer. Da werde ich so schnell keinem mehr was abnehmen

Nikolaus (16): Den Staat zu verscheißern, das ist doch schon Volkssport. Das macht doch jeder. Bei Schäuble finde ich das deshalb gar nicht so schlimm. Er hat ja nicht richtig gelogen, er hat sein Mitwissen nur etwas zu spät aufgedeckt. Übler ist es schon bei Kohl. Er, der das neue Parteispenden-Gesetz in die Wege geleitet hat, hat jetzt so saftig dagegen verstoßen.

Sylvia: Jeder hat doch seine Macken, vor allem wenn es um den Umgang mit Geld geht.

Ich habe mir auch schon mal Zuhause ein wenig Knete stibitzt. Und Kohl hat die Kohle ja nicht für sich kassiert, er hat sie der Partei zukommen lassen. Da halte ich das, was letztes Jahr mit Clinton war, moralisch schon für sehr viel schlimmer.

Welche Konsequenzen werden die Bürger Eurer Meinung nach aus der Spendenaffäre ziehen, wie verhaltet Ihr Euch selbst?

Natalie: Ich glaube ganz einfach, daß kaum mehr jemand die CDU wählen wird. Das zeichnet sich ja jetzt schon bei Meinungsumfragen ab. Ich selbst muß ja zum Glück noch nicht wählen.

Schelli: Also, wenn ich schon 18 wäre, hätte ich jetzt wahrscheinlich meine liebe Mühe.

Man kann doch keinen mehr wählen, irgendwie scheinen alle Dreck am Stecken zu haben.

Nikolaus: Die Parteien kriegen ihren Denkzettel bei den nächsten Wahlen. Allerdings glaube ich nicht, daß die Wähler von der CDU auf die SPD schwenken. Ich glaube eher, das alles geht auf Kosten der Wahlbeteiligung. Es werden ganz einfach immer weniger Leute ihre Stimme abgeben.

Wie können die Parteien sich und ihre Arbeit Eurer Meinung nach wieder ins rechte Licht rücken?

Hanne: Sie müssen jetzt sofort alles aufdecken, was gewesen ist. Und zwar nicht durch irgendwelche langweiligen Reden, sondern durch Beweise. Nur wie sie das machen wollen, ist mir schleierhaft.

Natalie: Die, die das alles verbockt haben, sollten zurücktreten. Neue, jüngere Politiker müssen her.

Nikolaus: Kohl muß weg. Der hat dem Ansehen am meisten geschadet. Schäuble sollte ruhig weiter den Parteivorsitz behalten. Die Flugaffäre der SPD finde ich überhaupt nicht schlimm. Das wird sich ohne Konsequenzen bereinigen.

fields.headline: Der Kanzler schweigt
fields.trailText: Beginners' German
fields.body:
Parteien brauchen Geld, um zu arbeiten. Jeder weiß das, jeder akzeptiert das.

Spenden sind eine wichtige Geldquelle. Sie anzunehmen ist erlaubt. Doch Parteien müssen über Spenden Buch führen. Die CDU hat das nicht immer getan.

Mehr als 1,5 Millionen Mark hat Ex-Bundeskanzler Helmut Kohl an den CDU- Konten vorbeigeschmuggelt. Ohne das Wissen der Bürger, ohne das Wissenseiner Partei.

Jeden Tag hört man von neuen Fehlern. Auch CDU-Chef Wolfgang Schäuble hat Geld angenommen. 100000 Mark waren es. In den Bilanzen erscheint die Summe erst drei Jahre später. Die Wähler sind enttäuscht. Enttäuscht, weil Politiker gegen das Gesetz handeln. Enttäuscht, weil sie weiter schweigen.

Auch andere Parteien bekommen wegen ihres Umgangs mit Geld Probleme. Die Liste der Verstöße ist lang: Privatflüge auf Kosten des Staates, falsche Finanzierung der Partei und, und, und. Die Politiker versuchen, den Schaden abzuwenden. Sie geben wichtige Ämter ab. Doch das Vertrauen vieler Wähler ist kaputt. Umfragen beweisen es. Bei den nächsten Wahlen zeigt sich, ob der Wähler die Politiker für ihre Fehler bestraft.

Die Affäre schadet der CDU. Sie schadet Ex-Kanzler Helmut Kohl. Diesmal wird er das Problem nicht "aussitzen" können. Diesmal muß er handeln.

Parteikollegen fordern: Kohl muß die Namen der Spender und die Höhe der Spenden verraten. Er muß endlich die Wahrheit sagen. Doch noch schweigt der ehemalige Kanzler...

fields.headline: The men can't help it
fields.standfirst: Evolution has made all males sexual predators, and women who want to be safe should think carefully about what they wear. At least, that's the claim of two US scientists whose book is causing outrage before it has even been published.
fields.trailText: Evolution has made all males sexual predators, and women who want to be safe should think carefully about what they wear. At least, that's the claim of two US scientists whose book is causing outrage before it has even been published.
fields.body:
It is rare indeed that a scientific theory originally based on observation of the male scorpionfly should so grip the popular imagination. Craig Palmer and Randy Thornhill might not be typical talkshow fodder, but their next work is already the most eagerly anticipated publication since the last Thomas Harris novel.

Three months before it hits the shops in the US, an extract has been printed in a prestigious journal; its subject matter has transcended the literary pages and broken the straitjacket of genre to make the final leap on to the afternoon television talk shows. It is said that the authors will grace the cover of Time in April.

Palmer and Thornhill are not popular novelists but scientists; the magazine that acts as a vehicle for their apostasy is not the New Yorker but The Sciences; and their Big Idea is that rape is a natural and biological product of man's evolutionary need to reproduce, as much a part of life as thunderstorms and epidemics.

Thornhill, a University of New Mexico evolutionary biologist, and Palmer, an evolutionary anthropologist at the University of Colorado, list a series of observations - many of them contested - in the magazine trailer for their book A Natural History of Rape: Biological Bases of Sexual Coercion.

Then they say: "As bizarre as some of these facts may seem, they all make sense when rape is viewed as a natural, biological phenomenon that is a product of the human evolutionary heritage. "We fervently believe that, just as the leopard's spots and the giraffe's elongated neck are the results of aeons of past Darwinian selection, so also is rape."

Human males will rape, they contend, whenever their capacity to reproduce is thwarted. Thus every man is a potential rapist, and given the right conditions may become one. If rape prevention is to succeed, they say, evolution must be taken into account. And it is the practical application of this belief that has caused so much controversy.

Palmer and Thornhill recommend that young men taking their driving test be instructed that "Darwinian selection" is the reason why a man "may be tempted to demand sex even if he knows that his date truly doesn't want it" or "may mistake a woman's friendly comment or tight blouse as an invitation to sex".

For women, the pair provide similar questionable prescriptions, arguing that women must acknowledge that the way they dress can put them at risk of attack. "Surely the point that no woman's behaviour gives a man the right to rape her can be made without encouraging women to overlook the role they themselves may be playing in compromising their safety."

The two scientists set out to answer this question: why do men rape? They found on the route to their answer the impediment of political correctness: until now, scholarly journals refused to carry papers that treated rape from a Darwinian perpective; public lectures on the subject were cancelled; universities denied positions to academics who shared their inconvenient view.

Susan Brownmiller, whose 1975 treatise Against Our Will: Men, Women and Rape, is rated by the New York public library as one of the 100 most influential books of the 20th century, disagrees vehemently. Brownmiller's comprehensive study, which has since set the tone for much of the academic argument around the issue, fails to convince Palmer and Thornhill, who blame political correctness for the academy's refusal to treat rape from a Darwinian perspective.

Sitting in her home in Greenwich Village, Manhattan, Brownmiller's thesis is less conspiracy-led. She describes their arguments about the causes of rape - and about her book - as wrongheaded and dangerous. "First of all, I think what they're saying is ridiculous. They misrepresented my position. I didn't say rape was only about power. I also say it's about humiliation and degradation."

"When women started to talk about this in the early 70s, the women who had experienced rape said they felt it had been an act of humiliation. They didn't see it as a sex act. But obviously we didn't think this had nothing to do with the sex act; of course it is, sexual organs are used."

"They can't deal with homosexual rape in prison because that doesn't fit their thesis of men spreading their seed. They can't deal with the rape of women over childbearing age, because that doesn't fit either.

"But the most important thing I can say about their book is that I think it will be used as a defence by lawyers in rape cases. These guys will become expert witnesses, for a fee, as part of the defence, and that's dangerous. The ones who will benefit will be high-profile rapists who can afford to hire them."

Dr Jerry Coyne, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Chicago, does not mince his words, describing the theory as "the worst efflorescence of evolutionary psychology that I've ever seen.

"It's irresponsible, it's tendentious, it's an advocacy article and the science is sloppy," he says. "There are some aspects of human behaviour that are fairly clearly evolutionary. But that's a long way from saying that rape is adaptive in males."

A US study in 1998 showed that about 302,100 women and 92,700 men are raped each year nationwide and, of the women, only 14% are attacked by strangers. This is taken to show that very few rapes are motivated by spontaneous reactions to the scientists' "tight blouse" scenario. The study also said that 22% of rapes involved girls of 12 or younger, ages at which reproduction is unlikely.

Kim Gandy, executive vice-president of the National Organisation for Women, has no time for the latest work by Palmer and Thornhill.

"It's been referred to several times as a study. It's not a study," she said. "It's a theory. And it is a theory that has no basis in research. In fact, the research that's been done - and we are talking about research with thousands of convicted rapists, thousands of victims of rape - demonstrates very clearly, from a sociological point of view, that rape is a crime of violence. It is a crime of control, it is a crime of power, not a crime of passion."

"It's insulting to both men and women to say that women ought to have chaperones and wear high necklines in order to prevent rape," said Gandy. "It's outrageous."

Thornhill has come to public attention before, as one of the authors of a famous work linking symmetrical features to genetic health and a better sex life. But Peter Brown, editor of The Sciences, says: "We don't always get this kind of feedback. We stand by the article. We checked it very carefully and they have some observations to back up what they're saying. Our aim is not to publish data but to create a forum for scientists. We thought this would stimulate discussion."

It is, of course, inevitable that this theory should create such controversy. As the sciences struggle to explain the complexities of modern sexual behaviour, the relatively new field of evolutionary psychology has not been without its critics.

Many argue that a strictly scientific approach is reductive, failing to allow for the vagaries of emotional behaviour. Dr Mary P Koss, an authority on rape and a professor of public health at the University of Arizona, says that evolution is a factor in rape. But, she cautions, "it is not proper to set up evolutionary and social causation as opposites. You have to think about how they work together".

"When women started to talk about this in the early 70s, the women who had experienced rape said they felt it had been an act of humiliation. They didn't see it as a sex act. But obviously we didn't think this had nothing to do with the sex act; of course it is, sexual organs are used." "They can't deal with homosexual rape in prison because that doesn't fit their thesis of men spreading their seed. They can't deal with the rape of women over childbearing age, because that doesn't fit either. "But the most important thing I can say about their book is that I think it will be used as a defence by lawyers in rape cases. These guys will become expert witnesses, for a fee, as part of the defence, and that's dangerous. The ones who will benefit will be high-profile rapists who can afford to hire them." Dr Jerry Coyne, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Chicago, does not mince his words, describing the theory as "the worst efflorescence of evolutionary psychology that I've ever seen. "It's irresponsible, it's tendentious, it's an advocacy article and the science is sloppy," he says. "There are some aspects of human behaviour that are fairly clearly evolutionary. But that's a long way from saying that rape is adaptive in males." A US study in 1998 showed that about 302,100 women and 92,700 men are raped each year nationwide and, of the women, only 14% are attacked by strangers. This is taken to show that very few rapes are motivated by spontaneous reactions to the scientists' "tight blouse" scenario. The study also said that 22% of rapes involved girls of 12 or younger, ages at which reproduction is unlikely. Kim Gandy, executive vice-president of the National Organisation for Women, has no time for the latest work by Palmer and Thornhill. "It's been referred to several times as a study. It's not a study," she said. "It's a theory. And it is a theory that has no basis in research. In fact, the research that's been done - and we are talking about research with thousands of convicted rapists, thousands of victims of rape - demonstrates very clearly, from a sociological point of view, that rape is a crime of violence. It is a crime of control, it is a crime of power, not a crime of passion." "It's insulting to both men and women to say that women ought to have chaperones and wear high necklines in order to prevent rape," said Gandy. "It's outrageous." Thornhill has come to public attention before, as one of the authors of a famous work linking symmetrical features to genetic health and a better sex life. But Peter Brown, editor of The Sciences, says: "We don't always get this kind of feedback. We stand by the article. We checked it very carefully and they have some observations to back up what they're saying. Our aim is not to publish data but to create a forum for scientists. We thought this would stimulate discussion." It is, of course, inevitable that this theory should create such controversy. As the sciences struggle to explain the complexities of modern sexual behaviour, the relatively new field of evolutionary psychology has not been without its critics. Many argue that a strictly scientific approach is reductive, failing to allow for the vagaries of emotional behaviour. Dr Mary P Koss, an authority on rape and a professor of public health at the University of Arizona, says that evolution is a factor in rape. But, she cautions, "it is not proper to set up evolutionary and social causation as opposites. You have to think about how they work together".

webTitle: Nazi camp war crimes suspect dies

fields.headline: Nazi camp war crimes suspect dies
fields.standfirst: Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: A former SS guard at a concentration camp, who settled in Britain after being deported from the United States for suspected war crimes, died yesterday after a heart attack.
fields.body:
A former SS guard at a concentration camp, who settled in Britain after being deported from the United States for suspected war crimes, died yesterday after a heart attack.

Alexander Schweidler, 78, moved to Milton Keynes in 1994 after evidence emerged implicating him in crimes against humanity. He had been receiving a state pension in Britain.

Mr Schweidler complained of chest pains at 3am yesterday and after being taken to hospital was pronounced dead at 4.30am. A Thames Valley police spokesman said: "It's believed he died of natural causes."

Mr Schweidler, born in Slovakia, was a guard from 1942 to 1945 at the Mauthausen camp in Austria, where more than 80,000 prisoners died through gassing, slave labour, being shot and being used for experiments. He became a British citizen in 1964 and left for the US in 1965.

Last week the Guardian revealed that a document bearing his signature gave details of how he shot dead two prisoners while they tried to escape.

Mr Schweidler's council bungalow was besieged by the media after the Guardian report. Yesterday his widow, Anna, speaking through Thames Valley police, appealed for privacy. She had complained of press harassment, and police had posted a guard.

The couple married in 1952 after meeting at a wedding and have a daughter, Helen, 46, who lives in the US.

Mr Schweidler denied shooting prisoners, saying a document he signed was "falsified". He said he had not seen any ill-treatment of the 191,938 people who passed through Maut-hausen and its satellite camps.

Lord Janner, secretary of the all-party war crimes group and a former war crimes investigator, said: "I deeply regret that Schweidler did not live to stand trial for the hideous crimes committed while he was a guard in the notorious Mauthausen concentration camp. No one will forget that tens of thousands of people were murdered in that camp."

George Sowa, a survivor of the camp now living in London, had also wanted Mr Schweidler prosecuted.

He said: "Let God judge him now."

Meanwhile, the only man convicted in Britain of Nazi war crimes is appealing against conviction. The retired British Rail ticket collector Anthony Sawoniuk was given two life sentences last year after being found guilty of murdering Jews in Domachevo, Belarus.

webTitle: Challenge to Straw on case secrecy

fields.headline: Challenge to Straw on case secrecy
fields.standfirst:
Freedom of information: special report
Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: Home office ministers are to be challenged today on why the government's new freedom of information bill would ban publication until 2030 of documents disclosing Jack Straw's decision to deport alleged Nazi war criminal Konrad Kalejs.
fields.body:
Home office ministers are to be challenged today on why the government's new freedom of information bill would ban publication until 2030 of documents disclosing Jack Straw's decision to deport alleged Nazi war criminal Konrad Kalejs.

The former Labour arts minister, Mark Fisher, and the Liberal Democrat constitutional affairs spokesman, Robert Maclennan, want the government to relax a proposed blanket ban on the release of information involving police enforcement.

The MPs plan to highlight the issue when the bill is debated in committee by MPs today. Mr Kalejs left the country after Mr Straw made it clear that he was going to deport him. Nazi-hunters accused the 86-year-old Latvian of being a member of the Arajs Kommanda who helped the Nazis liquidate 30,000 people, mainly Jews, during the second world war.

An internal inquiry was demanded by Mr Straw into how a man deported from the U S and Canada could still enter Britain, but any findings will not be available until they are put in the public records office in 2030.

webTitle: Daniels leads Sri Lanka to final

fields.headline: Daniels leads Sri Lanka to final
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka stayed on course to emulate their seniors in 1995 when they beat Pakistan by 10 runs in Galle to reach Friday's final of the Under-19 World Cup.
fields.body:
Sri Lanka stayed on course to emulate their seniors in 1995 when they beat Pakistan by 10 runs in Galle to reach Friday's final of the Under-19 World Cup. They may even face Australia, who play India today in the other semi-final.

Pakistan, chasing 220 in 50 overs, recovered from losing three wickets for 28 when the captain Hasan Raza, already a Test player, and Faisal Iqbal put on 96. A brilliant catch on the square-leg boundary broke the partnership, Iqbal going for 53.

Pakistan then lost two wickets in four balls, including Raza, who was fittingly run out for 44 - he had had a hand in four of the five run-outs in the Sri Lanka innings - and Prabath Nissanka's final over was too tight for Pakistan to get the 15 they needed.

Sri Lanka were indebted to the opener Ian Daniels, who made a classy 58 though he was also involved in two of the run-outs.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.trailText: Daily Mail
fields.body:
Daily Mail

Chelsea hope to steal to the front of the race to sign Ruud van Nistelrooy by buying his strike partner Luc Nilis. The Belgian international, now 33, is available on a Bosman in the summer, and with van Nistelrooy only wanting to move to the 'club of his dreams', the Blues hope the presence of Nilis will swing his decision.

Teamtalk

Liverpool will not be pursuing an interest in Pierre van Hooijdonk. They have however been linked with a move for unsettled Barcelona star Jari Litmanen, a lifelong fan of the Reds.

Celtic will sign Wimbledon keeper Neil Sullivan on a Bosman free transfer this summer.

The Sun

John Gregory wants to take £10-million rated Emile Heskey from Leicester this summer. "I'm a big admirer of Emile," said Gregory, "We've looked at him and would maintain an interest if he became available."

Wimbledon's Egil Olsen wants Sheffield United striker Marcus Bent, but his £1m bid has been rejected. Blades boss Neil Warnock said of the bid, "One million would not even buy Marcus' left leg! He is worth £3m."

webTitle: £25m in black hole after Star Wars flop

fields.headline: £25m in black hole after Star Wars flop
fields.trailText: The force deserted the children's book publisher Dorling Kindersley yesterday as the group revealed that it will plunge £25m into the red after massively over-ordering Star Wars books before Christmas.
fields.body:
The force deserted the children's book publisher Dorling Kindersley yesterday as the group revealed that it will plunge £25m into the red after massively over-ordering Star Wars books before Christmas.

The company's chief executive, James Middlehurst, has already quit and the chairman and 30% shareholder, Peter Kindersley, will return to the driving seat until a replacement can be found.

The dramatic announcement to the stock exchange admitted that directors had "seriously misjudged" the demand for Star Wars books and related merchandise.

The company's sales had risen strongly when the film Star Wars: The Phantom Menace was released last year, but the boardroom failed to realise that it would not be able to rekindle demand when the box office blockbuster had faded from cinema screens.

Fewer than 3m of the 13m Star Wars books Dorling Kindersley printed were sold, and the disastrous trading performance has forced the company on to the mercy of its bankers.

The mistake hit the company hard - plunging by more than 35% to wipe £42.3m off the personal fortune of Mr Kindersley and more than £140m off the group's value.

The fiasco is the latest in a series of setbacks since Dorling Kindersley joined the stock market in 1992. Once regarded as a shooting star of the media industry, DK has rarely managed to go for more than a year before an upset has threatened to derail its profits performance.

The company turned down a takeover offer from Bill Gates's Microsoft in 1995. He abruptly sold the 18% shareholding he had built in the publisher.

More recently, senior executives have come and gone with alarming regularity.

Mr Kindersley, whose wife Juliet is a Dorling Kindersley author, rejected suggestions that he should relinquish the reins of control at the group. "In the longer term, some [boardroom] issues will have to be considered, but at this particular moment I have to get back into the driving seat."

He added that the com pany's underlying business was good, and hoped that the video release of Phantom Menace in the spring and the re-release of the original Star Wars trilogy in the autumn would help use up some of the warehouses full of unwanted stock.

But the company's problems do not end there. It is running out of working cash because it has £44m worth of books in stock but unsold. By no means all of them are Star Wars titles.

It has also been suffering in a dispute with its main distribution agent, which meant DK did not manage to supply one book during September to WH Smith, its largest customer.

webTitle: The day a horrified minister turned into a silly cut

fields.headline: The day a horrified minister turned into a silly cut
fields.trailText: It was one of those dreams that make ministers wake up at 3.30am, sweating and perhaps even screaming with fear. "Darling, what's the matter?" ask anxious wives and mistresses, as their menfolk wipe the clammy moisture from their brows and crawl downstairs for a cup of cocoa and 20 restoring minutes of Judge Judy on ITV.
fields.body:
It was one of those dreams that make ministers wake up at 3.30am, sweating and perhaps even screaming with fear. "Darling, what's the matter?" ask anxious wives and mistresses, as their menfolk wipe the clammy moisture from their brows and crawl downstairs for a cup of cocoa and 20 restoring minutes of Judge Judy on ITV.

The dream is always the same. There they are in the Commons, confidently beating off Tory attacks - poised, assured, the facts perfectly disposed in well-marshalled files, the arguments deployed like a chessmaster's pawns.

As they speak, a glow of quiet satisfaction sends serotonin, the happy drug secreted by the body, into the correct receptors of the brain.

"The whips are listening," murmers the serotonin. "They'll be telling No 10 how brilliantly you laid about the Tories. Margaret Beckett, Mo Mowlam, Jack Straw, Robin Cook: who knows what will happen to them in the next reshuffle?

"Tony's bound to need someone as intellectually nimble as you to promote to the cabinet. All you need to do is keep going." John Spellar, the defence minister, dreamed on as peacefully as any child. In his noctural lucubrations, he was being assailed by Robert Key, a Tory spokesman. Mr Key had made himself sound rather foolish on the Today programme yesterday morning by declaring: "We can't be held responsible for things which happened 10 years ago" - in which case, who can be held responsible?

In any event, this was not a man whose debating skills were going to cause Mr Spellar difficulty. He could cope with him while fast asleep.

Mr Key was complaining about a cut in the amount of money being provided for service hospitals.

"How is it that when I asked you what had happened to the £1,500,000 allocated for orthopaedic waiting lists, you replied there were no cuts?

"We then discover that as long ago as last December, Admiral Sir John Brigstock had confirmed that there had been £1.5m cuts.

"I for one feel misled. Who is right - you or the admiral?"

Mr Spellar grunted gently and rolled over. Outside the first notes of the dawn chorus could be heard, and the soft whine of a milk float wafted from a nearby street. In his dreams he formulated the perfect reply.

"We recognised that these cuts in defence medical services had gone too far," he said - except that horribly, unimaginably, he inserted the letter "n" into "cuts".

The mistaken word was clear and crisply spoken. What made it worse, far worse, was that the sentence as spoken made just as much sense as what Mr Spellar was trying to say.

There was a sudden, terrible silence. The minister must have had the same feeling as a man who not only falls out of bed, but senses himself crashing down from a perilous clifftop bivouac.

I know that feminists are trying to reclaim the c-word, but this was extraordinary even by Commons standards. Yes, most male MPs talk like this in the bars. Some female MPs, the Blair ladettes, do too.

But never, not ever, in the chamber itself.

The Tory frontbench took a moment to realise what he had said. Then they all collapsed in hysterical stagey laughter. Mr Key, the shadow defence minister, Iain Duncan Smith, and even Ann Widdecombe mirthfully scanned the press gallery to make sure we had all heard what Mr Spellar had said.

Apart from that, you could say that the government survived a sustained and effective assault on its record.

Alternatively, you might argue that its shortcomings, failures and broken promises were mercilessly exposed by the Tory team.

As I beg Mr Spellar not even to try saying, you can take your pick.

fields.headline: Not this year, old boys
fields.standfirst: You thought the MCC was bad? Caribbean journalist Vaneisa Baksh on her struggle to gain membership of the Queen's Park Cricket Club in Trinidad and Tobago
fields.trailText: A little over two and a half years ago, I applied for membership at the Queen's Park Cricket Club. I was - and still am - the first woman to have done so. The Club did not officially acknowledge my application, but it caused a stir among the membership.
fields.body:
A little over two and a half years ago, I applied for membership at the Queen's Park Cricket Club. I was - and still am - the first woman to have done so. The Club did not officially acknowledge my application, but it caused a stir among the membership.

It provoked several discussions on the prospect of women being allowed into the Club, some in my presence, most not. Several QPCC members said they supported the idea of women as members, and they railed privately about the backwardness that prevailed among what they termed the Club's ruling elite. Ordinary members had no problem with the concept. Those who did, did so on grounds that they liked the idea of having a place to escape women, a place where they could curse and drink without having to be constrained, as gentlemen, by ladies in their midst.

Anyway, for two and a half years my application was sidestepped at every ballot, until my proposer, Desmond Allum, made some enquiries.The ballot committee met two weeks ago to consider 20 applications, one of which was mine.

I was rejected.

No one could give me an official reason for the rejection. The voting, you see, at this private members' club, is conducted by secret ballot. So, although I am well aware of the gender tone of the discussion regarding my entry because I was told about it, the QPCC cannot give a reason for its rejection.

I spoke with three members of its management committee, and none could offer any rationale, although the President, Willie Rodriguez, in pointing out that two other applications were rejected, assured me it had "nothing to do with gender."

Well, then what?

Let me see: the membership fee is not small, but no one has enquired about my financial situation. I asked several members why they joined, and every single one said the same thing: it was because the Members' Pavilion is a great place to watch cricket, and the Club was conveniently located to facilitate a little lunch and some recreation. Nowhere on the application form is anyone asked to give reasons for wanting membership, nor is anyone asked to show their possible value to the Club.

Yet, on the eve of the ballot meeting, I was asked to spell out possible benefits I could bring to the Club; just to ensure that my application was not viewed as an attempt to score one for women's "suffrage", as the late Gerry Gomez, a former president, had told me it would be seen. And what if it is?

I figured that as a journalist who often writes about cricket, and as someone with considerable editing experience, I could at least be of some use in the Club's documentation of West Indies cricket. I mentioned that there was little archival information regarding our cricket history, and that as a great many of our elder cricketers were approaching their twilight years, we should attempt to document their stories before it is too late. (It is a project I feel very committed to and will undertake with or without their support.) Their response was that the Club is not interested in that sort of thing, I should try the Trinidad and Tobago Cricket Board of Control instead.

So what is the Queen's Park Cricket Club interested in, then? And, more specifically, what was the reason for me being rejected, after waiting for so long? About six months ago, I had been told by a member of the management committee that although it was true that the waiting list was long, my application had been overtaken by several others, because the committee was unwilling to bring it up.

I had been told that the subject of letting a woman into the Club would have to come before the annual general meeting so that some kind of discussion could take place and the members could have a chance to ventilate their views. At least two such meetings have taken place without the matter even coming up for an official glance. The membership has not been given a chance to discuss it.

That confirms the suspicion that those not in favour are those occupying the rule-making positions. It suggests that they rely on the idea that the general membership, as is the case in most organisations, is ignorant about what goes on at the policy level. For those who do not know, I would like to point out that there is no rule debarring women from entry into the Club. I would like to point out that all the other Clubs in the region and really, in the world, have expressly made rules to allow women to join them (even the MCC).

I would also like to point out that the Queen's Park Cricket Club, which was formed in 1891 to control cricket in this country (until the TTCBC was formed 90 years later) took upon itself a large role in a sport which is of deep significance to everyone in the Caribbean, man or woman. Its status as a private members' club does not embrace its responsibility for the cricket culture it has chosen to hog to its bosom. It is home to this country's only Test-match ground, and as a citizen of this country, as a cricket supporter, I have the right to be able to attend cricket matches and not to be excluded on the basis of my sex from any part of that ground.

I had first been astonished by the decision, until I remembered the state of West Indies cricket and reflected that this is the kind of backward thinking which has dominated it.

I told the Club's manager, Joey Carew, that I intended to pursue this to the end, and asked his opinion. "Somewhere down the road, something will happen," he said vaguely. He didn't know what, but felt it was a can of worms which needed to be opened.

fields.bodyText: A little over two and a half years ago, I applied for membership at the Queen's Park Cricket Club. I was - and still am - the first woman to have done so. The Club did not officially acknowledge my application, but it caused a stir among the membership. It provoked several discussions on the prospect of women being allowed into the Club, some in my presence, most not. Several QPCC members said they supported the idea of women as members, and they railed privately about the backwardness that prevailed among what they termed the Club's ruling elite. Ordinary members had no problem with the concept. Those who did, did so on grounds that they liked the idea of having a place to escape women, a place where they could curse and drink without having to be constrained, as gentlemen, by ladies in their midst. Anyway, for two and a half years my application was sidestepped at every ballot, until my proposer, Desmond Allum, made some enquiries.The ballot committee met two weeks ago to consider 20 applications, one of which was mine. I was rejected. No one could give me an official reason for the rejection. The voting, you see, at this private members' club, is conducted by secret ballot. So, although I am well aware of the gender tone of the discussion regarding my entry because I was told about it, the QPCC cannot give a reason for its rejection. I spoke with three members of its management committee, and none could offer any rationale, although the President, Willie Rodriguez, in pointing out that two other applications were rejected, assured me it had "nothing to do with gender." Well, then what? Let me see: the membership fee is not small, but no one has enquired about my financial situation. I asked several members why they joined, and every single one said the same thing: it was because the Members' Pavilion is a great place to watch cricket, and the Club was conveniently located to facilitate a little lunch and some recreation. Nowhere on the application form is anyone asked to give reasons for wanting membership, nor is anyone asked to show their possible value to the Club. Yet, on the eve of the ballot meeting, I was asked to spell out possible benefits I could bring to the Club; just to ensure that my application was not viewed as an attempt to score one for women's "suffrage", as the late Gerry Gomez, a former president, had told me it would be seen. And what if it is? I figured that as a journalist who often writes about cricket, and as someone with considerable editing experience, I could at least be of some use in the Club's documentation of West Indies cricket. I mentioned that there was little archival information regarding our cricket history, and that as a great many of our elder cricketers were approaching their twilight years, we should attempt to document their stories before it is too late. (It is a project I feel very committed to and will undertake with or without their support.) Their response was that the Club is not interested in that sort of thing, I should try the Trinidad and Tobago Cricket Board of Control instead. So what is the Queen's Park Cricket Club interested in, then? And, more specifically, what was the reason for me being rejected, after waiting for so long? About six months ago, I had been told by a member of the management committee that although it was true that the waiting list was long, my application had been overtaken by several others, because the committee was unwilling to bring it up. I had been told that the subject of letting a woman into the Club would have to come before the annual general meeting so that some kind of discussion could take place and the members could have a chance to ventilate their views. At least two such meetings have taken place without the matter even coming up for an official glance. The membership has not been given a chance to discuss it. That confirms the suspicion that those not in favour are those occupying the rule-making positions. It suggests that they rely on the idea that the general membership, as is the case in most organisations, is ignorant about what goes on at the policy level. For those who do not know, I would like to point out that there is no rule debarring women from entry into the Club. I would like to point out that all the other Clubs in the region and really, in the world, have expressly made rules to allow women to join them (even the MCC). I would also like to point out that the Queen's Park Cricket Club, which was formed in 1891 to control cricket in this country (until the TTCBC was formed 90 years later) took upon itself a large role in a sport which is of deep significance to everyone in the Caribbean, man or woman. Its status as a private members' club does not embrace its responsibility for the cricket culture it has chosen to hog to its bosom. It is home to this country's only Test-match ground, and as a citizen of this country, as a cricket supporter, I have the right to be able to attend cricket matches and not to be excluded on the basis of my sex from any part of that ground. I had first been astonished by the decision, until I remembered the state of West Indies cricket and reflected that this is the kind of backward thinking which has dominated it. I told the Club's manager, Joey Carew, that I intended to pursue this to the end, and asked his opinion. "Somewhere down the road, something will happen," he said vaguely. He didn't know what, but felt it was a can of worms which needed to be opened. Well, he is right; and I am going to be the first worm out. Happy New Year, QPCC. You'll be hearing from me. Vaneisa Baksh writes for the Express Newspapers in Trinidad and Tobago. This piece was first used for her weekly column, Firefly

fields.headline: Willoughby helps Boland squeeze home
fields.trailText: South Africa
fields.body:
South Africa

Left-arm seamer Charl Willoughby, with match figures of 9-129, bowled Boland to an exciting 10-run victory over Eastern Province in the SuperSport Series game at Port Elizabeth. Willoughby began with 4-42 as EP, replying to Boland's 193, disintegrated to 87 all out. Boland then folded to 104 for 7 before a late rally lifted them to 232, setting EP an unlikely 339 for victory. That they even got close was thanks to 118 from David Callaghan, but it was Willoughby who stole the headlines with 5-87.

Boland 193 and 232 (Justin Kemp 4-30) Eastern Province 87 and 328
Boland won by 10 runs

Vasbert Drakes was in the wickets again as Border wallopped Western Province by an innings at East London. Drakes took 5-37 as WP collapsed to 111 in their first innings. Alan Dawson hit back with 6-51 for WP but Border still managed 340, before skittling WP a second time.

Western Province 111 and 155 (Ashwell Prince 51) Border 340
Border won by an innings and 74 runs

An unbeaten 118 from Free State opener Jacobus Venter was enough to inflict Boland's first defeat of the season in the one-day Standard Bank Trophy game at Paarl. Venter put on 144 for the first wicket with Boeta Dippenaar (56) and then added a further 93* with Johannes van der Wath (59*) as FS romped home by nine wickets with 14 balls to spare. But Boland remained top.

Boland 236 for 6 in 45 overs (Louis Koen 74, Justin Ontong 81) Free State 237 for 1 in 42.4 overs
Free State won by 9 wickets

Phil Simmons hit 73 to help Easterns to a comfortable win over Eastern Province and second place in the table. Chasing 199, EP reached 103 for 3, but folded sensationally to 117 all out. Only two men made double figures.

Easterns 198 for 7 in 45 overs (Deon Jordaan 64) Eastern Province 117 in 36 overs
Easterns won by 81 runs

Australia

A whirlwind 82* in 62 balls from Michael Hussey guided Western Australia to a six-wicket win over New South Wales at the WACA. It also took them ahead of NSW to the top of the Mercantile Mutual Cup table. Chasing a revised target of 246 in 47 overs after three overs had been lost to rain, WA were given a sound start by the in-form Justin Langer (53), but it Hussey who finished things off with a bang. NSW's total of 249 centred on 70 from Bradley Haddin.

New South Wales 249 in 48 overs (Mark Atkinson 4-38) Western Australia 246 for 4 in 45.2 overs
Western Australia won by 6 wickets (D/L method)

India

Vinod Kambli scored hundreds in each of his first two innings for West Zone in the limited-overs inter-zonal Deodhar Trophy. He began with 106 against North Zone in Rajkot, but still ended up on the losing side. Set a huge 313 to win after Ajay Jadeja had made 91, West Zone were in with a chance at 198 for 2 with 70 balls remaining, but Kambli became the second of two run-out victims for Jadeja, as North lost 5 wickets for 32. They were unable to recover.

North Zone 312 for 8 in 50 overs (Pankaj Dharmani 70) West Zone 283 for 9 in 50 overs
North Zone won by 29 runs

Kambli then plundered 119* off 103 balls against South Zone, this time in a winning cause. He added 226 for the third wicket with Amol Muzumdar (109) as West overhauled South's imposing total of 317 for 8 with 13 balls to spare.

South Zone 317 for 8 (Jagadish Arun Kumar 120, Sadagopan Mahesh 85) West Zone 320 for 4 in 47.5 overs
West Zone won by 6 wickets

East Zone made staggeringly light work of another target of 300-plus, as they trounced Central Zone by seven wickets at Baroda. Central made 305 for 7 with Jai Yadav smoting 128 off 117 balls, but East reached their target with almost ten overs to spare. Nikhil Haldipur biffed 127 off 111 balls, and Saba Karim bashed 102* off just 89. Opening bowler Harvinder Sodhi returned figures of 5-0-51-1.

Central Zone 305 for 7 in 50 overs East Zone 309 for 3 in 40.1 overs
East Zone won by 9 wickets

Vikram Rathour hit 70 to steer North Zone to an easy win over East Zone at Baroda. It also gave North an early lead in the table.

East Zone 166 in 44.5 overs North Zone 167 for 3 in 31.3 overs
North Zone won by 7 wickets

West Indies

Chris Gayle hit 121* but Jamaica fell short of the 300 they needed to beat Guyana in the Busta Cup game at Sabina Park, closing on 236 for 6. A century from Travis Dowlin (102) had earlier helped Guyana to 287 in their first innings, before Jamaica replied with 206.

Guyana 287 (Williams 6-45) and 218 for 8 decl. Jamaica 206 (Colin Stuart 4-53, Neil McGarrell 4-32) and 236 for 6
Match drawn

The other two games in the second round were ruined by rain. Just 15 minutes' play were possible on the final two days of the game between the Windward Islands and Trinidad & Tobago at St Lucia, while an undefeated 109 from Barbados wicketkeeper Courtney Browne turned out to be in vain in the draw with the Leeward Islands at Barbados.

Windward Islands 238 (Jan 5-67) and 5 for 0 Trinidad & Tobago 122
Match drawn

Leeward Islands 255 (Stuart Williams 62, Hendy Bryan 5-38) and 178 for 8 (RS Morten 70*) Barbados 266 (Curtly Ambrose 4-47)
Match drawn

New Zealand

Consecutive hundreds from Nathan Astle took Canterbury to the top of the one-day Shell Cup standings with one round to go. First Astle made 122 in the win over Wellington in Christchurch, putting on 153 for the 2nd wicket with Stephen Fleming (60). Then he hit 109 to see off Otago at Invercargill. Canterbury completed a third win when Fleming hit 90 to overhaul Northern Districts, after Astle had taken 4-52.

Mathew Sinclair, who will forever be remembered as the man who hit a double-century on Test debut, had to settle for 110 as Central Districts squeezed out Otago in the bottom-of-the-table clash at Oamaru. CD ran up 305 for 6, but Otago then opened with a stand of 120 for the first wicket before falling away.

CD were then put in their place by 145 from Auckland's Vincent in a 75-run defeat at Napier, and were humbled again when Wellington dismissed them for 114, with Richard Petrie taking 4-26.

The Parlane brothers, Michael and Neal, shared their second century partnership of the competition, but couldn't prevent Northern Districts going down to Wellington by one wicket in Whangarei. Michael made 111 and Neal 54 in a second-wicket stand of 114 as ND ran up 280 for 7, but Richard Petrie smashed 78* from just 54 balls, including five fours and five sixes, to win it for Wellington with one ball to spare. Petrie added 16* for the tenth wicket with Robert Kennedy, who didn't face a ball. Earlier, Matthew Bell made 70.

Round 7

Canterbury 270 for 6 in 50 overs (PA Hitchcock 4-39) Wellington 239 for 9 in 50 overs (ST Donaldson 71)
Canterbury won by 31 runs

Central Districts 305 for 6 in 50 overs (Jacob Oram 62) Otago 290 for 9 in 50 overs (AJ Hore 73)
Central Districts won by 15 runs

Round 8

Auckland 295 for 7 in 50 overs (Blair Pocock 50, Andrew Penn 4-58) Central Districts 220 in 43.4 overs
Auckland won by 75 runs

Northern Districts 280 for 7 in 50 overs Wellington 282 for 9 in 49.5 overs
Wellington won by 1 wicket

Canterbury 258 for 7 in 50 overs Otago 179 in 46.2 overs (RD Burson 4-45)
Canterbury won by 79 runs

Round 9

Auckland 218 for 7 in 50 overs (Tamahau Canning 84) Otago 213 for 9 in 50 overs (Chris Drum 4-28)
Auckland won by 5 runs

Northern Districts 234 in 49.2 overs Canterbury 235 for 6 in 48.5 overs
Canterbury won by 4 wickets

Central Districts 114 in 34.5 overs Wellington 115 for 3 in 19.1 overs (Chris Nevin 53)
Wellington won by 7 wickets

Standings (after 9 rounds) 1 Canterbury 15 pts, 2 Auckland 14, 3 Northern Districts 8, 4 Wellington 8, 5 Central Districts 5, 6 Otago 4

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Kohl slush fund inquiry to examine French connection

fields.headline: Kohl slush fund inquiry to examine French connection
fields.trailText: A German parliamentary inquiry yesterday broadened its scope to investigate a report that France's late former president François Mitterrand used £10m of taxpayers' money to get his friend and ally Helmut Kohl re-elected as chancellor.
fields.body:
A German parliamentary inquiry yesterday broadened its scope to investigate a report that France's late former president François Mitterrand used £10m of taxpayers' money to get his friend and ally Helmut Kohl re-elected as chancellor.

The decision came as Germany's Christian Democrat Union (CDU) revealed that the total amount of untraceable funds on its books had reached almost DM29m (£9m).

The sum is higher than the party had previously acknowledged. But the alleged secret contribution from France was not included in the accounts disclosed yesterday, so the total may go much higher.

Pledging to cleanse the party's financial arrangements, the CDU's leader, Wolfgang Schäuble, said the way it had gathered its revenue under his predecessor, Mr Kohl, was a "violation not only of the party funding laws, but of German democracy".

But the scandal is now about more even than that. The alleged French contribution raises the question of whether Europe's recent, rapid integration - largely a product of the Kohl-Mitterrand alliance - was bought on the sly.

The alleged French donation was reported to have been generated from commission on the sale of Leuna, an east German oil refinery, to the French oil consortium Elf Aquitaine.

A spokesman for the prosecutors' office in Paris said that an investigation into Elf's dealings had not so far found a link with illegal funding for the German CDU.

But in Berlin, the head of a parliamentary inquiry into the funding scandal said it would be looking at the possibility of a French connection. "We shall expand the focus of the inquiry," said Volker Neumann, a Social Democrat MP.

"We don't have any evidence for now, but we must investigate this. It seems to me unthinkable that one European state would use public money to try to influence an election in a neighbouring state - but in this world one can never be sure".

Releasing a long-awaited report from a team of independent auditors, the CDU's treasurer, Matthias Wissman, said the party had been unable to identify the origin of DM2.2m paid to the party's central treasury between 1993 and 1998. This roughly corresponds to the amount which Mr Kohl has already admitted taking and failing to disclose. The former chancellor refuses to identify the donors.

The report of a French contribution, compiled jointly by French and German television journalists, fuelled speculation that the CDU's benefactors might have been Mr Mitterrand and - unwittingly - the French taxpayer. But the reported transfer from France, said to have been made in 1993, is far bigger than anything traced by the auditors.

Mr Wissman said the CDU had found another unexplained DM10m (£3.4m). But that was in accounts covering the period 1989-92. The party has also admitted that DM14m (£4.7m) in undisclosed contributions went to its regional branch in Hesse.

Mr Schäuble hinted that the party was preparing legal action against its former treasurer. He said the CDU faced not only political repercussions but also "immense financial consequences".

The Christian Democrats, who have been haemorrhaging support in the polls, have set aside DM8m (£2.5m) to cover their liabilities. But that could prove to be insufficient.
