webTitle: Bush backs plan to make Cuban boy a US citizen

fields.headline: Bush backs plan to make Cuban boy a US citizen
fields.standfirst: Elian Gonzalez's grandmothers fly to meet him in Miami after pleading with attorney general
fields.trailText: The personal and political drama surrounding the six-year-old Cuban boy Elian Gonzalez escalated to a new level of intensity yesterday as his two grandmothers unexpectedly travelled to visit the boy in Miami and local Republican politicians announced moves to make him a US citizen.
fields.body:
The personal and political drama surrounding the six-year-old Cuban boy Elian Gonzalez escalated to a new level of intensity yesterday as his two grandmothers unexpectedly travelled to visit the boy in Miami and local Republican politicians announced moves to make him a US citizen.

The grandmothers' visit to the US to press for the refugee boy's return to his father in Cuba had been confined to New York and Washington and there had been no indication that the two women would enter the lions' den of the Cuban exile community in Florida to meet Elian.

Yesterday, Raquel Rodriguez and Mariela Quintana decided to fly from New York to Miami for an encounter with their grandson in the early evening.

Though details of the meeting were still being worked out as the two women left New York, it appeared that the encounter would take place with the blessing of both sides in the tug-of-love battle and that the grandmothers would then return to Cuba, probably today. There were no indications that Elian would accompany them back to Havana.

Florida's Republican senator, Connie Mack, announced in Washington yesterday that he will try this week to intro duce legislation in the US Congress to grant full citizenship to Elian, who was found clinging to a rubber tyre in December after a boat crammed with Cuban refugees, including his mother and stepfather, sank off the Florida coast.

The case has evolved into a full-blown political confrontation between Cuba, where 150,000 people rallied on Saturday calling for Elian to be returned to his father Juan Miguel Gonzalez, and the US, where the power and wealth of the Cuban community around Miami has galvanised opponents of the Castro regime to try to keep the boy in the US at all costs.

The grandmothers arrived in the US last week as guests of the American National Council of Churches, which has played a leading role in trying to secure Elian Gonzalez's return to Cuba. After meetings in New York on Friday, the women went to Washington on Saturday to tell the US attorney general, Janet Reno - who is a Miami Democratic Party politician - that "they are suffering" over the stand-off over the boy's future.

The women gave Ms Reno a letter expressing the wish that Elian "be returned to the normality of life with his father, brother, family, schoolfriends, his toys, dog and parrot".

Ms Reno, who has supported a US Immigration and Naturalisation Service(INS) ruling that Elian should be returned to his father, said that the two women "made a compassionate and heartfelt plea", but she told them that the matter was with the US federal courts.

In Miami, Armando Gutierrez, a spokesman for the boy's Cuban-American relatives who are seeking to keep him in the US, said relatives would "welcome the grandmothers".

"The doors are open and we will make the visit a family visit just as we have stated in the past, and we hope that they come," Mr Gutierrez said. He said talks had been going to prepare for the encounter.

Sen Mack announced yesterday that he would be introducing citizenship legislation in the senate this week, and that a similar move would start soon in the House of Representatives.

The campaign to keep Elian Gonzalez in the US has been embraced by many Republicans and some Democrats, and has become a touchstone issue in Florida politics.

Governor Jeb Bush is the brother of Republican presidential front-runner George W Bush and the state faces an important presidential primary election on February 14.

George W Bush said in an interview in Iowa at the weekend that granting Elian citizenship "would be a wonderful gesture". He added that the boy's father should come to the US to "get a taste of freedom".

Mr Mack's move was immediately condemned by Ms Rodriguez, who asked congress members not to give the boy US citizenship and to let him return to Cuba.

fields.bodyText: The personal and political drama surrounding the six-year-old Cuban boy Elian Gonzalez escalated to a new level of intensity yesterday as his two grandmothers unexpectedly travelled to visit the boy in Miami and local Republican politicians announced moves to make him a US citizen. The grandmothers' visit to the US to press for the refugee boy's return to his father in Cuba had been confined to New York and Washington and there had been no indication that the two women would enter the lions' den of the Cuban exile community in Florida to meet Elian. Yesterday, Raquel Rodriguez and Mariela Quintana decided to fly from New York to Miami for an encounter with their grandson in the early evening. Though details of the meeting were still being worked out as the two women left New York, it appeared that the encounter would take place with the blessing of both sides in the tug-of-love battle and that the grandmothers would then return to Cuba, probably today. There were no indications that Elian would accompany them back to Havana. Florida's Republican senator, Connie Mack, announced in Washington yesterday that he will try this week to intro duce legislation in the US Congress to grant full citizenship to Elian, who was found clinging to a rubber tyre in December after a boat crammed with Cuban refugees, including his mother and stepfather, sank off the Florida coast. The case has evolved into a full-blown political confrontation between Cuba, where 150,000 people rallied on Saturday calling for Elian to be returned to his father Juan Miguel Gonzalez, and the US, where the power and wealth of the Cuban community around Miami has galvanised opponents of the Castro regime to try to keep the boy in the US at all costs. "The doors are open and we will make the visit a family visit just as we have stated in the past, and we hope that they come," Mr Gutierrez said. webTitle: Bush and Gore win Iowa caucuses

fields.headline: Bush and Gore win Iowa caucuses
fields.trailText:
Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W. Bush won the Iowa caucuses last night, validating their
front-runner status in the opening contest of the 2000 presidential election season.
fields.body:
Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W. Bush won the Iowa caucuses last night, validating their front-runner status in the opening contest of the 2000 presidential election season.

Gore won big over Bill Bradley while Bush's victory was tempered by a dramatic second-place showing from conservative publisher Steve Forbes. Gore beat Bradley two-to-one in meetings of Democratic voters in the early counting.

In the Republican race, Bush led conservative publisher Steve Forbes in results that left four other candidates far behind. "It's a solid victory and I'm grateful," the Texas governor said.

webTitle: Chic Parisians find hookers a drag

fields.headline: Chic Parisians find hookers a drag
fields.standfirst: Transvestite draw moves on to steets out of bois
fields.trailText: Transvestite draw moves on to steets out of bois
fields.body:
For the inhabitants of Paris's most sought after district, the winter gales will be remembered not so much for broken windows or tiles as for the arrival of 400 transvestite prostitutes from Latin America.

With cars banned from the nearby Bois de Boulogne for risk of falling trees, the transvestites who walk the woods at night have been deprived of their kerb-crawling clientele. To the fury of residents, they have taken instead to patrolling the chic boulevards of the 16th arrondissement.

"One can't sleep any more. It's atrocious," said Marie-Capucine Fauvet, 63, who lives in an elegant block on Boulevard Anatole-France. "Every night there are dozens of them standing outside the door; add the voyeurs, the pimps, the dealers and the clients, and the noise becomes infernal."

For years one of the capital's leading attractions, the transvestites - known in French as "hermaphrodites in high heels" - are so popular a draw that Saturday night traffic jams can stretch almost a mile.

Mainly from Brazil, Venezuela, Ecuador and Colombia, the transvestites and transsexuals enter France legally on tourist visas. They work from minibuses parked in the 810 hectares (2,000 acres) of woodlands.

The arrival of the circus has so exasperated the arrondissement's mayor, Jean-Pierre Fourcade, that he has written to the justice minister. "The exhibition of hundreds of transvestites driven from their habitual hunting grounds is posing numerous problems," he said. "Please do something."

But a police spokesman said the problem should resolve itself in weeks, as the storm damage had almost been cleared up. "Things will soon be back to normal," he said.

fields.headline: Learning Curve
fields.standfirst: Comedian  Graham Fellows  on idle days in the college coffee bar where he learnt the art of observation
fields.trailText: Graham Fellows trades in nerds. First there was his creation John Shuttleworth, the 55-year-old demon of the Yamaha keyboard who still dreams of rock'n'roll glory. Now there is Brian Appleton, the 40-something musicologist from Solihull, seething at the injustice of his insignificance. The humour is all in the details; you either get the joke or you don't. Most do, thankfully for Fellows' credit rating. And you can't help feeling he picked up all he needed to know about the basics of nerd-dom while at Manchester Polytechnic School of Theatre.
fields.body:
Graham Fellows trades in nerds. First there was his creation John Shuttleworth, the 55-year-old demon of the Yamaha keyboard who still dreams of rock'n'roll glory. Now there is Brian Appleton, the 40-something musicologist from Solihull, seething at the injustice of his insignificance. The humour is all in the details; you either get the joke or you don't. Most do, thankfully for Fellows' credit rating. And you can't help feeling he picked up all he needed to know about the basics of nerd-dom while at Manchester Polytechnic School of Theatre.

"I was quite lazy," he says, "and through my idleness I learnt how to observe people while I was strumming my guitar in the coffee bar." The strumming proved just as useful as the observation, and during his first year he had a hit record in his guise as the classic 70s nerd, Jilted John.

"I came back for my second year while I was still riding high in the charts," he continues, "but I immediately regretted it. I went straight into a student production of a Greek Tragedy that was all papier mache masks, with loads of crying and groaning thrown in."

Like most other pop stars riding high in the charts in the late 70s, Fellows had also learnt a thing or two about smoking, drinking and getting off with women. The consequence was a warning letter from his tutors for repeatedly being late for rehearsals and a growing realisation that the life of a full-time thesp was perhaps not for him.

"In retrospect I should have cashed in on Jilted John," he says. "But my neo-Marxist record company, Rabid Records, advised me to baffle the industry by not producing a follow-up. So I remain a one-hit wonder and all I had to show for it was a house that was falling down."

Even so, he graduated with a 2:1 and got a job with Manchester Youth Theatre before joining Coronation Street as lorry driver Len Charlton. "I fell in love with the town," he sniffs, "I arrived as a 17-year-old on a Honda 50 and the roads all seemed so big. Then I ran out of pubs to go to and now I view the city with a certain sadness."

But maybe that's the price of swapping a Honda for a Yamaha.

 John Shuttleworth and Brian Appleton begin their UK tour on March 17. Call 0171-287 5010 for details.

fields.headline: Books setback for numeracy
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's campaign to improve numeracy among the under-11s is threatened by an acute shortage of suitable maths books in primary schools, the Educational Publishers Council said yesterday.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's campaign to improve numeracy among the under-11s is threatened by an acute shortage of suitable maths books in primary schools, the Educational Publishers Council said yesterday.

A survey of primary heads showed 75% spent less than £1,000 on maths books in the year when schools were preparing for the introduction last term of detailed government guidelines for teaching a daily numeracy hour.

Even the smallest junior school needed to spend more than £2,000 to implement the scheme properly, and the largest primaries more than £6,000. But 61% of schools spent less than £500, 13% less than £50 and 4% nothing at all, the publishers said.

Today the prime minister launches maths year 2000, a campaign to mobilise parents to help to improve the numeracy skills of under-11s. It was triggered by a Mori poll in November showing that parents who helped their children with reading were less confident about maths, and 41% wanted practical assistance.

Mr Blair will promise booklets for every household, backed up by a national advertising campaign and a schools fantasy football league to persuade boys lagging behind in maths that working with numbers can be fun.

He is expected to announce extra resources for primary schools for maths equipment, including number games, puzzles, dice, digit cards and classroom display boards, but it is not clear how much of this can be assigned to books.

The numeracy campaign, following last year's national year of reading, aims to help the government meet its target of 75% of 11-year-olds reaching the expected standard at maths by 2002.

 Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, yesterday promised an extra £20m for schools to manage the introduction of performance pay for teachers.

Senior staff will have until June 5 to apply to go on a higher pay scale, and heads will have until the end of the first week of the summer holidays to assess whether they deserve it.

fields.headline: Musical shares
fields.standfirst:
But has TW/EMI forgotten something?

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The merger of Time Warner (TW) with EMI barely a week after the former had been swallowed by AOL reflects the awesome speed of corporate realignment to meet the challenge of the world wide web. There is scarcely a moment to take breath in this new era when everything is done at a speed known as "internet time". So there's certainly no time to mourn the passing of the last big chunk of the UK music market - with a global share of 14% - into US hands: no time to lament the former dominance of British pop groups in the US. Last year only the Spice Girls (at 99) entered Billboard's Hot 100. And no time to lament this body blow to the founding spirit of the web - individual empowerment.
fields.body:
The merger of Time Warner (TW) with EMI barely a week after the former had been swallowed by AOL reflects the awesome speed of corporate realignment to meet the challenge of the world wide web. There is scarcely a moment to take breath in this new era when everything is done at a speed known as "internet time". So there's certainly no time to mourn the passing of the last big chunk of the UK music market - with a global share of 14% - into US hands: no time to lament the former dominance of British pop groups in the US. Last year only the Spice Girls (at 99) entered Billboard's Hot 100. And no time to lament this body blow to the founding spirit of the web - individual empowerment.

Multinational corporations appear to be the ones being empowered by the internet. They are busily buying each other up to become big enough in global terms to dominate the commerce of the internet. The new TW/EMI conglomerate will provide a one-stop shop for a dizzy array of talent ranging from the Beatles and the Rolling Stones to Madonna and the Red Hot Chilli Peppers. It hopes to take pole position as the industry races to deliver its music through the internet to personal computers, MP3 players (which receive music in digital form) or by wireless to mobile phones - which will be able to do everything that an MP3 player can do and more. Once they have provided a huge one-stop shop for music under a global brand name there will be no room for small players.

Or will there? The behemoths have forgotten one thing. The musicians they are colonising are also "brands" and able, contracts permitting, to deliver their own albums direct to customers. EMI did this first by releasing a David Bowie album recently through the net before it hit the stores. But there is nothing to stop Bowie or others from doing the same on their own. Maybe the TW/EMI colossus is just a huge intermediary waiting to be eaten by the latent power of the web.

webTitle: Nicoli deal delivers a ray of light

fields.headline: Nicoli deal delivers a ray of light
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: When Eric Nicoli , at the time chief executive of United Biscuits , was named as the next chairman of EMI at the start of last year the jibes came thick and fast.
fields.body:
When Eric Nicoli , at the time chief executive of United Biscuits , was named as the next chairman of EMI at the start of last year the jibes came thick and fast.

What did a man who had spent 19 years selling Jaffa Cakes and Hula Hoops know about the pop charts? More keenly felt than the barbed comments was the 4.5% fall in EMI's share price which accompanied his appointment.

Yesterday he sported a barely suppressed grin, perhaps in answer to those critics, as he presented the joint venture with Time Warner . With his close cropped hair and slim fitting suit over an admittedly burly figure, the 49- year-old sat tapping his hand on the arm of his chair in time to Madonna's Ray of Light suggesting he was every bit a player.

Mr Nicoli joined EMI after a sustained period of difficulty compounded by falling music sales worldwide. There were a succession of profit warnings, the business was rife with management disputes and its share price was at new lows after Seagram bought PolyGram instead of EMI.

Since joining, he has focused on reducing costs and developing a strategy for the internet. Profits are again moving up and its market is recovering, although it would be difficult to say how much credit could be laid at Mr Nicoli's door.

The one thing which he had to achieve was a deal with another entertainment industry major - which he has accomplished while maintaining the semblance of control.

fields.headline: Carve-up spares directors' blushes
fields.standfirst:
EMI deal offers board a chance
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lots of nasty things were said about Eric Nicoli last spring when he popped up as the boss of what was then routinely referred to as "embattled music group" EMI.
fields.body:
Lots of nasty things were said about Eric Nicoli last spring when he popped up as the boss of what was then routinely referred to as "embattled music group" EMI.

This business needed a heavy hitter, not someone from a company like United Biscuits, which had underperformed the market by 80% since he became chief executive. At least he would know all about bid speculation, ran the joke at the time.

Sure enough, EMI quickly entered talks with Seagram, but the deal apparently fell down because the EMI board was just too embarrassed to sell the company at less than than 700p a share, at which its was demerged from the Thorn group in 1997.

Shareholders were not given a chance to vote on that matter; instead they are now being asked to approve such a convoluted carving up of the business that only a cocktail of Warburg Dillon Read, Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Wasserstein Perella could have come up with it.

EMI's core music business is being combined with Time Warner's in not one but two 50:50 ventures, together called Warner EMI Music. This is said to be for tax reasons, with the joint ventures having identical boards.

"Old" EMI remains as a British-listed company, comprising the stake in the joint ventures and its holdings in HMV Media, Viva and Channel 5, while direc tors' blushes over the historical 700p share price target are addressed with a 100p cash-back promise to shareholders.

Accompanying this, Time Warner gets an incentive to maximise EMI's share price performance in the form of the right to buy 8% of the British firm if it can keep the stock above 900p, post-100p cash back, for any two weeks in the next three and a half years. Meanwhile, on this side of the Atlantic, EMI's directors have simply promised not to engage in any new business outside Warner EMI Music this side of 2004.

Confused? Well, joint-deputy chairman Sir Peter Walters and the other non-executives on the remuneration committee - Sir Dominic Cadbury, Harald Einsmann, Hugh Jenkins and Kathleen O'Donovan - had no problems at all. They have waved the deal through as a straightforward "change of control", so everyone at the top of the firm gets to see the shares and options sitting awarded as long-term incentives turned into short-term readies. Mr Nicoli has clearly got his head screwed on, but sadly it is not pointing in the direction of his regular shareholders.

Force required

Peter Kindersley may soon need to consult one of his own dictionaries to discover when lots of "one-off" disasters should more accurately be described as a litany of disaster.

The latest warning from his children's book publishing group seems to be one of the worst yet, and has already claimed the scalp of chief executive James Middlehurst. Dorling Kindersley is expecting to lose £25m after having grossly overestimated the number of Star Wars books it was likely to sell in the peak pre-Christmas period. It shifted only 3m out of 13m printed, a result many lay people could have predicted as most cinema-goers have long since moved on to new pastures.

Even if this fits Mr Kindersley's definition of "one-off", the other horrors lurking in the trading statement do not. The firm, now reliant on generous treatment from its bankers, is badly misjudging its stock control - it has £44m of unsold goods in warehouses - and has taken too long to come to grips with the need to establish a more reliable distribution arrangement in the UK. The group cannot afford, as happened last September, to fail to get its books on to the shelves of an important retailer like WH Smith.

Dorling Kindersley should be sitting pretty - it is developing a good multimedia offering, has an amazingly strong brand, a credibly strong presence in the American market and is smack-bang in the middle of one of the most promising media sectors - education.

But that franchise is persistently un dermined by management ineptitude. In its record since joining the stock market in 1992, there has been one constant, Peter Kindersley, who leapt straight back into the driving seat yesterday.

His strong identification with the company - he founded it and still speaks for nearly a third of the shares - should be an advantage.

But it is hard to escape the conclusion that he is part of the problem. He had to be prised out of the role of chairman and chief executive and remains executive chairman. Regardeless of whether the board complies with the rules of corporate governance, it is lacking in heavyweight independents to act as a counterweight to Mr Kindersley.

The chances of attracting a new chief executive of calibre can only be aided by a promise to strengthen the board. Either that, or Mr Kindesley's advisers should find a buyer for the firm, before the £1 bookshops are overwhelmed.

It shifted only 3m out of 13m printed, a result many lay people could have predicted as most cinema-goers have long since moved on to new pastures. Even if this fits Mr Kindersley's definition of "one-off", the other horrors lurking in the trading statement do not. The firm, now reliant on generous treatment from its bankers, is badly misjudging its stock control - it has £44m of unsold goods in warehouses - and has taken too long to come to grips with the need to establish a more reliable distribution arrangement in the UK. The group cannot afford, as happened last September, to fail to get its books on to the shelves of an important retailer like WH Smith. Dorling Kindersley should be sitting pretty - it is developing a good multimedia offering, has an amazingly strong brand, a credibly strong presence in the American market and is smack-bang in the middle of one of the most promising media sectors - education. But that franchise is persistently un dermined by management ineptitude. In its record since joining the stock market in 1992, there has been one constant, Peter Kindersley, who leapt straight back into the driving seat yesterday. His strong identification with the company - he founded it and still speaks for nearly a third of the shares - should be an advantage. But it is hard to escape the conclusion that he is part of the problem. He had to be prised out of the role of chairman and chief executive and remains executive chairman. Regardeless of whether the board complies with the rules of corporate governance, it is lacking in heavyweight independents to act as a counterweight to Mr Kindersley. The chances of attracting a new chief executive of calibre can only be aided by a promise to strengthen the board. Either that, or Mr Kindesley's advisers should find a buyer for the firm, before the £1 bookshops are overwhelmed.

fields.headline: Options row sours £12bn marriage
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: EMI put itself on a potential collision course with investors yesterday when it emerged that directors' share options will crystalise on completion of the proposed joint venture with Time Warner. At the current share price, Ken Berry, who is chief executive of EMI, will cash in options worth £14.3m while Martin Bandier who runs EMI's publishing division will make £8.6m.
fields.body:
EMI put itself on a potential collision course with investors yesterday when it emerged that directors' share options will crystalise on completion of the proposed joint venture with Time Warner. At the current share price, Ken Berry, who is chief executive of EMI, will cash in options worth £14.3m while Martin Bandier who runs EMI's publishing division will make £8.6m.

The creation of the £12bn Warner EMI Music joint venture, which will vie for the title of largest music group in the world, was formally unveiled after the two sides spent the weekend finalising the deal.

The agreement sees both companies pooling their star-laden music businesses into the venture with each owning a 50% share. EMI will retain its listing on the London stock market and shareholders will receive a special dividend of 100p on completion.

The two sides were at pains to present the deal as a merger of equals, but the EMI remuneration committee decided it does present a change of ownership triggering the directors' options and provoking anger among some investors. "When is a takeover not a takeover?" asked one fund manager with a large stake in the company. "It seems a little odd that they should be able to benefit from early exercise of their options when other shareholders are not cashing in in the same way." The options will exercise at the EMI share price on the day.

This is not the first time EMI has come under fire for the remuneration of its directors. Former chief executive Jim Fifield pocketed a £12.5m payoff when he left the group in 1998.

Around 3,000 jobs will be lost worldwide as a consequence of the joint venture and some poorer performing artists will also be culled in a drive to achieve cost savings of £250m.

Shares in EMI yesterday soared 11% to 720p on confirmation of the deal which brings Madonna, Janet Jackson, Blur and Robbie Williams under the same group - partly from anticipation that it may prompt a counter-bid from another of the global music businesses. Germany's Bertelsmann, the favourite candidate said however it would not torpedo the deal.

Richard Parsons, president of Time Warner said: "If there's such a thing as a perfect fit, Warner EMI Music is it."

America Online's armslength involvement through its takeover of Time Warner also excited other media shares as investors tried to guess where the convergence of content and internet would head next.

Eric Nicoli, EMI chairman who will assume the same co-role in the joint venture, said the sides had been talking since the end of September. "If it's Monday then it most be a megamerger. This may not be as big as Time Warner AOL or Smithkline Beecham and Glaxo Welcome but it's of just as much importance to our industry.

"We were committed to this deal before AOL appeared and, when we heard, we reviewed the situation and clearly it only adds power to the proposition." The combined group said it will have 20% global market share behind Universal PolyGram although some estimates said it would have as much as 27%. It will have a roster of 2,500 artists, 2,000 albums a year and over 2m song copyrights.

EMI, the listed entity, will also comprise the British group's stake in the HMV retail chain and a series of investments in web-based music companies.

Mr Nicoli forecast that within four years 10% of CD sales would be via the internet with digital downloading of content starting to make a contribution at around the same time.

Chris Smith culture secretary at the music industry's annual get-together in Cannes said British artists could benefit from the deal despite widespread concerns that the last major domestic company has effectively fallen into the hands of an overseas firm. The business will be based in New York and Roger Ames, chief executive of Warner Music, will be in the driving seat of the combined business. Time Warner will hold six seats on the board and EMI five.

Jeremy Batstone of NatWest Stockbrokers said: "I think EMI shareholders are likely to be underwhelmed by this. EMI shareholders wanted a full takeout. A 50-50 joint venture, with Time Warner holding a golden share is not what they anticipated." Time Warner has the right to receive 8% of EMI's enlarged share capital if the EMI share price reaches 900p within three and a half years following completion of the deal.

webTitle: You can't surf and watch, but you will surf and listen - any time, anywhere

fields.headline: You can't surf and watch, but you will surf and listen - any time, anywhere
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Time Warner's deals with AOL and EMI have changed the world. The focus of discussion of that change has been video, but it is audio, and radio in particular, that will, I believe, play as big a part in the future of the internet as video.
fields.body:
Time Warner's deals with AOL and EMI have changed the world. The focus of discussion of that change has been video, but it is audio, and radio in particular, that will, I believe, play as big a part in the future of the internet as video.

Radio, as the oldest electronic medium of all, ironically is best placed to capitalise on the brave new dot.com world.

One of the sobering facts reported in the wake of the Time-Warner/AOL deal was that sentiment moved towards the web in the US investment community when it was pointed out that more people were online in the evening than were watching the two largest cable channels, MTV and CNN, combined.

It is hard, now, to see UK television being overtaken by the web, but that is because we use a different web access business model - free access with charged calls (as opposed to charged access and free calls in the US).

But our model is about to change towards the American, led by the cable companies and BT's new broadband technology ADSL. Increased net usage, and lower television viewing, will be the result.

You can't do both at the same time. But you can go online and still listen to the radio, and that is why radio is such a powerful complement to internet activity, and the first of three reasons why radio has such a great role in the new economy.

For some, listening while online is simply a matter of switching on the radio by their PC; others listen to an online station while surfing.

The arrival of broadband web access promises better quality audio streaming, although even now radio broadcasts are pretty good. (Sample www.heartfm.co.uk or www.galaxyfm.co.uk from the Chrysalis stable.)

It will also allow the encoding of rich data within the audio stream. At Chrysalis we are already encoding advertisers' web addresses into our audio stream, which allows listeners to click on to their site as their ad plays, and we've also encoded e-commerce details for every song we play, along with links to the websites of featured artists.

The second reason why radio's future is bright is a new distribution technology - digital radio.

Every national BBC and commercial service is using the new technology, and new national digital-only commercial stations are being added almost every month. Regional cities will have up to 40 services available. London will have more.

As they are broadcast digitally, these stations can all carry data, just as web radio does now - and the receivers can be built into PCs. Digital radios will also work on the move - not just in cars, but also in mobile phones.

In a couple of years' time, just as the next generation of mobile phones are making high-bandwidth web access portable, they'll come with built-in digital radios. When not on the phone, users will be able to plug in their earpiece and listen to a digital station for free - and again embedded data will mean they can respond to, or get more information on, anything you hear on air.

The final reason why radio is looking forward to the dot.com future with such confidence is that our unique qualities as an advertising medium are perfectly suited to the new economy. We're immediate, trusted by our listeners, capable of being targeted (commercial radio in particular appeals to those under 45 - the online generation), and great for repetition of simple messages.

So, radio complements the internet in usage patterns, we're building a new transmission mechanism to allow both mobile-phone and PC-based radio listening, and as an advertising medium, we fit the needs of the new economy perfectly - not bad for the oldest electronic medium around.

 Phil Riley is chief executive of Chrysalis Radio

fields.headline: The notional health service
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: There were three reasons why I was reluctant to engage in bashing the National Health Service during the flu epidemic. First, after last year's experiences under the surgeon's knife and six long months in hospital, I owe my life to the NHS. Secondly, I read Lord Winston's interview in the New Statesman, and found what he had to say pompous and reactionary, both on the NHS and on the "hereditaries" thrown out of the House of Lords, whom he nostalgically supports. Then, gathering up courage, I fought my way through last week's Commons debate on the health service. The Tories could hardly contain their delight at what they felt was a crisis for the NHS. Too gutless to attack the principle of the NHS head on, as their party did when the NHS was formed, they all put forward "reforms" which would weaken or destroy it.
fields.body:
There were three reasons why I was reluctant to engage in bashing the National Health Service during the flu epidemic. First, after last year's experiences under the surgeon's knife and six long months in hospital, I owe my life to the NHS. Secondly, I read Lord Winston's interview in the New Statesman, and found what he had to say pompous and reactionary, both on the NHS and on the "hereditaries" thrown out of the House of Lords, whom he nostalgically supports. Then, gathering up courage, I fought my way through last week's Commons debate on the health service. The Tories could hardly contain their delight at what they felt was a crisis for the NHS. Too gutless to attack the principle of the NHS head on, as their party did when the NHS was formed, they all put forward "reforms" which would weaken or destroy it.

A blustering speech came from the former defence secretary, Michael Portillo, who seems to have lost none of his old SAS form. He concentrated on the way the NHS is funded - by general taxation. This was, he boomed, "a historical accident not replicated by any other country in the world". Sensible European countries, he revealed, finance their healthcare mainly by other means - by national or private insurance, for instance. Why could not Britain do the same? The same point in different ways was made by Dr Liam Fox, the Tory's health spokesman, and Sir Norman Fowler who spoke exactly as if he is a director of a private health insurance company. (Well, he is in a way. He's a director of Numark, which he described as an industrial provident society with more than 1,300 community pharmacies.)

Financing the NHS out of general taxation is not a historical accident. It was the result of a well thought out decision by the Labour government's secretary of state of the time, Aneurin Bevan. The proof is in Bevan's book, In Place of Fear, which was published in 1952, a year after Bevan and other ministers resigned over the imposition of the first prescription charges. Bevan writes that he carefully studied the various proposals for financing the health service. "Should the health service be on an insurance basis? I decided against this. It had always seemed to me that a personal contributory basis was peculiarly inappropriate to a national health service." He then listed the "endless anomalies" which would result from any insurance system - "limited benefits for limited contributions", for instance, and humiliating, vexatious means-testing of patients who can't afford the premiums. "The really objectionable feature," he concluded, "is the creation of a two-standard health service, one below and one above the salt. It is merely the old British poor law system over again. The essence of a satisfactory health service is that the rich and the poor are treated alike, that poverty is not a disability and wealth is not advantaged."

That the British health service, unlike any other in Europe, is paid for out of general taxation is not a historical accident but a socialist idea translated into action. No wonder Portillo & Co hate it so much, and refuse to draw the real lesson from the flu crisis: that the health service is in a mess not because of where its money comes from, but because that money is not enough.

I hope that the prime minister and his health secretary hold out for Aneurin Bevan's simple socialist idea against the latest assault on it by the Tories and the health insurance industry. This hope, however, is not encouraged by the enthusiasm with which ministers have endorsed PFI (private finance initiative) schemes for building new hospitals. These schemes have the same flaws and will lead to the same poor law catastrophes that Bevan predicted for an insurance-dominated health service.

Nor does there seem to be any limit to the government's craze for privatisation. Last week the name was announced of the head of the new transport super-quango, or task force. He is old Etonian Willy Rickett, described as "one of the chief architects of electricity privatisation in the late 80s". As such, no doubt he will be remembered by the opponents of electricity privatisation at the time. Labour's frontbench spokesman on energy, for instance, told the Commons on December 12 1988: "We are proud that we took this industry [electricity] into public ownership." He railed against the "stupidity, indeed the impossibility, of an energy policy determined by the interests of the private sector". And he promised: "When we come to power, it [the electricity industry] will be reinstated as a public service for the people of this country and will not be run for private profit." The name of this keen young socialist spokesman, who has since surrendered the entire electricity industry to private profit, and now promotes the civil servant most closely involved in its privatisation, will not surprise you: The Rt Hon Tony Blair.

webTitle: Labour peer renews NHS cash plea

fields.headline: Labour peer renews NHS cash plea
fields.standfirst:
Tories seize on fertility expert's new remarks in radio interview to maintain pressure over spending pledges
Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The Labour peer, Lord Winston, reignited the row he had triggered over the government's handling of the NHS when he yesterday urged Tony Blair to make a firmer commitment to raise health spending in line with the rest of Europe.
fields.body:
The Labour peer, Lord Winston, reignited the row he had triggered over the government's handling of the NHS when he yesterday urged Tony Blair to make a firmer commitment to raise health spending in line with the rest of Europe. The fertility expert also appeared to call for a broader approach to funding health care, possibly including closer links with the private sector.

Lord Winston's remarks in a radio interview were seized on by the Conservatives as they sought to keep pressure on the government over the NHS issue. William Hague, visiting the Christie cancer hospital in Manchester, said: "Any government commitment should be definite."

Liam Fox, Tory shadow health secretary, said: "At a time when Tony Blair is ever more dogmatic in his refusal to use private provision to bolster the NHS, Lord Winston rightly points out the beneficial experience of other European countries with mixed provision in health care." It was Lord Winston's criticism of the state of the NHS, almost a fortnight ago, that turned the government's problems with the winter flu outbreak into a full-blown crisis.

At the time, it was widely reported that the Labour machine had come down hard on the peer and forced him to qualify his comments. But he insisted yesterday that "nobody's got to me" and that he was "expecting to be able to talk to people in Downing Street in the next week or two".

Interviewed by Jeremy Paxman on BBC Radio 4's Start the Week, Lord Winston agreed that Mr Blair should declare a firm commitment - rather than an "aspiration", as it has been described officially - to raise NHS funding 5% a year in real terms to put Britain on a par with the European Union average of health spending by 2006.

"I think that there is a risk if you spend half of what other people spend of your gross domestic product on health care, and actually, practically speaking, that's what we do in Britain," he said.

It was not true, as had been argued, that the "European model" of health care was less efficient than Britain's heavy reliance on the NHS. "I think that there are a lot of things that we should be learning from ther countries' ways of spending on health care."

Lord Winston described his reported comment that Britain spent less on health care than did Poland as "a bit of rhetoric", but said he otherwise felt his intervention had been "a useful exercise".

 The government yesterday dismissed claims that NHS laboratories were using un qualified staff to test for disease. A survey by the Instititute of Biomedical Science had suggested 58% of laboratories were resorting to "inappropriate or unqualified" labour because of an acute shortage of scientists.

Lord Hunt, junior health minister, said that he "wholly rejected" suggestions that untrained staff were being used to test for cancer or HIV and that the survey was "pretty long on allegations and pretty short on facts".

fields.headline: '529 Russians' die in January as efforts to take Grozny escalate
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: New evidence detailing the extent of casualties suffered by Russia during its offensive against Chechnya emerged last night as sources in the security services revealed that at least 529 men had been lost this month.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow and  Ian Black  in Brussels
fields.body:
New evidence detailing the extent of casualties suffered by Russia during its offensive against Chechnya emerged last night as sources in the security services revealed that at least 529 men had been lost this month.

This figure far exceeds the number admitted by Russian officials. Since the beginning of the year, the military has continued to report extremely low daily losses - usually no more than two or three - despite the growing bitterness of the battle to seize Grozny.

Public scepticism of the officially released casualty rates has grown, particularly now that soldiers have taken to shouting out their own, much higher figures, to Russian television reporters in the war zone.

Overall, the Russian government has admitted to losing approximately 800 men, but the Soldiers' Mothers Committee in Moscow, which campaigns for the rights of Russia's beleaguered conscripts, has put the total estimated dead at around 3,000.

The independent television station NTV claimed yesterday that the actual death toll among Russian soldiers and interior ministry troops fighting in the separatist state exceeded even these leaked figures, suggesting that it could be up to 10 times higher than the official total.

The defence ministry has not released a figure for its dead for several days now, and was not available for comment on the death toll last night.

Explaining the high casualty figures for January, the same security service source told the Russian news agency, Interfax, that high casualties were inevitable for any attacker embarking on urban warfare.

"The rebels have turned Grozny into a strong fortress, mining buildings and roads. Moreover, the federal forces are being opposed by well-trained mobile rebel groups," one military analyst commented.

European Union foreign ministers, meanwhile, backed away from tough action against Russia yesterday, agreeing only to shift technical assistance programmes to humanitarian aid, to underline disapproval of Moscow's war in Chechnya.

Diplomats insisted that these steps were better than nothing, though some observers have begun to argue that it would in fact be better for the EU to abandon any pretence of taking action that will moderate Russian policy. Many believe privately that the popularity of the war is such than Mr Putin has no incentive to let up at all.

At last month's EU summit in Helsinki, western governments and human rights agencies issued mild threats to cut Russia off from the international community, which they believed had the temporary effect of halting the military onslaught on the Chechen capital.

Keith Vaz, foreign office minister for Europe, insisted last night: "Had we not taken this line, the situation would have been much worse." Privately, however, western diplomats concede that they have little influence on the way the Russian military conducts its campaign.

The EU also warned Russia that it should strictly implement the trade provisions of its cooperation agreement with the union.

In Warsaw, meanwhile, the Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, said he would like to discuss the war in Chechnya and Russia's new military doctrine in Moscow. He said he is awaiting an official invitation to meet Mr Putin and put relations back on track.

fields.headline: A morass of Welsh emotion
fields.standfirst:
What a true leader needs is flair, personality and sheer, damn hwyl

Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: What a true leader needs is flair, personality and sheer, damn  hwyl.
fields.body:
It is appropriate now and again to bring to readers' attention the politics of far-off countries that do not normally command much space in British newspapers. Sometimes it is even important to do so. Quite possibly you are unaware of the current crisis in a small, mountainous, inaccessible, mostly beautiful, European principality whose political life has hitherto been stunted by outside domination. The principality is called Wales.

Whereas the London mayoralty contest has engaged Fleet Street's constant attention, the Welsh crisis has been almost wholly ignored. There are sound reasons for this, starting with the fact that the mayoral race constitutes a municipal freak show unmatched anywhere outside the borough council of Royston Vasey, whereas Wales has only Alun Michael. As they say, charisn'tma.

But Wales might not have Alun Michael much longer. Next month he faces a vote of no confidence in the Welsh assembly. If the non-Labour parties all vote together against him, Mr Michael will lose: he only has 28 seats out of 60. Since the assembly is less than a year old and precedent is in short supply, it isn't entirely clear what would happen next, though we may assume - since this involves New Labour - that it will be something dishonourable.

The immediate casus belli is Objective One. This is the status recently granted by Brussels to huge tracts of west Wales and the Valleys, ranking them with Europe's most disadvantaged areas. No one is insulted, since it involves the injection of vast quantities of cash which is unlikely to be re-offered once the eastern countries start joining the EU, and Wales moves away from the bottom of the European non-champions' league. But this cash requires £85m worth of matching funds from the British government, which shows no sign of appearing.

There is a secondary cause of discontent, which concerns Mr Michael himself. No one wanted him to have the job of first secretary (and what a quaint title that is), including Mr Michael. And he has on the whole lived up to expectations: he is conscientious, hard-working and masterful with detail.

He has also been utterly unable to be the kind of leader Wales needed: someone with the flair and personality and sheer damn hwyl to embody the contradictory morass of emotions that constitute Welsh national aspirations, and enthuse the people with support for an assembly widely regarded as a waste of money. Less obviously, he has also been seen as dictatorial, and unable to adapt to the new cooperative forms of politics that were supposed to come with devolution, especially in a body that has no majority party.

There is some fascinating jockeying going on. At the centre of it is Ron Davies, aka Confused of Clapham Common, whose political death may have been exaggerated. He is now positioning himself as philosopher-king. Last week he gave a lecture at Cardiff University (Western Mail headline: "We can't go on like this") in which he advocated a full-scale coalition at the assembly, an option described by one hysterical Labour MP as "the road to fascism".

A Davies comeback is still improbable, though as he nudges closer to the nationalists, not impossible. The only other visible rival to Michael is Rhodri Morgan, whose stock has fallen in the year since Tony Blair sabotaged his moral victory in the battle to lead Welsh Labour. Being despised by Downing Street is probably a necessary qualification to be a credible leader in Wales, but not a sufficient one. Apart from that there are only people no one has heard of; the option of a Plaid Cymru-Lib Dem coalition, also without a majority; and (most likely of all) a fix, with some semi-bogus cash injection from Gordon Brown that enables Michael to limp on.

At the moment life is carrying on as ever. Michael yesterday unveiled a white paper with his plan for Wales. The aims include reducing teenage pregnancies so that there are no more than elsewhere in the UK, and increasing non-car journeys to work from a fifth to a quarter. All by 2010. This is just soooooo exciting, I can hardly tell you. But there are some far more general implications. Next week there is a Westminster byelection in Ceredigion (as in "I'm cold, I must find my ceredigion"). Plaid is expected to romp it. Indeed, if things go on the way they are, Labour could lose heaps of seats to them in the next election.

We see the same pattern all over Britain. No one, but no one, wants the Tories back. There remains great goodwill towards Mr Blair. However, when the opportunity comes to teach him a lesson without giving aid and comfort to William Hague, voters take it. The lesson is that devolution means giving away power: if that means letting in Rhodri or Ken, tough luck. Yet the prime minister can't grasp it at all. His infernal bossiness may yet destroy him.

 Matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

fields.headline: And still they come
fields.standfirst:
Asylum seekers arrive here at the rate of 6,000 a month but the system to process applications has led to a backlog of more than 98,000 cases

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Asylum seekers arrive here at the rate of 6,000 a month but the system to process applications has led to a backlog of more than 98,000 cases
fields.body:
If the last century was an epoch of wars and revolutions, this one will be marked by the mass flight of millions driven from their homes by famine, wars and ecological disasters. Sadako Ogata, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, says the massive asylum emergencies of recent years show no sign of disappearing. Indeed they seem to arrive with increasing frequency.

"Twenty years ago, we dealt with 2.5m refugees. Today we care for 21m," she said last month. "Large-scale refugee emergencies do not seem to end. In 1999 alone, we had to deal with the rapid exodus, and the even quicker repatriation of 1m Kosovans; in Indonesia, with the plight of 200,000 East Timorese forced by harassment and violence to abandon their homes; and very recently, in Russia, with 200,000 Chechens fleeing military action in their autonomous republic."

It is little wonder then that many more asylum seekers should make their way to Europe and to Britain in particular. Given the breathtaking numbers involved, perhaps the most surprising aspect is not how many try to find refuge in Britain but how few risk long journeys in the backs of lorries or on false passports in a desperate attempt to get into this country.

Britain's system for handling this growing flow of asylum applications and sorting out the genuine from the abusive remains close to breakdown. Official forecasts drawn up only last March predicted that the total number of asylum seekers coming to Britain in the financial year 1999-2000 would reach a record 59,000. Three months before the end of that financial year the total has already reached 67,500 and the home office admits it will have to revise its forecast. New figures are due out today.

A year ago the head of the home office immigration and nationality directorate publicly declared that the "wheels had come off the wagon", when the combination of a botched computerisation project and a head-office move reduced the number of decisions made on individual asylum cases to only 800 in December 1998. In the same month some 4,770 new applications were received. The scale of decision making has recovered to a small extent with 2,650 decisions made in November 1999, but applications are now running at 6,400 new asylum seekers each month. The final figure for this financial year is likely to be closer to 82,000 new applicants.

With asylum seekers arriving in Britain at the rate of 6,000-plus a month and decisions running at about 2,700 a month, another bleak consequence of this inefficient system is an ever-growing backlog of asylum seekers existing on a mixture of vouchers and cash, waiting for months for a decision on their cases.

The last official count put the backlog at the end of November at 98,045. A year ago the backlog stood at what was then regarded as a record 64,770 asylum seekers and their families waiting for a decision. Now, only 12 months later, it is more than 100,000 - an increase of more than 50%. It is yet to be seen if a decision to employ several hundred more immigration staff will solve the problem.

When the home office drew up its forecasts last March it assumed asylum applications would peak at 59,000 this financial year and then fall sharply in the 12 months to April 2001 to only 42,000 with 46,000 the year after. It was on this basis that civil servants estimated that Jack Straw's new asylum and immigration act with its move towards a "cashless" system of support for asylum seekers waiting for decisions would save the treasury more than £100m a year.

The home office document containing the original forecast predicted: "The fall in applications from 2000/01 onwards is based on the effect of the short periods for deciding applications and appeals, the replacement of current support arrangements for asylum seekesr... and the doubling of removals by 2000/01."

The impact of these measures in the new asylum legislation is to be underpinned by a national system of compulsory dispersal from April, the increasing use of airline liaison officers abroad to deter abusive applicants travelling to Britain, new moves against those who come into Britain clandestinely in the backs of lorries and the exchange of fingerprint data of abusive applicants around Europe.

The home office is still confident that this controversial package will arrest the increasing flow of asylum seekers to Britain. But one glance at the list of countries from which Britain's would-be refugees come and you might be forgiven for being slightly sceptical that such measures will deter them.

At the top of the latest monthly list is the former Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (1,195), Sri Lanka (510), Afghanistan (375), Turkey (250 - mainly Kurds), and Somalia (320). None of them could be safely described as tranquil havens of stable democracy.

It should also be remembered that contrary to some press claims not all asylum seekers are trying to abuse the system. At the present rate one in four or 25% of asylum seekers are recognised as genuine - double that under the Tories - and have fled to Britain because they have been persecuted and are in fear of their lives. Yet Britain's system for sorting out the genuine from the abusive is in severe danger of prolonging rather than relieving their suffering.

 Alan Travis is the Guardian's home affairs editor

webTitle: Improper allegiances are all the rage at Greg Dyke's BBC

fields.headline: Improper allegiances are all the rage at Greg Dyke's BBC
fields.standfirst:
That massive donation to New Labour is the real scandal

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: When Greg Dyke takes over at the BBC this week, a precedent will be established. He will be the first director-general, otherwise known as editor-in-chief, to be openly associated with a political party. The £50,000 he gave Labour before the election was interesting when it came to light, but what's interesting now is something different: how few people were shocked by this connection, and how unimportant it has been made to seem. Hardly anyone seems to think that Mr Dyke is, by all previous standards expected of the BBC, damaged goods.
fields.body:
When Greg Dyke takes over at the BBC this week, a precedent will be established. He will be the first director-general, otherwise known as editor-in-chief, to be openly associated with a political party. The £50,000 he gave Labour before the election was interesting when it came to light, but what's interesting now is something different: how few people were shocked by this connection, and how unimportant it has been made to seem. Hardly anyone seems to think that Mr Dyke is, by all previous standards expected of the BBC, damaged goods.

In enjoying this privilege, he is an exemplar of a wider cultural shift, alarming in a new way. He is better seen not as an entryist with New Labour allegiances, but as proof that allegiance no longer matters. To matter, allegiance needs to be contested. Somehow, when there is no contest, it no longer seems shocking. Mr Dyke plainly is New Labour: £50,000 is a pledge that can't be talked away, and it certainly wasn't withdrawn when it should have become unbearably embarrassing. But he is exonerated because New Labour is the only game in town, the thing to be, the orthodoxy. So much so that there's no other choice to be made, and therefore nothing wrong with this one.

The only proof of Mr Dyke's unsuitability for the BBC might have been giving money to the Tories. This would have backed not only the wrong side but the losing side, thus displaying him as a man of shaky judgment. As it was, he judged right. He supported the winning side, and reckoned that, in the interval, a gesture which would in other times have rendered him ineligible to uphold the perceived values of the BBC had been drained of controversy. For New Labour is the norm. As such it has acquired banality. Detachment and objectivity - in a word, outsiderdom - are not imperilled by it. Allegiance, therefore, requires no apology. It does not matter. Mr Dyke arrives in his job charged with a conflict of interest deriving from his Granada shares but not a breath of a conflict from being a Labour donor.

This is a development for which ironic is too weak a word. Hideously paradoxical would be better. The spirit of detachment, jealously guarded in both perception and reality, survived the decades in which allegiance really did matter. During the half-century in which right and left were at each other's throats, the BBC rigorously upheld detachment and was universally respected for doing so. Now that left and right are barely arguing, the tradition that exalted objectivity and resisted every signal of allegiance is treated with indifference verging on contempt.

The BBC is not suffering alone. In the same post-war half-century, the civil service was also a haven of detachment. That is what the politicians wanted, valued and preserved. They sometimes got impatient, and there were stories of Harold Wilson or Dick Crossman becoming exasperated with this or that mandarin. But when the central office of information put its name to a release, the facts in it tended to be true. A spirit of disinterested professionalism held the ring between parties that stood for opposite views of the world.

Now, when these views are much less easy to distinguish, the civil service tradition has been savagely eroded. The more the zeitgeist expresses consensus, the more partisan these former temples of detachment are expected to become and the less reliable are the rules that once protected their reputation. In place of the COI as a purveyor of facts, we have spin doctors as explainers-away of facts. In place of official truth-tellers, we have party propagandists on the state payroll. In place of a budget statement, once the holiest temple of statistical veracity, we have, even here, bent figures and selective disclosure.

This deterioration began with the most ideological of modern prime ministers. It was in the Thatcher era that the left/right divide reached greatest intensity, and the detachment of both BBC and Whitehall came under most severe challenge. But the trend has been much amplified by the supreme leader of post-ideological politics. The era when left has been subsumed into right turns out to be the era when allegiance is most heavily expected, and the disciplines against inappropriate allegiance are withering way. There is essentially no such thing as improper allegiance - for the simple reason that no other allegiance than to the prevailing, belief-less, convictionless, flexible, pragmatic orthodoxy makes any sense.

Such has been the escape route for Greg Dyke, and such the reason why his arrival at the BBC is regarded not as an affront to something sacred but the just preferment of a professional who happened to have an innocent little flutter on the side. He is indeed professional. Everyone says he cares about the programmes. He'll offer some escape from the structuralist aridities of Lord Birt. He might even resist appointment to the House of Lords, the final burial ground of any non-establishment instincts Birt might conceivably lay claim to.

All the same, the context that allowed the Labour benefactor to rise unresisted, into a job he would once have got nowhere near, is deplorable. The voiding of allegiance may seem seductive. The emergence of a world in which doctrine has become redundant makes for political continuity, which might be expected to bring a certain stability with it. But it seems to have led, in the British case, to an allegiance to Blairism which pretends to be innocuous: to be somehow above commitment, and above the normal rules that try to guarantee public life is neither corrupt nor totalitarian: yet which is, in fact, as parti pris as every other political affiliation.

The rules, on the whole, have worked in the past. But they depend on a vigilance which rejects the premise that has now become acceptable, whether at the BBC or in Whitehall. Values taken for granted in a time of political conflict need to be reaffirmed, doubly so, when conflict is being supplanted, as it is, by hegemony.

The Dyke succession shows these values are being neglected. His ready acceptance is said to speak for an age that has got things in perspective, no longer fusses about minutiae, gives the job to the right man and accepts that his own allegiance to Blair is as disposable as Blair's to any ideology. Actually it proclaims an era that is forgetting the dangers of one-party government, one-party allegiance, and a one-party state apparatus, all achieved under the illusion that the whole world, bar a few neanderthal conservatives, can be classified as one of us. Gliding into Broadcasting House, Mr Dyke is a reproach to all of us. We succumb to the belief that Blairism, banishing all rivals from the field, transcends politics. It doesn't. Nor does 50 grand.

This would have backed not only the wrong side but the losing side, thus displaying him as a man of shaky judgment. As it was, he judged right. He supported the winning side, and reckoned that, in the interval, a gesture which would in other times have rendered him ineligible to uphold the perceived values of the BBC had been drained of controversy. For New Labour is the norm. As such it has acquired banality. Detachment and objectivity - in a word, outsiderdom - are not imperilled by it. Allegiance, therefore, requires no apology. It does not matter. Mr Dyke arrives in his job charged with a conflict of interest deriving from his Granada shares but not a breath of a conflict from being a Labour donor. This is a development for which ironic is too weak a word. Hideously paradoxical would be better. The spirit of detachment, jealously guarded in both perception and reality, survived the decades in which allegiance really did matter. During the half-century in which right and left were at each other's throats, the BBC rigorously upheld detachment and was universally respected for doing so. Now that left and right are barely arguing, the tradition that exalted objectivity and resisted every signal of allegiance is treated with indifference verging on contempt. The BBC is not suffering alone. In the same post-war half-century, the civil service was also a haven of detachment. That is what the politicians wanted, valued and preserved. They sometimes got impatient, and there were stories of Harold Wilson or Dick Crossman becoming exasperated with this or that mandarin. But when the central office of information put its name to a release, the facts in it tended to be true. A spirit of disinterested professionalism held the ring between parties that stood for opposite views of the world. Now, when these views are much less easy to distinguish, the civil service tradition has been savagely eroded. The more the zeitgeist expresses consensus, the more partisan these former temples of detachment are expected to become and the less reliable are the rules that once protected their reputation. In place of the COI as a purveyor of facts, we have spin doctors as explainers-away of facts. In place of official truth-tellers, we have party propagandists on the state payroll. In place of a budget statement, once the holiest temple of statistical veracity, we have, even here, bent figures and selective disclosure. This deterioration began with the most ideological of modern prime ministers. It was in the Thatcher era that the left/right divide reached greatest intensity, and the detachment of both BBC and Whitehall came under most severe challenge. But the trend has been much amplified by the supreme leader of post-ideological politics. The era when left has been subsumed into right turns out to be the era when allegiance is most heavily expected, and the disciplines against inappropriate allegiance are withering way. There is essentially no such thing as improper allegiance - for the simple reason that no other allegiance than to the prevailing, belief-less, convictionless, flexible, pragmatic orthodoxy makes any sense. Such has been the escape route for Greg Dyke, and such the reason why his arrival at the BBC is regarded not as an affront to something sacred but the just preferment of a professional who happened to have an innocent little flutter on the side. He is indeed professional. Everyone says he cares about the programmes. He'll offer some escape from the structuralist aridities of Lord Birt. He might even resist appointment to the House of Lords, the final burial ground of any non-establishment instincts Birt might conceivably lay claim to. All the same, the context that allowed the Labour benefactor to rise unresisted, into a job he would once have got nowhere near, is deplorable. The voiding of allegiance may seem seductive. The emergence of a world in which doctrine has become redundant makes for political continuity, which might be expected to bring a certain stability with it. But it seems to have led, in the British case, to an allegiance to Blairism which pretends to be innocuous: to be somehow above commitment, and above the normal rules that try to guarantee public life is neither corrupt nor totalitarian: yet which is, in fact, as parti pris as every other political affiliation. The rules, on the whole, have worked in the past. But they depend on a vigilance which rejects the premise that has now become acceptable, whether at the BBC or in Whitehall. Values taken for granted in a time of political conflict need to be reaffirmed, doubly so, when conflict is being supplanted, as it is, by hegemony. The Dyke succession shows these values are being neglected. His ready acceptance is said to speak for an age that has got things in perspective, no longer fusses about minutiae, gives the job to the right man and accepts that his own allegiance to Blair is as disposable as Blair's to any ideology. Actually it proclaims an era that is forgetting the dangers of one-party government, one-party allegiance, and a one-party state apparatus, all achieved under the illusion that the whole world, bar a few neanderthal conservatives, can be classified as one of us. Gliding into Broadcasting House, Mr Dyke is a reproach to all of us. We succumb to the belief that Blairism, banishing all rivals from the field, transcends politics. It doesn't. Nor does 50 grand.

fields.headline: Making gene therapy safe
fields.trailText: All medical research carries with it risks, otherwise doctors would move straight to treatment. Rather then exposing particular risks for gene therapy, the death of Jesse Gelsinger highlights the importance of the regulatory bodies set up to monitor this work protecting patients who participate in trials (Death exposes risks of gene therapy, January 24) .
fields.body:
All medical research carries with it risks, otherwise doctors would move straight to treatment. Rather then exposing particular risks for gene therapy, the death of Jesse Gelsinger highlights the importance of the regulatory bodies set up to monitor this work protecting patients who participate in trials (Death exposes risks of gene therapy, January 24) .

The Pennsylvanian Institute appears to have mismanaged its research, and to have shown a disregard for good practice that must be condemned. But this should not be taken to imply that gene therapy is inherently unsafe and that properly regulated clinical trials should be halted.

Progress in genetics, and its application through gene therapy offers the best hope for a cure for many currently untreatable conditions. Without the research, and without volunteers willing to participate in clinical trials, then for those affected the inevitability is chronic ill health, progressive disability and premature death. Research must continue, and the mistakes or misjudgments at one centre should not be used to damage an aspect of scientific endeavour which hold out great hope for many millions of people with incurable diseases.

After all, the regulatory system in the UK is very different from the US.
Alastair Kent
Genetic Interest Group
mail@gig.org.uk

webTitle: Don't abolish council housing till we know what it's for

fields.headline: Don't abolish council housing till we know what it's for
fields.trailText: Whether or not John Prescott plans to "abolish" council housing (Report, January 24), it is clear that his forthcoming green paper must recognise that council housing is not sustainable in its present form.
fields.body:
Whether or not John Prescott plans to "abolish" council housing (Report, January 24), it is clear that his forthcoming green paper must recognise that council housing is not sustainable in its present form. Despite the government's recycling of money from right-to-buy sales, the backlog of disrepair stands at £22bn.

But it would be wrong to assume that disrepair is the only issue. It would also be wrong to adopt a "solution" that led to more investment but didn't answer the question "what is council housing for?" Almost as telling a feature of council housing's decline is the fact that, 20 years ago, it catered for all income groups whereas now its client group is overwhelmingly those without work.

Housing professionals want to help the government shape a new future for council housing which aims for a high quality service, a broader mix of customers and a real choice for the many people who cannot find what they want in the present market. This is the "big picture" that is likely to emerge from the inquiry into social housing being carried out by the Institute for Public Policy Research.

The housing green paper is the government's chance to set out a new vision for the future, rather than preside over continuing decline. This will be the real test of its housing policy.
Director of Policy, Chartered Institute of Housing
john.perry@cih.org

 Council housing remains popular with tenants not least because of their experience of social exclusion and benefit dependency caused by the high rents of new housing built by housing associations. They continue to value the ability to take their concerns directly to democratically elected councillors rather than housing bureaucrats and not surprisingly they continue to veto transfers to the private sector on a regular basis.

The proposals to end council housing would ignore the wishes of tenants when there are alternatives available which would renovate council homes, maintain democratic accountability and ensure community focused services. Unfortunately, the treasury continues with its dogmatic refusal to allow local authorities to establish companies that can borrow outside of the restricted capital control regime. They have recently agreed such an arrangement for local authority airports, why not for council homes?

The irony is that the plethora of consultants and vested interests presently promoting transfer and bemoaning tenant vetos would in the 1960s have been the advocates of high rise and system built housing. The answer to the problems of council housing is to listen to the tenants and demand some new thinking from the treasury.
Nigel Long
Local Government Information Unit
info@lgru.org.uk

fields.headline: ...and other mayoralties
fields.trailText: You are wrong to imply that all the large cities you mention (Cities to vote on elected mayors, January 22 ) are Labour-controlled. Both Sheffield and Liverpool have Liberal Democrat administrations.
fields.body:
You are wrong to imply that all the large cities you mention (Cities to vote on elected mayors, January 22 ) are Labour-controlled. Both Sheffield and Liverpool have Liberal Democrat administrations.

Part of Blair's agenda in ordering big cities to hold referendums to test whether electors want an elected mayor may well be in an attempt to promote high-profile Labour candidates in the hopes of winning back power in traditional strongholds where voters are now disillusioned with the party at both local and national level.

It's not just local authorities who are uneasy about the reforms being imposed upon them by the centre, and in particular the desirability of the elected mayor model. A wide debate on how and what changes should take place is currently on-going in Sheffield.

One group which has already responded with their views on the best political system for Sheffield is Sheffield's Citizens' Panel, which is made up of over 2,200 people aged 17 and over recruited through the electoral register. Of those who expressed a preference, the cabinet model was preferred by a ratio of four to one over the elected mayor model.
Cllr Sylvia Dunkley
Sheffield city council

 "Democracy Day" is a misleading description for the imposed referendums for city mayors. The proposed government changes, rather predictably, have more to do with New Labour regulation than local democracy.

With or without "Democracy Day", the local government bill will give the government the power to impose a fundamental restructuring of local government. There will be a statutory duty on councils to abolish the traditional committee system and to exclude all but a handful of "executive" councillors from policy-making. In this context, whether mayors are directly or indirectly elected is merely a side-show.

The new streamlined councils will be playing a largely administrative role, policed and monitored by a host of new government inspectorates overseeing "best value" targets.

The government enforced reforms may be strong on democratic rhetoric and exhortations about citizen participation, but they will further restrict any local say over council spending priorities.
Dr David Chandler
Policy Research Institute, Leeds Metropolitan University
david@dchandler. freeserve.co.uk
