fields.headline: The rubbishing of Ken...
fields.trailText: In the last 30 years I have not witnessesed such swinishness in British politics as the attempt to bury Ken Livingstone's candidacy.
fields.body:
In the last 30 years I have not witnessesed such swinishness in British politics as the attempt to bury Ken Livingstone's candidacy. Cllr Valerie Shawcross (Letters, January 22) finds it "incredible that a candidate for selection as mayor should attack prospective Labour assembly candidates".

The only thing we have heard from LA candidates so far has been abuse of Ken Livingstone. Does Cllr Shawcross think there is an admiring public for the proposition that it is all right for them to rubbish Livingstone day in day out but impermissible for him to talk back?
Stephen Vizinczey
London
stephenv@waitrose.com

 Cllr Shawcross is right in one respect: whatever Trevor Philips imagined he was doing putting up the Croydon Labour leader and GLA candidate to attack Ken Livingstone for questioning the independence of Labour's GLA candidates (Diary, January 21), we in Croydon can confirm that she does not listen to black people - eg our five-year demands for a local race equality council, which she prefers to put out to tender, even though her party has no electoral mandate for treating race equality like rubbish collection.

Last November, when Shawcross and local MP Malcolm Wicks chaired a meeting in Croydon for party members to listen to Dobson and Philips, she ruled questions on race relations in Croydon out of order.
Des Assanah
Croydon

 Not so long ago, Ken Livingstone was lecturing us all on Labour's failure to select more Afro-Caribbean candidates for the Greater London Assembly. Yet now (Livingstone offers Jackson deputy's role, January 24) we find that he wants to sideline the one Afro-Caribbean candidate who has a reasonable chance of winning, Trevor Phillips, and replace him with a white, time-served, political hack.

What is Trevor's crime? He has probably been a bit too uppity, a bit too likely to challenge Mr Livingstone's authority. Maybe it is that, as with the GLC, Ken is only interested in working with black people when they comply with his wishes as opposed to having ideas of their own.
Lorraine Marshall
London

 Maggie Cosin (Letters, January 20) makes a dog's dinner of her accusation of poodle-breeding against Ken Livingstone. It is she and her GLA-candidate colleagues who are the poodles, which is exactly why they were picked for the panel in the first place - to yap out Tony Blair's dogs' chorus in well-trained unison.
Paul Daintry
London
paul@daintry.fsnet.co.uk

 It's amazing that Ken Livingstone (along with Tony Benn and Arthur Scargill) can be blamed for Labour's disarray in the 80s. What about the parliamentary leadership? Was it nothing to do with them? What about the Gang of Four, who deserted Labour when the going got tough. If the GLC was such a bad advertisement for Labour, why did Thatcher abolish it?
David Butler
London
david@xerxesbutler.fsnet.co.uk

 I presume the government's continual backsliding over ethical foreign policy plus attempts to restrict trial by jury are all designed to provoke mass resignations among leftwing Labour party members before they have the chance to cast their votes for Ken as the party's candidate for mayor of London.

Am I being paranoiac, or does the presence of Baldrick on Frank Dobson's team suggest there really is a cunning plan at work?
Angela Cooper
Surbiton, Surrey

fields.headline: Sky larks
fields.trailText: Nick Pollard, head of Sky News, may not think that BBC News 24 ought to be abolished (Letters, January 24), but in a leader on January 17, the Sun make it clear that it wanted News 24 closed down.
fields.body:
Nick Pollard, head of Sky News, may not think that BBC News 24 ought to be abolished (Letters, January 24), but in a leader on January 17, the Sun make it clear that it wanted News 24 closed down. Last year Raymond Snoddy wrote in the Times that "Murdoch may want something done... about BBC News 24".

The concerted campaign by the various parts of New Corporation to get rid of News 24 and squash any of the BBC's digital ambitions, lest they threaten BskyB, is so obvious as to be laughable. Either it has passed Mr Pollard by completely or, like the rest of News Corp, he speaks with a forked tongue.
Stuart Britton
Southampton

fields.headline: Not much of a choice
fields.standfirst:
Londoners deserve rather better

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Starting today, the members of the London Labour Party face a difficult task. After months of mudslinging, back-stabbing and stitch-ups, they must now stare at the names of Frank Dobson, Glenda Jackson and Ken Livingstone and choose Labour's candidate to be the capital's first-ever directly-elected mayor. It is certainly an important task: the degree of attention lavished on the contest by the prime minister is proof of that. But it is nevertheless an unenviable one.
fields.body:
Starting today, the members of the London Labour Party face a difficult task. After months of mudslinging, back-stabbing and stitch-ups, they must now stare at the names of Frank Dobson, Glenda Jackson and Ken Livingstone and choose Labour's candidate to be the capital's first-ever directly-elected mayor. It is certainly an important task: the degree of attention lavished on the contest by the prime minister is proof of that. But it is nevertheless an unenviable one.

Can Labour party members confidently back the PM's favourite, the former health secretary? Our glum conclusion is that Mr Dobson may meet the qualifications required of a solid cabinet minister - loyal and predictable - but that he falls well short of the requirements of a mayor. He has no convincing plan for the city, lacks a history of commitment to London-wide government, has none of the charisma which might galvanise a metropolis of eight million and has failed to find a language to connect with the capital. Above all, Mr Dobson lacks the quality essential for a new, devolved body like the London mayoralty: independence. The fact that he is the leadership candidate - helped along by a Millbank bureaucracy which gave him organisational advantages denied to his rivals and by an unprecedented smear campaign against one of them - is a fatal flaw. For the London mayor to be credible he cannot be seen as a district branch of Whitehall: if he is, then this key plank of Labour's decentralisation programme will be seen as a sham. That is the risk of the Dobson candidacy.

Glenda Jackson may seem like the obvious alternative. She is independent enough to have defied Downing Street pressure to drop out, and has stood with Ken Livingstone in denouncing the machine tactics pushing Mr Dobson. She has ministerial experience and a name which would bring international glitz to the new London post. Having a woman as the capital's first mayor would be an undeniable plus. The pity of it is that Ms Jackson is, once again, not quite mayoral material. She disappointed as a minister and has failed to sketch a vision for the capital. The mayoralty is a big job and nothing in Ms Jackson's background or performance in this campaign suggests she is up to it. Her failure to catch fire with all but a tiny number of Labour party members proves the point.

Which leaves Mr Livingstone. His appeal is self-evident. He has an - admittedly mixed - track record on London, the flair to make local government come alive and a rare ability to make politics exciting. The sheer irritation he has stirred in the highest echelons of the party is a virtue as well as a vice: it proves he would be his own man. Those who want to take a stand against the control freakery which has been so damaging a feature of this government will find an easy weapon in a vote for Ken Livingstone. But they should think twice. As our own special report laid bare last week, those who have worked closest with the former GLC leader - many of them apparent natural political allies - describe him as a vain and manipulative opportunist congenitally prone to destructive oppositionalism rather than the unglamorous business of co-operation and collaboration required of a city chief executive. They foresee years of instability and political grandstanding.

So this is the choice, with not a natural first-pick among them. It is regretable that London's Labour activists have been offered so flawed a field. Newspapers, though they often endorse candidates, do not have votes. In this election that disfranchisement comes as some relief.

He has an - admittedly mixed - track record on London, the flair to make local government come alive and a rare ability to make politics exciting. The sheer irritation he has stirred in the highest echelons of the party is a virtue as well as a vice: it proves he would be his own man. Those who want to take a stand against the control freakery which has been so damaging a feature of this government will find an easy weapon in a vote for Ken Livingstone. But they should think twice. As our own special report laid bare last week, those who have worked closest with the former GLC leader - many of them apparent natural political allies - describe him as a vain and manipulative opportunist congenitally prone to destructive oppositionalism rather than the unglamorous business of co-operation and collaboration required of a city chief executive. They foresee years of instability and political grandstanding. So this is the choice, with not a natural first-pick among them. It is regretable that London's Labour activists have been offered so flawed a field. Newspapers, though they often endorse candidates, do not have votes. In this election that disfranchisement comes as some relief.

fields.headline: A new Boer war
fields.standfirst: Stop poaching overseas social workers
fields.trailText: Over the next few weeks, 16 South African social workers will be brought in by the Essex social services department to help plug the gaping holes in its services for at-risk children and vulnerable adults. Yet it is less than two months since the government banned health authorities and hospitals from recruiting South African or Caribbean nurses to protect these overseas services from being undermined.
fields.body:
First it was doctors, then nurses, now it is social workers. An over-stretched and under-staffed social services department, Essex, has turned to South Africa to resolve its recruitment problems. Over the next few weeks, 16 South African social workers will be brought in by the county to help plug the gaping holes in its services for at-risk children and vulnerable adults. Yet it is less than two months since the government banned health authorities and hospitals from recruiting South African or Caribbean nurses to protect these overseas services from being undermined. Both regions have suffered grievously from the emigration of expensively-trained medical staff. There are more Sierre Leone doctors in a single American city, Chicago, than in the entire African state. Yet the new approach to the recruitment of medical staff should apply with equal force to social workers.

No one can deny the pressure on social services. Recruitment problems across the country have been exacerbated by a steep fall in student numbers on social work courses. In the three years up to 1998, there was a 40% drop. This decline probably accelerated in 1998-99 with the introduction of tuition fees, which hit mature students, a traditional source of social work trainees, particularly hard.

What's going on? The root cause of the problem is the decline in morale and status of social work. Two decades of adverse coverage has systematically eroded its standing. No profession could have withstood such a forensic scrutiny, with every child's death examined in minute detail. Serious mistakes were exposed but the successes - the creation of one of Europe's most effective child protection services - rarely reported. It is not just the risk of being made a scapegoat - surveys have shown social workers stand a much higher risk of physical assault than health visitors or GPs. Social service directors could do more to introduce better risk-assessment procedures, but ministers need to take the lead in changing the image. Last week's social care awards were a start but there needs to be much more systematic support from the top for one of the most daunting and challenging jobs. Typically, the prime minister wrote a letter of thanks to NHS staff for their work in the flu epidemic, but ignored the crucial support provided by social services. The solution rests in our own hands; robbing South Africa of its social workers should not be an option.

fields.headline: Minister rejects childcare findings
fields.trailText: The government yesterday hit back over claims that children of working mothers suffer academically, and insisted it was taking steps to help parents balance work and home life.
fields.body:
The government yesterday hit back over claims that children of working mothers suffer academically, and insisted it was taking steps to help parents balance work and home life.

The employment and equal opportunities minister, Margaret Hodge, rejected suggestions made in last night's Panorama programme that children of pre-school age whose mothers work later achieve worse reading scores.

Ministers have also been stung by a study for the same programme indicating one-third of mothers are forced out of full-time working, with many blaming inflexible employers for failing to allow them necessary time off work.

Those findings gave ammunition to campaigners including trade unions who, while backing the government's pledge to give mothers who want to work new choices, insist that it has so far done too little to compel employers to help women return to the workplace. They will also be taken up by critics who argue Tony Blair's administration is seeking to force mothers back into employment.

Ms Hodge rejected a study by Professor Heather Joshi, of the Institute of Education, which suggested children were around a tenth less likely to advance one academic stage if their mothers worked during their pre-school years. She said: "This research is based on a time when nobody thought about childcare as a national issue. We now know perfectly well that it is choice and quality of childcare which are crucial to children's academic outcomes."

The government faces more pressure to make a reality of promises to improve "home-life balance" for employees from the TUC and other pressure groups. They are are urging legislation to ensure employers offer parents real choices to allow them to return to work.

Ms Hodge yesterday announced the creation of an advisory committee, whose members include former Observer editor Will Hutton and the author Shirley Conran, to "brainstorm new ways to transform work culture in Britain".

fields.headline: Not guilty, baby
fields.standfirst:
Angela Phillips has no patience with TV producers who try to make working mothers miserable

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Angela Phillips has no patience with TV producers who try to make working mothers miserable.
fields.body:
Why are we still asking whether mothers should work? And why are programme-makers selectively quoting research studies in order to try to prove the totally discredited notion that for mothers to go out to work is bad for their children?

Last night's Panorama on BBC television could have shown the real story of the past 10 years. This is that as mothers pour in ever increasing numbers into the workplace, there has been no long-term damage. Children have not disintegrated; women, against massive odds, have managed what seemed not so long ago to be impossible and are (on the whole) more positive about work than their partners are. So why then does programme-maker Sarah Powell find it necessary to pick through the accumulating evidence of this success story looking for evidence of negative effects and telling us, once again, that if we work our lives will be miserable and our children will be damaged?

In her last programme, also for Panorama which went out in 1997, Powell "discovered" that children with full-time working parents performed less well at school. The research on which that programme was based was a tiny case study of working-class families in a particularly educationally and financially impoverished area of London. Powell illustrated "the evidence" with footage of middle-class families with the clear implication that the findings can be generalised. Margaret O'Brien, of the University of North London, did the original research, and is remarkably polite about the way in which her research was used, pointing out that the juxtaposition of words and pictures: "created different meanings for the audience".

Too right it did. Any working mother not equipped with the research background would have been led to believe that her job was directly, and negatively, affecting her children's life chances. Another prominent academic in the field, approached by the same production team, told me: "I will not have anything to do with that woman."

So what is the evidence of educational failure that last night's programme headlines? Well, according to Heather Joshi, researcher at the Institute of Education on which much of this week's programme was based, there is no effect from the mother's employment on future job prospects; there is no effect on teenage pregnancy. Yes, there is a slight effect on the level of qualifications of older children, but that effect is cancelled out by the overwhelming issue of class and the mother's educational attainment. What this actually means in practice is, as Joshi says: "It's a trade off. You either have more material resources or a mother at home. The effect on the children will be the same." In other words, it is only if you can coerce your partner into earning enough to offset your share of the family income that your presence by the hearth will actually have a positive effect on your infant's future.

More important to my mind is a factor which the programme-makers chose to ignore. The very same research they have been trumpeting so loudly also found that children whose mothers went out to work when they were under the age of five are "less anxious and significantly better adjusted" than their peers and, where the "qualifications" effect is highly sensitive to class and educational background, this effect is not.

How do we explain this? Could it be that the anxious and maladjusted children of the overbearing stay-at-home mothers are so keen to succeed that they go on clocking up qualifications to bolster their flagging self-esteem - leaving their better adjusted peers to pick up the jobs? Now that would be a new angle. Perhaps Sarah Powell should go for it? I rather doubt that she will.

Last night's programme, far from adding to a debate on the future of work and families, has dragged it back years. That sonorous voice introducing it with the words: "Many mothers are finding it harder and harder to balance work with children." Dong! "Research shows that young children may lose out if both parents work." Dong! Cue miserable, exhausted women with slightly bemused and pissed-off partners who seemed to think it unfair that they should be expected to bear their share of the stress of early parenthood. But then parenthood is by nature stressful. Why do we expect it to be otherwise? It is the central job of humanity to care for its young so why do we expect it to be a recreational activity, somewhat akin to gardening? The problem is not that parenthood is hard work but that the rest of society believes that individual mothers (not fathers, let alone employers or government) should bear the entire responsibility.

A new thought? Not really. I wrote this on the same subject in 1983: "It was having a baby which... brought home to me with real force the hopelessly unbalanced nature of a society which is organised solely for the needs of people without responsibility for children." Plus ça change.

In Powell's programme, "society" was represented by Ruth Lea, of the Institute of Directors, who intoned that if a woman wanted a man's job, she should be prepared to work like a man. Who says so? Why isn't it equally acceptable to say that if a man wants to be a parent he should parent like a woman? Or that those who have not contributed to the upbringing of children should be barred from reaping the rewards of their labour in years to come? Life would indeed be tough if we all gave up having children.

The overwhelming story which Panorama barely touched on is the degree to which the workplace revolution of the past 10 years has taken place in spite of, rather than because of, legislative change which has been at best grudging and at worst positively obstructive. When the last government introduced a maternity leave of just 14 weeks, forcing many women to return to work or lose their jobs, many campaigners thought that the law had actually been designed to fail. They were expecting a huge drop-out rate from mothers who returned to work too early. Now the first research studies are beginning to show that drop out.

According to Susan Harkness, the social scientist who contributed to last night's programme, those mothers least likely to drop out had high job satisfaction and partners who helped out with childcare. Those most likely to drop out were the mothers who went back earliest and for the longest hours. Interesting stuff except that this programme chooses to show the results as a by-product of motherhood rather than the effect of lousy legislation and lack of support.

It is surely the inhumanity of current employment law and the reluctance of even this family-loving government, to address the real, practical needs of working parents, that is the real issue here - not the ability of a mother to hold down a job. And if there is a scandal to uncover it is the passivity of those campaigning organisations which, instead of putting pressure on the government for change, seem to have collectively rolled over and allowed Tony to tickle their tummies with new year honours and promises of large grants. We still have lousy maternity leave, our parental leave is unpaid, we have the most expensive childcare in Europe and we are still plagued with programme-makers who tell us to feel guilty. We have no reason for guilt, only for anger.

 Angela Phillips is an author, lecturer and parent

fields.headline: Just good friends
fields.standfirst: As whispers follow Hammond Innes's bequest to Celia Imrie,  Terri Apter  asks the age-old question: can the sexes get along without sex?
fields.trailText: As whispers follow Hammond Innes's bequest to Celia Imrie,  Terri Apter  asks the age-old question: can the sexes get along without sex?
fields.body:
Friendship, especially between a woman and a man, is one of those relationships that has no well-defined script: each friendship has to define its own rituals and routines. And as a result, people outside the friendship read their own meanings into it. But while friends themselves tend to be subtle and creative in building the relationship, outsiders' guesswork tends to be pretty crude.

I was reminded of this last week, when it was revealed that the novelist Hammond Innes had bequeathed his £750,000 Kensington house to the actor Celie Imrie. Although this bequest amounts to only 10% of Innes's estimated fortune, it is, by any measure, a generous one. According to Imrie, the generosity stems from "just" friendship - that is, not one that included sex.

"Yeah, right," has been the common response. We live in a cynical world: there's no such thing as a free lunch, no one gives something for nothing and wealth is never exchanged outside the bonds of blood or sex.

Cynicism makes us feel wise, but in fact it often makes us stupid. Friendships between women and men are often passionate, and they are rarely simple. Like all human attachments, they involve a range of emotions. It is the quick shifts of feeling that make them so interesting - and a wonderful subject for romantic comedy. And that question, "Can a woman and man be close friends without sex coming into it?" remains unanswered.

It was posed cleverly in the 1989 film When Harry Met Sally. Harry and Sally are great friends. They can talk about just anything, and see the world anew as they speak. They are one another's "date" when they have no real date. And although they are just substituting - at weddings and a new year - for "the real thing", they have as much fun as they would with a romantic partner. Then sex (inevitably?) enters the friendship and there are two possible resolutions: separation or marriage.

It's a pity, really, because life offers so many more possibilities. There is a distinctive flavour to male and female friendships. Women enthuse about their supportive and irreverent conversations with other women, but they positively glow when they speak about friendships with men. Men are known to have strong friendships with other men, but these rarely involve the play of conversation that their friendships with women do. Instead, with their male friends they play competitive games and "discuss issues". Friendship with a woman can offer a great release.

With women, they can reveal their vulnerabilities and explore their own and others' inner lives. Man/woman friendship can be so intimate that some men say that when they learn their partner has had an affair, they are far more jealous of the talking that has gone on than of the sex.

In the close encounters between friends, there are often flare-ups of sexual interest and sexual appreciation. But this is very different from having sex. It may be a revelation of possibility - of what might have happened under different circumstances. It may offer reassurance that we can still be attractive or "sexy". With a friend, we can signal our need for such reassurance - without burdening anyone with the extreme complications of an affair.

Friends meet the deep need for support systems beyond those of our family. In certain circumstances, these attachments can be equal to any bond. Celia Imrie describes Hammond Innes as her mentor, one who encouraged her to develop her thoughts and skills. After all, this friendship developed when Innes was in his 70s and 80s, when the urge to participate in rising generations is strong, and its satisfaction overwhelming. But, like all good friendships, this one was reciprocal. When Innes's wife died, Imrie provided what comfort she could - in the form of company and conversation.

His bequest, like any bequest, speaks of attachment, and the desire to have one's care and concern felt beyond one's own life. Instead of using this generosity to feed our cynicism, we can use it to extend our understanding of friendship.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: • We've had members of the Women's Institute stripping off in a calendar to raise money for cancer research: good cause, novel idea. Now the women of Haydon Hunt in Northumberland have shed their jodhpurs and been photographed in various states of undress. The proceeds from their calendar are going not towards saving lives, but towards the hunt. Bare breasts have been used to sell many things, but this must be the first time they've been used in the advancement of blood sports. Let's hope it's the last.

 We've had members of the Women's Institute stripping off in a calendar to raise money for cancer research: good cause, novel idea. Now the women of Haydon Hunt in Northumberland have shed their jodhpurs and been photographed in various states of undress. The proceeds from their calendar are going not towards saving lives, but towards the hunt. Bare breasts have been used to sell many things, but this must be the first time they've been used in the advancement of blood sports. Let's hope it's the last.

 Women are the main losers in countries where spending on arms takes precedence over social and educational provision. The Campaign Against the Arms Trade has launched a new information pack aimed at women in the UK interested in campaigning against the trade: for information call 0171-281 0297 or email enquiries@caat.demon.co.uk

 Ali G, eat your heart out. Formula one driver Eddie Irvine loves women - he just wouldn't sit in a car with one driving. The reason there aren't any women formula one drivers, he tells the Mail on Sunday, is that "their brains aren't up to it". However, unlike the boy from Staines, Irvine laughs at his own jokes. Eddie I: is it cos he is an idiot?

 She's it, she's hot, she's overexposed. "Brazilian bombshell" Gisele Bundchen is the most talked about supermodel. The fashion world is getting excited about her because, well . . . she, er, actually has breasts. But all those articles about how Gisele's fame indicates a shift in the fashion industry's attitude to womanly bodies are so much humbug. How many of us can wear knickers the size of which have previously only been seen on six-year-old boys?

Email women@theguardian.com

fields.headline: A real player at last
fields.standfirst:
More popular than Dobbo, courted by Ken - Glenda Jackson is back in the limelight. Melissa Benn follows her campaign to become London's mayor

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: More popular than Dobbo, courted by Ken - Glenda Jackson is back in the limelight.  Melissa Benn  follows her campaign to become London's mayor.
fields.body:
Until recently, one could have been forgiven for thinking that the only women who mattered in the race for London mayor have been, variously, fragrant wives, adoring mistresses and disgraced call girls. But yesterday a woman candidate finally made the big time, in headline terms at least, when Ken Livingstone offered Glenda Jackson a key role in any future administration, including chair of the new police authority and the role of roving ambassador for the capital.

Livingstone may have spoken of Jackson in sentimental terms, honouring "the widespread affection and respect" she commands from Londoners, her "honesty and forthrightness". But Livingstone is an acute political tactician. His offer is no last-minute attempt to play the feminist card, but belated acknowledgment of a surprisingly successful political campaign which has finally transformed the actress-turned-MP into a serious political player.

This new potency and her deepening public popularity was very much in evidence on the Jackson campaign trail last week. Visiting a gallery at the Sternberg Centre in north London featuring new paintings on the Holocaust, one can see how the public, as opposed to fellow MPs and the lobby, see her. A small slim woman, neat rather than glamorous in a red coat and well-styled reddish hair, Jackson brings out both deference and protectiveness from the men and women present. I understand why her personal political heroine is Mary Robinson, ex-president of Ireland; Jackson has the same mix of seriousness and charm. When she tells a story about herself as a child, witnessing the "absolute frozen shock" of the adults who had just watched the first footage from Belsen, there is complete silence. And a little later she makes them laugh, with a story about her Oscar statuettes ending up in a cardboard box.

No one calls her Glenda - but she is not Ms Jackson either. She is a hybrid figure: Glenda Jackson, national cultural monument, politician of principle and a frail, formidable woman of sixtysomething whom you want to wrap your arms around, ask advice of, then give her a little of your own. Perhaps it is something to do with her recent revelations that she was beaten up in not one but two previous relationships. But Jackson now has only one thing on her mind: winning the Labour nomination to be London's first elected mayor.

She won't win; the maths doesn't add up. But she has scored consistently higher ratings than the official frontrunner, Frank Dobson, in the opinion polls. She has resisted both the pressure and indifference of new Labour headquarters, and she was righteously incandescent at suggestions made in a Panorama programme that Dobson was given privileged access to London membership lists. Her new semi-detached status from the leadership has freed her to criticise the government on issues such as the Pinochet affair, which has only increased her popularity.

In short, Jackson has turned her one obvious disadvantage as a candidate - her remove from the titanic ideological struggle currently being waged at the heart of Labour - into a positive feature of her campaign. Jackson has been doing that old-fashioned thing: getting out and about. One London Labour MP, a Dobson supporter, invited all three candidates to talk to his local party. "Glenda Jackson was the outstanding candidate. She was engaged, thoughtful and answered people's questions in surprising ways."

She is certainly in skilful form at one of the final campaign debates with Trevor Phillips, Dobson's urbane deputy. Her set speech is brisk and seamless, but in the discussion she comes alive. It is standard new Labour stuff - defence of the public/private partnership plans for the tube, contemptuous rejection of any arguments for greater redistribution - but she brings to it an intellectual precision and a fury that most reminds me of Blair when he is riled. How much does she want to be London's mayor? "Oh, I want it," she laughs. "I really, really, really want the job." And, no, she won't consider any offers from other candidates until she knows she hasn't got it.

She first thought of standing when, as a junior minister in Prescott's department, she and Nick Raynsford (another mayoral hopeful whose candidacy lasted a matter of weeks) piloted the original bill through the House. "I've always resented the idea that all new and important jobs are the preserve of men."

Jackson is a Labour loyalist - even now she speaks of Margaret Thatcher with biting contempt - but she talks of the mayoralty in almost apolitical terms. "All the truly successful mayors, whatever their political base, have to speak for and on behalf of that city." Her personal manifesto is a thoughtful 15-page document full of special teams and squads to fight everything from crime, drugs and skills shortages to London's multiple transport failures.

She is better on people than policy. "London is a city which has been good to me. All the main experiences of my life have happened here. I've been poor in London. I've been well off in London. It's a great city with great problems." When she visited Barcelona, she loved the fact that "everyone knew the mayor as we walked through the streets". It's easy to imagine: Glenda in the streets and squares of Bromley, Harrow, Brixton and Hackney, drinking in all the complaints, all the suggestions, all the stories. And, as Livingstone recognises, she has a cultural cachet which would fit her exactly for the role of "roving ambassador". A bit of make-up, her favourite Jean Muir suit, that stroppy, sexy voice. Fellow Europeans would adore her.

Yet one wonders why it has taken her so long to make her own distinctive political mark. When first elected to parliament in 1992, there was an explicit pressure on the Oscar-winning actress to become our own version of Melina Mercouri or Jane Fonda, a gravelly-voiced temptress turned passionate political campaigner. Instead Jackson appeared a dutiful, slightly droney moderniser and then a competent but unexciting minister at Prescott's department of transport. Throughout the 90s the media has insistently dissected its disappointment in the ex-actress. Why is she so much more interesting when she stops talking politics? Why does she leave her pale, brutally beautiful face so often unpainted? But beneath the rote complaints lay a deeper truth. Something was missing in Jackson's political personality. It was not merely charm, as some MPs and lobby correspondents have claimed, the fact that "she simply walks around parliament clutching a pad of A4 papers to her chest", according to one political journalist. She was clearly sincere, undoubtedly hardworking, but a spark was missing.

Perhaps it was her total loyalty to the leadership, which inevitably dulls a true political voice, or a lack of confidence that no one had the imagination to see in a film star. Maybe it was that old British affliction: class. Jackson started her working life stacking shelves in Boots. It might take a few years to get used to the staggering arrogance of some Westminster men (and not a few women).

But fighting for London and for herself has liberated new political gifts in her. There is certainly no brusqueness when she is meeting the people. She is modest, amusing and engaged. At the Sternberg Centre, somebody tentatively asks her about the difference between acting and politics. Quick as a flash, she answers: "Both are about stripping things away. In their different ways, each are about trying to get to the truth."

"You will come back, won't you," someone calls out as she leaves. "I certainly will," she says with that Jackson grimace, a parody of determination. Both question and answer are surely metaphors for Jackson's future, which looks surprisingly bright. Even if she loses this time there will be another campaign for mayor in four years' time. And she will still be a tough, talented woman with a lot more experience and with yet more protective layers stripped away: a more truthful politician.

webTitle: Candidates sprint to first hurdle on road to White House

fields.headline: Candidates sprint to first hurdle on road to White House
fields.standfirst:
Race for the presidency - World's media descend on Des Moines for parties' crucial Iowa caucus votes

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Yesterday's morning traffic report on the local television station in Des Moines contained an unusual warning for Iowa commuters: watch out for television satellite trucks causing congestion in the city centre.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Des Moines, Iowa
fields.body:
Yesterday's morning traffic report on the local television station in Des Moines contained an unusual warning for Iowa commuters: watch out for television satellite trucks causing congestion in the city centre.

Media traffic in central Des Moines reached its peak yesterday, as Iowa prepared to hold its presidential caucuses last night in more than 2,000 constituency meeting-places across the largely white, largely rural and disproportionately elderly plains state in middle America.

CNN has 180 people in town to cover the caucuses. NBC has 160. CBS, evidently anxious not to lose out in the ratings game, refused to reveal how many staff were here. If there was any genuine Iowan among the state's 1.8m voters who had not been interviewed and lobbied about last night's voting, they were not letting on.

With snow on the ground and in sub-zero temperatures unmitigated by bright winter sunshine, seven men who would be the next American president spent the final day of their long siege of Iowa campaigning as hard as ever, followed by busloads of journalists, activists - and even the occasional Iowa voter.

Then, as the sun went down and the cold grew colder still, the candidates retreated to their campaign headquarters to await the outcome of last night's Iowa caucuses - the first real test on the long campaign trail that leads to November's presidential election.

As usual on cold January mornings, several candidates made early calls at breakfast diners around the state. George W Bush, the Republican favourite, breezed through a Des Moines restaurant almost before sunrise, urging supporters not to assume that the Republican contest was as well wrapped up as his accompanying posse of followers.

"The only thing that will deter turnout is complacency. That's why we're campaigning right to the end," Mr Bush said.

The Democratic frontrunner and vice-president, Al Gore, pounded local streets, even knocking on doors to bring his message to startled Iowa voters. Mr Gore had a similar message to his Republican rival, telling supporters: "All of the cheering and clapping and slogans and speeches will amount to nothing compared with what you do here today."

Some of the presidential election rivals preferred to continue their last-minute campaigning from the more traditional stage of the television studios, their minds already turning to the next stop on the trail, next Tuesday's primary in New Hampshire.

Mr Bush's chief challenger in Iowa, Steve Forbes, said he would "feel good about a good, strong second" in last night's caucus votes because "here you get that boost for New Hampshire".

Meanwhile the Democratic challenger, Bill Bradley, whose campaign has stumbled in recent weeks, went on network television to assure supporters that he would campaign all the way to the Democratic national convention in August, whatever the results in Iowa and New Hampshire.

It was hard to find a television channel which was not carrying a last-minute blizzard of campaign ads, as the candidates strove to get out their supporters to the evening caucuses, at which organisation and resources are often decisive in finding the eventual winners.

In contrast to the more carefully crafted Bush, Forbes and Gore ads, those from Mr Bradley and the fiery conservative challenger Alan Keyes used excerpts from their respective eve-of-poll campaign rallies. Though pollsters and pundits increasingly doubt he can win, Mr Bradley still told the voters: "It can happen."

The four-yearly media invasion is the price which Iowa voters have to pay for their jealously-guarded right to get the first chance to choose between the presidential aspirants. But there are increasing signs that the political parties, as well as some disgruntled Iowans, expect the whole thing to come to an end next time.

Even before the first votes were cast yesterday the New York Times reported that both Republican and Democratic party officials are now thinking of changing a presidential nominating system that has become too compressed into a short period early in the year; too confused for informed decision-making; and too concentrated into "untypical" states such as Iowa and New Hampshire.

"We're taking the whole issue of what happens beyond 2000 very seriously," said Joe Andrew, chairman of the Democratic national committee. "What's different is that both parties have blue-ribbon committees out there studying whether frontloading is a problem and seeking testimony on what the solution might be."

"There is a very considerable number of states that feel they have no voice, and frankly an awful lot of people feel they have no effective voice in the selection process," his Republican counterpart, William Brock, said.

Meanwhile, a Des Moines opinion poll yesterday shows that only 54% of likely caucus participants believe their state will again host the first event in the 2004 political calendar.

At least today the traffic will be flowing more smoothly - and untelevised - in Des Moines.

webTitle: Gore and Bush in line for Iowa win

fields.headline: Gore and Bush in line for Iowa win
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Vice President Al Gore and the governor of Texas, George W Bush, looked set for convincing victories in the Iowa caucuses last night, as real American voters finally got the chance to have their say in the first round of the US presidential nomination contest.
fields.body:
Vice President Al Gore and the governor of Texas, George W Bush, looked set for convincing victories in the Iowa caucuses last night, as real American voters finally got the chance to have their say in the first round of the US presidential nomination contest.

As many as 200,000 voters were expected to brave snow and sub-zero temperatures to cast their votes in some 2,000 precinct meetings around the state. Last-minute opinion polls showed Mr Gore with a two to one advantage over his only Democratic rival, the former basketball star and New Jersey senator, Bill Bradley.

On the Republican side, Mr Bush, the eldest son of former President George Bush, led millionaire publisher Steve Forbes by 43% to 20%, with Mr Forbes battling three other candidates for the conservative vote and second place.

In the first primary election in New Hampshire next week Mr Gore and Mr Bush face closer contests. Latest opinion polls show Mr Gore narrowly ahead of Mr Bradley there, but Mr Bush trails nine points behind John McCain, who is not campaigning in Iowa.

From 8am today the Guardian's website will carry full results of the Iowa caucuses and analysis, plus a timetable of the electoral process and a state guide.Follow up to date developments at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/uselection

fields.headline: Polls boost Gore and Bush
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush seemed to be cruising towards easy victories last night in the Iowa party caucuses, the first big test of the 2000 presidential election race, landing successes which would give them a boost for next week's tougher New Hampshire primary.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Des Moines, Iowa
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush seemed to be cruising towards easy victories last night in the Iowa party caucuses, the first big test of the 2000 presidential election race, landing successes which would give them a boost for next week's tougher New Hampshire primary.

A final poll of more than 1,200 likely Iowa caucus goers in the Des Moines Register newspaper showed Mr Gore with a 2:1 lead among Democrats over his only rival, Senator Bill Bradley. Mr Gore had 56% support and Mr Bradley 28%, with 16% undecided.

With New Hampshire polls now showing Mr Gore edging ahead, the vice-president is pulling out all the stops to devastate Mr Bradley in the opening contests, all but ending his rival's chances.

Late last year Mr Bradley set the campaign agenda and Mr Gore seemed unable to respond. Now the roles are reversing, and Mr Bradley has been compelled to insist he will stay in the race even if he loses both the early contests.

Among Republicans, the Iowa poll gave Mr Bush 43% support, putting Steve Forbes second with 20%. The conservative campaigner Alan Keyes was tied in third place, on 8%, with Senator John McCain, who is not campaigning in Iowa but concentrating on New Hampshire.

Two other conservatives, Gary Bauer and Senator Orrin Hatch, trailed on 6% and 1%, with 14% undecided.

The money-no-object Forbes campaign faced a late challenge from Mr Keyes, an African-American anti-abortion campaigner whose fiery eloquence on the stump has propelled him ahead of the more lack-lustre conservatives Mr Bauer and Mr Hatch.

Speculation mounted yesterday that Mr Hatch and Mr Bauer might drop out of the Republican contest if they score poorly in Iowa.

webTitle: Police link 11 attacks to serial rapist

fields.headline: Police link 11 attacks to serial rapist
fields.trailText: Detectives hunting a serial rapist who has struck at least 11 times over the past nine years yesterday linked the knifepoint attacks for the first time.
fields.body:
Detectives hunting a serial rapist who has struck at least 11 times over the past nine years yesterday linked the knifepoint attacks for the first time.

Following a review of unsolved cases police in Avon and Somerset said it had intensified its investigation, called Operation Eagle, and warned there was a strong possibility of another assault.

Two of the women attacked will speak about their ordeal tonight on the BBC programme Crimewatch UK, and Detective Superintendent Bill Davies, who is leading the inquiry, will appeal for other victims who have not reported incidents to come forward.

As far as the police can tell, the rapist first struck on May 21 1991, when a 36-year-old woman was abducted at knifepoint as she tried to park her car in Coronation Avenue, Bath.

She was forced to drive to a quiet lane where she was attacked. Five months later an 18-year-old was grabbed by a man as she walked up Bathwick Hill in Bath. She was marched to a field where she was subjected to a serious sexual assault.

There was a three-year gap before the next attack, and then a further two years of apparent inactivity.

Three women were attacked in 1996 and three more in 1997. The last assault was on Tuesday January 26 1999.

On that occasion a man attempted to abduct a 39-year-old woman in Forrester Lane, Bathwick, Bath, but was scared off when she screamed for help.

As he ran away he dropped a faded grey baseball cap with a green "Batman Forever" logo embossed on the front.

Within 10 minutes he had abducted another woman in a nearby road. He forced her to drive to the village of Monkton Combe just off the A36 where he assaulted her.

fields.headline: Institutional racism dogs Scottish travellers
fields.trailText: They have been part of the landscape for generations: a moving band of people, linked by family and friendship, driven by tradition, derided often for their chosen way of life.
fields.body:
They have been part of the landscape for generations: a moving band of people, linked by family and friendship, driven by tradition, derided often for their chosen way of life.

Now, with today's publication of a report revealing a disturbing level of institutionalised racism towards their community, Scotland's 15,000 travelling people have an acknowledgment of the hostility they have encountered.

The study, by Save the Children and Dundee university law department, found that 92% of traveller families had been forcibly moved on, often with little or no notice; and that racist and intolerant attitudes among health professionals were stopping travellers from getting access to health services.

On one occasion, a young mother trying to get medical attention for her sick child was reportedly told the doctor's surgery "didn't take scum like her".

"Discrimination happens all the time," said Nadia, an 18-year-old traveller who contributed to the report. "You don't get any notice taken of you. You get pushed from pillar to post. You don't get any respect. The way I live is a tradition. It's our culture to move around, to do different things. I could not live by a routine. That would be hell for me."

Cathy McInnes, 51, a grandmother of 15 who has travelled all her life, said there was too much hostility and too few designated sites. "Where are we supposed to go? What do they want us to do? To die out? They forget we are part of Scotland."

The report, Moving Targets, was based on 12 months of re search among travellers, the police, local authorities and health professionals. It comes as the Scottish executive is examining the final report by the secretary of state's advisory committee on Scotland's travelling people, which was wound up in December after 20 years.

Today's study found that nearly 60% of travellers had been told to leave a site immediately or were given only hours to clear out. Of those ejected, 43% had been receiving health care at the time they were forcibly moved on.

It also found that two-thirds of health professionals questioned believed racist and intolerant attitudes by colleagues were the primary obstacle to travellers accessing health services. Traveller families were denied access to GP lists and even pregnant women were turned away without care. Police understanding of racism towards travellers was also shown to be limited.

"It is a really concerning picture," said Alison Davies of Save the Children Scotland. "There is no other ethnic minority who are so seriously affected by discrimination and harassment and the threat to their lifestyle."

Ms Davies said Save the Children was calling on the Scottish communities minister, Wendy Alexander, to commission an urgent, independent review of policy towards Scotland's travellers. Neither the old Scottish office nor the advisory committee on travelling people had investigated the prevalence of discrimination towards travellers.

Responding to the report, the deputy Scottish communities minister, Jackie Baillie, said: "We deplore discrimination of any kind towards travelling people and are working with councils, health authorities and travellers to encourage a policy of toleration and non-harassment."

"The patients charter requires health services to treat all patients with respect and dignity regardless of their sex, religion or ethnic background. Health services must be accessible to all members of the public."

The Scottish Gypsy Association, meanwhile, welcomed the research.

"It brings clear evidence of institutional racism against the traveller community," its spokeswoman, Florence Garabedian, said.

"It underlines that without unambiguous government recognition of travellers' rights, members of the community will still suffer racism and social exclusion."

fields.headline: Lapotaire seriously ill
fields.trailText: The actor Jane Lapotaire was in a serious condition in a Paris hospital last night after a brain haemorrhage.
fields.body:
The actor Jane Lapotaire was in a serious condition in a Paris hospital last night after a brain haemorrhage.

The 55-year-old star of the TV series Love Hurts, who collapsed during a one-day shoot in the French capital last week, has been making good progress after surgery.

Ms Lapotaire, who has a 27-year-old son from her marriage to Killing Fields director Roland Joffe, is best known for her stage work. She has been nominated both for Baftas and Emmys and only recently finished touring Masterclass, a play about the the opera diva Maria Callas which she helped devise.

fields.headline: Parents overturn meningitis jab rules
fields.standfirst: Mass immunisation programme agreed following boy's death
fields.trailText: A health authority has been forced to overturn existing guidelines and offer a mass immunisation programme after worried parents refused to send their children to classes following the death of a teenage student from meningitis.
fields.body:
A health authority has been forced to overturn existing guidelines and offer a mass immunisation programme after worried parents refused to send their children to classes following the death of a teenage student from meningitis.

Hundreds of pupils at Cwmcarn high school near Newport, south Wales, have been kept off school since last week.

Under national guidelines mass vaccinations do not normally take place unless two or more cases of the same strain of meningitis are reported within a certain period.

Following the death of Ashley Burnett, 14, from the C strain of the illness early last week, close family and contacts were offered jabs. But Cwmcarn parents have been insisting that all children at the 680 pupil school be vaccinated.

Pupils aged 15 to 17 were vaccinated last autumn as part of the nationwide immunisation programme aimed at protecting high risk groups.

More than a third of the school was absent again yesterday as Gwent health authority and national assembly health officials held a crisis meeting.

The decision to extend the vaccination programme to younger pupils came as it emerged that a seven-month- old baby had been admitted to hospital with meningococcal septicaemia in what could be a related case. Although it has not yet been established what strain of meningitis the baby is suffering from, it is understood that a friend of Ashley recently babysat for the family.

Don Touhig, MP for Islwyn, said the health authority's decision was a victory for common sense.

"Parents will be pleased we have got a positive reponse," he said last night before a public meeting at Cwmcarn rugby club to explain the outcome of negotiations.

The vaccination programme is to begin on Thursday, the day after Ashley's funeral.

Cwmcarn's headteacher, Bill Beales, said 450 of the school's pupils failed to turn up for lessons on Friday and almost 300 were still absent yesterday.

He said a public meeting called by the health authority last week following Ashley's death had failed to allay fears and had led to some parents fighting their corner more vehemently.

"The tragic loss of any child is bound to trigger off highly charged emotional feelings," he said. "Things have calmed down a bit now, but there is a strong and vocal parental group that won't be satisfied unless they have their children vaccinated".

Gwent health authority insisted that the proposed immunisation against meningitis C was not an emergency vaccination but a rescheduling of a programme under which 11- to 14-year-olds were due to be vaccinated in the spring.

Eddie Coyle, the authority's director of public health, said that as Ashley's death was an isolated case there was no requirement for emergency public health measures within the school.

But he said the authority had agreed to consider the feasibility of bringing forward the vaccination programme in the light of the "considerable anxiety" of parents.

He said the fact that the children were due to be vaccinated in due course and that it had proved feasible to reschedule the programme were important factors in the decision.

fields.headline: Clubbers' drug confessions
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A survey by a dance and club culture magazine has given an insight into the degree of drug-taking and dealing among young people.
fields.body:
A survey by a dance and club culture magazine has given an insight into the degree of drug-taking and dealing among young people.

Seven out of 10 who responded to a questionnaire in Mixmag magazine said they had sold ecstasy, risking a jail sentence of up to four years, and six out of 10 admitted having driven a car after taking it.

Eight out of 10 respondents said they regularly took combinations of drugs - ecstasy, amphetamine, cocaine, LSD, amyl nitrate and cannabis; such cocktails carry both mental and physical risks.

Adam Winstock, of the national addiction centre at King's College, London, who compiled and analysed the survey, said he had been surprised by how many young people were using ecstasy regularly over a long period.

"Ecstasy is not a fad drug. People have been taking it for five, six or seven years - something you might consider chronic use."

The survey found that ecstasy was the most common drug among clubbers - taken by 86% of the 1,100 who took part, compared with 73% for cannabis, 46% for cocaine, and 39% for amphetamine.

On average males had taken ecstasy 180 times and females 120, with more than half taking at least five pills a night.

Four out of 10 young women said they had used amphetamines to control their weight.

The survey found women started ecstasy at age 19 on average, compared with 20 for men. A tablet cost between £2 and £25, with an average of £6.89. One clubber from the south coast said he had taken an ecstasy tablet every day for four years, and had used up to 30 in one weekend. Dr Winstock said 5% of the clubbers who responded were "heavy chronic binge users" taking 15 ecstasy pills in one night.

Nearly 80% of clubbers combined ecstasy with amphetamines, 55% with cocaine, 49% with amyl nitrate, 29% with LSD; others had used ketamine, Prozac, crack cocaine, and Viagra to create a new high while on ecstasy.

More than 17% said they had used benzodiazepines such as Valium to come down from an ecstasy high. "Valium on the black market is a drug you normally associate with opiate use, so the fact that it has moved into the club scene is worrying," said Dr Winstock.

Mixmag's editor Tom Whitwell said: "The really extreme use was quite shocking. And a lot of people are still taking a surprising number of risks, such as driving on drugs and mixing them.

"But the survey also showed that people are taking on board the safety messages, like drinking lots of water and taking vitamin C."

webTitle: Crohn's disease 'disaster' blamed on pasteurised milk

fields.headline: Crohn's disease 'disaster' blamed on pasteurised milk
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Pasteurised milk infected with dangerous bacteria is responsible for a "public health disaster", a leading medical specialist warned last night.
fields.body:
Pasteurised milk infected with dangerous bacteria is responsible for a "public health disaster", a leading medical specialist warned last night.

John Hermon-Taylor, head of the surgical department at St George's medical school in Tooting, south London, claimed that a bacterium believed to cause Crohn's disease, the inflammatory bowel disorder, was not killed by pasteurisation.

The bacterium, mycobac terium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (or MAP), was thought to be destroyed by pasteurisation, but Professor Hermon-Taylor claimed that his 20 years of research had proved that Crohn's disease in humans was linked with Johne's disease in cattle and passed on in pasteurised milk.

He called on the government to take urgent action to prevent the spread of the disease through unsafe milk. In pasteurisation milk and other foods are heated to destroy disease-causing micro-organisms and protect against putrefaction.

A ministry of agriculture spokesman said: "The government is carrying out its own research, and the advice from the department of health is that, on the basis of what is currently known, there is no need for anyone to change their dietary habits."

A National Dairy Council spokeswoman said: "The dairy industry has already taken voluntary steps to increase the pasteurisation time, purely as a precautionary measure. This is only one of a series of hypotheses, and what is needed is further research."

Crohn's disease, which afflicts about 80,000 people in the UK, is a severe inflammation of the small intestine and the colon, sometimes requiring surgery. Symptoms include chronic diarrhoea, abdominal pain, weight loss, extreme tiredness and psychological problems, and it can produce ulcers and tumours in the bowel.

Government scientists researching a possible link between milk and Crohn's disease are due to report this year. However, at present medical specialists assess the risk of infection from drinking a glass of pasteurised milk at one in 5m.

Prof Hermon-Taylor, who is funded by the charity Action Research, said: "The problems caused by MAP in the milk supply constitute a public health disaster of tragic proportions, for which a range of remedial measures are urgently needed, and for which the government must take responsibility.

"I am certain that MAP causes a substantial proportion of Crohn's disease."

Addressing the Royal Society of Medicine last night, he called for an immediate ban on the sale of unpasteurised milk and greater stringency in the pasteurisation process, including doubling sterilising time from 15 to 30 seconds.

He wanted the disease to be made notifiable, requiring doctors to report cases to the department of health, and for wide-ranging testing for MAP in dairy herds and the water supply. "I'm not scaremongering, but this disease ruins people's lives," he said.

"We need as a matter of urgency to carry out research to determine whether MAP is being conveyed from animals to the human population in water supplies."

Crohn's disease is not fatal. It is estimated there are between 4,000 and 8,000 new cases a year, costing as much as £240m a year in health care.

It has become five times more common in people aged under 26 in the past 20 years, and Anne Luther, director general of Action Research, described the problem in the UK as far greater than either the BSE-linked Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease or Aids.

Calls for a ban on unpasteurised milk - the raw cow's milk known as "green top" favoured by 100,000 consumers, including the Queen - were rejected by the government last January.

 Research by Japanese scientists published today suggests that fears of a link between Crohn's disease and the measles vaccine were unfounded.

webTitle: Government tells Opera to 'get a grip'

fields.headline: Government tells Opera to 'get a grip'
fields.trailText: The government yesterday told the Royal Opera House to "get a grip" as technical problems again threatened its closure.
fields.body:
The government yesterday told the Royal Opera House to "get a grip" as technical problems again threatened its closure.

As unions demanded that the rebuilt £218m complex be shut until the recurring problems with the computer system controlling the scenery were solved, a source close to the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said that moving sets, no matter how complicated the computers, "was not rocket science".

"Progress needs to be made, and made soon," the source said. "The Arts Council too needs to monitor them vigorously."

The patience of behind-the-scenes staff, who had been working overtime to get productions on, was running out, warned Gerry Morrissey of the technicians' union, Bectu.

"Unless the management can send a very positive message to both the staff and patrons that all the glitches have been sorted out, we believe that there is no alternative but to close the house down."

Ten performances, including one production, Le Grand Macabre, have been cancelled, and several performances delayed, since the house reopened last month. A series of sometimes comic faults, breakdowns and safety disputes have plagued those productions that have gone ahead. Last week a schools performance of Gawain was axed and on Thursday night the audience booed a decision to cut the final part of a ballet triple bill after another long hold-up.

The opera's executive director, Michael Kaiser, said they were working around the clock to solve the technical problems. "We hope we can solve it in the very short term, at which point we will have an opera house that will be with us for many centuries," he said. We are making progress."

Complaints from opera goers, however, about everything from the prices of tickets to those of the sandwiches - £6.50 each - has taken the shine off the new regime. The only hopeful sign has been the critical acclaim greeting performances that have gone ahead.

A series of sometimes comic faults, breakdowns and safety disputes have plagued those productions that have gone ahead. Last week a schools performance of Gawain was axed and on Thursday night the audience booed a decision to cut the final part of a ballet triple bill after another long hold-up. The opera's executive director, Michael Kaiser, said they were working around the clock to solve the technical problems. "We hope we can solve it in the very short term, at which point we will have an opera house that will be with us for many centuries," he said. We are making progress." Complaints from opera goers, however, about everything from the prices of tickets to those of the sandwiches - £6.50 each - has taken the shine off the new regime. The only hopeful sign has been the critical acclaim greeting performances that have gone ahead.

webTitle: Champagne on ice for women's polar double

fields.headline: Champagne on ice for women's polar double
fields.trailText: A team of British women has claimed a double by becoming the first all-female expedition to conquer both poles.
fields.body:
A team of British women has claimed a double by becoming the first all-female expedition to conquer both poles.

The five completed the 695-mile trek to the south pole at 6am yesterday, having in 1997 been among the first women to reach the north pole as part of a relay team of 20 women.

The five had set out from the edge of Antarctica, on November 24, and had battled against freezing wind and snow dunes up to 10ft high.

At the pole the first person they called was the Prince of Wales, who is patron of the expedition and had met them in London. They continued by raising the Union Jack, singing the national anthem, and eating some of the prince's Duchy biscuits.

Speaking on a satellite phone, Caroline Hamilton, leader of the £350,000 expedition, described their arrival as like a scene from a James Bond film: "The US polar base appeared out of the mist, people came towards us, and a Hercules landed in front of us.

"The prince said he was very proud of his ladies, and we hope to meet up with him when we get back."

The team also called Pen Hadow, of the Polar Travel Company, which had organised the relay trek. Mr Hadow said: "They called at 6am, and they had just had champagne.

"They have been self-reliant from beginning to end. They call me up occasionally, and have been incredibly upbeat.

"It requires resilience being in such a bleak landscape. The main problem is crevasses up to 100ft deep - some are known, some are not."

The pole is 9,500ft up on the Antarctic plateau, and the women got there on skis, pulling food and equipment on sledges twice their weight. They got new supplies on January 3.

En route they collected physiological data on how the female body reacted to extreme conditions. They have raised funds for the charity Special Olympics UK.

The team comprised Caroline Hamilton, 35, a film director from London; Zoe Hudson, 32, a physiotherapist and lecturer from London; Pom Oliver, 46, a builder from West Sussex; Ann Daniels, 32, a mother of triplets from Somerset who had no prior outdoor experience; and Rosie Stancer, 39, a writer based in Prague who is the Queen Mother's great niece.

Although it is summer in Antarctica temperatures are as low as -50C with 80mph winds. There is 24-hour daylight, so the team wore masks and nose shields to ward off ultraviolet radiation.

Animals cannot survive the conditions, and the women had each to consume more than 5,000 calories a day to pull their sledges - eating a kilo of food a day. They wore layers of clothing, goggles, neck gaiters, wristlets and several pairs of socks, as well as scarves, hats and windproof suits. Satellite equipment enabled the team to track its position, and a solar powered satellite phone kept it in touch with base. The glass fibre sledges carried a dome tent, sleeping bags, ice axes, cookers, snow shovel, thermos flasks, and presents for Christmas. Each woman had a watch that could send a signal in an emergency.

Each was also allowed one luxury: Ms Hamilton chose nail scissors, Ms Daniels a perfume miniature, Ms Oliver a tapestry, and Ms Stancer a sheet of poetry. Ms Hudson did without.

webTitle: Millionaire 'killed wife for calling him mean'

fields.headline: Millionaire 'killed wife for calling him mean'
fields.standfirst: Prosecution tells Old Bailey how nagging over spending £1m on two flats ended in angry words, a struggle, and a body wrapped in a sheet
fields.trailText: A millionaire suffocated his wife with a pillow when she told him he was mean for being unwilling to buy her a £730,000 flat in an exclusive district of London, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A millionaire suffocated his wife with a pillow when she told him he was mean for being unwilling to buy her a £730,000 flat in an exclusive district of London, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Malcolm Horsman, 66, had already bought Ursula Horsman, 54, a £300,000 apartment in her native Switzerland, and had been persuaded to buy the flat in Belgravia.

When he argued with her than they needed only one home, she allegedly told him: "The trouble with you is that you're mean, and everybody says so."

William Boyce, prosecuting, told the court: "He welled up in a sense of outrage and grabbed her to vent, in some way, his irritation on her physically." Having killed her early in the morning, the businessman went ahead with his daily routine in an attempt to regain his composure before reporting the death to police, the jury heard. Horsman denies a charge of murder.

A director of two companies which specialise in company recovery and a former director of the Bowater Corporation, Horsman married for a second time in 1983, and the couple moved into a leased apartment in Knightsbridge. Horsman described their marriage as "happy and loving", but his wife wanted somewhere better to live, the court was told.

Mr Boyce said that in the months before Mrs Horsman's death in December 1998, the couple had agreed to buy a flat in Belgravia and were in the process of buying an apartment in Switzerland.

"He consistently tried to persuade her to settle for just the Swiss property," Mr Boyce told the court. The "drip, drip" of his wife's constant and forceful remarks over property had been hurtful, Horsman allegedly told police.

The court heard that Mrs Horsman had spent the night in a spare bedroom because she had a cold. At 7am, when her husband came into the room, she raised the dispute over lifestyle.

Mr Boyce said: "The debate became louder and more volatile, more insistent on her part, and more defensive on his. She was bickering and it got more heated. She told him that 'the trouble was that he was mean and everybody said so'. It was that, he said, which made him go for her, for the first time ever."

Horsman had told police that he grabbed his wife's shoulders, and she lunged back at him, the court heard. The pair grappled, and fell to the floor. The next Horsman could recall was that his wife was limp. She had given out a sound resembling a "death rattle", Mr Boyce said. "He noticed a pillow with blood on it nearby, and thought somehow he might have smothered her."

He dragged her into the en suite bathroom, stripped off the nightgown, and threw it in the bath with his pyjamas. After wrapping the body in a sheet, he tidied up the bedroom and resolved to carry on with his daily routine "to get some of his sanity back", he was alleged to have told police.

Mr Boyce told the court that the hall porter in the apartment block saw Horsman leave at 8.30am, as they exchanged "the usual pleasantries".

Horsman picked up a painting the couple had been keeping in storage, went to a DIY store, attended a business meeting in Knightsbridge, then went to work, the jury heard. At 4.30pm he walked into Chelsea police station and told the receptionist his wife was dead.

He allegedly then told police officers: "It hasn't really hit me yet what's happened. I suppose that's why I just carried on with my normal daily routine."

When officers got to the apartment they found the body wrapped in the sheet. A post mortem concluded Mrs Horsman had been smothered with a pillow for between one and three minutes.

There were signs she had put up a struggle, and killing her would have required "quite an effort", said Mr Boyce.

Horsman is defending himself. The trial, before the Common Serjeant of London, Judge Neil Denison, continues.

webTitle: Mother died after tummy tuck op

fields.headline: Mother died after tummy tuck op
fields.standfirst: Coroner calls procedure that went wrong 'unnecessary' Inquest told woman wanted removal of fat caused by pregnancy
fields.trailText: A mother preoccupied with losing weight gained through her third pregnancy died when an unnecessary tummy tuck operation went wrong, a coroner's court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A mother preoccupied with losing weight gained through her third pregnancy died when an unnecessary tummy tuck operation went wrong, a coroner's court heard yesterday.

Lorraine Batt, aged 36,from Wickford, Essex. saved for years to pay for the £5,500 abdomenoplasty after dieting failed to shift the saggy pouch caused by a caesarean section.

But complications swiftly set in, and within two days of the operation last January she had died.

Yesterday, as he recorded a verdict of death by misadventure, the coroner, Stephen Chan, described the operation on the nine-and-a-half stone, 5ft 5in mother as "unnecessary".

And he warned: "The point must be made that all surgery can have complications of devestating effect. It is important for those who are in a position to do so to make it clear that there is no safe surgery."

The consultant responsible, Winston Shear, said he found his patient's death very distressing and apologised to her family.

St Pancras' coroners court, north London, was told the procedure on January 27 at the Highgate private hospital, in north London, initially went smoothly.

Mr Shear removed the 1.4kg of skin and fat and Mrs Batt returned to the ward conscious and on a routine saline drip.

By the following morning she had vomited and was complaining of nausea and a headache.

The surgeon gave her an anti-emetic to stop the sickness and increased the level of salt in the drip. But, by the evening, she was still suffering from nausea and a headache. After a nurse gave her morphine, Mr Shear believed that she had reacted badly to this and asked for blood samples to be tested.

When he returned at 11pm, she was no longer confused and was able to recognise him. "I was happy and relieved to see what I felt was a normal clinical picture," he told the court. "I didn't ask for blood test results because her situation was normal."

But, by 5.15 the next morning, the picture had altered, with Mrs Batt lying face down on her bed and refusing to cooperate.

Mr Shear told the hearing "My assessment was that there was something very wrong and I couldn't explain why. I felt she couldn't stay in the hospital."

While she was being transferred to the nearby Royal Free hospital in Hampstead, she stopped breathing, the court heard. She died at 12.40pm in the hospital's intensive care unit.

Pathologist Susan Davies told the court that the cause of death was waterlogging of the brain, leading to swelling. She said that the condition was caused by a low level of salt in the blood, and it could often occur after operations - particularly on pre-menopausal women and children. The reasons why were "not perfectly clear," she added.

Mrs Batt's underactive thyroid was also a factor, said Dr Davies, as was the anti-diuretic hormone she released, due to stress of the operation, which meant that she was unable to secrete urine and so diluted fluids in her body.

Mrs Batt's husband, David, said after the hearing that the family would speak to their solicitor before deciding whether to sue for compensation.

webTitle: Cancer study adds to olive oil's list of virtues

fields.headline: Cancer study adds to olive oil's list of virtues
fields.trailText: A golden liquid at the heart of the Mediterranean diet has been given a new virtue to add to its seemingly magical list of properties for promoting a long and healthy life.
fields.body:
A golden liquid at the heart of the Mediterranean diet has been given a new virtue to add to its seemingly magical list of properties for promoting a long and healthy life.

Research published today suggests olive oil may stave off bowel cancer, as well as combating heart disease, breast cancer, and diabetes, strokes and gallstones.

Tests on rats fed a cancer-inducing agent found they developed fewer tumours when their diet included olive oil.

The researchers report today in the BMJ publication Gut that this may be due to flavonoids - an antioxidant found in olives, red wine and apples, and proved to help prevent cancer.

Miguel Gassull and a team at Barcelona's university hospital divided rats into three groups, and fed them diets rich in either safflower oil (similar to sunflower oil), olive oil, or fish oil (a known anti-carcinogen). Half of each group was given a cancer-inducing agent. Those fed safflower oil had more precancerous tissue and tumours than for fish or olive oil diets.

Oleic acid, 75% of olive oil, is the main fat component of the Mediterranean diet. Professor Gassull said it was unlikely oleic acid was solely accountable for olive oil's beneficial effects, and suggested further research into olive oil's properties.
