fields.trailText:
Eurotunnel hit by duties
The number of people taking shuttle trains through the Channel tunnel dipped 1m to 19m last year, as the end to duty free shopping took its toll. Eurostar train passenger levels, however, increased 4.5% to nearly 6.6m, Eurotunnel said.

The playwright John Godber has taken the stage in his musical Thick as a 16-year-old girl. A cast illness forced Godber, 6ft 3in, 17 stone and aged 43, to step into the role 15 minutes before curtain up at Hull's Truck theatre.

Britain's first online undertaking service is launched today by the supermarket chain United Norwest Co- op and 70 funeral parlours. A spokesman said: "If a family member died today you'd be able to go online and order everything from a black tie to flowers."

Croquet man killed himself
The croquet writer and former champion Keith Wylie, hailed as the game's most innovative thinker, gassed himself in his car after becoming depressed, a Cambridge inquest heard. A verdict of suicide was recorded on Wylie, 54, a father of two from Southampton.

Booth out, Carman in
The libel lawyer George Carman will join Cherie Booth's present chambers at Grays Inn Square, London, when she leaves to join a new practice in April. Mr Carman's present practice, New Court Chambers, will be "dissolved amicably".

Jams today for jam tomorrow
Up to 250,000 extra cars were expected in London this morning as Connex train drivers seeking a shorter working week held a 24-hour strike.

fields.headline: Divorcees may get church weddings
fields.standfirst:
Report could pave way for Charles to marry Camilla

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Church of England's ruling body, the general synod, will today receive a report which is likely to pave the way for the church to allow divorcees with ex-partners still alive to remarry with a full church wedding.
fields.body:
The Church of England's ruling body, the general synod, will today receive a report which is likely to pave the way for the church to allow divorcees with ex-partners still alive to remarry with a full church wedding.

The proposals before the synod are based on the recommendations of a working party report, Marriage in Church after Divorce. The implications of the legislation could have far reaching effects.

While the report does not refer directly to the Prince of Wales, it is believed his relationship with Camilla Parker Bowles did influence some decisons. If the legislation were implemented it is possible that the future monarch would be able to remarry in a full church ceremony, even though Mrs Parker Bowles's former husband, Andrew, is still alive.

The report, by a working party headed by the Bishop of Winchester, will not propose that the church allow remarriage on demand, but that, given certain circumstances, it should be allowed.

The Bishop of Winchester, writing in today's Times, said the changes were imminent and that the report recommended allowing parish priests the discretion to agree to perform marriage services for divorcees whose former partners were still living.

The recommendations are seen as an attempt to regulate the church's policy to remarriage as many anglican priests already remarry divorcees with living former partners.

In the foreword to the report, the bishop, Michael Scott-Joynt, makes it clear the church's preferred view is that marriage should be a lifelong institution. He said: "We recognise the sincerely held views of those who take an indissolubist line, but propose nothing that alters the church's traditionalist teaching that marriage should always be undertaken as a life-long commitment, nor do we propose any alteration to the existing statutory protection of clerical consciences on this matter.

"We do nevertheless recommend, unanimously, a straightforward procedure whereby clergy may, by way of exception, solemnise further marriages of divorced persons, with a former partner still living, where circumstances meet the appropriate pastoral criteria, in such a way that this is no longer inconsistent with the declared mind of the church."

Under the proposals, guidelines for remarriage would be drawn up to ensure a consistent policy on the issue nationwide. The couple seeking to be remarried would discuss with the clergy reasons for the previous breakdown, how the remarriage would affect children from the previous marriage and whether the new relationship had ended the old.

Parish priests would also consider how many times either partner had been married, and would refer each case to the diocesan bishop before agreeing to permit the marriage to take place in church.

The final decision would rest with the parish priest, although priests would not be forced to carry out marriages if they believed it to be wrong.

The report recommends that the option of a service of prayer and dedication after a civil marriage service should remain at the discretion of the priest. Diocesan synods will consider the recommendations, reporting back to the House of Bishops by March 2001, with a view to discussions in the general synod by the end of that year.

webTitle: Blair bid to calm gay sex dispute

fields.headline: Blair bid to calm gay sex dispute
fields.standfirst:
Anger over section 28 repeal

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday mounted a rearguard action to prevent a "silent majority" backlash over gay sex education sweeping south from Scotland into middle England as ministers moved towards repealing the Thatcherite legislation at the root of the controversy.
fields.body:
The government yesterday mounted a rearguard action to prevent a "silent majority" backlash over gay sex education sweeping south from Scotland into middle England as ministers moved towards repealing the Thatcherite legislation at the root of the controversy.

English bishops and the Conservative opposition weighed in behind the Catholic hierarchy in Scotland to oppose repeal of section 28, which forbids councils from promoting homosexuality.

But Tony Blair appealed for a "rational and sensible" debate on the issue and Downing Street insisted that the controversial 1988 clause had never applied directly to schools in England and Wales, although officials admitted that many teachers believe it does.

Labour is desperate to head off another public kicking on a populist controversy which could find the cabinet on the unpopular side. Most of the cabinet is solidly behind repeal but the government is treading a tightrope and anxious not to pick new enemies.

Local government ministers Lord Whitty and Beverley Hughes were sent on a round of television and radio interviews to promise "family-values-oriented guidance" to schools and local authorities. Repeal of section 28 would free teachers and council workers from the fear of "stepping over the line" of the current law, Ms Hughes suggested.

"The guidance in relation to sex education in particular will stress the importance of the context of family values and what children need to grow up, but it will also enable teachers to deal with the real issues that gay and lesbian pupils bring into school and want schools and teachers to help them with," she said.

With the issue bitterly dividing Scotland, the local government bill which would repeal the clause moves to the Lords today. It is likely to face defeat by a cross-party coalition within the next week.

Ministers are saying that the 1988 legislation - then a subject of impassioned debate over sex education books such as Jenny Lives with Eric and Martin - was hopelessly badly drafted.

Its existence deters teachers from providing either protection or pastoral care to vulnerable gay teenagers, pro-reformers argue.

"The practical implications of this is that a lot of teachers don't understand what they can teach," one said last night.

One third of teachers still believe they are bound by the section not to do anything to promote homosexuality, Downing Street conceded last night.

"We have seen outbreaks of homophobic bullying, we have gay and lesbian pupils and indeed adults feeling that they had got no response from the authorities for addressing their problems," Lord Whitty said on BBC Radio 4's The World at One.

"What we are talking about here is discrimination against a significant minority of our citizens, many of whom find themselves in quite serious emotional difficulty."

The prime minister's official spokesman said: "To read some of the papers in Scotland, you would think being gay was being put on the national curriculum, that people are being taught to be gay. It's not like that.

"He (Mr Blair) is a parent as well as a prime minister and simply doesn't accept that repeal would do what the opponents say."

The danger of a socially conservative backlash against the government's Queen's speech commitment spreading to England became evident yesterday when the Catholic bishop of Liverpool, the Rt Rev James Jones, joined Cardinal Thomas Winning, the Catholic primate in Scotland, in publicly opposing repeal of section 28.

More cautiously, George Carey, the Archbishop of Canterbury, also called for safeguards in schools and warned against putting "homosexual relations on an equal footing with marriage."

Unwilling to pick a fight, Downing Street says everyone is entitled to their view, but insists that "a tolerant UK in which everyone feels comfortable with themselves" is best served by removal of section 28 which prevents "intentional" promotion of homosexuality.

The Lords have already rejected sexual equality at 16 this session, claiming that expulsion of the hereditary peers gives it new legitimacy to thwart the elected Commons.

John Redwood, the Tory Commons spokesman, last night warned against repeal. But he admitted the law might need to be amended even though, as it stands, it does not provide "any legal impediments to teachers tackling bullying".

fields.headline: Assembly rejects RUC reforms
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Politicians in Northern Ireland yesterday voted against Chris Patten's proposals for the RUC, backing a motion asserting that his recommendations rewarded terrorists and destroyed the force.
fields.body:
Politicians in Northern Ireland yesterday voted against Chris Patten's proposals for the RUC, backing a motion asserting that his recommendations rewarded terrorists and destroyed the force.

With unionists in the majority in the 108-seat assembly, the outcome was a foregone conclusion, voting being 50 to 42. Because after devolution security remains the reponsibility of Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, the vote was largely symbolic.

The Democratic Unionist party's Nigel Dodds, minister for social development, condemned Mr Mandelson for announcing last week that he was implementing virtually in full Mr Patten's 175 recommendations. He said that Mr Mandelson had used "slick and oily words" in awarding the RUC the George Cross before destroying it.

Unionists were unhappy last night after the Commons passed by a majority of 283 a motion allowing members of the Stormont parliament also to sit at Westminster. Ken Maginnis, Ulster Unionist security spokesman, said it was a concession designed solely to aid Sinn Fein.

Mary Harney, the Irish deputy prime minister, yesterday called on the IRA to start decommissioning. At the inaugural meeting of the trade and industry cross-border body, she said it was vitally important the Good Friday agreement was implemented in full. Republicans should play their part in ensuring decommissioning happened.

Her call came as the Irish police intercepted two home-made Semtex bombs in Tipperary and arrested a man.

fields.headline: Mother 'unaware' of morning after pill
fields.trailText: A mother who is suing the makers of Durex condoms told the high court yesterday she had never heard of the "morning after pill".
fields.body:
A mother who is suing the makers of Durex condoms told the high court yesterday she had never heard of the "morning after pill".

Marian Richardson, 36, claims that she became pregnant through a faulty Durex made by LRC Products - formerly the London Rubber Company. She has legal aid to seek £120,000 in compensation. Besides damages for the pain of a caesarean to have Kara, four next week, she wants reimbursing for what was her third and an unplanned child - including £5,000 to upgrade to a Volvo estate to hold three children, and £40,000 for her daughter's care. There is also an estimated £39,000 financial loss when plans for a business as a health consultant and beautician with her boyfriend, Anthony Pugh, ended because the stress led to them splitting up. They have since married.

In evidence, Ms Richardson, of Carlton Colville in Suffolk, told Mr Justice Ian Kennedy that she noticed the sheath's teat was missing immediately after intercourse in May 1995, and kept the "Jeans" prophylactic as evidence. LRC, whose instructions point out no contraception is 100% safe, denied supplying a defective condom, and argued she in any case contributed by failing to take the "morning after pill".

Cross-examined by Jeremy Stuart-Smith QC for LRC, she said she had not read the instructions and was unaware makers did not offer 100% protection. She did not know about the "morning after pill" at the time, and in any event would have thought it available only from her GP and not from her weekend emergency doctor service. She denied she had "taken the risk".

Outlining Ms Richardon's case, John Williams said LRC was liable under the 1987 consumer protection act in the first action of its kind before the court. The case continues.

fields.headline: Better late than never
fields.trailText: Sometimes it feels like there's nothing on TV. Last week you'd have been forgiven for thinking there was only one show: Gormenghast, screaming from the covers of your TV guides, with endless puff-piece discussion and blanket trailer coverage shouting: "WE ARE HERE - YOU MUST WATCH!"
fields.body:
Sometimes it feels like there's nothing on TV. Last week you'd have been forgiven for thinking there was only one show: Gormenghast, screaming from the covers of your TV guides, with endless puff-piece discussion and blanket trailer coverage shouting: "WE ARE HERE - YOU MUST WATCH!"

But hidden among the schedules are shows that for some reason don't make it into this consensus du jour, that the broadcasters seem almost embarrassed to have on, but which are more entertaining than most prime-time offerings.

Seinfeld's much-maligned near-midnight run on BBC2 is the most obvious example of recent times: the biggest US sitcom of the 90s, tucked in a corner like the brainy genius no one wants to talk to at school.

This week, for the benefit of students and anyone with the foresight to program a video, there's two: Disinfo Nation and Oz, both on Thursday night's 4 Later slot.

Disinfo Nation, (12.40am, C4) is an alt.news show that this week spends almost the entire 30 minutes talking to Robert Anton Wilson, one of the founding fathers of conspiracy culture; not flawless, but more entertaining than another prank on TFI Friday.

Then there's the repeated second series of Oz, (1.15am, C4), one of those rare things in modern pop culture: something great that no one seems to know about. A prison drama that manages to have something new to say, with great characterisation, compelling acting, gripping storylines and an original visual style, it comes a close second to that other HBO show that everyone knows about, The Sopranos, yet we hear nothing and it's on too late for most viewers to stumble across.

Both of these shows are unlike anything shown during prime time, which is great if you've got insomnia, but not if you have to get up in the morning.

fields.headline: Some mothers do 'ave 'em
fields.trailText: Panorama | Delia's How To Cook - Part Two
fields.body:
Panorama (BBC1) opened a big can of worms with a programme debating the pros and cons of working motherhood. Back in the 70s, new legislation on maternity leave and sex discrimination seemed to promise women that they could have careers as well as families; the working mothers featured in the programme are now finding just how difficult that can be.

Penny put her daughter into day care at the age of six weeks, and goes through hell every morning when the little girl, now three, screams the nursery down. Cathy has never been to any of her four-year-old son's open days, and puts him into an "after-school club" every evening until she can pick him up. The little boy recently announced that he hates his mother. Both women appeared exhausted and unwell; Cathy doesn't eat or sleep properly, and Penny feels she's on the verge of a nervous breakdown.

These women are obviously on the horns of a painful dilemma. Penny is the main breadwinner and, anyway, enjoys the stimulation of going out to work. Cathy is loath to watch a successful pre-motherhood career go down the plughole. It was at this point that certain obvious options could have been addressed: both women were married, but it was never suggested that their husbands might give up work and look after the children. Both were double-income households, but there was little discussion of giving up one salary and living a humbler, more frugal lifestyle while the children needed day care. There was much talk of "having it all", but nobody ever seemed to consider that having children might mean making sacrifices.

Instead they laboured under a daily burden of guilt, sending unwell children to school because there was nobody at home to look after them, hoping that the misery of childhood would be forgotten in later years. To make matters even worse, some research was trotted out to suggest that academic achievement in later life is directly related to the mother's employment during the pre-school years. Anecdotal information suggested that legislation to protect working mothers will actually put employers off the whole idea of hiring women of prime child-bearing age.

With the evidence stacking up so horrendously, it's hardly surprising that Cathy gave up her job and went freelance. Ultimately, Panorama raised more questions than it was prepared to answer. The conclusion was that working motherhood isn't working at all - it would be hard to think otherwise after such a parade of domestic misery. But anyone who suggested that parenthood and career don't necessarily mix - that the problem lies not with unsympathetic employers but with parents trying to lead two lives - was demonised as an enemy of women's rights.

Far, far away from these vexing issues, in a sunlit kitchen in East Anglia, Delia Smith got to grips with meat. A definite religious vibe permeates Delia's How To Cook - Part Two (BBC2), from the hymn-like opening music to the lovely close-ups of flowers that punctuate the chopping and frying. No worries about work or childcare here: no worries, even, about the unpromising slop that will turn into a delicious steak and kidney pie. "You'll have to trust me", said Delia, and we do, we do.

The scheduling of Delia's How To Cook at 8.30pm is a stroke of genius: after most people have eaten, but before their stomachs have shut down for the night. As mini boeuf-en-croutes were cut open to reveal pink, glistening interiors, the food-loving nation staggered towards the television with little inarticulate cries of hunger. (Vegetarians, one can only hope, were still washing up.) Last night's episode ended with yet more delicious glimpses of food that we can only learn how to cook if we buy the book, although Delia is too discreet to state the fact baldly.

She was not too discreet, however, to make a blatant bid for a longer slot. "Until we get longer cookery programmes," she said, with a rare steely glint in her eye, "that's all we've got time for." Would anyone dare refuse her? Will next week's show (poultry) stretch to an hour?

fields.trailText: For 50 years Major CC Allport's cricket pavilion was the major source of entertainment in the small Lincolnshire village of Woodhall Spa. But it didn't provide the classic rural sound of leather on willow: what attracted the punters was the Compton organ and The Perils Of Pauline. In 1922 the major had converted the building into The Kinema in the Woods, one of Britain's earliest Flicks In The Sticks (9.30am, Radio 4). Film director Bryan Forbes recalls its heyday in the first of a new series.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Sheena Sings The Bard 9pm, BBC2

Before last summer, singer Sheena Wellington was well known within Scottish folk music circles, but after she performed Man's A Man at the ceremony marking the opening of the Scottish Parliament, she swiftly became a household name. Tonight, in celebration of Burns Night, she pays tribute to the Bard in a special concert from Hill of Tarvit House in Fife, helped out by performers Aly Bain, Rod Paterson, Ewen Sutherland and John Morran.

Behind The Crime 9pm, C4

Those who smirked when Earl Spencer's equally posh friend Darius Guppy was nabbed for his part in an attempted insurance fraud can catch the full story in this enlightening series. Guppy's partner in crime, Benedict Marsh, vividly recalls every excruciating and incriminating mistake they made when they concocted a fake jewel theft to cover their crippling debts. Better still is Terry Bradley, an art forger who did very well out of conning people into buying pictures he knocked up in his kitchen with the aid of copious amounts of tea and coffee stains. He even saw one of his portraits end up on the Antiques Roadshow, much to his delight. He shows no regret in selling fakes to people he thought were more interested in the supposed value of a painting rather than its artistic merit.

Whitbread Book Awards Live 9.30pm, BBC2

Overshadowed by the more flamboyant and sometimes controversial Booker Prize, the Whitbread book awards have been quietly showing perhaps a more realistic indication of what the British book-buying public is actually purchasing. This is reflected in its considerably more populist panel of judges, which includes Ann Widdecombe, Imogen Stubbs, Sandi Toksvig and, oddly, Jerry Hall. Mark Lawson presides over the BBC's own critical panel (consisting of Ian Hislop, David Baddiel and Rosie Boycott) as awards for best novel, first novel, children's book, poetry and biography are handed out

fields.headline: The great DVD scandal
fields.standfirst: Video, we're told, is dead. DVDs - films on CD - are taking over the home entertainment market. But the system is having a host of teething problems. And, as  Dave Green discovers, British fans are the ones losing out
fields.trailText: Video, we're told, is dead. DVDs - films on CD - are taking over the home entertainment market. But the system is having a host of teething problems. And, as Dave Green discovers, British fans are the ones losing out
fields.body:
DVD was launched in Japan in November, 1996, and officially arrived in the UK about two years later. Ostensibly it offers the same advantages over videotape that CDs have over cassettes - crisp, digital quality, instant access to different tracks, durability - but users have found that, compared to CDs, buying a DVD player (or just one of the films) can be riddled with complexities.

For instance, does the disc come with "extras"? Will it work on my machine? And if a shop sells me an American Region 1 DVD that doesn't have a British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) certificate, are they breaking the law? Lee Stoneman runs The UK DVD Debate website (www.dvd-debate.com) cataloguing not just the latest releases, but also the format's more noteworthy controversies - not least of which the reports (hilarious to non-owners) that some films don't work on some players, sometimes causing them to "freeze up" - or worse.

Alarmingly, it's not obscure, low-rent flicks that are responsible, but major releases like You've Got Mail, Wild Wild West and Entrapment. "Until recently there was not one single player that would play every disc out there", Lee concedes. "My own Pioneer 515 will not play the Robocop Special Edition disc, for example and that was far from a budget-range machine."

The situation is improving now, with newer machines able to "play pretty much everything", and more publicised problems receiving manufacturers' attention - for instance, the Samsung machines that balked over the hotly awaited DVD of The Matrix. "Samsung issued free chip upgrades to owners that fix the problem," Lee reports, "but many people are still unaware of the fact."

If there's one factor every DVD owner knows about, it's the Regions. To prevent the "nightmarish" scenario of anyone in the world being able to play any DVD, the format includes the facility to lock-out any disc from a different geographically bizarre domain: Region 1 covers the US and Canada; Region 2 Europe, Japan, and the Middle East; Region 4 Australia, New Zealand and Central and South America.

The system is designed to protect global distribution rights - for instance, most American productions hit DVD long before they hit cinemas here. But among its side effects is the fact that Region 2 discs sold here often have fewer "added extras" than their US counterparts.

Sometimes it's due to rights and costs, but sometimes it's the film-fan's old friend, the BBFC. When a film's UK release requires scenes to be cut to achieve a particular age-rating - as with The Abyss and, of course, The Matrix - all those fancy extra commentaries and soundtracks need re-editing as well. So, to save cash, these are usually ditched from discs in Region 2.

Of course, the dedicated UK DVDer can buy a player (or get theirs "modified") to play Region 1 discs as well, but a clampdown on sales of imported "R1s" in this country, oddly coinciding with the main launch of Region 2s, is making them harder to find. "It has always been illegal for UK-based companies to sell material that is uncertified by the BBFC," Lee confirms - although apparently they can't touch you for "personal importation" from, say, US web stores.

But for all its many "teething troubles" the DVD Debate site still comes out in favour in the format.

"The one thing that does seem to be stopping people from buying DVD players at present, and a complaint which I hear a lot, is that you can't record onto DVD", Lee jibes. "I assume the people who say this have only just bought CD players some 20 years later, now that they are recordable too."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The October Man
fields.body:
The October Man

(Roy Baker, 1947)

5pm, Carlton Cinema

After suffering a brain injury in a road accident, an industrial chemist moves into a provincial hotel and tries to rebuild his life. But shortly after he moves in, a female guest is murdered. Did he do it? Did he 'eck. Question is, can he conquer his own demons for long enough to nobble the bloke who did? While slightly lacking in pace, this is an involving, atmospheric suspenser in the Hitchcock mould - director Baker was one of Alfred's protégés - with a tortured performance from John Mills in the lead.

Andy Bodle

A Simple Twist Of Fate

(Gillies MacKinnon, 1994)

9pm, UK Arena

A polished reworking and updating of George Eliot's Silas Marner, with Steve Martin playing very effectively against type. He is the miserable furniture-maker McCann, who finds a new meaning in life when a child is abandoned on his doorstep: he brings her up as his own daughter (played impressively by Alana Austin) until, 10 years on, the biological father, local big-wig Gabriel Byrne, returns to claim her. The plotting remains old-fashioned and over-reliant on coincidence, but MacKinnon and the fine cast keep the emotions running high.

Reservoir Dogs

(Quentin Tarantino, 1992)

12.05am, FilmFour

The heist botched, the gang assemble in a warehouse. Macho rage bounces off the walls: Tim Roth lying in a slick of blood, Harvey Keitel (pictured) and Steve Buscemi at each other's throats and Michael Madsen dancing a comic-Gothic torture scene to Stuck In The Middle With You. Tarantino's debut is a brilliant thriller.

Come See The Paradise

(Alan Parker, 1990)

2.45am, Sky Premier

Parker's account of a shabby episode in US second world war history - the internment of Japanese Americans after Pearl Harbour - is an old-fashioned, sentimental melodrama, shot in seductive Ridley-Scott style by Michael Seresin. Fine central performances, though, from Dennis Quaid as the Irish-American (another kind of outsider) union activist-turned GI, and Tamlyn Tomita, the love torn from him.

fields.headline: Straight-talking bishop
fields.standfirst:
The Bishop of Liverpool was seen as the ideal modern churchman - a contender to be the next Archbishop of Canterbury. So what is he doing pronouncing that gay sex is unnatural? James Meek finds out

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Bishop of Liverpool was seen as the ideal modern churchman - a contender to be the next Archbishop of Canterbury. So what is he doing pronouncing that gay sex is unnatural?  James Meek  finds out
fields.body:
In conventional political terms, the Anglican Bishop of Liverpool, James Jones, normally looks and sounds like the perfect Blairite bishop. Young, articulate, a campaigner for social justice and inclusiveness, angered by the damage raw Thatcherite economics inflicted on communities, he is a TV and radio natural with a genuine talent for networking and motivating people. He is a product of the middle class with a clear vision of a classless Christ, equally at ease with references to the Acts of the Apostles and the latest Martin Amis novel: he wants, he says, to be an "advocate for the voiceless and powerless".

No wonder sage heads nodded at his enthronement in 1998, and murmured that here was a future Archbishop of Canterbury, the man Tony Blair - who rejected the first two nominees for the post - would like to see leading the Church of England. In conventional political terms, that is. But ultimately Jones is not a politician, conventional or unconventional. He is an evangelical Christian priest who believes firmly in the rightness of the New Testament, and sooner or later all the passion for social justice comes back to that.

That's why the bishop popped up in the Daily Telegraph yesterday, throwing in his lot with the campaign in Scotland to keep Clause 28, the Tory-introduced measure which, by forbidding local authorities to "promote" homosexuality, has prevented schoolteachers from even raising the topic in the classroom. In his article, the bishop defended Cardinal Thomas Winning, the spiritual leader of Scotland's Roman Catholics, who last week called homosexuals "perverted" and at the weekend - though Jones may not have been aware of this - said "an active and militant homosexual lobby" at work across Europe was comparable to Nazi bombers during the second world war.

Cardinal Winning has led the pro-Clause 28 campaign north of the border. Of the Catholic cleric's earlier anti-repeal efforts, Jones wrote: "Cardinal Winning's intervention makes an appeal over the heads of the gatekeepers of political correctness direct to the silent constituency." He went on: "Much is made of the equal rights of gay people to express their sexuality and fulfil the desire of their heart and body. But the Christian moral tradition has never taken the view that just because we have certain desires we ought to give them expression."

The media-savvy bishop was avoiding the media yesterday, pleading a packed schedule. How ever, he agreed to talk to the Guardian. "I don't think education can be free of values and moral priorities," he said. "The next question is: are gay and straight relations morally equivalent? It seems to me, there's a social and moral priority to a family based on marriage. That's establishing a priority over the gay relationship.

"A civilised society must respect those of different viewpoints. I readily admit that there is homophobia and that homosexuals have been oppressed in our society, but not everybody who says there is a moral and social priority to family life is necessarily homophobic."

In his article, the bishop called for schoolchildren to be introduced to gay and heterosexual people who had chosen celibacy. He said he respected homosexual people, but made clear that in his view the Bible and "natural theology" were authoritatively against it, said that gay sex was more threatening to health than straight sex, pointed out that if everyone was gay there wouldn't be any children, and even delved into anatomical detail. "Physiologically," he observed, "the genitalia are manifestly designed for the opposite, and not the same, gender."

One of the ironies of Bishop Jones's position is that, as a religious education teacher himself before Clause 28 was introduced, he was able to - and did - discuss homosexuality in the classroom without fear of prosecution. He told the Guardian yesterday that Clause 28 didn't prevent this, but the advice of education authority lawyers to teachers tempted to test the vaguely worded clause by mentioning the H-word has consistently been: don't risk it.

Bishop Jones sounded genuinely upset that anyone could interpret his position as hostile to homosexuals. His responses were seeded with the irreproachable vocabulary of tolerance: "respect different viewpoints", "both sides of the argument", "taking the debate beyond sloganising and name-calling".

Yet what is a gay man or lesbian to make of this paragraph from his article, which seems to suggest homosexuality is bad because it provokes people who don't like it? "The consequences of homosexual acts provide a field day for prejudice," he writes. "Do they lead to stable relationships? Is there something about male homosexuality that renders it inimical to faithful relationships? While some gays point to committed partnerships, others see the pressure to keep to one partner as an oppression by the heterosexual community."

Asked about this, the bishop said: "As I read gay literature, these are the questions that are being asked." Many in the church see the bishop as saying openly what the current Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr George Carey - another evangelical and a fan of Bishop Jones - only thinks, although Dr Carey also ventured a shot across the bows of the government's intention to abolish Clause 28 this week.

Yet the bishop may believe he can somehow align himself with scourges of liberal sexuality such as Cardinal Winning and not be seen as anti-gay. Asked several times, he refused to say how he thought gays and lesbians came to be that way, if it was not a perfectly natural state.

"The causes of homosexuality are not known to us. There are several theories about it and I would not rush into judgment."

Bishop Jones's stance came as little surprise to those within the church struggling to keep liberal voices heard. "I think we must simply face the fact that a substantial proportion of the church, not just church leaders but what I would call grassroots Christians, have inherited centuries of theology and alleged Biblical teaching which says that the practice of homosexuality is a sin," said Paul Oestreicher, canon resident at Coventry Cathedral.

Another liberal said the bishop had at least shown some integrity in jeopardising his chances of advancement by speaking out. "Full marks to him for speaking his mind," he said. "It's just a shame now we know what's in it."

fields.headline: How it all adds up
fields.standfirst: Tricky calculations of Labour's voting systemThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The selection of Labour's candidate for London mayor is conducted through an electoral college.
fields.body:
The selection of Labour's candidate for London mayor is conducted through an electoral college.

Unions and affiliated organisations get one-third of the college; MPs, MEPs, and candidates for the Greater London Authority one-third; party members one-third.

If no candidate wins a majority, the third-placed candidate drops out. The second choice votes of their supporters are then redistributed between the top two candidates.

Unions

The Labour party is refusing to break down the precise share of the vote of each unions and affiliate organisation - partly because, as it points out, if an organisation decides to abstain it would affect every other organisation's share of the electoral college. But information gathered by the Guardian suggests that, assuming each union and affiliate votes, the proportions are as follows:

AEEU (3.86% of the electoral college) Not balloting. Chosen by general committee delegates. Certain to vote Dobson

Aslef Dc No 1 (0.07%) Having a "consultation" with members. Leadership recommending Livingstone and certain to vote that way

CWU (3.9%) Balloting. Likely to vote Livingstone

Co-Op party (3.976%) Not balloting. Likely to vote Dobson.

CRS London (3.9%) Balloting. Likely to vote Livingstone

CWS south-east (0.386%) Balloting. Likely to vote Livingstone

Local Co-Ops (0.07%) Balloting. Likely to vote Livingstone

FBU (0.5%) Holding workplace ballot. Certain to vote Livingstone

GMB (4.3%). Balloting. Will cast its vote proportionately for each candidate - "split voting" - based on result of ballot. Possible outcome: Livingstone 66%, Dobson 25%, Jackson 9%.

GPMU (0.8%). Balloting. Likely to vote Livingstone.

 Iron and Steel Trades Confederation (0.07%) Not balloted. Decision made by executive. Voting Dobson

Labour Students (0.07%) Not yet decided how to choose. Likely to vote Dobson

MSF Eastern Region (0.07%) Balloting. Likely to vote Livingstone

Poale Zion (0.15%) Balloting. Uncertain. Possibly Dobson

Socialist Health Association (0.07%) Balloting. Likely to vote Livingstone

TGWU (3.86%) Has balloted. Voting Livingstone.

Fabian Society (0.15%) Balloting. Uncertain - possibly Dobson - but in any case split voting. Possible outcome: Dobson 50%, Livingstone 40%, Jackson 10%

TSSA (0.386) Balloting. Uncertain but probably voting Livingstone

UCATT (0.386) Not balloting. Voting Livingstone

Unison (6%) Balloting. Likely to vote Livingstone

Usdaw (0.386%) Balloting. Uncertain - executive recommending Dobson - but in any case split voting. Possible outcome: Dobson 47%, Livingstone 47%, Jackson 6%

On this basis, the share of vote as a percentage of the electoral college is:

Dobson Guaranteed/likely: 8.126%, plus estimated 1.331% from split voting Equals: around 9.557%

Livingstone

Guaranteed/likely: 20.398%, plus estimated 3.641% from split voting Equals: around 24.039%

Jackson

Guaranteed/likely: 0%, plus estimated 0.387% from split voting Equals: around 0.387%

MPs

Eligible: 57 London region MPs, 4 MEPs, and 14 Greater London Authority candidates

Frank Dobson has the support of 43 MPs, 4 MEPs and 14 GLA candidates

Ken Livingstone has the support of 10 MPs

Glenda Jackson has the support of 2 MPs

One MP is abstaining. One MP is undeclared but is believed to be voting for Dobson

On this basis, the share of vote as a percentage of the electoral college is:

Dobson 27.927%

Livingstone 4.504%

Jackson 0.9%

Unions plus MPs

Dobson estimated 37.484%

Livingstone estimated 28.543%

Jackson estimated 1.287%

Dobson needs a further 12.517% of the electoral college from the members section

Livingstone needs a further 21.458% of the electoral college from the members section

Party members

Labour says about 49,000 Labour party members will be eligible to vote (those who joined on or before September 24, 1999 and have paid up at the time the ballot papers go out). Ballot papers go out tomorrow and have to be returned by February 16. There is likely to be at least a three-day delay to allow votes to be counted, and to give time for representations to be made. Unity Balloting Services is conducting the ballot. The result is likely to be announced on February 21

According to Guardian calculations:

Dobson needs 37.371% of members' votes to win the electoral college outright

Livingstone needs 64.374% of members' votes to win the electoral college outright

If either MP fails to win that number of votes, transfers from Glenda Jackson will decide the election

fields.headline: A third of party voters may give Dobson victory
fields.standfirst: Analysis shows contest is still wide openThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson could win Labour's nomination for mayor outright with just over a third of the votes of rank-and-file members. That potential outcome is one of several possibilities to emerge from a Guardian analysis of the electoral college by which Labour will select its candidate.
fields.body:

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Sally Farmiloe. The former mistress of Jeffrey Archer revealed that she has had a book offer to reveal her version of the three-year affair with the former Tory mayoral candidate. It follows on the heels of news that Archer's spokesman Stephan Shakespeare is planning a book in his boss's defence.

Bad day

Rambling MPs. Workington Labour MP Dale Campbell-Savours sneaked on his colleagues, complaining that he and others became "distinctly agitated" when they "ramble on" while asking questions. Commons speaker Betty Boothroyd has complained about this before and agreed it was getting worse.

Launch of the day

Chas & Dave's London mayor manifesto. The boys included pledges to install bars at tube stations, hot drinks machines at bus stops, legalisation of busking, the banning of piped music in pubs, cheap football admission and best of all - an annual street party on the Queen's birthday.

Confession of day

Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman Matthew Taylor. He became the latest politician to admit smoking cannabis as a student. He called the experience "absolutely disgusting'.

Today

Questions to Scottish secretary John Reid. Remaining stages of the electronic communications bill.

webTitle: Sink or swim? Ministers on defensive over forces cutbacks

fields.headline: Sink or swim? Ministers on defensive over forces cutbacks
fields.trailText: The government last night was coming under growing pressure to reshape or increase defence spending after a string of reports claiming that RAF jets were unable to fly, the navy lacked sufficient fuel, and all three armed forces were short of equipment and skilled personnel.
fields.body:
The government last night was coming under growing pressure to reshape or increase defence spending after a string of reports claiming that RAF jets were unable to fly, the navy lacked sufficient fuel, and all three armed forces were short of equipment and skilled personnel.

A leaked letter from Admiral Sir John Brigstocke, the former second sea lord, who warned that the forces' medical service was in a "parlous" state, added to the discomfiture of defence ministers who faced a barrage of hostile questions from opposition MPs in the Commons.

Sir John said 1,500 sailors in the navy were unfit for duty because of cuts.

"There are soldiers and sailors whose careers are being held back, and in some cases who are being invalided out of the navy because they cannot get treatment", he claimed.

The ministry of defence conceded that a naval exercise had been cancelled and 14 ships will be withdrawn from another but said the idea ships were being ordered to slow down to save fuel was "rubbish".

It also pointed out that the aircraft carrier, Illustrious, left, had just set off on an exercise with nine other ships to the Gulf.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, and his two junior ministers, John Spellar and Peter Kilfoyle, shrugged off criticism of their handling of the defence budget, totalling about £22bn.

They pointed out that the previous Tory administration had cut it by far more than Labour.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, said last night: "There is so much evidence from so many sources about financial difficulties that there is much more in this than ministers are willing to acknowledge".

Senior budget holders in all three branches of the armed forces, he added, were saying in private that the need to meet their targets was crippling.

webTitle: Victory in Livingstone's grasp, survey shows

fields.headline: Victory in Livingstone's grasp, survey shows
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone appears to have a remarkable victory within his grasp in the race to become Labour's candidate for mayor of London, according to a detailed analysis by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone appears to have a remarkable victory within his grasp in the race to become Labour's candidate for mayor of London, according to a detailed analysis by the Guardian.

On the eve of ballot papers being posted to party members, calculations suggest that the leftwing MP for Brent East could win the party's nomination outright with 64.3% of the votes of activists. This is very close to the 66% suggested by Mr Livingstone's own surveys and within a whisker of previous polling indications.

According to the survey of votes being cast by the electoral college, his main challenger, Frank Dobson, needs around 37.3% to win outright on first-choice votes.

The electoral college is divided up into thirds: one third for the members; one third for MPs and representatives; and one share for unions and affiliated organisations.

The third candidate, Glenda Jackson, has become increasingly hostile to Millbank and Downing Street through the selection process. "There is no doubt that Ken will win, but we think he will win on the first ballot," her spokesman said, predicting that Mr Dobson would come third in the constituency section.

If neither Mr Livingstone nor Mr Dobson achieves an overall majority, the second preference votes given to Ms Jackson will decide the election.

A poll at the weekend suggested that Mr Livingstone had the support of 63% of Labour party members, with Mr Dobson on 25% and Ms Jackson 12%. That scenario would also appear to tilt the election Mr Livingstone's way.

Certainly Ms Jackson's camp think so. "Our analysis is that between two-thirds and three-quarters of her second preferences will go to Ken," a spokesman for Ms Jackson said last night - a view shared by the Livingstone camp.

Ms Jackson will decide who to name as her second choice after a ballot in her Hampstead constituency. "Glenda has become a catalyst for party loyalists who have become disillusioned with the way that the selection is being conducted and the excesses of some of the elements in New Labour," said her spokesman.

But the temptation to cast Ms Jackson in the role of "kingmaker" was resisted by sceptics last night. Her decision on her second preference vote may have a small bearing on her supporters, but will not be the only factor playing on their minds. Many will not be prepared to vote for Mr Liv ingstone as their second choice, and others will not put down a second choice at all.

Her only other supporter in the MPs' section of the electoral college, Stephen Pound, said he would vote for Mr Dobson as his second choice.

He said he would even rethink his vote for Ms Jackson if she accepted an offer, made at the weekend, to become Mr Livingstone's deputy. "I genuinely think he would be a disaster for London," he said.

Mr Dobson's camp believe about a fifth of party members are still undecided. They say their telephone canvassing returns from 20,000 members show that 40% are committed to voting for Mr Livingstone, 35% for their candidate, and 5% for Ms Jackson.

"We're confident that Frank will win," a spokesman for the former health secretary said last night. "It will be very close but we are confident. We are getting more and more don't knows who say they are voting for Frank."

Mr Dobson has the benefit of a massive guaranteed majority in the MPs and representatives section, which will deliver an estimated 28% of the total electoral college to him. And there are a few anecdotal signs that some activist support among the 49,000 or so eligible members is moving towards him. But the arithmetic suggests that the usual Westminster refrain - "the machine always wins" - might just be upset.

fields.headline: Henry Eriksson
fields.trailText: Henry Eriksson, who has died aged 79, was the only Swedish runner ever to win a gold medal in the blue-riband 1500 metres. He triumphed in one of the biggest shocks of the 1948 London Olympiad, where the pundits had expected him to merely help his team-mate, Lennart Strand, to victory.
fields.body:
Henry Eriksson, who has died aged 79, was the only Swedish runner ever to win a gold medal in the blue-riband 1500 metres. He triumphed in one of the biggest shocks of the 1948 London Olympiad, where the pundits had expected him to merely help his team-mate, Lennart Strand, to victory.

Because of the second world war, the revival of the Olympic games was conspicuous for a shortage of top-class middle-distance runners, with both Great Britain and the United States completely stripped of their quality competitors in the field. Only the Swedes, who had remained neutral during the war, had progressed.

At the London games, they were expected to sweep all three medals, thanks to Strand, Eriksson and Gosta Bergkvist. Indeed, almost everybody predicted Strand would have little trouble winning the gold. In the 1946 European championships at Oslo, Eriksson had been Strand's only opposition as he claimed the silver medal. He had never beaten Strand, yet a strange sense of confidence enveloped him on the eve of the final. "Before falling asleep, I ran the race again and again in my thoughts, and won it regularly," he said afterwards.

On the great day Eriksson ate an omelette, meatballs and potatoes 4 hours before the race, then went back to sleep. Wembley's cinder track was badly soaked, and the race was run in a downpour. Strand predicted that no one would finish in under 3min 50sec, but the Frenchman Marcel Hansenne, the fastest of the non-Swedes, started off at a very fast pace, and was leading at 800 metres, with Eriksson in lane two to avoid trouble.

The three Swedes went into the lead on the third lap, and the tall, 165lb Eriksson led by two metres at 1,000 metres. But, splashing through the puddles, Strand closed the gap, and looked as if he would handle Eriksson easily.

With 300 metres remaining, only Strand was still with Eriksson. His team-mate followed him round the final bend and into the home straight, where Strand pulled alongside him, ready for the kill. For 20 metres the two ran shoulder-to-shoulder. Then, with 40 metres to go, the script deviated from its normal course and Eriksson became the first to break the tape in 3min 49.8sec.

From then until his death, he was distinguished from the many other Erikssons in Sweden by the nickname "Guld-Eriksson" - Gold Eriksson. He ran for one more season before retiring to become a fireman in the town of Gefle.

fields.headline: Lucas Hoving
fields.standfirst: Vibrant champion of modern dance
fields.trailText: Lucas Hoving, who has died aged 87, was an influential and distinctive modern dancer, choreographer and teacher. His artistic associations ranged from Kurt Jooss, Martha Graham and Agnes de Mille to such contemporary artists as Meredith Monk, Pina Bausch and Eiko and Koma.
fields.body:
Lucas Hoving, who has died aged 87, was an influential and distinctive modern dancer, choreographer and teacher. His dramatically intense performances began in his native Holland in the 1930s and continued into the 1990s, reaching an extended climax during his 14-year association with the José Limón Dance Company. His artistic associations ranged from Kurt Jooss, Martha Graham and Agnes de Mille to such contemporary artists as Meredith Monk, Pina Bausch and Eiko and Koma.

Born Lukas Hovinga in Groningen, he was attracted to drama and dance at an early age, beginning his studies with the German dancer Yvonne Georgi. He later studied in England with Jooss at Dartington Hall, and joined the Jooss Ballet. When the company disbanded during the second world war, Hoving moved to New York and performed with the Martha Graham Dance Company.

After three years of military service in the Dutch army, he worked briefly with Agnes de Mille on a film project in London, then emigrated to the United States in 1946, where de Mille offered him Broadway assignments in Beggar's Holiday and Bloomer Girl. She would later describe Hoving as "a staunch artist, a man of distinction and taste, and a noteworthy choreographer."

Hoving first encountered José Limón as a fellow student in Nenette Charisse's ballet classes in New York. The year was 1949, and this fateful encounter was to determine the course of Hov ing's life and career. Work soon commenced on his first Limón dance, La Malinche, to be followed by perhaps the most famous role of his career, Iago, in The Moor's Pavane, Limón's classic distillation of Othello.

It was Hoving's commanding presence that created the necessary foil to Limón's tragic Moor, and the dramatic tension between these two powerful performers set the tone for the entire dance. Limón singled out Hoving's performances as "vibrant, passionate, incandescent."

Two other enduring and iconic roles in Limón dances were created by Hoving in the next few years: the Christ figure, known as the Leader, in The Traitor (1954), and the White Man in The Emperor Jones (1956). Again, Hoving and Limón were antagonist and protagonist, setting off theatrical sparks that thrilled audiences and critics alike. Hoving also featured in dances by Limón and Doris Humphrey when the Limón Company made its London debut at Sadler's Wells in 1957.

By the time he left the Limón Company in 1963 to devote himself fulltime to his own choreography, Hoving had originated roles in 14 Limón works, as well as six premieres by Humphrey.

With his wife, the fellow Limón dancer Lavina Nielsen, he had also co-choreographed several works performed under the auspices of the Limón Company in the 1950s. He created and directed works for his own group, Lucas Hoving and Dance Company, until 1971. All told, he choreo graphed about 24 ballets, including his best-known and most widely-performed dance, Icarus. In addition to the Limón and Hoving troupes, companies that performed Hoving's works included the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theatre, Mexico City's Ballet de Bellas Artes, the Jooss Ballet, Israel's Bat Dor and Les Grands Ballets Canadiens.

As a teacher of dance composition, Hoving was on the faculties of the Juilliard School and the American Dance Festival, mentoring generations of young dancers. In 1971, he was invited to become director of the Rotterdam Dance Academy, where he remained until 1978. Renowned for his individualised and meticulous coaching, he returned to the Limón Company as an artistic adviser in the late 1970s. Once asked to describe his methods for coaxing performances from dancers, he explained: "You go from the inside out."

Hoving resumed performing in 1984, creating an autobiographical dance monologue called Growing Up In Public, in collaboration with Remy Charlip. He continued to perform this demanding and compelling solo into the early 1990s, and was also seen as the physician in Meredith Monk's film, Book Of Days (1988).

Hoving's wife died in 1988. His only survivor is a niece, Mieneke Faber, in the Netherlands.

fields.headline: John W R Taylor
fields.trailText: John WR Taylor, who has died aged 77, was for many years editor of Jane's All the World's Aircraft, and master of a parallel art to Kremlinology, the deduction of the performance of Soviet military equipment from blurred photographs.
fields.body:
John WR Taylor, who has died aged 77, was for many years editor of Jane's All the World's Aircraft, and master of a parallel art to Kremlinology, the deduction of the performance of Soviet military equipment from blurred photographs.

Thus in 1961, when western intelligence was fascinated by early glimpses of a new Soviet bomber, the Tupolev Tu-22, many analysts estimated it could reach a speed of mach 2.5 - 2 times the speed of sound. But Taylor, after noting the shape of the aircraft's engine intakes, put the maximum at no more than mach 1.4, which proved much closer to the truth. In 1983, he analysed the MiG-29 fighter, whose agility was the cause of much anxiety among Nato's war-gamers; seven years later, when a team from Jane's was able to check his suggested measurements during a visit to the Soviet Union, they were found to be accurate to within an inch.

Respect for the accuracy of the technical reference book he edited for 30 years tran scended political enmities. Cold war notwithstanding, Soviet authorities supplied Jane's with information. Such was Taylor's reputation that Argentina even provided details of its aircraft during the Falklands war in 1982.

He later specialised in rectifying design defects. In 1955, he joined Jane's as an editorial assistant, becoming editor four years later. Until the late 1960s, he had almost no editorial support, but such was his love of the job one cannot imagine him complaining.

The journalist and naval enthusiast, Fred T Jane, had established his catalogue of the world's fighting ships in 1898, following it 11 years later with what became Jane's All the World's Aircraft. His publications became universally accepted authorities and the response to any query about the performance of a ship or an aircraft became: "Look it up in Jane's."

Taylor contributed to that reputation for three decades of the cold war, reluctantly retiring as editor emeritus in 1989, just as the curtain obscuring the Soviet bloc's secretive technology began to lift. He was a deeply religious man and is survived by his wife Doris, a son and a daughter.

fields.headline: Norman Blamey
fields.standfirst: Painter who caught the spirit of Christian worship on canvas
fields.trailText: The painter Norman Blamey, who has died aged 85, was a consummate draughtsman specialising in contemplative domestic subjects and episodes from the liturgy of the Anglo-Catholic church.
fields.body:
The painter Norman Blamey, who has died aged 85, was a consummate draughtsman specialising in contemplative domestic subjects and episodes from the liturgy of the Anglo-Catholic church. His paintings have only recently been given due recognition, for both his subject and his style were unusual, but he brought to his work an intensity that expresses not only the spirituality of high Anglicans but of all who value ritual.

The setting of Blamey's religious pieces was usually Old St Pancras church, London, where he worshipped all his life, and his pictures sometimes show him as an assistant in the ritual.

In his work, the sense of the spiritual was translated into a crystalline geometry, worked out with a fascination for mathematics worthy of the early renaissance masters. Space is telescoped, manipulated to form tightly-knit compositions in which the human figure creates powerful patterns. The depictions of ritual make telling use of this device, with lines of repeated cassocks and copes building up magnificent counterpoint, while dull tertiary colours, with greys and whites, supply a rich, subdued harmony.

Blamey was born in St Pancras, the only son of a manufacturing chemist and his wife. His first studies in art were at the Regent Street polytechnic, and he went on to teach there himself. He first showed at the Royal Academy in 1938, and continued to do so for 50 years. His war was spent with the army in Egypt, Palestine and the Lebanon, where, in hospital, he made a series of fine drawings of his fellow patients.

After the war, Blamey returned to the Regent Street poly, and, in the 1950s, began to produce the sequence of paintings of ritual that forms the backbone of his output. In 1956, he was commissioned to decorate the apse of St Luke's church, Leagrave, Luton; the result, the imposing Christ In His Glory, reflects Byzantine stylisation.

In it, Blamey adopted pronounced distortions of the figure in this decade, devices which he was later to regard as unsatisfactory, mere lip-service to modernism. They are often, nevertheless, powerfully effective, and betray the great impression made on him by Stanley Spencer's work, notably at Burghclere chapel, and by van Eyck's Ghent Altarpiece, which he first saw as a 19-year-old in 1933.

Another mural, for the Lutheran church of St Andrew, Ruislip Manor, was executed in 1964. Blamey's career saw the steady elimination of mannerisms, until, by the 1970s, he was painting with a realistic directness strengthened by his unfailing dedication to pictorial geometry. This is embodied in the paint itself, applied with a palette knife, often guided by the straight edge of masking tape. (He is said to have used the same palette knife for some 40 years.)

These technical comments apply as much to Blamey's domestic subjects as to his ecclesiastical ones. Enclosed spaces are defined and amplified by mirrors, reflections rendered ambiguous by the presence of the miscellanea of an artist's collecting - fossils, flints, small sculptures, postcards. His models are usually Margaret, his wife, whom he married in 1948, and his son, Stephen.

Blamey was a very private man, and his pictures reflect that. When he painted himself, it was usually to make a pictorial statement about the artist's viewpoint, rather than to record a personality in which he took interest. But he painted fine portraits, too, the work of an incisive and humane mind.

He continued to teach at Chelsea School of Art, where he was senior lecturer from 1963-79, and, after his election as a royal academician in 1975, as visiting lecturer at the RA schools. Blamey believed passionately in the traditional disciplines of the draughtsman, but was too retiring to pronounce on them, and taught by example, making drawings himself to show how he thought things should be done.

His gentle reserve and modesty were commensurate with the concentrated power of his painting. He did not expect success; indeed when he was invited to a celebratory lunch on his 80th birthday at the Tate Gallery, which had acquired several of his works, he remarked: "I had to keep pinching myself to make sure I wasn't dreaming." A one-man show was organised by Lynda Checketts for the Norwich Gallery in 1992; it travelled to the Victoria Art Gallery, Bath, and the Fine Art Society, London. He was awarded the OBE in 1998.

Blamey's wife died in 1989. He is survived by his son.

webTitle: Anger at growing textbook bias in India

fields.headline: Anger at growing textbook bias in India
fields.standfirst: Critics accuse ruling party of teaching intolerance
fields.trailText: Concerns that India's increasingly nationalistic government is rewriting school text books to depict Muslims and Christians as alien villains will be made public this week as history teachers launch a protest against a creeping bias in their curriculum.
fields.body:
Concerns that India's increasingly nationalistic government is rewriting school text books to depict Muslims and Christians as alien villains will be made public this week as history teachers launch a protest against a creeping bias in their curriculum.

Extraordinary examples of non-Hindus being described as foreigners, attempts to defend the caste system and even a laudatory account of Hitler are being pointed to as examples of an attempt by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), the dominant partner of the ruling coalition, to influence attitudes by stealth.

For example, an examination question in the state of Uttar Pradesh asked: "If it takes four Savaks [Hindu religious workers] to demolish one mosque, how many does it take to demolish 20?"

Teesta Setalvad, a prominent campaigner against the changes, said: "Prejudice is being bred among children. Some texts heighten irrational thinking and glorify upper-caste Hindu symbols. The [education] minister has made his intentions amply clear."

She fears not only that deliberate distortions are being written into textbooks by pro-BJP academics, but that at a time of heightened tensions with Pakistan, the country's schools are fuelling intolerance.

Although the central government does not have control of the curriculum, India's state governments do, and changes in textbooks are arising in all states, but especially those with a BJP majority.

Murli Manohar Joshi, India's human resources development minister with responsibility for education, has called for textbooks to be overhauled and "enthused with national spirit", and has attacked "myopic western mind-sets" in the Indian education system.

In Rajasthan, a recently issued text on conversation points and essay writing techniques depicts a pupil discussing India's nuclear weapons tests with his teacher.

It reads: "Student: 'Master, what has India achieved by doing the nuclear tests? Was it a right step?' Teacher: 'Undoubtedly it was correct, India has achieved a huge success.'

"Student: 'What success? Economic sanctions have been slapped on.' Teacher: 'Economic sanctions do not matter. The country should first become powerful. Only the powerful are listened to. Now we can talk about world peace aggressively.'"

A social studies text in Gujerat describes the country's caste system as an ideal way of building society's social and economic structure, and says of lower-caste people: "Of course, their ignorance, illiteracy and blind faith are to be blamed for lack of progress because they still fail to realise the importance of education in life."

Most astonishingly of all, though, are the other textbooks in Gujerat that extol the superiority of the Aryan race. A new history and civics textbook claims: "Aryans were the most illustrious race in history. They were a tall, fair complexioned, good-looking and cultured people."

Another of the state's social studies books finds no space for describing Hitler's persecution of the Jews but claims "he instilled the spirit of adventure in the common people".

About 60 teachers - a tiny proportion of a quiescent profession in India - are calling on the government to abandon the indoctrination. "The demand to rewrite textbooks should come from academics, not politicians," the academic philosopher M P Rege said. "In the interest of academic impartiality, political moves of this kind must be resisted."

 For further information, try the Indian Department of education

webTitle: Anwar trial restarts as Mahathir's critics pay price dissent

fields.headline: Anwar trial restarts as Mahathir's critics pay price dissent
fields.trailText: The sodomy trial of the deposed Malaysian deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim reconvenes today under the renewed glare of international scrutiny after the arrest this month for sedition of Anwar 's lawyer, Karpal Singh.
fields.body:
The sodomy trial of the deposed Malaysian deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim reconvenes today under the renewed glare of international scrutiny after the arrest this month for sedition of Anwar 's lawyer, Karpal Singh.

Because Mr Karpal was arrested, along with four other prominent opposition figures, for allegedly "uttering seditious words" while defending Anwar in court, doubt has been cast on whether the defence team's leading lawyer will be able, or still inclined, to continue to defend his client.

But Mr Karpal, who was released on £1,875 bail this week and is awaiting a date with Malaysia's high court to defend himself, remains defiant.

"I don't think my arrest will affect [the defence's strategy] in any way," said Mr Karpal, the former deputy chairman of the opposition Democratic Action Party's (DAP).

"It will be business as usual, we will carry on. Why should I change my strategy?"

Those who know him best, such as DAP chairman Lim Kit Siang, do not doubt Mr Karpal's commitment to provide the best defence possible.

"I am fully confident that Karpal will not allow the charges hanging over him to affect his advocacy," Mr Lim said. "But the charges he is facing are very serious ones and if he is convicted and sentenced, he could be disenfranchised - unable to stand for election - and he could be disbarred, which would be a great loss to Malaysian constitutional defence."

Nevertheless, Anwar is ex pected to launch more pointed attacks against the prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, and other ruling party members for their alleged conspiracy to discredit him. Meanwhile, his defence team says it will produce witnesses who can account for Anwar's whereabouts on the night six years ago when he allegedly sodomised his former family driver.

For Dr Mahathir's United Malays National Organisation (Umno), the trial reconvenes amid growing discontent within Umno's ranks and elsewhere.

Its party faithful, who were demoralised by the results of November's general elections despite the Barisan Nasional coalition's retention of a two-thirds parliamentary majority, saw a depletion of their Malay powerbase, particularly in the north, their traditional heartland.

There is also growing concern within the ruling coalition about the potential for renewed street protests to coincide with the resumption of the trial today.

Despite the prime minister's calls to stop complaining, Umno members are increasingly voicing their displeasure with "Malaysian politics as usual".

A particular bone of contention is the Umno supreme council's decision to reject calls for the party's top two positions to be elected from within the party in May.

"I believe Umno has to make changes which are tailored along the aspirations of the people, especially the Malays, who spoke through the ballot box," the former finance minister, Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah, told the pro-government New Straits Times on Friday.

But the high price of public dissent continues to censor Dr Mahatir's critics; publishing an editorial questioning the Umno council's decision appears to have cost the New Straits Times editor, Kadir Jasin, his job last week.

Mr Kadir stepped down on January 18 under pressure from senior politicians who were angry that he had the audacity to question the council's decision. His demise surprised even his critics.

"We all know that the mainstream media is at the beck and call of the authority of the day," Mr Lim said from Kuala Lumpur.

"But [Mr Kadir] had to step down not because he was disloyal, not because he did not try to serve the [Barisan Nasional] - even to the extent of dishing out false truths - but because he was not seen as a totally compliant creature."

The mainstream media and Mr Kadir appear to be in a no-win situation; reviled by the Malay on the street for being an unbending government mouthpiece, while criticised by the ruling coalition for inadequately portraying its campaign message in November.

After another two months in isolation at a high-security prison outside Kuala Lumpur where he was only allowed a family visit every three weeks, Anwar is reported to be in good spirits.

"He is a fighter," said Sankara Nair, a member of his defence team.

The trial is expected to last two more months.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Pastor faces war crimes trial
fields.body:
Pastor faces war crimes trial

A Rwandan church minister accused of participating in genocide lost a supreme court appeal yesterday, freeing US officials to hand him over to a UN war crimes tribunal.

Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, 75, was pastor of a Seventh Day Adventist church in Rwanda when in 1994 Hutu extremists killed more than 500,000 people. AP, Washington.

Flood victims saved by UN

The UN refugee agency yesterday airlifted thousands of Angolan refugees to safety from rising flood waters in western Zambia.

The UN said at least 3,500 refugees were to be flown from the Kalabo region, on the Zambezi river, to the provincial capital, Mongu. AP, Lusaka, Zambia.

Bank opens in Kosovo

The Micro Enterprise bank, funded largely by the German and Dutch governments, began operating in Kosovo yesterday.

And in a separate sign of a return to normality, 137 legal officials were sworn in yesterday to tackle a backlog of thousands of criminal cases in Kosovo. AP, Pristina, Yugoslavia.

Seven killed in delta violence

At least seven people died in a clash between riot police and youths in the delta of southern Nigeria.

Violence flared following the death of the Evwreni village chief, who had been the centre of controversy over a payment from the Shell oil firm. AP, Lagos.

webTitle: Submarines to dredge lake for Nazi gold

fields.headline: Submarines to dredge lake for Nazi gold
fields.standfirst: Witness recalls seeing Third Reich treasure being dumped into water from lorries
fields.trailText: An American-Israeli submarine mission is preparing to dredge an Austrian lake said to have been the dumping ground for Nazi gold and Third Reich archives, including information relating to secret Swiss bank accounts.
fields.body:
An American-Israeli submarine mission is preparing to dredge an Austrian lake said to have been the dumping ground for Nazi gold and Third Reich archives, including information relating to secret Swiss bank accounts.

Lake Toplitz in Upper Austria has been the subject of rumours for more than half a century, fuelled mainly by witness accounts that senior Nazis deposited their booty in its 100 metre depths in the final days of the war.

The lake was part of the so-called Alpine fortress in the Salzkammergut region, which was designated the last Nazi stronghold. Hitler picked the area and is believed to have ordered the Third Reich's treasures to be transported there.

Millions of pounds have been pumped into recovery projects over the years, with varying degrees of success. In the 1960s several Austrian government diving missions uncovered hundreds of thousands of pound notes with which the Nazis planned to flood the money markets to destabilise Britain's economy.

Now an Israeli journalist whose family was murdered by the Nazis has persuaded the company that located the Titanic to bring its expertise to bear. Yaron Svoray says he will not be satisfied that there is nothing there until every inch of the lake has been scoured.

"I lost my family in a concentration camp," he said. "I am hopeful that files and records which pertain to them might be recovered."

Next month computer-controlled mini submarines and divers from the Maryland-based company, Oceaneering, will begin a 10-week search. The initial stage will involve compiling the first complete picture of the lake, using video cameras and sonar equipment. If anything is spotted, a salvage operation will begin.

"We will either be discovering history or establishing that this is a legend," said Ridgely Albaugh, one of the project leaders from Oceaneering, which was also involved in recovering the remains of the exploded Challenger space shutle from the Atlantic in 1986.

The team was reluctant to reveal details, but their interest is believed to focus on Nazi secret service files which could lead to the identification of Swiss and other foreign bank accounts where German capital was transferred towards the end of the war.

It is unclear why the project is being carried out in the middle of winter. The lake is covered by a 30cm thick ice sheet.

"We hope that as well as possible treasures, documents will finally come to light, particularly name lists or registers, which indicate where the Third Reich chiefs hid their money," said the Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal, who is supporting the mission.

But some experts remain sceptical. Markus Koeberl, an historian and author of the book Toplitzsee, said: "I think anything the lake was hiding has already been discovered."

Mr Koeberl said the mystification around the lake stemmed from the fact that it was closed to the public from 1943. The Nazis then used it to test underwater weaponry.

But Patrick Loftus, who was a prisoner of war and slave labourer at Lake Toplitz, said: "I saw with my own eyes how the Nazis drove to the edge of the lake and threw boxes of treasure into the water."

Lake Toplitz in Upper Austria has been the subject of rumours for more than half a century, fuelled mainly by witness accounts that senior Nazis deposited their booty in its 100 metre depths in the final days of the war. The lake was part of the so-called Alpine fortress in the Salzkammergut region, which was designated the last Nazi stronghold. Hitler picked the area and is believed to have ordered the Third Reich's treasures to be transported there. Millions of pounds have been pumped into recovery projects over the years, with varying degrees of success. In the 1960s several Austrian government diving missions uncovered hundreds of thousands of pound notes with which the Nazis planned to flood the money markets to destabilise Britain's economy. Now an Israeli journalist whose family was murdered by the Nazis has persuaded the company that located the Titanic to bring its expertise to bear. Yaron Svoray says he will not be satisfied that there is nothing there until every inch of the lake has been scoured. "I lost my family in a concentration camp," he said. "I am hopeful that files and records which pertain to them might be recovered." Next month computer-controlled mini submarines and divers from the Maryland-based company, Oceaneering, will begin a 10-week search. The initial stage will involve compiling the first complete picture of the lake, using video cameras and sonar equipment. If anything is spotted, a salvage operation will begin. "We will either be discovering history or establishing that this is a legend," said Ridgely Albaugh, one of the project leaders from Oceaneering, which was also involved in recovering the remains of the exploded Challenger space shutle from the Atlantic in 1986. The team was reluctant to reveal details, but their interest is believed to focus on Nazi secret service files which could lead to the identification of Swiss and other foreign bank accounts where German capital was transferred towards the end of the war. It is unclear why the project is being carried out in the middle of winter. The lake is covered by a 30cm thick ice sheet. "We hope that as well as possible treasures, documents will finally come to light, particularly name lists or registers, which indicate where the Third Reich chiefs hid their money," said the Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal, who is supporting the mission.
