webTitle: Israeli head of state may cut duties

fields.headline: Israeli head of state may cut duties
fields.trailText: President Ezer Weizman of Israel, under police investigation for possible tax evasion and failure to report cash gifts, may curtail some of his activities, such as granting pardons and swearing in judges, his lawyer said yesterday.
fields.body:
President Ezer Weizman of Israel, under police investigation for possible tax evasion and failure to report cash gifts, may curtail some of his activities, such as granting pardons and swearing in judges, his lawyer said yesterday.

This would be the president's first concession to calls from a growing number of politicians that he resign or take leave of absence.

Mr Weizman, 75, seemed unaware of the suggestion made by his lawyer, Yaakov Weinroth. Asked yesterday whether he would continue to carry out all his duties, Mr Weizman said: "Yes, absolutely."

He was due to swear in a group of judges next week.

Mr Weizman has admitted accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars from a French millionaire, Edouard Sarousi, between 1988 and 1993, when he became president, but has denied that this was a bribe.

In a national TV broadcast on Sunday, Mr Weizman said he would not step down. He said he consulted his lawyer before taking the money and was told all his acts were legal.

He also rejected a call from the justice minister, Yossi Beilin, to take leave of absence during the investigation.

Mr Beilin said yesterday that if Mr Weizman would not go on holiday he should at least cease some functions. "Two very important and delicate functions, swearing in judges and granting clemency, should not be fulfilled by the president himself in the near future, while he is under investigation by the police," he said.

Mr Weinroth said that if the applications for clemency or the appointment of new judges were not urgent, Mr Weizman might agree to postpone them. "It is possible that we will accept some limitation _ We will reach an agreement with the minister of justice on this matter, because he has a point," Mr Weinroth told Israel army radio.

Signalling business as usual, Mr Weizman attended a ceremony in parliament yesterday to mark the 51st anniversary of its founding, defying threats from rightwing opposition members to heckle him or walk out.

webTitle: Victims celebrate death of South African paedophile

fields.headline: Victims celebrate death of South African paedophile
fields.trailText: Victims of one of South Africa's worst serial sex offenders have published several dozen obituary notices celebrating the death of the former teacher and Scoutmaster who spent 20 years abusing boys.
fields.body:
Victims of one of South Africa's worst serial sex offenders have published several dozen obituary notices celebrating the death of the former teacher and Scoutmaster who spent 20 years abusing boys.

Almost every day since Douglas Drysdale died a fortnight ago, newspapers have printed adverts denouncing the headmaster and former assistant area commissioner of the Scouts in KwaZulu-Natal.

They include obituary notices that said: "God has a special place for your kind" and "I pray you are where you belong, far away from us." Others said: "Forgive and forget they say; I'm afraid I can't" and "Douglas Drysdale is dead. South Africa is a safer place."

The police said they had received "numerous complaints" against Mr Drysdale over the years, but had been unable to prosecute him because the parents of the abused children were reluctant to expose them to the further trauma of a court case.

Mr Drysdale, who was 48 when he died of a heart attack, was forced to resign from the Scouts in 1980 after a 12-year-old boy told another Scoutmaster he had been raped. But he was readmitted to the organisation nine years later and continued to abuse children.

The Scouts have defended the decision to allow Mr Drysdale back in, saying that "no case was ever proven" against him. But the police say they warned the organisation that he was "a very high priority" case and should have been kept away from children as a precautionary measure.

Mr Drysdale finally resigned from the Scouts two years ago after he was linked to another paedophile and Scoutmaster, Ken White, who shot himself when one of his victims went to the police.

When child protection officers raided Mr White's home they found large amounts of pornographic photos of Scouts. His house was rigged with hidden cameras including one in the toilet, and the tapes were sold to other child pornographers. The police also found incriminating pictures of Mr Drysdale.

webTitle: Rivals for Croat leadership spurn Tudjman legacy

fields.headline: Rivals for Croat leadership spurn Tudjman legacy
fields.trailText: Croatians voted yesterday to elect a successor to President Franjo Tudjman, who died of cancer last December.
fields.body:
Croatians voted yesterday to elect a successor to President Franjo Tudjman, who died of cancer last December.

After a landslide victory of the centre-left opposition in this month's parliamentary election, which changed the political landscape of Croatia almost overnight, the three main presidential candidates have appeared to compete to distance themselves from Tudjman's legacy.

Stipe Mesic, backed by four centre parties but not seen as primarily a party figure, led the opinion polls. He has made a virtue of accessibility, campaigning under the slogan: "Coffee with the president".

Briefly president of Yugoslavia on the eve of its disintegration, he was in Tudjman's party, the HDZ, as speaker of parliament before resigning in 1994 over what he saw as Tudjman's "meddling" in Bosnia.

"Where Tudjman was authoritarian, Mesic is a great communicator; where Tudjman was conflict-prone, Mesic is a conflict solver," said Vesna Pusic, of Mr Mesic's Croatian People's party.

In the Croatian capital Zagreb voters were divided. An architect, Hrvoje Devideja, 60, said Croatia needed continuity with the Tudjman years. Another man backed Mate Granic, the outgoing foreign minister and HDZ candidate.

Long the favourite, Mr Granic's campaign has suffered because of deep divisions in the party after its defeat in the parliamentary elections. He resigned all his party posts during this campaign, and made clear he would rather stand as an independent.

A group of three young women, first-time voters, said they had voted for Drazen Budisa, riding on the momentum of the victory of his Social Liberals and the Social Democrats three weeks ago.

Mr Mesic is the only Croat to have given evidence for the prosecution at the war crimes tribunal in the Hague. Married to a Serb, he has campaigned openly for all suspects to be surrendered to the tribunal.

The issue is likely to emerge as the most sensitive for the new government later this year, when indictments are expected for alleged war crimes against Serbs in Croatia during the 1995 military operations to retake areas occupied by Serb forces in 1991.

Mr Budisa, 51, served four years in prison after the nationalist "Croation spring" of 1971. He was routed by Tudjman in the presidential election of 1992, but has staged a comeback.

Like Mr Mesic, he supports a reduction in the powers of the presidency to strengthen government.

"If President Tudjman marked the era of the creation of the Croatian state, then a new generation of politicians - and I'm one of them - has to mark the other era: to make Croatia a country of human rights, democratic freedoms, liberal democracy, attractive to the world and integrated into the Euro-Atlantic community," he told the Guardian.

A runoff between the top two candidates on February 7 is almost certain.

fields.headline: French strike over healthcare crisis
fields.trailText: A strike by surgeons and anaesthetists in French hospitals yesterday began a week of protests over poor financing and staffing in the first nationwide industrial action over healthcare since 1974.
fields.body:
A strike by surgeons and anaesthetists in French hospitals yesterday began a week of protests over poor financing and staffing in the first nationwide industrial action over healthcare since 1974.

The demonstrations will reach a climax on Friday when unions are due to stage a mass rally for all medical and administrative staff. Chaos during the recent flu epidemic has reinforced their complaints.

The 845,000 staff in state hospitals, clinics and retirement homes claim that at least 10% more personnel are needed to provide proper care and that the whole system is critically underfunded despite promises by Lionel Jospin's Socialist-led government.

The secretary general of the Communist-led CGT, Jean-Luc Gibelin, said the protests were the result of frustration at all levels. "There have been sporadic protests for months and the staff are now fed up," he said.

Some of the problems are blamed on a cost-cutting programme in which many small hospitals are being closed down while services are concentrated on big centres.

Some of France's biggest hospitals jumped the gun by starting separate industrial action several days ago. Among the protesters were the 2,800 staff at the Henri Mondor hospital in the Paris suburb of Créteil.

"We just can't give proper care any more," said a senior nurse on the picket line at the entrance, where beds taken from the wards were piled up to prevent new admissions.

Tempers frayed long before the flu epidemic, which has affected about 3m people. The crisis worsened a shortage of beds - patients had to sleep in corridors on stretchers or were sent hundreds of miles for treatment.

fields.headline:
No: 1563
 The Fergie
fields.trailText: Appearance: Irrepressibly chirpy little character with permanent grin and unkempt ginger wool hair.
fields.body:
Appearance: Irrepressibly chirpy little character with permanent grin and unkempt ginger wool hair.

Occupation: None as such. But there are endless possibilities for commercial exploitation.

Age: A couple of months.

But surely the woman has two children?! Ah, you're thinking of the other Fergie. The Fergie, or Little Red if one is being proper about titles, is a rag doll based on the Duchess of York's now copyrighted cartoon image. The toy, carrying her name on its label, has been on sale in the US since before Christmas, and will be hitting the shops in Britain and Europe later this year.

Easy mistake to make. Indeed, and the Duchess is herself aware of their uncanny similarities. "The doll is me," she says. "She is a loveable little character who represents hope in a troubled world."

I feel inspired already. What else does she represent? A hefty boost to the Duchess's bank balance, if you believe what you hear. Spin-offs from the doll are expected to be worth at least £1m in book and TV deals.

Still, brings a tear to your eye, all that hope for our troubled world. Indeed: a third of the proceeds do go to the Duchess's charity Chances for Children. And unlike most toys, which represent only a cynical attempt to make as much money as possible, Little Red comes with a message.

Which is? That "no matter how terrible life becomes, you have to keep on going".

And how is Little Red to avoid a terrible life? Well, weight gain should not be a problem. And without toes to suck, she is probably safe from public humiliation. But toybox marriages with Action Man are possibly not destined for success.

The Duchess says: "Everyone remembers Budgie the Helicopter, my last children's book, but I hope this is even more successful, because it really is about me."

Don't say: "Budgie the what?"

Do say: "Suddenly the world looks so much less troubled."

Not to be confused with: The Diana, Princess of Wales doll; Prince Andrew's golf course at Windsor castle; the Furby.

fields.headline: Wanna buy a giant wok?
fields.standfirst: The gizmos don't work, the body's boring and the show's naff. But enough carping. In the spirit of constructive co-operation, our crack team of dome recycling engineers suggest 101 uses for a £750m tent
fields.trailText: 1 Rename it the St Paul's Dome and hope wealthy Americans will buy it in the way they bought London Bridge thinking it was Tower Bridge.
fields.body:
1 Rename it the St Paul's Dome and hope wealthy Americans will buy it in the way they bought London Bridge thinking it was Tower Bridge.

2 Turn it on its side and stick to the side of a stone-clad council house in Greenwich where it can be used as a satellite dish, picking up no fewer than 758m satellite channels, including a fuzzy Channel 5.

3 Turn it over, create a giant wok and make the world's biggest stir-fry.

4 Turn it over and donate it to a steel band so they can do a cover version of the 1812 Overture.

5 Turn it over to create the world's largest skateboarding park.

6 Fill it with all the newspaper articles entitled "Whither the Dome".

7 Cover it with yellow paint and say: "From the moon this looks exactly like a fried egg."

8 Ask Lord Falconer to eat it with two rashers of bacon and some dodgy-looking mushrooms.

9 Cover it with green paint, look at it from the moon and bemoan the fact that the new Wembley pitch isn't flat.

10 Cover it with brown paint, look at it from the moon and say it's an offshoot of the Great Wall of China.

11 Send it to China and say a 14th-century British explorer stole it from the Great Wall and we're frightfully sorry.

12 Convert it into a home for very large Teletubbies.

13 Offer it to Cherie Blair as shoe storage, to avoid embarrassment next time she moves house.

14 Convert it into a home for the Queen (having first sold Buckingham Palace to a Japanese bank for £758m).

15 Sell it to a Japanese bank for £758m (offering the Queen and Buckingham Palace as part of the deal).

16 Make it the permanent home of the Museum of the Third Way, a unique multimedia experience which will be accessible, multicultural and available to all.

17 Stand in a darkened Jubilee Line tunnel just outside it for five hours and indulge in 1999 new year's eve nostalgia.

18 Convert it into a vast mausoleum for Baroness Thatcher.

19 Convert it into the Augusto Pinochet home for retired dictators.

20 Build a highly congested circular road inside and market it as the M25 experience.

21 Build a highly congested straight road inside and market as the M1 experience.

22 Build a toll road inside and say: "How ridiculous, isn't that what they have in France?"

23 Sell £10 tickets to gullible, excitable foreign visitors saying that if they press their ears to the PVC carapace and concentrate they can hear Lord Falconer laughing.

24 Sell £100 tickets to coolly rational, discerning people, to hear the clanging sound of Lord Falconer's head being banged against the PVC carapace.

25 Comb a long nylon strand of hair over the top as a tribute to Robert Robinson.

26 Comb two long nylon strands of hair over the top of it as a tribute to Sir Bobby Charlton.

27 Cut off the nylon strands, give it a ridiculous voice and an unhealthy obsession with the euro and dedicate it to William Hague.

28 Turn it into a camp for Conservative party dissidents. (It won't be big enough, but it can be enlarged.)

29 Store Peter Mandelson's ego in it. (Ditto.)

30 Turn it into a meeting place for supporters of Frank Dobson. (On second thoughts, they can meet in the telephone box at the end of the road while "Red" Ken and his band of Trotskyite revolutionary scum party in the Dome [it won't be big enough, etc etc].)

31 Stand on top of it, look out at London and say: "It's so nice not to have to look at that bloody Dome."

32 Stand on top of it, look out at London and say: "It's so nice to be able to see the London Eye not turning."

33 Stand on top of it, look out at London and say: "Who are those three loonies in the telephone box?"

34 Drag it to Highgrove under cover of darkness, wait till daylight, then knock on Prince Charles's door saying: "Suprise!"

35 Remove the exhibits and turn it into an open prison.

36 Leave the exhibits in and turn it into a grade-one prison.

37 Leave the exhibits in it, ask Lord Falconer to do guided tours and turn it into a torture chamber (Mick Hucknall concerts to be played on a continuous loop).

38 Take Pinochet to the middle of it, ask Mick to sing something affecting in Spanish, and say: "Welcome back to Chile, General." Then throw away the keys.

39 Plant trees and create the world's largest arboretum.

40 Plant Michael Heseltine.

41 Move the hallowed turf from Lord's and use the Dome for the new and highly popular two-day Test matches.

42 Move the less hallowed turf from the Valley and invite Charlton (no, not Sir Bobby) to play there.

43 Build a stage, sell tickets at £70, offer champagne at a tenner a glass, and put on opera productions under the banner "opera for all".

44 Attach a rubber band to two of the spires and use as a catapult for firing low-cost short-haul no-fuel Ryanair flights to Dublin.

45 Attach rocket boosters and use it for Britain's first attempt on Mars (Messrs Blair, Mandelson and Falconer to man the first mission - good luck guys, do call when you get there).

46 Cover it with pink latex and enter for the Turner Prize under the title "Buttock".

47 Give Rachel Whiteread £758m to build an adjoining dome, cover that in pink latex too, and enter for the Turner Prize under the title "Buttocks".

48 Give Rachel Whiteread an unlimited budget to build a succession of domes, cover them in pink latex and enter for the Turner Prize under the title "the Cabinet".

49 Re-open it as the National Pedants Centre for all the people who are still insisting that the new millennium does not begin until 2001.

50 Turn it into a permanent studio for ITN's late-night news (don't bother with cameras - nobody's watching anyway).

51 Place it in the middle of the road as a particularly effective traffic-calming device.

52 Place an electric bulb in it and pass it off as an exciting new Conran Shop lamp design.

53 Sell it to Terence Conran so that he can continue to meet the overwhelming public demand for restaurants as big as domes.

54 Place a tea cosy on top and let it stand for five millennia.

55 Pleat the surface and use as a giant lemon squeezer.

56 Cover it with fuzzy yellow material, place large white petals around the outside and pass it off as a very big daisy.

57 Attach a wooden handle and use it as the world's biggest sink plunger.

58 Use as a bunker for the Welsh Assembly in the event of nuclear war. (Supply attacking power with precise grid reference.)

59 Cover it with a rich clay-based soil and say that it is now the Loam.

60 Place Andrew Motion under the Loam.

61 Stand outside it, and listen to Andrew Motion screaming to be let out.

62 Ask him why his screams don't scan.

63 Stand next to it and say: "Really it should be about six inches long with a row of plastic teeth, allowing one to tidy one's hair. Oh, I thought you said the Millennium Comb."

64 Use it to incarcerate whoever supplied that appalling line.

65 Convert it into an office for the new London mayor. (Supply attacking power with precise grid reference.)

66 Lease it to Andrew Lloyd Webber for his new musical, Dogs.

67 Lease it to Richard Rogers and suggest he stages a new version of the Sound of Music. (Incidentally, whatever happened to Oscar Hammersmith?)

68 Offer it to Greg Dyke as an appropriately 21st-century office for the DG. (Tell him if he sets off now, he should get in by 2003.)

69 Insert Alastair Campbell, lock door, throw away key.

70 Construct two giant ears, place on either side, and say it is the London Ears.

71 Construct two giant ears, place on either side, and call it the Prince of Wales.

72 Construct two giant ears, enter for the Turner Prize and call it "Buttocks" (it's sure to win).

73 Announce that it is, in fact, a gigantic steel globe buried in the ground, emerging at a fraction of a millimetre a day and by 2008 it will be hovering in the air.

74 Turn it into a spaceship able to move faster than the speed of light and travel through time (that couldn't possibly cost more than the original £758m).

75 Twin it with the Millennium Dome on the planet Jupiter (this will mean building a replica on the planet Jupiter.)

76 Shout "warp factor seven, Lieutenant Uhura" and hope for the best.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an article, The gender benders, page 6 (Women), G2, yesterday, we said the author of The Towers of Trebizond was Rose Tremain. We meant to say Rose Macaulay. In the same piece the writer suggested circumstances in which we might not have had the Book of Revelations. We do not have it. We have the Book of Revelation (an error resistant to correction).
fields.body:
In an article, The gender benders, page 6 (Women), G2, yesterday, we said the author of The Towers of Trebizond was Rose Tremain. We meant to say Rose Macaulay. In the same piece the writer suggested circumstances in which we might not have had the Book of Revelations. We do not have it. We have the Book of Revelation (an error resistant to correction).

In the Guide, page 33, January 22, we remarked how tough it must have been for Gwen John "growing up in the shadow of her father, the illustrious but rather overrated painter Augustus John". She had no such problem. Augustus John (1878-1961) was not her father, he was her younger brother. (Gwen John: 1876-1939).

In a column, The e-words take over, page 15, yesterday, we inadvertently referred to Professor Kevin Warwick of Reading University as Richard. Apologies.

Spanish department, from our report on page 7, yesterday, about the planned return of General Pinochet to Chile, which was, we said, "daily anticipated as imminente in the Chilean press". The Spanish for imminent is inminente.

We referred to Sebastian Coe as a Tory backbencher in a report headed Hague delivers knockout blow - on the judo mat, page 7, yesterday. Mr Coe is no longer an MP.

In a letter, page 21, January 22, referring to a correction, the writer spoke of Alma Mahler and her second husband, Franz Werfel. He was her third husband (m1 Gustav Mahler 1902; m2 Walter Gropius 1915; m3 Franz Werfel 1929; source Britannica ).

Homophone corner, from page 13, Forbidden love outlives apartheid, yesterday, in which we spoke of someone who "could be readmitted to her old school [provided] that she did not become a border".

fields.headline: Chemical bond
fields.standfirst: BTP goes to Swiss as City looks away
fields.trailText: Leading British chemical group BTP yesterday paid the price for City disdain for the sector when it was snapped up for £1.1bn by Clariant, based at Muttenz in Switzerland.
fields.body:
Leading British chemical group BTP yesterday paid the price for City disdain for the sector when it was snapped up for £1.1bn by Clariant, based at Muttenz in Switzerland.

The deal will increase pressure on Britain's dwindling band of survivors in the industry .

The latest consolidation came at 600p per share, which gives BTP shareholders a 73% premium to the closing price last Tuesday, before the takeover plan emerged.

The low values given to chemical companies on the London stock market, encouraged by fierce competition and pressure on costs, has led to a host of companies, including Albright & Wilson, Allied Colloids and Courtaulds, to lose their independence.

Another sector giant, BOC, is also poised to fall into French hands, leaving Laporte, a trimmed-down ICI, and a few others, including Burmah Castrol, which has been in the sights of BP Amoco.

Clariant's chief operating officer, Reinhardt Handte, said BTP, which is ranked third among the world's specialty chemicals producers, was a perfect fit for its growth strategy.

"BTP has a nice technological platform and a nice platform of customer relationships. Our primary focus is to integrate it, make use of platforms and develop it internally," he said.

The future of the Manchester head office is in doubt, however, and redundancies will number "in the low hundreds".

BTP's chief executive, Steve Hannam, will join Clariant's board.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: After four days of selling, the FTSE 100 index closed in positive territory yesterday, led by some impressive performances among media and telecom stocks.
fields.body:
After four days of selling, the FTSE 100 index closed in positive territory yesterday, led by some impressive performances among media and telecom stocks.

But dealers warned that prices in London still looked vulnerable ahead of a string of economic news releases due later in the week.

Bouncing from its lowest levels since November 5, the benchmark index finished the session 33.5 points higher at 6,379.8, clawing back just over 10% of the 312 points shed last week as fears over interest rate rises on both sides of the Atlantic gripped investors.

But it was another "merger Monday" and leading shares responded with a 2% surge early in the day - led by consolidation hopes in the media sector following a tie-up between music group EMI and Time Warner. The advance fizzled when early forecasts of a strong day for American stocks proved unfounded.

Having jumped more than 100 points at the opening, the Dow Jones industrial average had reversed to show a 50-point deficit by the time London trading closed.

Cable & Wireless , the day's top performer, rose nearly 14% as investors applauded news that the company was considering a tie-up between its Hong Kong Telecom arm and Singapore Telecom.

In a frenzy of dealings, more than 28m shares in C&W changed hands, even though the company insisted the talks were at too early a stage to make any predictions as to their outcome. Market insiders have been whispering about such a move for months and many are now convinced that its days as an independent company are numbered.

EMI and pay-TV operator BSkyB were also in strong demand as merger hopes shunted the whole sector higher in the wake of EMI's merger with Time Warner.

In the retail sector, there was a surge of interest in Boots on talk that US drugs store chain Walgreen might be considering a bid. Shares in the British group ended the day at 544p, up 54p.

Yet trading volume across the market as a whole looked disappointing, with just over 1.3bn shares changing hands.

Lower down the corporate scale, Sports & Media , a sports marketing and advertising firm, jumped 24p to 112p on news that it had received a takeover approach. The suitor was not named.

An investment trust with the enticing name of Foresight Technology soared from 210p to 335p after news that one of the unquoted companies in which it has an investment is planning to float. The statement was forced on the company after a rise in the share price.

Software group Systems Integrated Research soared as high as 96p at one stage after it said it had signed a deal with Freeserve to distribute its Learning System software on Freeserve's education online channel. The shares finally settled at 79p, 13p higher on the day.

Another software firm, Lynx Financial Systems , was also in heavy demand after news that it is to provide the core systems for Halifax's new internet banking venture - codenamed Greenfield.co. The shares ended 32p higher at 220p.

webTitle: Responsible, loved, but can it stay free?

fields.headline: Responsible, loved, but can it stay free?
fields.standfirst: News Analysis -  Protesters gather to defend Ben and Jerry's ice-cream and its community ethos
fields.trailText: As many as 2,000 people are expected to attend rallies throughout the US today to try to protect an ice-cream company. Their slogan is "multi-flavours not multi-nationals".
fields.body:
As many as 2,000 people are expected to attend rallies throughout the US today to try to protect an ice-cream company. Their slogan is "multi-flavours not multi-nationals".

The coalition to save Ben & Jerry's Homemade formed last month, when the company announced that it had received several takeover approaches from multinational competitors. The anger felt in Vermont, the homeland of the firm's founders, Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, and the beneficiary of many of their socially responsible projects, soon spread across the US.

Campaigners expect thousands to congregate at its shops in nine US cities at midday today. Wavy Gravy and Patch Adams, idols of the Woodstock generation, will attend two rallies. More than 8,000 people have clicked on savethecownow.com, one of several campaign websites, and organisers hope the protest will spread to shops in Canada, Europe and Japan.

Many groups opposed to the power of big business are united in the fight to keep Ben & Jerry's independent. The organisers suggest it is a continuation of last November's battle in Seattle, when anti-trade demonstrators disrupted the meeting of the World Trade Organisation.

Judy Wicks, owner of the White Dog Cafe in Philadelphia, does not even sell Ben & Jerry's. But she has become a campaign organiser through her involvement with the National Organisation of Progressive Businesses. "We can't just remain silent about what's going on at Ben & Jerry's," she said. "They have been leaders in the community and many people have felt influenced by them." A takeover by a large corporation would be "another nail in the coffin for locally-based businesses".

At the heart of the campaign is the fear that huge, faceless multinationals have too much power. "There are a lot of concerned people including some of the folk who were involved with Seattle," Ms Wicks said.

The fight is not just an ideological one, however. Many campaigners feel that they have much to lose if anticipated bids from corporate food giants Unilever, Diageo or Dreyer's materialise.

Common Ground, a charity that provides shelter for the homeless in New York, is one of several groups supported by Ben & Jerry's. The ice-cream firm waives its franchise fee for the charity, which operates a "scoop shop" near Times Square that provides training and work experience for formerly homeless people. Toby Sherman at Common Ground said: "A takeover would be particularly challenging for us. We can't be certain that the level of support we receive would stay intact."

As well as donating almost 8% of group pre-tax profits to charities each year, Ben & Jerry's also espouses popular environmental causes. It uses locally-produced, hormone-free milk to create its ice-cream. Mr Cohen has toured the US supporting a stakeholder-friendly approach to business, saying firms must be socially as well as fiscally responsible.

His company, which made $209m in sales last year, is famous for being started by the two former schoolfriends back in 1978 after they had taken a $5 correspondence course in making ice-cream. Their folksy approach has, however, not always pleased investors, who fear that the company is not fulfilling its global potential. Share performance has been particularly lacklustre since the company fought off a takeover attempt by Dreyer's in 1998.

Several reports have suggested that Unilever, the world's largest ice-cream marketer, has offered more than $30 a share, valuing the company at about $225m. Before the announcement that it had received several indications of interest the company was trading at less than $21.

Investors have been irked by a state law passed last year, with the perceived backing of Ben & Jerry's, which allows a company's directors to reject a takeover bid if they deem it to be not in the best interests of employees, suppliers, and the economy of the state. Analysts believe that a bidding firm could be annoyed enough to attempt to use the law itself if the company scuppers the latest takeover attempts. Although the two co-founders control 45% of the voting shares, the company's board of directors may have to prove that shareholders have not suffered a significant financial disadvantage if they reject a deal.

Such legal issues have encouraged the company to put up the shutters to all enquiries. It refuses to say when or if the board is discussing the bids.

But in a letter to a US newspaper several weeks ago, Mr Cohen sought to explain why his all-inclusive approach represented a "wise business investment". In it, he wrote: "I love capitalism as much as anyone else who reads the Wall Street Journal. But I also believe that a company has a responsibility to three different stakeholders: the customers, the employees and owners of the company, and the community at large."

The next few weeks could define whether those three different stakeholders can continue to be given equal weight, or whether the demands of an increasingly global market will win out against a company which buys all its milk from local cows.

Many groups opposed to the power of big business are united in the fight to keep Ben & Jerry's independent. The organisers suggest it is a continuation of last November's battle in Seattle, when anti-trade demonstrators disrupted the meeting of the World Trade Organisation. Judy Wicks, owner of the White Dog Cafe in Philadelphia, does not even sell Ben & Jerry's. But she has become a campaign organiser through her involvement with the National Organisation of Progressive Businesses. "We can't just remain silent about what's going on at Ben & Jerry's," she said. "They have been leaders in the community and many people have felt influenced by them." A takeover by a large corporation would be "another nail in the coffin for locally-based businesses". At the heart of the campaign is the fear that huge, faceless multinationals have too much power. "There are a lot of concerned people including some of the folk who were involved with Seattle," Ms Wicks said. The fight is not just an ideological one, however. Many campaigners feel that they have much to lose if anticipated bids from corporate food giants Unilever, Diageo or Dreyer's materialise. Common Ground, a charity that provides shelter for the homeless in New York, is one of several groups supported by Ben & Jerry's. The ice-cream firm waives its franchise fee for the charity, which operates a "scoop shop" near Times Square that provides training and work experience for formerly homeless people. Toby Sherman at Common Ground said: "A takeover would be particularly challenging for us. We can't be certain that the level of support we receive would stay intact." As well as donating almost 8% of group pre-tax profits to charities each year, Ben & Jerry's also espouses popular environmental causes. It uses locally-produced, hormone-free milk to create its ice-cream. Mr Cohen has toured the US supporting a stakeholder-friendly approach to business, saying firms must be socially as well as fiscally responsible. His company, which made $209m in sales last year, is famous for being started by the two former schoolfriends back in 1978 after they had taken a $5 correspondence course in making ice-cream. Their folksy approach has, however, not always pleased investors, who fear that the company is not fulfilling its global potential. Share performance has been particularly lacklustre since the company fought off a takeover attempt by Dreyer's in 1998. Several reports have suggested that Unilever, the world's largest ice-cream marketer, has offered more than $30 a share, valuing the company at about $225m. Before the announcement that it had received several indications of interest the company was trading at less than $21. Investors have been irked by a state law passed last year, with the perceived backing of Ben & Jerry's, which allows a company's directors to reject a takeover bid if they deem it to be not in the best interests of employees, suppliers, and the economy of the state. Analysts believe that a bidding firm could be annoyed enough to attempt to use the law itself if the company scuppers the latest takeover attempts. Although the two co-founders control 45% of the voting shares, the company's board of directors may have to prove that shareholders have not suffered a significant financial disadvantage if they reject a deal. Such legal issues have encouraged the company to put up the shutters to all enquiries. It refuses to say when or if the board is discussing the bids. But in a letter to a US newspaper several weeks ago, Mr Cohen sought to explain why his all-inclusive approach represented a "wise business investment". In it, he wrote: "I love capitalism as much as anyone else who reads the Wall Street Journal. But I also believe that a company has a responsibility to three different stakeholders: the customers, the employees and owners of the company, and the community at large." The next few weeks could define whether those three different stakeholders can continue to be given equal weight, or whether the demands of an increasingly global market will win out against a company which buys all its milk from local cows.

webTitle: Secretive Versailles office at centre of inquiry

fields.headline: Secretive Versailles office at centre of inquiry
fields.trailText: Investigations at collapsed trading group Versailles are focusing on the secretive "client services department" that kept confidential details of clients amid concerns that several customers either did not exist or had ceased to trade, sources said yesterday.
fields.body:
Investigations at collapsed trading group Versailles are focusing on the secretive "client services department" that kept confidential details of clients amid concerns that several customers either did not exist or had ceased to trade, sources said yesterday.

The department's separate sets of accounts make it very difficult to trace back from the published figures to work out which deals generated Versailles's explosive profits growth during the 1990s.

The group's profits grew from nothing to more than £16m annually in less than a decade.

It has become clear that the company's client services department - which had its own computer and operated quite separately from the Versailles accounts department - has become pivotal to the inquiry.

The serious fraud office and receivers PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) are investigating Versailles.

Records from the client services department may be critical in establishing the group's relationship with the private offshore interests that funded Versailles during its early days and are thought to have supported it during more recent difficulties.

This funding group is thought to be registered in the British Virgin Islands, and the SFO is believed to be planning to request information from the authorities in the Caribbean tax haven.

Group members are not registered as shareholders and there are suggestions that the money they circulated through Versailles may have been disguised as fees from clients. The accounts of the client services department should help to show whether these suggestions are true or false.

Meanwhile, the London office of Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, yesterday denied ever having employed anyone named "A. Mills," the self-styled company analyst who early last year wrote to national newspapers urging them to write in glowing terms of Carl Cushnie, founder of Versailles, describing him as a "truly self-made man".

At least one newspaper did quote the "analyst", but Goldman said it had never followed the shares of Versailles, which - even in its heyday last year - was too small to attract the bank's attention.

The true identity, and motivation, of "A Mills" remains a mystery.

Versailles's accounts first came under scrutiny last year, when the department of trade and industry was investigating the collapse of a Versailles client. It was unhappy with aspects of Versailles's book-keeping and prompted the company to order an independent audit.

An audit took place and was unable to give the books a clean bill of health. Versailles asked on December 8 for its shares to be suspended, and PwC began an inquiry on behalf of the group's banks.

Last week, PwC reported that: "There would appear to have been complex, extensive and long-running fraud inside the company of a very material nature."

As a result, the group was put into receivership.

webTitle: There'll be £13,500 along for bus drivers employees

fields.headline: There'll be £13,500 along for bus drivers employees
fields.trailText: More than 1,900 Merseyside bus drivers are to receive £13,500 payouts as part of a £34.7m agreed bid for their company, MTL Services. Arriva, the bus and coach group, is bidding for MTL as part of an increasing consolidation of the rail and bus sectors.
fields.body:
More than 1,900 Merseyside bus drivers are to receive £13,500 payouts as part of a £34.7m agreed bid for their company, MTL Services. Arriva, the bus and coach group, is bidding for MTL as part of an increasing consolidation of the rail and bus sectors.

MTL was formed in 1992 when drivers and other employees of the state-owned Merseyside Passenger Trans port Executive bought the business for £1. Arriva's chief executive, Bob Davies, said the deal offered MTL's shareholders "value and certainty at a time of instability for the company".

MTL risks losing its Merseyside and northern England rail franchises as a result of the shadow strategic rail authority's plans for reorganisation of rail services this year. The franchises were due to expire in 2004. Northern Spirit, the MTL franchise serving northern England, is making large losses, even though some of its services are supported by local passenger transport executives. MTL also owns a specialist transport cleaning services business.

It is the second time MTL employees have benefited from their original decision to buy the business. They awarded themselves a bumper payout averaging £22,000 in December 1998.

MTL's bus operations made an operating profit last year of £11.8m on a turnover of £68.6m. The firm is now 80% owned by its staff.

Arriva, the country's largest passenger transport operator, is offering 40p a share for MTL. It also plans to take on MTL's net debt of £50m.

It already has irrevocable acceptances from MTL directors and certain other shareholders in respect of 19.8% of the MTL shares. Mr Davies said the deal was a new step in Arriva's strategy of developing its position as one of Europe's leading passenger services groups.

webTitle: Tories demand inquiry into Robinson grants

fields.headline: Tories demand inquiry into Robinson grants
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson is being pressed to investigate grants of £6.9m which were made to a plant in Derry owned by TransTec, the collapsed engineering company founded by Geoffrey Robinson, the former trade minister.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson is being pressed to investigate grants of £6.9m which were made to a plant in Derry owned by TransTec, the collapsed engineering company founded by Geoffrey Robinson, the former trade minister.

The call for an inquiry, from Conservatives at Westminster, follows allegations at the weekend that Mr Robinson encouraged his then accountant to inflate claims for department of trade and industry grants in the late 1980s. TransTec's former accountant, Max Ayriss, said the inflated claims related to research grants totalling about £400,000.

Senior Conservative sources said last night that they would be asking the government to investigate the £7m grant to build the Campsie motor parts plant in Northern Ireland. The funds were paid over several years beginning in 1994.

Although the Tories have no proof of any wrongdoing, they argue that all government subsidies to TransTec should be re-examined in the light of Mr Ayriss's evidence.

Mr Mandelson, who previously resigned from the cabinet over an undisclosed loan from Mr Robinson, may refer calls for an inquiry to the devolved government in Belfast, which is due to assume responsibility for industrial subsidies.

The Tories also pressed the government over the links between Robert Maxwell and Mr Robinson. Conservative MP Angela Browning said last night that the whole question of the Maxwell engineering group Hollis - of which Mr Robinson was chairman for a period - should be reopened.

Mrs Browning said that given two Hollis businesses - Lock and PSS - were transferred to Central & Sherwood just before the 1991 deal with TransTec, an understanding of Hollis was "pivotal" to an understanding of TransTec.

A confidential DTI inquiry into Hollis was terminated by trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers a few days before Christmas. The decision was criticised when TransTec went into receivership almost immediately afterwards.

Mrs Browning added that it may prove necessary to examine Mr Robinson's entire 30-year history of dealings with the public sector.

This would include his time as chief executive of the ill-fated Meriden motorcycle cooperative in the late 1970s and his period as an executive with state-owned mergers promoter the Industrial Reorganisation Corporation in the late 1960s.

webTitle: Shareholder disquiet forces Procter & Gamble out of talks

fields.headline: Shareholder disquiet forces Procter & Gamble out of talks
fields.trailText: Procter & Gamble yesterday bowed to shareholders who demanded an end to takeover talks with two rival drugs companies that might have created a rival to the new giant GlaxoSmithkline.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble yesterday bowed to shareholders who demanded an end to takeover talks with two rival drugs companies that might have created a rival to the new giant GlaxoSmithkline.

Shares in P&G rose sharply on the announcement that it had terminated discussions with Warner-Lambert and American Home Products. The increase failed, however, to erase a decline of almost 20% since the talks were first reported last week.

Durk Jager, P&G's chairman and chief executive, blamed a series of news reports for his decision to call off talks which started three weeks ago.

"We have concluded that leaks and resulting speculation on a possible transaction have created an environment in which we cannot continue meaningful discussions," he said.

In a statement that revealed frustration over his failure to convince shareholders of the value of what could have been one of the world's biggest takeovers, Mr Jager said: "We believed Warner-Lambert, American Home Products and P&G could have been a blockbuster combination of technology, marketing and scale capabilities. It would have created substantial shareholder value with minimal up-front dilution."

A company spokesman ad mitted that the shareholder reaction to two takeovers, valued together at about $140bn, had been "a factor" in the decision to call off talks.

The move leaves Warner-Lambert and AHP in awkward positions in an increasingly tortuous bid battle.

Warner-Lambert had been in merger discussions with AHP before Pfizer, a rival drugs group, launched a $78bn hostile bid. Pfizer was rebuffed by Warner-Lambert and AHP, which sought out P&G as a friendly saviour. Warner-Lambert said yesterday that it was continuing to explore its options.

Analysts also expressed some wariness about P&G, where Mr Jager, appointed last year, has taken an unusually aggressive position at a company previously seen as averse to large corporate deals. The group's board was understood to have agreed to continue talks with the drugs companies only last Friday, in spite of the unsupportive reaction from shareholders.

A company spokesman said that the group would continue to look at "strategic acquisitions as a key part of our growth strategy". He refused to comment on reports that it had approached Gillette, the underperforming razor company.

P&G, which sells 300 brands of household goods in 140 countries, is keen to extend its large marketing and distribution network into more products.

fields.headline: Electric light orchestra
fields.standfirst: It hums, it rumbles, it rings:  Adrian Searle tunes into an exploration of sound and vision
fields.trailText: It hums, it rumbles, it rings: Adrian Searle tunes into an exploration of sound and vision
fields.body:
I hear a deep electric moan, a noise with a baleful edge to it. It reminds me of standing under electricity pylons on a damp day. A picture pops into my mind: a stencilled human silhouette contorted against a yellow background, a black lightning zigzag delivering a fatal punch. The kind of enamelled sign they fix to the local electricity substation. "Don't go too close. Danger of death", it says.

Listen more attentively and the noise separates into harmonics, a 50 kilohertz hymn to the mighty electron, whirring at 50,000 cycles a second. It could almost be by Gyorgy Ligeti. Listen hard enough and any noise has music in it. At home, I harmonise with the Hoover. Is this what composers do? The sound here is a carefully modulated mix, derived from the electromagnetic fields generated by a small television, a cooker, a bar heater and a radio, all ranged along the back wall of a cordonned-off, semi-darkened space. The TV picture is a red fizz and the radio is tuned into a gulf between stations. This is an installation by Swedish artist Carl Michael von Hausswolff, in the exhibition Audible Light, at the Museum of Modern Art in Oxford. Audible Light is about sound, light and sculpture, and includes artists from Britain, Scandinavia, Belgium and Germany.

"Hmmnn" goes Hausswolff's work, and I go "Hmm", not knowing what to make of it. The title doesn't help me: Domestic Audiction Suggesting a Constant Flux of Semi-Individuals to be Detected - a sort of boffin's plodding variant on an old Damien Hirst title. The work generates the sort of sound the Aphex Twin might twiddle with on a hardcore ambient recording. Is this future disco? This morning I played all 70 tracks on the CD Trace, a compilation of two-minute sound works, a belatedly released part of last year's Liverpool Biennial. It included a man talking to himself near a spore of bear shit in the Canadian woods, and the sound of Yoko Ono doing something in her bathroom. There was lots of dweebling, and the odd gem. The 71st work on the CD I created myself, using the fast forward button.

An alarm went off as I walked through the next gallery at Moma, competing with the bells already ringing in my head. The source of the clamour, a red industrial alarm, is sealed off behind glass in a tall, shiny aluminium cabinet, a sort of sentry box standing in the middle of the room. A sensor detects you as you move in close and a bell sounds.

The point of this work, surely, is to outwit the alarm. I tried going round the cabinet in a low crouch, like Groucho Marx. I tried sidling to one side, but it caught me out. I almost tried crawling, but this was an interaction too far. Bruce Gilbert and Edward Graham Lewis, authors of Alarm (did it really take two people to think this up?), are members of the experimental punk group Wire. Alarm is terribly slight, an ambient interruption on your way through the gallery. I wanted it to be louder, scarier, more forceful and jarring. I wanted the earth to move for me.

For that, I had to stand in Carsten Nicolai's installation. Pressure waves bent my ears; sound rumbled through my feet and my stomach. Nicolai has inset eight loudspeakers flush with a false grey floor and through them comes a low, juddering oscillation. It is a room filled with thunderous heavy breathing. Two spherical flagons half filled with water sit on the floor, doing their own reciprocal vibration. I guess they are body surrogates. You start to oscillate along with everything else in the room. I reeled out, shudder-ing. Oddly, the work made me want to pee, but I don't think that was the point.

The most accomplished work here is Danish artist Ann Lislegaard's In Another Room. A blank white wall cuts across a darkened space, at an angle. There are speakers inset in each corner of the wall and a powerful halogen lamp blasts a bright smear of light on the middle of it. The light flares on and off, sometimes brighter, sometimes dimmer, faster and slower, in tandem with the sound of someone moving around in an apartment - footsteps on a wooden floor, furniture scraping, an office chair being wheeled from room to room. A female voice describes the action.

The narrator tells us that the man in the room is looking out of his window. He goes through papers on his desk. He listens to his answering machine. He trundles his chair about, he sits and reads. We are told that the light is falling, day turning into night. The voice of the one who watches him sometimes overlays itself, incomprehensibly. The white of the wall where we watch is the same white as the walls in the room we cannot see. I hear the man in the room and I know that it is growing dark outside and that, as he looks through his window, he sees trees and a dog.

I see real light flaring painfully on the wall in front of me, burning on to my retina. I have to turn away after a while, and I see in my mind's eye the room he inhabits. I imagine his furniture and his solitary maunderings. This is, of course, a bit like listening to a radio play, with sound effects, but the work also does something to the physical space of the gallery, turning it into a space for the imaginary.

Finnish artists Tommi Grönlund have wired up the biggest space at Moma, with eight interconnected, wall-mounted parabolic reflectors. They look like satellite dishes. Cables snake into the centre of the room, plugged into two reel-to-reel tape recorders, each with a turning loop of tape. The effect is to turn the space into a whispering gallery. You hear yourself and others in the space relayed back, with a slight but perceptible delay. Stand near one of the reflectors and you hear the mutterings of people on the far side of the space, and their echoing, out-of-synch footfalls.

One annoying character insisted on playing the various ring options on his mobile phone into one of the reflectors while I was there, reminding me of Gerard Hoffnung's anarchic advice to tourists - to try the famous echo in the British Museum reading room. Walking around in the space, you come across pockets of reflected sound and dead spots. The gallery feels enlarged and the reflectors look kind of pretty.

I gather that Ann Veronica Janssens's installation Cyberlight is rather beautiful, too, but someone at the show's opening on Saturday night tampered with it, and it wasn't working on my visit. Janssens filled the Belgian pavilion at last year's Venice Biennale with a thick fog of dry ice, which created a minor stir. This new work is essentially a light installation, the only sound being the whirr of its "cyberlight" projector - included as aural accompaniment to the still images on Moma's PC-friendly Audible Light CD-Rom. It whirrs, helpfully.

 Audible Light is at the Museum of Modern Art, Oxford (01865 722733), till March 19.

The light flares on and off, sometimes brighter, sometimes dimmer, faster and slower, in tandem with the sound of someone moving around in an apartment - footsteps on a wooden floor, furniture scraping, an office chair being wheeled from room to room. A female voice describes the action. The narrator tells us that the man in the room is looking out of his window. He goes through papers on his desk. He listens to his answering machine. He trundles his chair about, he sits and reads. We are told that the light is falling, day turning into night. The voice of the one who watches him sometimes overlays itself, incomprehensibly. The white of the wall where we watch is the same white as the walls in the room we cannot see. I hear the man in the room and I know that it is growing dark outside and that, as he looks through his window, he sees trees and a dog. I see real light flaring painfully on the wall in front of me, burning on to my retina. I have to turn away after a while, and I see in my mind's eye the room he inhabits. I imagine his furniture and his solitary maunderings. This is, of course, a bit like listening to a radio play, with sound effects, but the work also does something to the physical space of the gallery, turning it into a space for the imaginary. Finnish artists Tommi Grönlund have wired up the biggest space at Moma, with eight interconnected, wall-mounted parabolic reflectors. They look like satellite dishes. Cables snake into the centre of the room, plugged into two reel-to-reel tape recorders, each with a turning loop of tape. The effect is to turn the space into a whispering gallery. You hear yourself and others in the space relayed back, with a slight but perceptible delay. Stand near one of the reflectors and you hear the mutterings of people on the far side of the space, and their echoing, out-of-synch footfalls. One annoying character insisted on playing the various ring options on his mobile phone into one of the reflectors while I was there, reminding me of Gerard Hoffnung's anarchic advice to tourists - to try the famous echo in the British Museum reading room. Walking around in the space, you come across pockets of reflected sound and dead spots. The gallery feels enlarged and the reflectors look kind of pretty. I gather that Ann Veronica Janssens's installation Cyberlight is rather beautiful, too, but someone at the show's opening on Saturday night tampered with it, and it wasn't working on my visit. Janssens filled the Belgian pavilion at last year's Venice Biennale with a thick fog of dry ice, which created a minor stir. This new work is essentially a light installation, the only sound being the whirr of its "cyberlight" projector - included as aural accompaniment to the still images on Moma's PC-friendly Audible Light CD-Rom. It whirrs, helpfully.  Audible Light is at the Museum of Modern Art, Oxford (01865 722733), till March 19.

fields.headline: Arizona, NW3
fields.standfirst: What's a sign telling you how to find your way round an American desert doing in a north London car park?  Jonathan Jones reports
fields.trailText: What's a sign telling you how to find your way round an American desert doing in a north London car park? Jonathan Jones reports
fields.body:
London has some of the worst public art in the world. Eduardo Paolozzi's robot heads, a mouldy Oscar Wilde emerging from his crypt... Recently that has started to change. A few adventurous initiatives have led to all kinds of ambitious contemporary artworks appearing in London's streets and squares. Surely the strangest of these is the sign that Adam Chodzko has planted in a shopping centre car park off the Finchley Road, with its double in the Arizona desert.

Public art sounds like it ought to be useful. Adam Chodzko, an artist who works like an anthropologist tapping into collective cultural fantasies in projects such as a reunion for extras in Ken Russell's The Devils and, most famously, The God Lookalike Contest, has translated that ambition into the most down-to-earth and quintessentially urban conversation: the ritual giving of street directions. Giving directions is a transaction that can take place between absolute strangers or intimate friends, and the A-Z is the one text that unites our hugely disparate capital. So there's something cosy and recognisable about the big blue sign topped by a wind chime that stands in the car park of the O2 shopping centre. It offers detailed directions; the only thing is they're about how to find your way around Arizona.

"From Flagstaff, Arizona, take route 89 east, then route 510 east, then 505 north-east for 7 miles until you reach a left turn soon after passing Maroon Crater," advises the sign off Finchley Road. "Half a mile beyond a small well, take a track that leads past little Roden spring_" If you were to fly to Flagstaff and follow the signs, you would eventually find, near a rough cinder track at a point overlooking the Roden Crater and the pink rocks of the Painted Desert, another sign.

There's a photograph in the shopping centre's lobby of the sharp, scorched desert grass and empty sky of Arizona. There, in the middle of nowhere, is a sign giving detailed London street directions. "Heading north out of London along the west side of Regent's Park is the Finchley Road (A41). Follow it through St John's Wood and half a mile beyond to Swiss Cottage..."

If your head is reeling, imagine trying to explain this to the management of O2 who have allowed it to be installed until August as part of North London Link, a community art initiative by Camden Arts Centre. The humour of Chodzko's sign grows when you enter the building. This is a full-on American mall transplanted to north London, a place that claims to transport the shopper to another reality. O2 has fibreglass rocky outcrops all over the place, brown encrustations you can sit on to eat a lunchtime sandwich, a vast central mountain whose parched heights you can reach by escalator and, between the mountains, live fish. Giant tropical fish tanks bubble and shimmer and rare species flutter by. Reflected in the water, the mall is green and wobbly.

When Adam Chodzko was invited to make a public artwork here, you can see he might have blanched: you can't really compete with O2 - it has a surrealism all its own. So his sign is an interpretation of what is already here. The mall is US culture transplanted to London and so, in a very different way, is Chodzko's sign. Because he is not giving Londoners directions to nowhere. Its twin stands within eyeshot of the Roden Crater, an extinct volcano where, for more than 25 years, the American light and space artist James Turrell has been creating a vast and beautiful installation. In the late 60s, artists such as Turrell and Robert Smithson, creator of the legendary Spiral Jetty in Salt Lake, Utah, set out to create art which couldn't be contained in the urban commercial art world, but had to be searched for - with difficulty. That's what Chodzko is doing with his sign.

If you went out to the desert, you would find something strange and wonderful: an American artwork situated inside a volcano, something unique. And if you followed the sign from Arizona to London? "Keep Holy Trinity Church and the Laser Eye Clinic to your right," says the sign in the desert, "and Finchley Road Underground Station to your left. Then take a left turn, following the graceful curvature of the prodigious concrete and glass O2 building..."

E ach text ends with the revelation that, when you reach your destination in Arizona or north London "here, in this place, is a sign which describes the location of this sign you have just finished reading". Chodzko hypothesises a fold in space, a wormhole in the universe. When you stand in the car park and read his sign you can imagine for a moment that two remote places have become one, that the thin slice of air cut by the placard really is a gate to transport you instantly to Arizona. The wind chime heightens that feeling; it jangles to a distant movement. Like a story by Borges, the narrative of street directions takes us into another dimension. London in the middle of the desert, the desert in the middle of London.

The magic works both ways. Better Scenery, the title of the artwork, is what is written at the top of each text. We may dream of Arizona, but if you were used to the desert, it might be magical to come across a signpost to distant places called St John's Wood and Swiss Cottage. In fact, in Chodzko's directions, London appears as a pastoral fantasy of woods, cottages, Regent's Park. Chodzko has explored the fantasy of pastoral before: in 1995 he placed an advert in a sex contacts magazine which consisted of a drawing of a woodland with the invitation "Please will you join me here?". Better Scenery is what art has offered ever since the ancient Romans had rustic idylls painted on their walls, and pastoral retreat is one of the great fantasies of painting from Titian to Watteau. Chodzko's public artwork offers a modern pastoral hidden under the surface of everyday life, a mysterious fantasy world located somewhere between the Roden Crater and Finchley Road tube station.

 Adam Chodzko, Better Scenery, car park and lower lobby, O2, 255 Finchley Road, London NW3 (information: 0171-431 8767) till August 27.

webTitle: Perfect pitch helps champions hold ground

fields.headline: Perfect pitch helps champions hold ground
fields.trailText: The contrast in the build-ups the two teams enjoyed to this game has been well documented. Manchester United took the modern route, a couple of weeks off in warmer climes to mend damaged limbs, to restoke jaded endeavour, to prepare for the challenges ahead. The kind of midwinter break enjoyed for some time by the more civilised footballing nations, such as Scotland.
fields.body:
The contrast in the build-ups the two teams enjoyed to this game has been well documented. Manchester United took the modern route, a couple of weeks off in warmer climes to mend damaged limbs, to restoke jaded endeavour, to prepare for the challenges ahead. The kind of midwinter break enjoyed for some time by the more civilised footballing nations, such as Scotland.

Arsenal meanwhile took the old-fashioned path, the debilitating grind of Cup replays and penalty shoot-outs, of lengthening injury lists and suspensions. The result was much the same: both sides have only one domestic trophy to pursue. And this was the game which both believed to be crucial to their remaining ambition. The way Arsène Wenger and Alex Ferguson talk, anyone would think Leeds United were in free fall towards relegation, the league already a carve-up between the big two.

It also promised to be a heavyweight bout of significantly greater balance than the charade taking place in Manchester on Saturday, with an undercard of individual contests for the unofficial divisional crown: Thierry Henry against Jaap Stam, Ryan Giggs against Lee Dixon, and Roy Keane against Patrick Vieira. Not forgetting top-of-the-bill Teddy Sheringham against the visiting supporters. Sheringham won that one; quite apart from scoring, he warmed up on the touchline in front of the Arsenal fans, performing an elaborate mime involving the raising of trophies. If he tires of life on the fringes of the United team, there is a future for him on the fringe of the Edinburgh Festival.

The two teams went at each other with the bone-ringing intensity that characterises their meetings. In one passage, six huge challenges followed in dizzying succession and it seemed impossible that Paul Durkin wouldn't intervene. But it was all apparently legal, the scrapping went on unmolested, every sliding lunge was hugely cheered by the biggest crowd in Premiership history.

The majority in the huge gathering fell silent early on when Fredrik Ljungberg took advantage of a mistake by Stam of the sort that Gary Neville thought he had trademarked in Brazil. More celebrated Gunners may have been unavailable, but it is hard to imagine Messrs Kanu, Bergkamp or Suker inflicting greater embarrassment on the United back four. Henry in particular, playing as if Nicolas Anelka had never existed, ran at them at pace, forcing Mickael Silvestre ever deeper in an attempt to cut off his runs. Indeed, with Henry everywhere it was only Mark Bosnich's elastic arms which prevented Arsenal from establishing a first-half advantage even this United team would have found hard to peg back.

Before this game, Roy Keane had completed 900 passes in the season, more than any other player, and it seemed likely his probing accuracy would be United's best route to parity. But as the second half wore on, and Ferguson began to wonder if it might not have been better for United to have stayed at home after all, the ball would not break for Keane.

And for once Ferguson could not blame his favourite bugbear: the Old Trafford pitch. The sodden cabbage patch that had passed as a playing surface before his team's winter break had undergone something of an early spring itself. Thanks to tons of grass seed from Amsterdam, it had blossomed into a lush and springy greensward.

This is now the third pitch tried in 18 months: at United they change playing surfaces almost as often as they change away kits. But it was not before time: Paul Scholes, it is rumoured, was absent from this game not because of an uppity hernia but because he disappeared into a divot several weeks ago and has not been seen since. Apparently its predecessor's deterioration was caused by the vertiginous new stands blocking out the light. Which seems an odd excuse. No light has penetrated the corridors of the FA for years, but it still manages to produce an endless crop of vegetables.

fields.headline: Sheringham the saviour
fields.standfirst: United caught cold by pace of Ljungberg
fields.trailText: Teddy Sheringham yet again came off the bench to rescue Manchester United here last after an early goal from Fredrik Ljungberg had enabled Arsenal to provide a rude homecoming from Brazil for Sir Alex Ferguson's team.
fields.body:
Teddy Sheringham yet again came off the bench to rescue Manchester United here last after an early goal from Fredrik Ljungberg had enabled Arsenal to provide a rude homecoming from Brazil for Sir Alex Ferguson's team.

After the Swede punished an error by Jaap Stam United struggled to get into their game and Arsenal might have scored more. But with 17 minutes remaining Sheringham, who had replaced Andy Cole six minutes earlier, brought the scores level with a tap-in after David Seaman had touched on Ryan Giggs's cross to David Beckham, who promptly returned it to the goalmouth

It is one thing to have matches in hand but quite another to win them. In Rio, United might have been comforted by the knowledge that while they were making a poor fist of the World Club Championship their rivals back home were scarcely doing any better.

Ostensibly Arsenal employed a five-man midfield with Stephen Hughes starting a league match for first time since he played at Old Trafford last February. Yet with Ljungberg moving up to support Thierry Henry and Ray Parlour quick to push forward on the right the approach was far from negative.

Playing on their umpteenth relayed pitch, United could expect the ball to roll more smoothly than it had done in the long grass of the Maracana. But their initial movements were uncharacteristically tentative and they had scarcely mounted an attack by the time Arsenal came close to taking the lead in the sixth minute.

Ljungberg's acceleration enabled him to catch Gary Neville in possession on the left and from the Swede's low centre Henry cleverly flicked the ball back over the head of Mark Bosnich, only to see it glance away off the crossbar.

Three minutes later, at the other end, Gilles Grimandi lost possession to Dwight Yorke, who set up Andy Cole for a shot that he dragged wide from a narrow angle. But Arsenal still looked brisker and brighter and in the 11th minute they scored.

The goal was down to attacking opportunism and sluggish defending. Henry won the ball in the air against Mickael Silvestre and headed it forward towards Stam. The Dutch defender appeared to have covered the danger but as he turned ponderously Ljungberg darted in to head the ball off Stam's toes before driving a low shot past Bosnich.

Midway through the first half Silvinho gave way to Nigel Winterburn. The Brazilian showed no obvious sign of injury; perhaps Winterburn was required to keep a closer eye on David Beckham. Either way Cole, set up by Yorke two minutes later, should have done better than volley the ball over the bar from inside the six-yard area.

Nevertheless United were steadily getting their act together and Arsenal were having to defend for longer periods. Just past the half-hour a firm downward header from Cole was turned towards the net by Yorke. Seaman was caught out of position but Dixon manage to chest the ball off the line.

The nearness of an equaliser set Old Trafford roaring anew but all was still not well with United's defence. Eight minutes before half-time, Ljungberg's head flicked the ball through for Henry to outpace the centre-backs and bear down on Bosnich. The United goalkeeper did wonderfully well to push the Frenchman's shot aside, but it was wasted chance all the same.

So was the opportunity missed by Butt at the end of the half. A brisk exchange of passes with Beckham sent the midfielder through the Arsenal defence to draw an equally good diving save from Seaman.

But for Dennis Irwin Arsenal would have increased their lead two minutes after half-time. Bosnich was slow getting to Petit's inswinging corner and after Grimandi had glanced the ball towards the net Irwin volleyed it clear from under the bar.

For all Keane's goading United still seemed unable to raise the tempo of their game to its usual height. Vieira remained the dominant force surrounded by intense industry as Arsenal continued to deny their opponents space and time on the ball.

Arsenal themselves were content to drop a gear and concentrate on retaining possession. Generally speaking this is a dangerous policy for visitors to Old Trafford.

fields.headline: Investors make UK a frontrunner
fields.trailText: The world's top business leaders have promoted Britain to second most desirable location for foreign investment despite growing doubts about the government's commitment to joining Europe's single currency.
fields.body:
The world's top business leaders have promoted Britain to second most desirable location for foreign investment despite growing doubts about the government's commitment to joining Europe's single currency.

In a move which contradicts claims that remaining outside the euro zone will damage the UK's economic prospects, the biannual poll of 1,000 bosses from the world's largest firms by US management consultants AT Kearney found no adverse reaction to the prospect of Britain retaining the pound.

Although Japanese investors, such as Toyota and Komatsu, are considering turning away from the UK, it remains the most favoured destination for American companies and it is also the top choice in Europe of European firms.

The poll, which looks at investment intentions over the next three years, found that America retained top place even though its ability to maintain strong economic growth is also the biggest worry for global chief executives. Britain rose to second from third, overtaking China where investment returns are failing to live up to expectations.

The survey shows that wholesale and retail global corporations and banks regard Britain as even more attractive than America, citing its market size, potential and the presence of competitors as main reasons for investment.

Only heavy manufacturing firms show little enthusiasm for investing in the UK, ranking it seventh behind Mexico, Poland and Germany because of relatively poor access to natural resources.

Business for Sterling's head of research, Dominic Cummings, said the survey showed "being outside the euro zone was irrelevant.Only last week a huge German company, BASF, left Frankfurt for London. "

Simon Buckby, Campaign Director of Britain in Europe, said Britain attracted inward investment because it was a gateway to Europe but added: "Ruling out membership of a successful single currency in the long term would cause inward investors to reconsider their position in Britain."

Although Japanese investors, such as Toyota and Komatsu, are considering turning away from the UK, it remains the most favoured destination for American companies and it is also the top choice in Europe of European firms. The poll, which looks at investment intentions over the next three years, found that America retained top place even though its ability to maintain strong economic growth is also the biggest worry for global chief executives. Britain rose to second from third, overtaking China where investment returns are failing to live up to expectations. The survey shows that wholesale and retail global corporations and banks regard Britain as even more attractive than America, citing its market size, potential and the presence of competitors as main reasons for investment. Only heavy manufacturing firms show little enthusiasm for investing in the UK, ranking it seventh behind Mexico, Poland and Germany because of relatively poor access to natural resources. Business for Sterling's head of research, Dominic Cummings, said the survey showed "being outside the euro zone was irrelevant.Only last week a huge German company, BASF, left Frankfurt for London. " Simon Buckby, Campaign Director of Britain in Europe, said Britain attracted inward investment because it was a gateway to Europe but added: "Ruling out membership of a successful single currency in the long term would cause inward investors to reconsider their position in Britain."

webTitle: Cancer drug revelations lead to Biotech shares plunge

fields.headline: Cancer drug revelations lead to Biotech shares plunge
fields.standfirst:
British Biotech home page
Latest stock quote from Yahoo!
Marimastat home page
fields.trailText: Shares in British Biotech had plunged 38% to 29.5p by 11.40am this morning as the City took fright as the former flagship of the UK biotech sector revealed its marimastat cancer treatment to be no 'wonder drug'.
fields.body:
Shares in British Biotech had plunged 38% to 29.5p by 11.40am this morning as the City took fright as the former flagship of the UK biotech sector revealed its marimastat cancer treatment to be no 'wonder drug'.

British Biotech has been struggling to re-establish itself as a serious industry player since a series of scandals 18 months ago led to the exit of its founder Keith McCullagh and the collapse of shares which once traded at £3.

But the vital 'phase 3' trials failed to show that marimastat helped in cases of advanced pancreatic cancer and new chief executive Elliot Goldstein admitted: "The negative results from this trial are disappointing."

The poor results on Study 193 are the first to be unveiled since British Biotech entered into collaberation with Schering-Plough Corp to develop a matrix of metalloproteinase inhibitors for cancer.

The collaberation is set to continue and patients treated with marimastat at less advanced stages of cancer did respond better. Schering-Plough was set to develop and commercialise marimastat and a second product BB-3644.

The failure backs up scepticism expressed by its former head of clinical research, Dr Andrew Millar, who was fired after talking to company shareholders about his concerns.

Dr Millar was worried that British Biotech's share price was flying high on the back of unreasonable expectations about the company's key drugs zacutex - a treatment for pancreatitis - and marimastat. He claimed that marimastat had only a 40% chance of success and his scepticism now appears well-founded.

But City analysts said despite the setback they had not given up all hope on marimastat and hoped that further trials could be more successful. One said he remained optimistic about the company: "It (marimastat) was always a bit of a wild card option. Today's news is bad news but it has not really changed the fundamentals." But the share price fall showed overall City confidence in British Biotech was seriously dented.
