fields.headline: Bass for minimalists
fields.standfirst:
Ryoji Ikeda, :zoviet*france:
Contact, Manchester/ touring
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText: Manchester's recently re-opened Contact was the perfect venue for the evening's explosion of experimental music and video, featuring very different sets by Japan's internationally acclaimed digital minimalist, Ryoki Ikeda, and Newcastle's long-established impro-electronic duo, :zoviet*france:.
fields.body:
Manchester's recently re-opened Contact was the perfect venue for the evening's explosion of experimental music and video, featuring very different sets by Japan's internationally acclaimed digital minimalist, Ryoki Ikeda, and Newcastle's long-established impro-electronic duo, :zoviet*france:.

Indeed, Space 1, Contact's 360-seat warehouse-auditorium, felt as if it had been designed for the event. A bank of vivid red seats led down to a bright white stage and screen. The walls were magenta. The beams high above looked as if they were made iron. Did somebody say post-industrial?

Then there was a flash of strobe, an electric crackle. High-pitched bleeps began to resound and distort. Geometric lines on the screen crossed and recrossed. And when the sonic boom of the bass started to hammer itself into a rhythm, it was so loud and deep that you could feel it in your elbows and knees.

Ikeda's pre-programmed sound is a kind of pared-down techno. You can't dance to it, you just sort of sit there and vibrate. It's very intense, and the inventive play with tone, pulse and frequency proves challenging to say the least. At times it can feel as though a scream of static has become trapped within your ears.

Yet the drilling, scraping, warping noises - the very sound of Ikeda stripping away excess - sometimes gave way to a less abrasive ticking, a celestial metronome accompanied by night-sky lighting and the graphics of a splintering crystal.

But his desire to keep it pure and simple soon meant a return to the thunderous bass, another apocalyptic burst of strobe, and what sounded like something being frazzled. Afterwards the screen flashed up a message, reading: "It's the most beautiful ugly sound in the world".

:zoviet*france:'s approach was altogether different. For a start, they were actually on stage. Like workers under night-lamps, they knelt in the semi-darkness behind a three-sided rack of equipment, adjusting the controls to influence their output. This improvisation was matched by the use of percussion.

A heavy bass also structured their non-songs, but the overlaying tones were much softer than Ikeda's; more like a clashing of beads than of heads. With a steady and hypnotic escalation of effects, there was a definite sense of everything coming together and moving forward, and this was complemented by dual screen footage of swimming pools and tunnels and people in motion.

And when the last bleep of the night had died out, Manchester's hip initiates were, for a moment, too stunned to applaud.

 At the Arnolfini, Bristol (0117-929 9191) on January 27, and touring.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Scots scramble to up NatWest ante

fields.headline: Scots scramble to up NatWest ante
fields.trailText: The two Scottish banks in the battle for NatWest were last night scrambling to find extra cash to raise the offers for their prey, which yesterday promised its shareholders an extra £1.5bn cash payout.
fields.body:
The two Scottish banks in the battle for NatWest were last night scrambling to find extra cash to raise the offers for their prey, which yesterday promised its shareholders an extra £1.5bn cash payout.

In its final defence against the £22bn bids by Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland, NatWest also highlighted the "outstanding record" of Gordon Pell, lured from Lloyds TSB two weeks ago, and released an early estimate of £1.3bn profits for 1999.

Industry sources insisted both Scottish banks were looking for ways to add to the cash element of their cash and shares bids.

NatWest, depending on its success in selling off non-core business, can offer over £6bn in cash - including news of yesterday's extra £1.5bn share buy-back - while the two Scottish banks have come up with £5bn each.

Mr Pell, still on the Lloyds TSB payroll, agreed that NatWest had underperformed but said the question for shareholders was whether this was the right time to sell out.

NatWest admitted problems in the retail banking arm, where income had grown by only 1.6% in two years. Ron Sandler, the new chief operating officer, pledged to improve its record at selling more than one product to its customers, many of whom are likely to be attracted to its new internet bank.

Mr Sandler said the bank intended to sell its customers life insurance products "outsourced" from other companies as well as sell its own mortgages, under a different brand, through other companies. The bonus structure is also to be altered as an incentive to branch employees.

Shareholders have until Saint Valentine's Day to decide which case to back, and are not expected to reach a decision until after next Monday when both Scottish banks will have had to reveal any higher offer.

Sir David Rowland, the new chairman and chief executive of NatWest, insisted a new "lean and fit" NatWest would offer better returns for shareholders who, he said, were giving him "a fair hearing".

Sir David insisted he had received assurances from his counterpart at the Prudential that a deal it had secured with BoS would not influence the decision of its fund managers who own the biggest single chunk of NatWest.

webTitle: BP to play hard ball as US demands Arco concessions

fields.headline: BP to play hard ball as US demands Arco concessions
fields.trailText: BP Amoco's planned $27bn (£16.4bn) takeover of US oil company Atlantic Richfield (Arco) is likely to be blocked after regulators made it clear the British firm must offer significant concessions before the deal can go ahead.
fields.body:
BP Amoco's planned $27bn (£16.4bn) takeover of US oil company Atlantic Richfield (Arco) is likely to be blocked after regulators made it clear the British firm must offer significant concessions before the deal can go ahead.

Industry experts believe the merger with Arco faces being vetoed by the federal trade commission on Friday if BP Amoco, as expected, refuses to sell off parts of the merged company in some states.

FTC insiders have let it be known the regulator has the three votes necessary among its commissioners to sue the companies and halt the merger on the grounds that competition on the US west coast will be affected.

BP Amoco refused to comment except to say that talks with the FTC continue. But industry watchers are convinced that the British company will refuse to back down, especially as previous offers to divest assets were dismissed as insufficient.

Fadel Gheit, analyst with New York broker Fahnestock & Co, said: "This has become a political issue caught up with the presidential elections.

"The FTC wants to be seen to be getting tough but there are no economic or factual reasons for turning down the deal."

The analyst believes BP Amoco's chairman, Sir John Browne, is ready to play hard ball in the courts and long-term investors remain confident that he will win, leading to little movement in the company's share price.

BP Amoco closed up 10p at 574p helped by developments yesterday in Russia.

These delivered good news for the company's $1bn investment there, which was all but safeguarded when creditors agreed to support a rescue plan for a bankrupt local oil group, Sidanko, in which BP Amoco holds a 10% stake.

The British company, one of Russia's largest foreign investors, had threatened to pull out of the country over the way the collapse of Sidanko in May last year had been treated by the courts.

The case was seen a test for future investment in Russia by western companies.

Howard Chase, a BP Amoco spokesman, said the restruc turing - the first of its kind for a leading Russian industrial company - was an encouraging sign for the country's oil sector although it must still be endorsed by a Moscow court on Friday.

"We are hopeful that the court will approve the deal. It has the full support of creditors, provides a good basis for future Sidanko operations and secures the position of BP Amoco as a leading foreign investor," said Mr Chase.

webTitle: Trade halted as France's first dot.com rises too fast

fields.headline: Trade halted as France's first dot.com rises too fast
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: France's Nouveau Marché will try to get trading underway in stock market newcomer Artprice.com today after dealings had to be halted before they began yesterday as huge demand twice triggered trading controls.
fields.body:
France's Nouveau Marché will try to get trading underway in stock market newcomer Artprice.com today after dealings had to be halted before they began yesterday as huge demand twice triggered trading controls.

The price has already hit €42.88 (£26) - more than double the price at which shares were initially offered to investors and looks set to surge higher today.

Under stock market rules shares are temporarily suspended if the price rises too fast. For public offers the initial ceiling is 20% after which a further 20% rise triggers a second suspension of dealings.

For Artprice.com, the online fine art auction database, exchange authorities had widened the 20% bands to allow a price jump of up to 50% but even that proved insufficient to allow trading to start. The price immediately hit the first stop of €28.59.

"The demand was so strong we decided to allow a further 50% price rise but we could not trade even at this price," an exchange spokesman said.

This morning the exchange will allow a further 50% appreciation and if that is not sufficient to get trading under way it will allow the price to rise another 50%.

Artprice.com is the first pure dot.com to hit the French market and demand for the shares on offer has been huge. According to the offer's lead manager, Europe Finance and Industrie, the institutional element was 70 times oversubscribed. Retail demand was also strong. Only 5% of bids for up to 100 shares and none of the bids for more than 100 shares could be met.

webTitle: I've been promoted but the job's a nightmare

fields.headline: I've been promoted but the job's a nightmare
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I am a restaurant and bar supervisor in a popular West End hotel. I've worked for this company for the past eight years but my job is about to become a nightmare.

Our current manager is leaving at the end of the month and I am going to be running things, but the restaurant and bar are in total disarray. I'm furious about this because the demands of the job were too much for all the previous managers - partly as a result of badly-planned budgets, a shortage of skilled staff and the fact that it's a 24-hour operation.

I know you might think this is a good opportunity for me to move up the career ladder but I can't see it that way. My experience is that managers and assistant managers only seem to last from three months to a year at most.

I've helped to train and support incoming managers but their task, I believe, is beyond them. They are expected to work ten, fourteen and sometimes eighteen hours a day behind the bar or serving in the restaurant and as a consequence are not able to do paperwork or plan properly.

I have just told my head of department that I've wanted the restaurant manager's job for a long time but in reality, I wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy. I am now looking for alternative employment. What should I do?

The solution

Take the job: but, with a few provisos. First of all, you should present your head of department with a short report outlining your concerns regarding staff shortages and budget planning.

Back up your assertions with evidence. Rather than just complain about badly-planned budgets, for example, give a few examples of what you mean and how this has affected the running of the business.

Make realistic suggestions as to how operations need to improve if managers such as yourself are to be retained but don't threaten to leave at this stage.

Once you are in your new post, you will be in a much better position to look for a job at this level at a better-run establishment. When you are asked at interviews why you are leaving your new position so soon, take your report with you by way of explanation. A future employer might well be impressed by your insight, business acumen and pro-activity.

This is assuming, of course, that your current boss ignores your report. S/he might, in fact, take on board your comments and make some changes. So, either way, you should win in the long-term.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: C&W opens door to bids
fields.standfirst: Hong Kong ploy removes barrier to takeover
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless effectively declared itself a potential takeover target yesterday after announcing plans to create a £37bn Asia-Pacific telecommunications group by merging its 54% stake in HKT, fomerly known as Hong Kong Telecom, with Singapore Telecommunications.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless effectively declared itself a potential takeover target yesterday after announcing plans to create a £37bn Asia-Pacific telecommunications group by merging its 54% stake in HKT, fomerly known as Hong Kong Telecom, with Singapore Telecommunications.

The British firm's holding in HKT has in the past acted as a defence against potential predators, with Hong Kong stock exchange rules stipluating that any takeover of C&W would require a costly buyout of the HKT shareholding.

Analysts said a joint merger of HKT with SingTel, which is 80% owned by the Singapore government, would remove this barrier. It sent C&W's shares soaring up yesterday by 146p to £11.85 on expectations that the group will finally join the orgy of consolidation in the telecoms sector.

After weeks of increasing speculation C&W revealed that it was in talks with SingTel to create what promises to be the second largest telecoms in the region behind China Telecom Hong Kong. The news emerged despite denials by HKT's chief executive, Linus Cheung, last week that the firm may soon be split from its British parent.

A C&W spokesman, meanwhile, insisted that the potential merger would leave the British company vulnerable to predators such as Bell South and SBC Ameritech of the United States, or Deutsche Telekom in Europe.

He said a merger of HKT and SingTel was part of C&W's transformation into a global provider of internet services.

"In terms of our strategic view it would free up resources to focus on data and IT businesses," he said.

Steve Trowbridge, analyst at Teather & Greenwood, said the transfer of HKT into a joint holding company could allow C&W to realise the value of its investment in the Hong Kong business which has not been reflected in the share price. HKT accounts for almost 60% of C&W's operating profit.

However, HKT reported a surprise loss of about $356m (£215.7m) in the six months to September 30.

"It's Graham Wallace's strategy to unlock value, as the company has always traded at a discount to the the sum of its parts," Mr Trowbridge said.

In a series of rapid-fire deals C&W's chief executive Graham Wallace has sold a string of non-core assets - most notably the sale of the One2One mobile telephone business for £8.4bn to Deutsche Telekom last year.

Last week the group an nounced that in pursuit of its new strategy it is spending almost £500m snapping up 11 internet business service providers in Europe.

The new Asian telecoms group created from HKT and SingTel would have a combined market capitalisation of £37bn, revenues of £4.5bn and net cash of £3.5bn, according to analysts. The City expects full terms to be agreed by the end of March, although as yet the structure remains uncertain. It would require government and regulatory approval.

The Chinese government also owns 7% of HKT, but it is understood that it has been kept informed of the discussions and is likely to be supportive of the deal.

If C&W took an entire equity stake in the combined group it would end up with a 27% holding - with observers noting that this would be considered to be a much more liquid investment than the existing structure of the group.

The likelihood, however, is that shareholders in both companies will be offered a combination of cash and shares.

A merged group would be listed in the stock exchanges in Hong Kong, Singapore, New York and possibly also London.

Last week Singapore announced that it would speed up the opening up of its telecoms sector to boost its ambitions to be a regional hub for that market. The Singporean market is expected to be entirely deregulated by April 1.

The news emerged despite denials by HKT's chief executive, Linus Cheung, last week that the firm may soon be split from its British parent. A C&W spokesman, meanwhile, insisted that the potential merger would leave the British company vulnerable to predators such as Bell South and SBC Ameritech of the United States, or Deutsche Telekom in Europe. He said a merger of HKT and SingTel was part of C&W's transformation into a global provider of internet services. "In terms of our strategic view it would free up resources to focus on data and IT businesses," he said. Steve Trowbridge, analyst at Teather & Greenwood, said the transfer of HKT into a joint holding company could allow C&W to realise the value of its investment in the Hong Kong business which has not been reflected in the share price. HKT accounts for almost 60% of C&W's operating profit. However, HKT reported a surprise loss of about $356m (£215.7m) in the six months to September 30. "It's Graham Wallace's strategy to unlock value, as the company has always traded at a discount to the the sum of its parts," Mr Trowbridge said. In a series of rapid-fire deals C&W's chief executive Graham Wallace has sold a string of non-core assets - most notably the sale of the One2One mobile telephone business for £8.4bn to Deutsche Telekom last year. Last week the group an nounced that in pursuit of its new strategy it is spending almost £500m snapping up 11 internet business service providers in Europe. The new Asian telecoms group created from HKT and SingTel would have a combined market capitalisation of £37bn, revenues of £4.5bn and net cash of £3.5bn, according to analysts. The City expects full terms to be agreed by the end of March, although as yet the structure remains uncertain. It would require government and regulatory approval. The Chinese government also owns 7% of HKT, but it is understood that it has been kept informed of the discussions and is likely to be supportive of the deal. If C&W took an entire equity stake in the combined group it would end up with a 27% holding - with observers noting that this would be considered to be a much more liquid investment than the existing structure of the group. The likelihood, however, is that shareholders in both companies will be offered a combination of cash and shares. A merged group would be listed in the stock exchanges in Hong Kong, Singapore, New York and possibly also London. Last week Singapore announced that it would speed up the opening up of its telecoms sector to boost its ambitions to be a regional hub for that market. The Singporean market is expected to be entirely deregulated by April 1.

fields.headline: Gent: 'I don't need 50% of Mannesmann'
fields.trailText: Vodafone Airtouch could press ahead with a takeover of German bid target Mannesmann even if it failed to gain outright control of the German giant.
fields.body:
Vodafone Airtouch could press ahead with a takeover of German bid target Mannesmann even if it failed to gain outright control of the German giant.

Vodafone AirTouch chief executive Chris Gent said yesterday that the outcome would depend on "whether we believed we could effectively control the business going forward with less than 50%".

But Mr Gent said his group was still determined to secure more than 50% because that would bring a "total clarity" to the situation.

Speaking after a shareholders' meeting which gave overwhelming backing to the Mannesmann bid and the planned venture with Bell Atlantic in the United States, Mr Gent said he still hoped he would be able to strike a deal with the Mannesmann board that would allow it to agree the takeover.

But although Vodafone has said it is prepared to make a modest increase in its £80bn bid in order to win a recommendation, Mr Gent stressed that Vodafone would still have to account for more than 50% of the enlarged group and that there was no question of a cash element being added.

Mannesmann argues that its value means the German com pany should account for 58.5% of an enlarged group. "Cash is not the consideration because we do not want to breach commitments we have made to our bondholders," Mr Gent said.

Only last week Vodafone launched a bond offering of up to $5bn as part of its debt restructuring programme.

Mr Gent called on Mannesmann shareholders to tender their shares before the close on February 7, but said Vodafone could leave the offer open for a further period, especially if it felt there were further acceptances in the pipeline.

The Vodafone Airtouch chief executive dismissed talk of a possible "white knight" emerging which could thwart his company's bid by launching an agreed offer of its own.

The government had said that even if the bid is hostile, it had to be looked at on economic grounds, while initially belligerent trade unions were prepared to be pragmatic if Vodafone AirTouch respected Germany's governance norms.

Summing up, Mr Gent said: "Mannesmann is a good company, it is run well. We are not going there saying this is a lousy management or talking of missed opportunities.

"The only thing we are arguing about is that putting the two together is better than being separate and in competition."

webTitle: Winners in trillion dollar goldrush will trade business-to-business

fields.headline: Winners in trillion dollar goldrush will trade business-to-business
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Suddenly it seems everybody is at it. The underground is plastered with posters advertising new internet job sites, every advert contains a web address, and no self-respecting high street retailer would dream of ignoring the potential of e-commerce.
fields.body:
Suddenly it seems everybody is at it. The underground is plastered with posters advertising new internet job sites, every advert contains a web address, and no self-respecting high street retailer would dream of ignoring the potential of e-commerce.

The OECD has estimated that e-commerce will be worth $1 trillion worldwide by 2005 - around 3% of global GDP. Yesterday, HSBC pointed out that almost every forecast of potential e-sales to date has proved too conservative, and suggested that the $1-trillion mark could be breached within a few years.

From virtually zero in 1995, total e-commerce grew close to $102bn in 1998 - equivalent to 0.4% of global GDP. The US is the market leader. 80% of worldwide e-commerce took place within its borders, with Europe accounting for just 10% and Asia a mere 5%.

But despite the huge sums firms are spending on advertising their new sites to the public, the real transformation will occur behind the scenes, in business-to-business trade, according to HSBC.

"The consumer side gets all the attention in the media but the real impact will be on business-to-business sales - things like inventory and procurement," says Gwyn Hacche, HSBC's European economist.

Business-to-business already accounts for 80% of total e-commerce activity and by 2003 will be worth $800bn a year, according to the OECD.

Meanwhile, e-sales to consumers, will be worth $175bn worldwide - or about 15% of the current sales through traditional direct marketing in the US through mail, telephone and newspapers.

The internet has the potential to carve vast chunks out of industries' supply chains and reduce the level of inventories firms hold.

One study suggests that US auto manufacturers could reduce inventory levels by 20% and increase profits by 10%. Or, of course, they could pass the benefits onto the consumer in the form of lower prices.

The consumer will be king of this new world. Although e-sales will not completely replace shopping on the high street, consumers will use the net to compare prices on web sites before making a conventional purchase.

"Consumers will be able to search among thousands of merchants for the lowest prices, increasing the downward pressure on prices and leading to a shift in market power from producer to consumer," Mr Hacche says.

Many conventional wholesalers and retailers could fall by the wayside. Such intermediaries typically add up to one-third to the cost of the goods which they handle, so cutting out the middleman has to be more good news for the final purchaser.

But new intermediaries will arise - advertisers to tell us how to make sense of the array of choices consumers will face, search engines for navigating the web and new transport companies to deliver purchases to the home. Business costs will fall, making it easier for new firms to spring up and replace the old.

Some businesses clearly think the internet is going to bring about a new gold rush. But the beneficiaries are unlikely to be the high-profile firms pushing their new websites, HSBC says.

"In the gold rush of the 1800s the real winners were not the miners but the suppliers that sold them food, clothes and pickaxes," Mr Hacche says. In the modern gold rush, the firms who stand to benefit are those providing the infrastructure e-commerce requires - the internet service providers, the PC manufacturers and the inventors of encryption technology for credit card sales.

fields.headline: Europe's tech deals hit record £275bn
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Mergers and acquisitions among Europe's telecommunications, internet and media companies jumped more than five times in value to a record-breaking $455bn (£275.7bn) last year, according to new industry research.
fields.body:
Mergers and acquisitions among Europe's telecommunications, internet and media companies jumped more than five times in value to a record-breaking $455bn (£275.7bn) last year, according to new industry research.

Europe's share of technology deals globally more than doubled from 16.5% in 1998 to an unprecedented 38% during 1999. The value of European technology deals added up to more than all the other years of the decade put together.

The value of deals in the European wireless sector rose 5,140% last year while it more than trebled in the cable and digital media industries.

In total there were a record 2,271 deals across the information technology, communications and media industries last year, up from 1,782 in 1998.

Victor Basta, the head of European operations at Broadview, the investment bank which published the research yesterday, said that part of last year's record-breaking increase reflected the fact that Europe felt a need to catch up with the United States, where technology deals have led the takeover boom for longer.

The deals are also driven by the strategic demands of the internet as large European ca ble and telecommunications groups fight to provide access to the web.

Among last year's ground-breaking deals were Vodafone's hostile bid for Mannesmann of Germany and Telecom Italia-Olivetti takeover.

Mr Basta believes that if the first hostile bid for a German group by a non-domestic company is successful it could result in a wave of copycat deals across Europe.

"We will see the barriers coming down if this deal is successful," he said.

Few bankers are predicting a slowing in the number of mergers and acquisitions this year - especially after America Online started the year off with the world's largest takeover attempt by bidding for Time Warner.

Mr Basta forecast a "European version of the AOL-Time Warner deal between a European media group and a European online business" over the coming year.

Technology deals around the world more than doubled last year, from $474bn to $1,200bn in 1999 as consolidation in the cable, telecoms and media industries increased.

Many of the deals have been predicated by groups vying to provide broadband access, which offers faster data transmission across all networks, including the internet.

Most internet access in the US is linked to the use of personal computers, whereas in Europe the use of mobile devices is more advanced.

Mr Basta predicted that even more Europeans could use the internet than Americans because of the greater penetration of different access devices.

fields.headline: Brahms and no qualms
fields.standfirst:
London Philharmonic Orchestra/Marin Alsop
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText: New York-born conductor Marin Alsop made such a mark on London audiences last year with her performances of contemporary music, that one wondered just what she might be like in the mainstream repertoire. Thanks to the LPO, we had the chance to find out - and the results can only be described as very impressive.
fields.body:
New York-born conductor Marin Alsop made such a mark on London audiences last year with her performances of contemporary music, that one wondered just what she might be like in the mainstream repertoire. Thanks to the LPO, we had the chance to find out - and the results can only be described as very impressive.

This was one of the Audience Request concerts with which the LPO has been packing the Festival Hall of late. One item in the programme is elected by the public via a ballot form sent in with ticket applications. On this occasion it was a violin concerto which was up for grabs, with a choice between the teenage Strauss's Concerto in D (sketched in his maths book when he was bored at school) and Bruch's ever-popular First - which won hands down.

Alsop and the Dutch violinist Isabelle Van Keulen strode onto the platform, and proceeded to deliver the finest performance of the piece that I've heard. The whole thing was much more intense than usual. Alsop, taking it slowly, emphasises brooding orchestral colours that you don't normally notice. Van Keulen, subordinating flamboyance to drama and employing a velvety-rich, sensual tone throughout, really lets the music live, breathe and sing.

Alsop also showed her prowess in works by Brahms and Tchaikovsky, with varying impact. Tchaikovsky's Hamlet is a peculiar piece which has less to do with Shakespeare than with the composer's own tendency to depression. It shirks the play's Oedipal implications, jettisoning Claudius, Gertrude and Polonius altogether and focusing on Hamlet's tormented psyche, interwoven with portraits of his spectral papa, Ophelia and, oddly, Fortinbras. Alsop pitches it a fraction too high, opening in an atmosphere of such near-hysteria that she comes dangerously close, in places, to going over the top. On the other hand, there are fabulously unnerving insights. The way she stresses the grotesque twisting of Ophelia's theme as her image distorts in Hamlet's mind was particularly telling.

No qualms about Alsop's Brahms, though. She got the balance of elements in his First Symphony absolutely right, instilling a remarkable cogency and homogeneity of mood into a work which can sometimes seem an episodic collection of movements rather than an integrated whole. The LPO were superlative here, too. In an era when great Brahms interpreters are a bit thin of the ground, Alsop is well on her way to becoming one of the best.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: A farce of nature
fields.standfirst:
Winner Takes All
Orange Tree, Richmond
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText: Forced to abandon its autumn season through underfunding, the Orange Tree is back with a bang, almost literally, since this delirious 1904 Feydeau farce, translated by Reggie Oliver, shows sex being achieved rather than, as is more usual, frustrated. The result is the funniest evening in London.
fields.body:
Forced to abandon its autumn season through underfunding, the Orange Tree is back with a bang, almost literally, since this delirious 1904 Feydeau farce, translated by Reggie Oliver, shows sex being achieved rather than, as is more usual, frustrated. The result is the funniest evening in London.

Here Feydeau combines morality with a dash of physical cruelty. He presents us with a young bourgeois, Chanal, whose wife Francine is having a passionate affair with the two-timing, married Massenay. Accidentally recording details of their adulterous hideaway on Chanal's phonograph, the lovers find their trysting-place invaded not just by the outraged husband but by a gibbering politician and a pistol-packing drunk who hurls Massenay's trousers into the street. Debagging, however, reaches epic proportions in the second act, set in the Massenays' apartment, when virtually all the male members of the cast are stripped to their underpants.

"Do not adultery commit, advantage rarely comes of it," wrote Arthur Hugh Clough and Feydeau makes much the same point. But he takes the argument a stage further by suggesting that the greatest penalty is to end up permanently hitched to your secret partner. The real winner may be the person who, rather like Feydeau himself, ends up fancy-free. But what gives his farce a touch of genius is its surreal inventiveness. In other Feydeau plays we have a man who mislays his false palate and another who stammers violently during thunderstorms. Here he brings on a bricklayer who barks compulsively because of his mother's unhappy encounter with a seal. The inherent cruelty of the joke is overlaid by its sheer maniacal wildness.

In farce there is little time for considerations of good taste - we are too busy laughing. Sam Walters's production achieves the right comic propulsion without ever dehumanising the characters. Paula Stockbridge's Francine is not only, in her sexy bloomers, a sight for the sorest of eyes, but a wonderful mix of lechery and asperity. David Antrobus as her husband is all indignation and there are brilliant supporting performances from Stephen Finegold as a politician who manifests his secret passion for Francine by vegetable offerings ending up with an outsized marrow and from Jason Baughan as the hilariously bricklayer. Sheer bliss, and a slap in the face for the Orange Tree's mean-spirited funding bodies.

 Until March 4. Details: 0181-940 3633.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible
